Toward the end of the eighteenth century, taking the Liverpool Guide of 1797 as an authority, we find the port described as a "vortex that has nearly swallowed up the foreign trade of Bristol, Lancaster, and Whitehaven." This swallowing up...

Capt. Franzel, of the Hamburg steamer Suevia, yesterday caused the arrest at Hoboken of three of his crew on a charge of atrocious assault and battery. The prisoners--Charles Lenhardt, August Amtel, and Frederick Hinchens--the Captain alleges, attacked Zonkofsky, a fellow-sailor, and stabbed him several times. The prisoners are held subject to the orders of the German Consul.

Charles Heywood Stratton, "Gen. Tom Thumb," the most famous of the little family of liliputians introduced by P.T. Barnum to the sight-seeing world more than 40 years ago died at his late residence in Middleboro, ...

SHENANDOAH VALLEY, July 4.--The Presidential outlook for 1844 from a Virginia stand-point is shrouded in mists to the merely casual observer. To those who study the currents as they are forming, and understand the influences which are shaping ...

FERNANDINA, June 30.--The Republicans here are in three classes: The negroes, who are led by their preachers, and they by the white officeholders; the white men from the North, who take no active part in politics and are not consulted, ...
LEONARDTOWN, June 30.--St. Mary's being one of the strongest Republican counties in Maryland, the choice of its Republican leaders may be considered a good index whereby to judge the ...
CHARLESTON, S.C., July 15.--THE TIMES'S interview as to Tilden's candidacy for President has created a sensation in political circles here. Tilden can count on no support from this State.

There were over 60,000 people at Coney Island yesterday. It was the biggest day of the season except the Fourth of July. They began coming early in the morning, and poured in by rail and water in steady streams until nightfall.

DOVER, June 30.--The political caldron is very quiet in this State. There is little talk of Presidential candidates. The choice of Delaware would be James G. Blaine if he were in the field, but it would be folly for the party to nominate him in its present temper.

While the people of California are deeply concerned to learn that Chinamen are being smuggled over the lines from British Columbia, there is apprehension on this side of the continent that "assisted" immigrants from ...

A rare day's sport for admirers of trotting horses was furnished at the part of the Gentlemen's Driving Association yesterday. A large number of the members of the association with their friends occupied seats on the ample verandas of the club-house.

MASON CITY, July 2.--Allison, of Iowa, is the man first spoken of by the Republicans here for President. No other names are mentioned. As to the Democrats, local politics, prohibition, , so take up their time and thought that I can get no expression except that they will be solid for anybody.

GREENWOOD, June 28.--There is little speculation yet among the Republicans of this State as to Presidential candidates in 1884. The feeling, however, strongly leans toward men who, with a pure record, have not been mixed up in any of the unfortunate personal animosities within the party during the last few years.

The opportunity which we give to our readers this morning to study the drift of public opinion with reference to Presidential nominations in both parties, and in every State in the Union, will prove a valuable one.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 15.--Germans are gathering in this city in large numbers to attend the twenty-third Saengerfest of the North American Saengerbund, which opens to-morrow.

COLFAX, June 30.--Intelligent Republicans are scarce in this locality. There are only three or four white Republicans in the parish. I heard one of them express himself favorably for Blaine a day or two ago.

TOPEKA, June 28.--There is very little being said in this State by either Republicans or Democrats on the subject of Presidential candidates. Judge Miller, of Iowa, because of his extensive acquaintance in the State and his decisions and dissenting opinions during a series of years on the ...

TEXARKANA, June 28.--Informal inquiry among leading Republicans indicates a political preference for Blaine as the most available, for Edmunds as the most representative, candidate. Our Republicans are rather of Stalwart make, but ...

The weights for the three great handicaps to be run at the present meeting at Monmouth Park are given below. The recent running of many of the horses engaged in them is of such a character as to make the study of the chances of certain animals a difficult and unsatisfactory occupation.

LEWISTON, June 28.--As yet very little has been said upon the Presidential succession, and very few preferences are heard. The Maine Republicans would prefer to see Mr. Blaine made the Republican candidate, and would give him an enthusiastic...

PARIS, July 15.--Many of the flags displayed yesterday in honor of the national fete were draped with crape for Louise Michel. After the unveiling of the statue of the republic two anarchists stuck a black flag upon the statue.

DES MOINES, July 15.--An accurate statement of yesterday's exciting scene at Elkhorn Grove is now at hand. The dying desperado said his real name was H.I. Crawford, and that he killed Postmaster Clingan at Polk City.
Albert Levi, aged 3 years, died yesterday from injuries received on Friday by falling from a fire escape at his parents' residence, No. 46 Forsythstreet.

Several misfortunes conspired to mar the Casino concert last night. In the first place, the weather was not of a nature to inspire people with eagerness to sit upon a roof, however handsomely transformed into a garden, and drink in ...
Early in June THE TIMES sent letters to over 400 points in the 38 States asking answers to the following questions:

MEMPHIS, June 25.--There is very little talk among the people generally of this region regarding the Presidential election next year. The politicians, however, are quietly considering the chances of the various candidates, and laying their plans accordingly.

WARREN, June 30.--Both the "large" and "small" of the so-called politicians here, on what is known as the old "Western Reserve," are busy predicting the nominees of the Republican and Democratic National Conventions to be held next year.
SOMERVILLE, June 26.--Blaine is the first choice of the Republicans. I have heard no other named. Arthur stock is slim.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28.--Both the Republican and Democratic State Central Committees are comatose just now, but nevertheless there is a good deal of discussion over the coming Presidential campaign among the politicians of both parties, and strong preferences are expressed.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 15.--The proceedings of the Window-glass Workers' Convention, which finished its labors on Friday evening, have been closely kept from the public, and the meagre reports heretofore given by the press were not ...

PORTLAND, June 26.--The nomination of any good man will secure the vote of Oregon. The State is Republican and grows more strongly so every month. It is probable--and certain, I think--that the best class of citizens here, men who value principle, ability, and experience, prefer Edmunds to any man that can be named.

A report that Denis Kearney would speak at yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union resulted in a large attendance of delegates. The business of the day was hurried through and then the Chairman announced that Denis Kearney was in the hall and would address the meeting.

WINONA, June 23.--It is a trifle early to expect anything like crystallized Presidential sentiment. The country press chatter a good deal about William Windom, but do not seriously regard him as palpable. He would get the vote of Minnesota, I think, but he is generally regarded as a political wraith or shadow without substance.

LOUISVILLE, June 26.--Among the Republicans in Kentucky at present the fight for 1884 is shaping up on the old lines of 1880, when the Stalwarts controlled the State overwhelmingly and 20 out of 24 delegates were for Grant.
A jury has at last been secured in the case of the State of Tennessee against MARSH T. POLK, and the trial promises to be an exciting one. POLK'S crime can be very briefly described.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 15.--The case of Green T. Franklin, a former Deputy Marshal under Marshal Osborne, charged with making fraudulent accounts against the Government and with perjury in connection therewith, which terminated for the present yesterday with the discharge of ...

It has been a quiet day at the camp, with comparatively few visitors. A few of the Peekskill girls braved the blazing sun of the morning and the threatening weather and rain of the afternoon and came over to the camp.
CAMDEN, June 25.--The question of a Presi-- dential candidate among the Republicans of this region is never heard. No matter who the nominee may be, they will support him.

The telegraph operators who belong to the New-York Assembly of the Telegraphers' Brotherhood discussed their grievances and purposes at considerable length yesterday afternoon. Their meeting was held with closed doors in the Pyramid Masonic lodge-room, at Eight-avenue and Eighteenth-street ...

LONDON, July 15.--Donald Currie Co.'s steamer Taymouth Castle was boarded at Tamatave on June 26 by a French officer, who stated that the French had taken Tamatave. The passengers were forbidden to go ashore, and the cargo was allowed to be landed only on the payment of duty.

LOCKPORT, June 30.--The Republican Party here has not begun to rally from the exhaustion following the savage political throat-cutting of last Fall. Never were the vindictive forces of faction so systematically set to work in Niagara County as then.

LANSING, July 2.--There has been little expression as yet in regard to Presidential candidates, but the few straws that have come floating from Republican sources tend generally in the direction of Senator Edmunds, of Vermont.
CARTERSVILLE, June 27.--It may be truthfully said there was never a time in the history of Georgia when there was so great indifference to politics and political candidates.
CORINTH, June 29.--Mr. Arthur is mentioned by Republicans here as their first and Mr. Legan as their second choice for a Presidential candidate. I hear no other names canvassed.

By a succession of victories over the Philadelphia Club last week the Cleveland nine caught up to the Providence nine in the race for the championship of the League, and now lead in that association. Providence is second, Boston third, Chicago fourth, New-York fifth, Buffalo sixth, Detroit seventh, and Philadelphia last.

Signor Stagno is to receive, we learn, 60,000f. ($12,000) per month, for 10 performances, during his American engagement. Mr. Abbey offered Signor Masini 80,000f. a month, but the tenor demanded 100,000.

JEFFERSON CITY, June 25.--The Republicans of Missouri will go into the next National Convention with less of the spirit of dictation than heretofore. For the first time in many a year they bid fair to attend a National Convention of the ...

MUNCIE, June 30.--On the part of the Republicans, Senator Benjamin Harrison is mostly spoken of, and is undoubtedly the choice of a great majority of his party as the Republican candidate for President in 1884.

NORWICH, June 30.--If the Republicans of Eastern Connecticut were called upon to announce their favorite candidate for the next Presidential campaign there is little doubt that three-fourths of them would say Chester A. Arthur.

WALTHAM, June 30.--Edmunds is undoubtedly the first choice of Republicans hereabout, next perhaps being Grant. There is practically little mention of candidates at present, and beyond the above no one is spoken of.

ALLENTOWN, June 28.--The Presidential question has not been agitated sufficiently to develop the full sentiment of the people. Those who talk the most prefer Blaine. The masses hope for the nomination of some good man under whose leadership the Republican Party can again win a victory. Edmunds, Lincoln, and Arthur are mentioned.

GREENSBORO, June 27.--So far the names of candidates for the Presidency in 1884 have not been discussed here. The Democrats favor Hendricks first, Hancock next, and Tilden last. The Republicans, (we have only five white ones in the county,) are pleased with Arthur's Administration and mention no one else. The negroes would rather support Grant than any man.

The disabled steam-ship Main, of the North German Lloyd, was towed up to her dock yesterday. Capt. O. Heimbruch stated that the Main left her dock in Hoboken at 2 o'clock on Saturday afternoon with 64 cabin and 143 steerage passengers and a full general cargo.
PROVIDENCE, July 2.--The Republicans have little to say upon the subject of their possible Presidential candidate in 1884. They appear to have given little, if any, thought to the matter.

BURLINGTON, July 5.--The Republicans of Vermont have only one candidate for the Presidential nomination, and that one, it is hardly necessary to say, is George F. Edmunds. Senator Edmunds's influence over the people of the State is due entirely to his great ability and the commanding eminence it had gained for him.

CLINTON, July 15.--The college year which has just closed was, on the whole, favorable for astronomical observations, and the amount of work done by the Director of the Litchfield Observatory and his assistant testifies to their activity.

Christopher Moore, an ex-gambler and general rough was shot last night and instantly killed by Eugene Moulle, a bar-tender employed at Stacom's liquor saloon, on the north-east corner of Third-avenue and Thirty-fourth-street, during an altercation on the opposite corner.

ROCKFORD, June 27.--Since receiving the request from THE TIMES for information relating to the prominently mentioned candidates for the Presidency for 1884, I have taken much time and trouble to thoroughly investigate this matter.

WILSON, June 26.--The Presidential question is not exciting much interest at this time among our people. There are very few white Republicans in this neighborhood, and the colored ones have no choice whatever in the selection of a candidate.

CINCINNATI, July 15.--John G. Thompson has been here since Thursday. His visit is said to be in the interest of Democratic harmony. He met some of the local leaders yesterday, and a second conference was held to-day ...
TECUMSEH, June 25.--Among Republicans in this (Johnson) county and State, J.G. Blaine on the Republican side is undoubtedly the most popular man in the party now, and has been for six or eight years.

There will be a few Oswego strawberries in the markets during the earlier part of this week, but they will generally be of poor quality. Those which come after this week must come from Canada, and when they arrive in good order they will doubtless be sold at high prices.

KENOSHA, June 26.--It is difficult to voice public sentiment in the present condition of our political affairs. As it respects the most prominent Republican candidate for the Presidency spoken of in this portion of the State, as well as in ...
It is a difficult matter for a legislative body composed of two branches which are politically hostile to each other to agree upon a measure for apportioning representation.
PORTSMOUTH, July 9.--The Republican preferences for Presidential candidate in 1884 are, first, Chester A. Arthur, and, second, Edmunds. Blaine is a bad third; hardly spoken of.

A romantic story is told of the circumstances attending the marrige a few days ago of B.C Tunison, a young lawyer of Jersey City, son of the Rev. Mr. Tunison, of the Newark Methodist Episcopal Conference. Miss Belle Barton, an attractive young lady, whose parents reside at York, ...

WHEELING, July 4.--While the present political preferences of West Virginians touching Presidential candidates can be accurately given, little can be said as to how the State representation in either National Convention will vote.

TROY, N.Y., July 16.--At Cheever, near Port Henry, yesterday afternoon, Levi McConnley shot and killed his wife and wounded Mrs. Marston, his mother-in-law, in the hand. McConnley fled and is still at large.
LONDON, July 16.--A dispatch from Trincomalee, Ceylon, dated the 15th inst., says the British corvettes Euryalns and Tourmaline have left there for Mauritius.

The payment of a quarterly dividend on the full amount of the stock of the Western Union Telegraph Company was begun yesterday by a private arrangement made by Mr. JAY GOULD, who nominally, advanced the money, amounting to $1,400,000, for the purpose.
Evidence is increasing of the renewal of the Tilden boom. From the Burlington, (Vt.) Free Press and Times. Well, the Democracy might go further and fare very much worse.

Yesterday was the tenth day of the July meeting at Brighton Beach, the weather being warm and the track in excellent condition, so that fast time was the order of the day. There was a break in the monotonous winnings of the favorites, who for the past two weeks have carried all before ...

It is understood that Mr. ROLLINS is very angry with the New-Hampshire Republicans. In fact, he is not only angry, but he is very much astonished. He is as deeply amazed as Bumble was when Oliver Twist asked for "more."

The second day of the midsummer meeting of the Monmouth Park Association promises excellent sport, as the five flat races have good fields of starters in each, and several horses of merit will measure strides, notably, Kinglike and Parole, who will renew their struggle over a furlong more ...

Wednesday, the 30th ulu., was very generally observed in this city as a holiday, the date being that set apart in America for the decorating of the graves of United States soldiers and sailors who fell durine the war of the rebellion, and known as "Memorial Day.

A very respectable-looking fiddle, good enough to play "Haste to the Wedding" upon, may be purchased at a second-hand dealer's for a few shillings. An undoubted Antonius Stradivarius may, on the other hand, bring, in an auction, sale, as much as 500.

The clans are gathering at Saratoga in great numbers, and when the bell rings for the first race on Saturday next the Vandals and the Goths from the West and South will have completed their invasion. BRISTOL, Conn., July 16.--Edward Hyland, of Forestville, was arrested to-day, charged with the murder of his wife, Hyland, who is 50 years old and reputed to be rich is a man phlegmatic temperament, and lately, for some reason, he has been drinking heavily.

This title, which Prof. Huxley gave to a lecture delivered at the Fisheries Exhibition Congress, was in the first sentence admitted to be too large for the subjects discussed. The learned Professor spoke entirely upon that particular disease which attacks fresh-water fishes ...

ALBANY, July 16.--About 10 o'clock last evening a party at the club-house at the Island Park Race Course, two miles from this city, was startled by two pistol-shots in the direction of the grand stand, about 200 yards distant. Three-quarters of an hour later, having summoned up ...

BUFFALO, July 16.--The Germans have been pouring into the city all day to attend the Saengerfest which opened this evening. A count kept at the stations of eleven railroads shows that the number of arrivals Sunday evening and to-day exceeds 28,000.
Princess Louise will send several oil and water-color paintings to the Boston Foreign Exhibition next October.

WASHINGTON, July 16.--Rear-Admiral Nichols, Acting Secretary of the Navy, to-day issued a general order to the effect that the regulations for the change of uniforms of naval officers will not go into effect until the department so orders.

CHICAGO, July 16.--Unless the demands of the brotherhood are complied with the telegraphers of this city and of the North-west will stop work on Wednesday. The contemplated strike has been a leading topic ot conversation in business circles here to-day.

PARIS, July 4.--Military reviewers--and by this I mean not those parlor strategists who talk glibly and write eloquently about military matters from hearsay, but practical soldiers who have seen the elephant--are beginning to agitate a question of some importance.

A committee of the Cigar-makers' Progressive Union visited the factory of S. Ottenberg Brothers, at No. 340 East Twenty-third-street, yesterday afternoon, and had a conference with the Messrs. Ottenberg. They offered to return to work in the factory at once providing...

Mayor Edson returned to his duties in the City Hall yesterday after a week's vacation. Controller Campbell will spend this week on Long Island.

DES MOINES, July 16.--This city was visited by a terrific wind-storm early this morning, which surpassed anything of the kind ever seen here before. At no time has the velocity of the wind been so great.

For a year or more S.W. DORSEY has been scattering from Washington, through the columns of every newspaper to which he could get access, a series of charges against the integrity of the late President GARFIELD.

In the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday, Judge Van Hoesen denied a motion for an injunction to restrain John L. Drummond and Thomas O. Smith from carrying on the milk business in a noisy manner, and from allowing it to be carried on, at No. 133 West Fifty-third-street.

LONDON, July 4.--The Fourth of July no longer serves to remind England of a certain International hostility but of the ties of a blood friendship. Independence Day will this year be marked in London by special honors to a great artist and a true gentleman in view ...

CONCORD, N.H., July 16.--If complete discomfiture could operate to disturb him, William E. Chandler would be a very unhappy man. Last Thursday he sprang into the Senatorial arena with the air of a conqueror. Four days as a candidate has convinced ...

CHICAGO, July 17.--The feeling of the Chicago telegraphers is one of the atmost confidence as to the outcome of the present situation. A Western Union official here said this morning:
The Directors of the Oregon and Transcontinental Company have made their annual report to the stockholders for the year ending June 30, 1883.

A collision occurred in the North River, opposite Pier No. 11, at about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, between the excursion steamer Plymouth Rock and the Kill Von Kull, a large ferry-boat belonging to the Central Railway of New-Jersey.
Putney has already been awakened from its customary quiet by a sudden invasion of volunteers. It cannot be said to have been quite unprepared ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 17.--The court-martial appointed by the President to examine into the case of Col. Guido Ilges, charged with duplicating his pay accounts, assembled here at 11 o'clock this morning.
OGDENSBURG, N.Y., July 17.--A brisk gale has swept down the river since sunrise, lashing the surface into whitecaps from shore to shore.
It is now about 10 years since I first ventured to predict the result of the foolish experiment of introducing the European sparrows into this country.

CHICAGO, July 17.--The leading produce markets were more active to-day and averaged stronger. The upturn in prices was led by wheat, which commanded more confidence, both here and on the other side of the Atlantic, the crop prospect not being so roseate as recently painted by the fancy of the bears.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 17.--Great excitement was created in commercial circles to-day by a rumor that the McGeoch settlement might eventually fall through on account of the inability of Mr. McGeoch to secure the large sum of money which it will be necessary for him to place in the hands of Receiver Bentley in order to enable the ...

The Democratic papers friendly to Mr. TILDEN are naturally pleased that the canvass of Presidential preferences in their party should show so decided a leaning toward their favorite, within a few days of his formal announcement as a candidate.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 17.--Judge Allen announced in the Criminal Court to-day that he had considered the motions made by the counsel of ex-State Treasurer Polk to quash the indictment against him, and would overrule them.

WASHINGTON, July 17.--The Hill Investigating Committee resumed its sessions to-day, James P. Lowe, of the Architect's office, was recalled, and testified that there was no draughtsman in the office in 1878 able to prepare the plans for heating apparatus for the Chicago building.
The Commissioner of Internal Revenue today appointed Isham Young, of Knoxville, Tenn., to be a Revenue Agent, vice C.M. Horton, of Boston, removed.
CONCORD, N.H., July 17.--"We never speak as we pass by" is the popular refrain here, rising from the little personal animosities of the Senatorial strife.

Henry F. Doyle, an ex-convict and member of the "Border" gang of thieves and ruffians, was shot and fatally wounded by Frank Donnelley, bartender in Peter McCarron's liquor saloon, No. 652 Water-street, yesterday afternoon.
The Due de Broglie has written a letter to say that no reunion of the Orleans Princes was held in his house.
BRUSSELS, July 17.--The Belgian Government will accept a compromise on the proposed tobacco duty.

WASHINGTON, July 17.--A day having elapsed since Washington people were afforded a chance of reading the letters in THE TIMES giving the Presidential outlook, the results of the extended inquiry made are found to have attracted even wider attention than was at first supposed.

A remarkable story about the labors and expectations of the Southern Pacific and Central Pacific Railroad combination in Washington has been sent to the Chicago Tribune by its Washington correspondent.

No definite information as to what disposition the Western Union Telegraph Company would make of the demand for increase in the pay of its operators and linemen and a reduction in the time of the former could be obtained yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 17.--Gov. Hamilton to-day made public his determination not to pardon Charles W. Angell, whose embezzlements of large amounts of money from the Pullman Palace Car Company created so much excitement in 1878. He was convicted in February, 1879, and sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment.

BUFFALO, July 17.--The second day of the Saengerfest has seemed to assure its entire success. The weather was fine, and the number of visitors has been augmented by several thousands.
One of the London papers says: "In the opinion of Mr. Briggs fox-hunting was an 'image of war without its guilt, and only five-and-twenty per cent. of its danger.'

The crowds still flock to Monmouth Park, and the enthusiasm displayed yesterday shows that the interest in the races gains with the accession of new material from the West.

Judge Donohue yesterday denied the motion for a new trial for Edward Hovey, who is sentenced to be hanged on the 27th inst. at the Tombs for the murder of his sister-in-law, Fanny Vermilyea.

The Five Points Mission sent the first installment of its little scholars, whom it has given a holiday out of town every Summer for the last four years, into the country yesterday to remain for periods of from two to six weeks.
CHICAGO, July 17.--Gen. Eckert sent the following dispatch to the Superintendent of the Western Union Company here to-day:

The respective rights of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and the Jersey Central Railroad Company to the use of the Long Branch Railroad is now in litigation, but officers of the Pennsylvania Company have declared that, no matter what the court decides, that company will build a road of its own to Long Branch.
John Morrissey, 12 years old, of No. 37 Jefferson-street, was found drowned yesterday at Pier No. 48 East River.

CAIRO, July 17.--The Sanitary Commission is endeavoring to purify Cairo and to isolate the houses where cholera has appeared, but if the disease takes a firm hold in the city it is probable that it will be allowed to take its course, and that general precautions only will be taken to check its progress.

A sale of thorough-bred stock took place in the paddock at Monmouth Park yesterday before the races began, and it was well attended. Some bargains were no doubt obtained by the buyers.

ST. PAUL, July 26.--The daily telegraphic reports received at the railroad offices in St. Paul as to the condition of the crops continue very encouraging. The only anxiety felt now is regarding the effect of the late storm in some of the south-eastern counties.

ST. LOUIS, July 26.--An unusual stir was apparent among the striking telegaphers this morning. The leading officers of the brotherhood had long and earnest consultations with one another, and the body at large was not slow in finding out that something of more than usual importance was under discussion.

During the past three or four months the extinct volcano of Ometepe--an island in Lake Nicaragua, 20 miles long--has given signs that it was about to burst into activity. Smoke, flames, ashes, pumice-stone, small lava flows, and all the accessories which mark a complete volcanic outlet have been seen.

DETROIT, July 26.--A calamity of unprecedented magnitude visited the city of Grand Rapids, in the western part of the State, to-day. Since Saturday there have been very heavy rain-storms in that region. Over 4 inches of water has fallen. As a result the streams swelled to overflowing.

LYNCHBURG, Va., July 26.--The work of the Democratic Convention gives very general satisfaction to the party leaders. The tariff plank in the platform does not, however, meet the wishes of the members of that body who are directly interested in manufacturing interests in Virginia.

CHICAGO, July 26.--The leading produce markets were uncertain and unsettled to-day. There was a fair volume of business at generally lower prices except in corn. There was not much trading on outside account, and the news was not specially favorable to higher prices.

LANCASTER, Penn., July 30.--Reports from all sections of this county show that the hail and rain storm of Saturday night was more destructive than was indicated by the earlier reports. Over 1,000 acres of growing tobacco were completely destroyed, much of which, however, is insured. The streams were greatly swollen and several bridges were carried away, a number of narrow escapes from drowning being reported.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 31.--A telegram just received here makes the startling announcement that a train bearing an excursion party of 170 persons, bound for the Grand Canon, was precipitated from the trestle crossing the palisades of the Black Canon, into the Gunnison River, and that 140 persons of the 170 on the train were killed or wounded.

Owing to the contraction of a severe cold on his journey East, Denis Kearney has given up his missionary work in this City and will return at once to "the glorious climate" of his adopted State. Mr. Kearney has also discovered that he needs rest and freedom from care, and nowhere, he thinks, can they be so well obtained as in the bosom of his family.

Mgr. Thomas J. Capel, the famous Catholic revivalist of England, arrived in this City yesterday morning on the Guion steam-ship Arizona. Mgr. Capel aspects to remain in this country several months, if possible, and will make an extended tour through the United States.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 30.--At 11 o'clock this morning Theodore George, the wrestler, and Isidore Magnificio, a gambler, became involved in a difficulty on Franklin-street, between Custom House and Blenville streets. George was out in the right breast and slightly wounded by his antagonist, who was arrested.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 30.--The Governor today pardoned Dennis Kennedy, who was sentenced in the Court of Sessions, in Washington County, Dec. 1, 1881, to imprisonment in Clinton Prison for five years and five months upon his conviction of the crime of robbery.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--By direction of the President a general court-martial was to-day appointed to meet at Vancouver Barracks, Washington Territory, on Aug. 30, or as soon thereafter as practicable, for the trial of Second Lieut.

NAPLES, July 30.--Prof. Palmieri, Director of the Meteorological Observatory on Mount Vesuvius, states that the disaster on the island of Ischia Saturday night was not due to an earthquake, but to the subsidence of the ground.
All of the counties, so far as heard from, report a large increase in their assessment rolls, and from the agricultural counties there is every indication of prosperity.

LONDON, July 30.--In the House of Commons, this afternoon, Mr. Gladstone said that before any action was taken in regard to the second Suez Canal, the House should have an opportunity of expressing its opinion on the subject.

Local politicians talked a good deal yesterday about the vacancy in the Finance Department caused by the resignation of Controller Allan Campbell. They were especially anxious to learn who would be appointed to the Controllership, but their curiosity was not gratified.

House flies have at last put in an appearance on the Comstock. With them have come nearly as many small green flies, which feed with the genuine house flies. Some here assert that the green flies never come with the others except in cholera years. They are about half the size of the common blow-fly, and are of a bright metallic lustre.
OTTAWA, July 30.--The Marine and Fisheries Department has been informed that three of her Majesty's ships of war will arrive at Quebec about the middle of August.

The fifth annual picnic of the Order of the Sons of St. George was celebrated yesterday at Ridgewood Park, Brooklyn, by Heart of Oak, Anglo-Saxon, and Commonwealth Lodges. The order includes more than 100 lodges, scattered about the United States.

BREMEN, July 30.--The Senate has issued an order to all Captains of vessels which arrive from America with pickled pork as a part of their cargo to inform the Customs authorities of the quantity they have on board of such pork under pain of 300 marks' fine for neglect to do so.

Abraham Ostheim and Joseph Stern, doing business as Ostheim Stern, at No. 89 Mercer-street, where they were engaged in the manufacture of suspenders, have made an assignment to Herman Kahn, with the following preferences: To German Exchange Bank, $485 15; to Jacob London, $950; to Bernard Kahn, $1,000; total preferences, $2,435 15.

Columbus, after a long period of quietness, is becoming a lively camp once more. It would be vain to expect it ever to regain its old-time bustle and activity--the days of "booms," in the full meaning of the term, have passed away--when it was the metropolis of the county.

SARATOGA, July 30.--Delightful weather, coupled with a superb programme, attracted a large attendance at the course to-day to witness the fourth extra day's sport of the Saratoga RaceTrack Association. The purses were all closely contested for and the only disagreeable feature ...

A crowd made up of roughs from Brooklyn, Hoboken, and this City played cards in the liquor saloon of Joseph Millig, of No. 116 Maiden-lane, last evening, Having become quarrelsome over their game, Millig attempted to put them out. When he got the last man to the door several others grabbed Millig and hauled him out and threw him to the sidewalk.
A short telegraphic dispatch was handed in at the Western Union telegraph office on Saturday afternoon by the writer directad to the Providence Journal at 1:40 o'clock, and contained about 100 words.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--The Hill investigation was resumed this morning. Mr. Hill was recalled by Mr. Coleman and questioned in regard to contracts for elevators. He said he had invited competition by circular-letter. Five elevators were removed from the Appraiser'e stores in NewYork because they were worn out, and replaced with new ones.

LOUISVILLE, July 30.--All Sunday, day and night, busy hands were at work at the exposition building, putting in exhibits, and to-day thousands of workmen have been engaged, and by electric light to-night will continue to work.

FINDLAY, Ohio, July 28.--One of the saddest affairs to oocur in a long time is reported from Orange Township, this county. Miss Alice, the charming daughter of John Montgomery. Esq., was courted by the beaus of all that section, but was won by a bright, industrious young man named Will Swank, who had long been devoted to her.

Two pistol shots, fired within five seconds of each other, shortly after 9 o'clock yesterday morning, alarmed the inmates of No. 211 West Twentysecond-street, which is a respectable furnished room house leased by Mrs. G.R. Williamson. The shots were fired in a room on the street side of the third floor, occupied by Horace ...

LIMA, July 30, via Galveston.--According to El Comercio, very few persons attended the meeting in the Politema Theatre yesterday. After resolving to canvass for public signatures for future action the meeting adjourned.

CHICAGO, July 30.--The body of Thomas Hoyne, who was killed in the accident at Carlyon station, N.Y., reached Chicago to-night, and was escorted from the station by a committee of the Iroquois Club, headed by Judge Moran.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--Surgeon-General Hamilton, of the Marine Hospital Service, to-day received a cable dispatch from Havana stating that the City of Merida, from Vera Cruz to NewYork, left 11 cases of yellow fever at that port. The steamer was disinfected on July 28.
The eighteenth day of the July meeting and the thirty-first day of the season at the Brighton Beach track brought together another large crowd of people.
TROY, N.Y., July 30.--Selar Knigt, who was for 20 years a Justice of the Peace in Crescent, Saratoga County, committed suicide to-day by hanging.

NEWBURG, July 30.--The first accident to a passenger on the new West Shore and Buffalo Railway occurred to-day. George Weller, of Burnside, on the Ontario and Western branch of the West Shore Road, took a train at West Point to go to his home. When about one mile north of West Point he left his seat to go into the smoking car.

A poorly dressed, middle-aged colored woman, who was evidently slightly insane, complained to Justice Patterson yesterday morning that she had been bewitched by some of her colored neighbors in a tenement-house in Thompson-street, into which she and her husband had recently moved.

The manager of the clearing department of tha New-York Stock Clearing-house is so well satisfied with the result of the business thus far that he has resolved to add 12 more stocks to the present list of 12 for clearing purposes. A phenomenon surpassing anything of the kind that has come undar my observation was seen not only by myself, but by several persons from the residence of Mr. G.H. Jerome, in the suburbs of Niles, Mich., which I would be glad to have explained by some one versed in the arcana of the atmosphere.

The second day of the Badisches Volksfest was celebrated by the Baden residents of this City at Washington Park, at Sixty-ninth-street and Avenue A, yesterday. A high column was erected in the middle of the arounds, and was entwined with the Germen national and Baden colors, and the dancing platform was decorated in a similar manner.
Last Winter, in Ouray County, Gol. D. R. Frasar and his partner, J.R. Murdoch, lost their lives in a snowslide. They were covered with snow to such a depth that their bodies could not be found.

ST. LOUIS, July 30.--The striking telegraph operators are, if possible, more confident than ever that they will succeed. On 'Change the service improved considerably and the dissatisfaction was less general.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--An important and interesting report, entitled "The Mineral Resources of the United States," is now in press, and will soon be published by Mr. Albert Williams, Jr., Chief of the Division of Mining Statistics and Technology, United States Geological Survey, the Hon. J.W. Powell, Director. This report is for the calendar year 1882 and the first six ...
The comrades of Dahigren Post, No. 113, G. A.R., will enjoy an excursion to Mount Pleasant Grove on the Hndson to-morrow. There will be music and dancing in the grove.

A correspondent, whose letter appears in another column, writes in a conservative vein on the subject of strikes. He does not quite agree with an assertion made in these columns on Sunday that wage-earners, through union, are gaining some ...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 30.--Another railroad accident happened this afternoon at Charlotte, seven miles north of this city. A Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg freight train ran into a New-York Central passenger train, tipping over three coaches and smashing one. Mrs. Joseph Davis, George Harris, Conductor Smith, and another person, name unknown, were seriously cut and bruised.

The house of Mr. George Handy, on the town road, had the appearance of a hospital. Among the injured removed there were Mrs. Hall and her invalid daughter, of Leslie, Mich., who were on their way to the White Mountains. The health of the young lady is so delicate that the shock rendered her unable to continue the journey.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., July 25.--Two days spent in this beautiful city, where David Davis has filled so much space, has opened to my ears and eyes a good deal of current history, personal and political. The Hon. John Oberly, editor of the Daily Bulletin, is Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, and evidently talks politics at home.

MADISON, Ind., July 30.--Sanford Osborn was arrested yesterday in Kentucky, five miles from Madison, charged with robbing the cars, Post Office, and Wagner's store. Thomas Brandley, John Furgeson, and Hiram Weddle were also arrested as accomplices.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 30.--The Parnell testimonial fund, as reported by the Treasurer the Rev. T.J. Conaty, now foots up $5.528.
Our contemporaries, the Eastman Times and the Dodge County Journal, give an account of a battle between a king snake and a moccasin.

The Hon. John Simpson used to call it "mesmerism." The Hon. George Brown called it "making a big push." John Madiver described it as "putting down bribery and corruption with lots of money." Mr. Morris described it as "missionary work." Mr. W. Ross, Mr. Mackenzie's first Minister of Militia, termed it "relieving honest, worthy men." But Col. Morin, of Welland, has a new name for it.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 30.--Thanks to the executive ability of Mr. Hermann Oelrichs, of New-York, the polo difficulties have been overcome and there will be no further trouble. Mr. Oelrichs arrived this morning and called a special meeting of the Governors, nearly all of whom are new men.
A meeting of the recently organized Real Estate and Traders' Exchange was held in the Exchange Rooms, No. 39 Broadway, yesterday afternoon and the attandance numbered about 150 members.

On the 21st inst. Mr. John Guion, a bookkeeper in a paint warehouse in Pearl-street, started on his vacation, with his wife, childran, and servant, and went to New-Jersey, leaving his motherin-law. Mrs. Ellen Coleman, 55 years old, a widow, in his flat on the third floor of No. 407 Lexingtonavenue.

BOSTON, July 30.--The announcement this morning of the suspension of C.W. Copeland Co., one of the largest shoe firms in the city, followed soon after noon by that of the suspension of F. Shaw Brothers, the largest leather-tanning firm in the country, created consternation on the street, particularly in the boot, shoe, and leather districts of the city.

CINCINNATI, July 30.--During the great flood in February a portion of the Southern Railway passenger station was carried away, and several persons--it will never be known how manywere buried deep in the debris, which was strewn several feet deep on some low ground near by.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30.--The base-ball match to-day between New-York and Philadelphia telegraph operators for the benefit of the striking operators resulted in favor of the former by a score of 20 to 6. The exact amount realized from the sale of tickets is not yet known, but is something over $1,000.
CARLINVILLE, Ill., July 30.--Two miners named Henry Staats and George Kaiser were instantly killed in the Loomis coal mine yesterday by the falling of the slate roof.

LONDON, July 9.--On Friday last it was my good luck to get down to Henley on the second day of this year's regatta, probably the most brilliant meeting, weather and all things considered, that has been held for years past.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 30.--A dispatch to the Gazette from Hot Springs says: "An officer and posse in pursuit of the Montgomery, Zell, and Garland County outlaws came up with the Daniels brothers and their bands on the mountains in Perry County, on the head waters of the Fourche la Fave River, on Sunday.
WASHINGTON, July 30, 1883. The Treasury reserve, which is steadily in creasing, to-day amounted to $147,741,268.

NORWICH, July 30.--John Kendall, a hardheaded blacksmith of the neighboring town of Preston, died several years ago, leaving an estate valued at about $13,000. He had originally made a will bequeathing his property to Mrs. William T. Chamberlin, a neighbor, who had befriended him during the latter years of his life; ...

FRANKFORT, Ky., July 27.--A tide of capital has surely set in toward Eastern Kentucky, and lands which a few years past were not thought worthy the attention of the Tax Collectors are now eagerly sought after, either by "land sharks," who will hold them for a future increase of value, or by the people of Ohio.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 30.--The Hon. Mr. Norquay, Premier of Manitoba, and a car-load of special policemen have arrived at Rat Portage, where all was quiet at last accounts.
OTTAWA, July 30.--Nearly 1,000 pilgrims left this city to-day on an excursion to St. Anne de Beaupre. They were accompanied by the Roman Catholic Bishop of Ottawa and a number of clergymen.

United States Special Agents, assisted by the Post Office authorities, have during the past few months intercepted several thousands of dollars' worth of valuable goods which have come into this conntry in the foreign mails without the payment of the Customs duties.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30.--Robert H. Hunter, well known to billiard-players in Philadelphia and New-York, died to-day at his residence, No. 1,221 Catherine-street. He was manager of Green's billiard-room.

VINEYARD HAVEN, July 30.--The schooner Ella M. Storer, Capt. Pitcher, from Baltimore for Bath, which ran ashore Saturday night on Hedge Fence Shoal, Vineyard Sound, was floated yesterday morning, with assistance from this port, without apparent damage, and has arrived here.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--There is no change in the telegraphic situation here to-day except that the strikers claim to have captured a Western Union man sent to open a branch office at the Baltimore and Fotomac Railroad station and initiated him into the brotherhood.

CINCINNATI, July 30.--The vinegar factory of F. Miller has been seized by order of internal revenue officers for carrying on the manufacture of vinegar in an illegal manner. Several barrels of spirits above legal proof for vinegar were found on the premises.

Just two years ago to-morrow Collector Robertson began his administration of the affairs of the Custom-house at this port as successor to Gen. Merrit. The number of employes removed by the present Collector thus far is 17, and in each case the removal was for cause.

Gen. Francis C. Barlow applied to Judge Haight, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, for the adjournment of the hearing of the application of Russell Sage for a mandamus to compel the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad Company to issue 500 shares of its stock to him on a certificate bought by him from George H. Pullman.

BOSTON, July 31.--The annual report of the Rutland Railroad Company for the year ended July 1 was presented at a meeting to-day. It embraces a statement of the Directors' balance-sheet for the year and a report of the special expert accountant.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 31.--Referring to Dr. G. Farrar Patten, who achieved some notoriety last week in connection with a Government steam launch, Gov. McEnery to-day issued an executive order expelling him from the quarantine station, ...
ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 31.--The Demo cratic County Convention to nominats candidates for State Senator, House of Delegates, and county officers was held here to-day.
BALTIMORE, July 31.--A meeting of prominent Israelites was held in this city to-night to consider whether further aid shall be given to the Middlesex, Va., colony of Russian refugees.
PARIS, July 31.--The Cabinet has fixed an extra budget of 254,000,000f.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 31.--The Southern Exposition, not as it stands to-day, incomplete and with partially empty halls, but as it will perhaps be in a few weeks, is the first organized effort to attract national attention to one of the most interesting, beautiful, and prosperous cities in this country.

Do the Chinese eat rats? This has always been a mooted question. Geographies contain the assertion that they do, and an old wood-cut of a Chinaman peddling rodents, strung by the tails to a rack which he carried over his shoulders, is a standard illustration of the common school atlases of 10 years ago.

BUFFALO, July 31.--The Western Union telegraph manager claims to have set two new men to work to-day, and says with assurance that no concession to the strikers will be made. The strikers say, nevertheless, that his force is an exceedingly poor one. There is no break in their ranks, and with the outside help they are getting they say they can hold out indefinitely. The situation shows no noticeable change.

CLEVELAND, July 31.--Mrs. Charles Burke, 48 years old, left her dwelling on Clifton-street last night attired only in her night-dress, walked to the lake at the foot of Wason-street, and drowned herself. The body was found early this morning.

WASHINHGTON, July 20.--Twenty-six years ago, in the early Summer of 1857, a young man of fine promise and modest ambition left the City of New-York on a prospecting tour through the West, with a view to investment and perhaps to a permanent settlement in some inviting locality. This gentleman was then 27 years of age.
LONDON, July 31.--O'Donnell, who shot James Carey, the informer, was accompanied from England by his wife, who appeared to be on intimate terms with the Carey family during the voyage.

William Wilson, of No. 1,262 Third-avenue, entered the liquor store at No. 431 First-avenue last night and asked for a drink. It was refused him. He attempted to go behind the bar, and a man named Flynn, who was in charge of the saloon, shot him twice in the leg. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital, and Flynn was looked up.

BALTIMORE, July 31.--The Grand Jury of this city to-day began the investigation of charges by Fire Marshal J. Monroe Heiskell against J. Frank Morrison and Mr. Register, who were formerly Fire Commissioners of this city. The Commissioners were put out of office by the efforts of Mayor Whyte, who secured the abolition of the board, and then appointed his private secretary, Heiskell, as Fire Marshal.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., July 31.--At noon today six operators in the general office of the Chicago, Alton and Bloomington Railroad Company were requested to vacate their seats, and their places were filled with men not belonging to the brotherhood.
CINCINNATI, July 31.--Receipts of wheat at this port during the month of July fell off 1,200,000 bushels, as compared with the receipts for the same month last year.

CONCORD, July 31.--Absolute uncertainty prevails to-night in regard to the Senatorial question. The vote to-day contributed as much as any previous one to complicate the situation. The Pike boom took on a little additional strength, but not as much as Pike's friends had hoped for.

TRENTON, N.J., July 31.--There has been considerable curiosity among politicians as to the reasons which induced the Democratic State Committee to fix upon Sept. 13 as the date of the State Convention to nominate a candidate for Governor.

WASHINGTON, July 31.--Paragraph 8, special orders No. 167, July 21, 1883, relating to Post Chaplain (George W. Collier, is revokod, and the extension of leave of absence granted to this officer is further extended one month.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 31.--A dispatch from Gilroy last evening reported two shocks of earthquake yesterday. A rumbling sound was distinctly heard.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 31.--The fishing schooner Humming Bird recently capsized in Minas Basin, off Cape Split, after an unusually large catch of herring. Parker Dykens, of Carleton.
CINCINNATI, July 31.--A meeting that may be attended with important results will be held in Louisville on Aug. 8.

DES MOINES, July 31.--The Greenback State Central Committee is in secret session here to-day.
WASHINGTON, July 31.--All sorts of reports about the telegraph strike here appear to have gone out, and an effort to show that the striking operators have "weakened" has plainly been made.
Mr. Georgo J. Gould busied himself yesterday at the office of W.E. Connor Co., of which firm he is a member, and assured all inquiring friends that he had enoyed his European trip very much.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., July 31.--The Pennsylvania Railroad Company to-day suspended for an indefinite period 150 workmen from their machine shops in this city, giving as the cause the light freight business of the past month. It is expected that the company will re-employ the men in six or eight weeks.

NAPLES, July 31.--The search of the ruins for bodies of victims of the earthquake on the island of Ischia was continued during the night. All the bodies recovered are buried immediately to prevent miasma. An eyewitness describes the scene at the theatre at Casamicciola when the earthquake occurred as an awful one.

DENVER, Col., July 31.--There is no truth in the report of an accident to the Grand Army excursion train on the Rio Grande Road. The train was delayed by washouts.

MOLINE, Ill., July 31.--Edward J. Dahms, a young attorney of this place, became so popular that at the last election he was chosen City Attorney of Moline without opposition a position he still holds.

MONTREAL, July 31.--No news has been received of the overdue steamer Ludwig, now 29 days out. Her passages have heretofore been made in 14 days.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 31.--The compesitors on the Evening Journal struck to-day because the proprietors would not discharge a young woman compositor who did not belong to the Typographical Union.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., July 31.--The totals of the July oil report of operations in Western Pennsylvania were given to the trade this afternoon, and complete figures will be published tomorrow.

YOUNGSTOWN, N.Y., July 29.--Here at the month of the Niagara, as elsewhere along the river, great interest is felt in the recovery of the body of the ill-fated Capt. Webb, and no opinion is uttered by tue hardy and experienced boatmen, who are as much at home on the river as on shore.

Curtis B. Wells, of this city, has received letter from Henry M. Burt, detailing the editor's experience with lightning. Mr. Burt certainly had a narrow escape.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 31.--At an icecream festival in Union, S.C., on Saturday, 30 persons were poisoned by eating ice-cream that had been prepared in a brass vessel. No deaths have yet occurred, but some of the victims are in a very dangerous condition. No criminal intent is charged against any one, but gross carelessness, and the matter may undergo investigation.

BALTIMORE, July 31.--The Rev. Dr. George R. Bristor, who recently left St. Luke's Methodist Episcopal Church in Newark, under a cloud, and came to this city to his father's home, to-day sent a letter to the Presiding Elder of that District in defense of his conduct. In his answer to the charges Dr. Bristor claims that the trial was a farce, and that he resigned the Pastorate of the church for ...
Laurea P. Stubbs, an intelligent young man, was arrested one day last week on the complaint of Qong Tek, a Chinaman, who charged Stubbs with the larceny of a book valued at $10.

Robert McIntyre, a conductor, of No. 77 North Seventh-street, Brooklyn, while under the influence of liquor yesterday afternoon, showed an inclination to sit down and sleep near the express department of the railroad station at Hunter's Point.

The Republican State Committee of Massachusetts met yesterday and named Boston as the place and Sept. 19 as the time for holding the State Convention of the party. This is regarded as the formal opening of the campaign for the redemption of the old ...

BOSTON, July 31.--The Republican State Committee met to-day and agreed upon this city as the place and Sept. 19 as the time for the State Convention. Col. Charles R. Codman, of this city, was selected for presiding officer. The meeting was quite fully attended, and its action was reached without a great deal of discussion.

VICKSBURG, Miss., July 31.--A special dispatch to the Herald from Marysville says: "Ben Hardy and two other men, whose names are unknown, employed on Government pile-drivers at this place, fell overboard to-day and were drowned near where five men were drowned by the capsizing of skiffs last Saturday."
Brig Goodwin, Hicks, Cardenas 11 ds., with sugar and asphalt to order--vessel to Swan Son.

CLVELAND, July 31.--The Grand Circuit races began here to-day. The weather was delightful and the track fast. The attendance was large. George V. won the first heat of the 2:29 trot in 2:21 Allegheny Boy second. Maggie F. third, Felix, the favorite, fourth. In the 2:24 trot Bronze won the first heat in 2:21 . St. Cloud second. Nellie G. third. Edwin A. fourth.

CHICAGO, July 31.--Application was made in the United States Circuit Court to-day for leave to file a petition for a Receiver for the Toledo, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad. The application was made by Granville D. Brannan, one of the heavy bondholders, who alleges that the road is so involved financially that it must stop business, unless a Receiver is appointed.

RICHMOND, Va., July 31.--An Associated Press report in the Dispatch this morning states that one striker returned to work in Richmond, and two who applied for work were not needed here and were sent to washington. This is untrue.

WASHINGTON, July 31.--When the Hill investigating committee met this morning Mr. Coleman asked for a ruling on a request made by him four or five weeks ago that the committee secure the attendance or have the testimony taken at his home of Mr. M.H. St. John, of Albany, who, he thought, could throw some light on the contract system of the architect's office.
James Bedford, a bricklayer, of No. 344 Third-avenue, and Richard Clark, a painter, of No. 125 Eleventh-street, went to Rockaway Beach yesterday morning to spend the day.

There was another disorderly scene at Monmouth Park yesterday which every true friend of the turf must regret. These frequent conflicts between the betting crowd and the judges are becoming a source of annoyance to all respectable people who attend the races, and it may be asked if the association does not think it worth while ...

A man who gave the name James Brown, and who was apparently a mechanic or a laborer, hired a room in Charles Koch's lodging-house, at No. 209 Bowery, yesterday, and left instructions to be called at 5 o'clock in the afternoon.

The complete history of the London syndicate's absurd scheme to make something out of Confederate bonds has not been told. We have heard about the engagement of Lord PENZANCE, a banker, and two members of Parliament who are to pose before the public as Trustees.

A lad named Abraham Alexander was arrested on March 17 last on a charge of highway robbery made by Lazarus Levi, a Mott-street button manufacturer. Alexander was tried and acquitted in the Court of General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, July 31--It seems to be the general belief here that Senor Barca, the Spanish Minister, became deranged because the Government he represented refused his application for an extended leave of absence, which he is understood to have regarded as humiliating.
BUFFALO, July 31.--The Coroner's inquest in the case of Capt. Webb, who lost his life in the Niagara Whirlpool Rapids, to-day rendered a verdict of death from unknown causes.

LOCKPORT, July 31.--An enthusiastic railroad meeting was held in the Opera-house in this city to-night under the auspices of the new Lockport Improvement Association for furthering the building of a narrow-gauge railroad between Lockport and Olcott Harbor, with prospects of ...

Sadder revelations of flendish cruelty have never been made than those which recently came to light in connection with the illtreatment and murder of fishing lads on board vessels of the Hull fishing fleet.

HAVANA, July 31.--Gen. Prendergast, Captain-General of Cuba, has tendered his resignation, owing ostensibly to ill-health, and it has been accepted by the home Government. He will leave for Spain on Sunday. Gen. Chinchilla, the viceCaptain-General, has also resigned. Gen. Castillo has been appointed Gen. Prendergast's successor. Pending the arrival of the new Captain-General, Gen. Reina will assume the duties of the office.

JACKSON, Miss., July 31.--The Hon. J. B. Yellowly, late candidate for LieutanantGovernor on the Ben King ticket, supports the Democratic-Pepublican fusion ticket in Madison County. James Hill, one of the most prominent colored politicians in the State and candidate for Congress against Barksdale at the late election, will write a letter advising the same course.

HARRISBURG, Penn., July 31.--New Congressional and Legislative Apportionment bills were introduced in the House to-day. The former gives the Republicans 17 districts and the Democrats 11. The latter bill gives the Republicans 30 Senators and the Democrats 20. In the Senate a resolution was adopted to adjourn on Tuesday next.
The Board of Fire Underwriters met yesterday and received the final reports of the sub-committees on the dry goods district.
PHILADELPHIA, July 31.--Minister Preston, of the Haytian Republic, returned to New-York this morning. His mission to this city was to make the second payment of $30,000 due on the ...
It is said at the Treasury-Department that the reduction of the public debt for July will be unusually small, if any. An estimate cannot be given to-day.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 31.--Charles Parrish, the coal king of the Wyoming regions, for 20 years operating the various mines owned by the Lehigh and Wilkeabarre Coal Company, will sever his connection with the company as contractor to-morrow. A farewell addreas to his many thousand miners was prepared by him today, and was posted at the various collieries tonight. The company will hereafter mine its own coal.

The inquest held by Coroner Merkle into the cause of death of Policeman William F. Brady, a Roundsman of the Fourteenth Precinct, who fell into Third-avenue, at One Hundred and Sitxeenthstreet, from an elevated railroad train, was closed ...
ST. LOUIS, July 31.--The correspondent of the Agricultural Department for Northern Texas reports early planted cotton well fruited, with faces now blooming near the top, but needing rain.
CHICAGO, July 31.--The Western Associated Press, now in session here, visited Pullman today.

BUFFALO, July 31.--The United States revenue cutter Fessenden, which has been reconstructed and partially rebulit here, made a trial trip of four or five hours on Lake Erie to-day. About 200 invited guests were on board. The cutter looked very handsome, and was pronounced perfect in all respects and the equal of any of her class. There was a brisk breeze and many of the guests were sick.
LONDON, July 31.--The steam-ship Quebec, (Br.,) Capt. Cross, from Montreal July 17, has arr. at Liverpool.

At No. 36 Beach-street, an old-fashioned house in what was once a fashionable neighborhood, Capt. John Ericsson, the veteran engineer, yesterday celebrated his eightieth birthday by doing his usual amount of work and doing it with his accustomed energy. He arose at 7 o'clock and took his customary breakfast of eggs, bread, and ice water.

NEW-HAVEN, July 31.--Mrs. Clarence Leonard, accompanied by her mother, came up from New-York this morning to testify in the case in which her husband, the actor, was arrested for improper relations with Mrs. Gerard.

It is encouraging to observe a man whom opposition, aided by a combination of misfortunes, has striven to crush quietly at work for the purpose of conquering obstacles. Col. Mepleson is one of the instances now visible.

There will be opened to the public to-day at the Edinburgh Museum of Science and Art an exhibition of paintings and drawings by John Constable, which, were it only for the name they bear, will be examined with interest by all lovers of art. A portion of the United States Senate Committee on Education and Labor will meet in this City to-day to arrange for the Immediate resumption of its inquiry into the relations between capital and labor.
John Kelly had a long talk with Mayor Edson yesterday about the appointment of a Controller to succeed Allan Campbell, whose resignation goes into effect to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 31.--Mlle. Rhea appeared in the title role of Scribe's play of "Valerie" at the Casino Theatre this evening before a large audience, composed principally of the cottage residents. It was a full-dress affair and quite a society event. Mlle. Rhea was supported by Lieut. Little, of the United States Navy, ...

CARBONDALE, Penn., July 31.--George Rowley, while engaged in sawing in his mill this morning, at this place, was instantly killed by the saw bursting. A large piece struck him in the neck, nearly severing his head from his body. His father, who was standing beside him, was sprinkled with his son's blood, but escaped injury.
MONTREAL, July 31.--It is stated that a new French company of capitalists are about to establish a line of steamers between Rouen and Quebee.

Mayor Edson, Public Works Commissioner Thompson, James C. Spencer, and William Dowd, the committee appointed by the Aqueduct Commissioners to examine the merits of the various candidates for the position of Secretary to the commission, met in the Mayor's office yesterday.
DES MOINES, July 31.--One of the party that so summarily hanged young Hardy at Harlan makes a public statement of the affair.

The St. Boniface Benevolent Society, of Newark, N.J., went on an excursion yesterday to Dobbs Ferry, on the Hudson. During the trip a row oocurred. Hermann Schlagel was shot in the hand and Jacob Glasse, of Livingston-street, Newark., jumped overboard and was drowned.

Mr. PARNELL has begun his career as the avowed leader of a band of free companions in the House of Commons. Simeon D. Dias, a salesman in the jewelry store of James C. Aiken Co., at No. 23 Maidenlane, was put in charge of $525 worth of jewelry to dispose of for his employers on or about June 20.

BOSTON, July 31.--Further suspensions occurred in the shoe and leather trade to-day, as a consequence of yesterday's faliures, but there was no panic in the trade and it is believed that the effect of the original break will be limited substantially to the concerns with which Shaw Brothers were most intimately connected.
DENVER, Col., July 31.--Osmond Tearle, the leading man of Wallack's company, was married this morning to Minnie Conway, the well-known actress.
ST. PAUL, July 31.--Hanlan, Lee, Plaisted, Hosmer, and Teemer arrived here last evening, and went immediately to Lake Minnetonka, where the races occur to-morrow and Thursday.
ST. LOUIS, July 31.--The representatives of the telegraph companies and the strikers each claim that "the other side is used up," and that the boasts of success made by each are unfounded.

LONDON, July 31.--The meeting at Goodwood began to-day. The race for the Craven Stakes was won by Lord Rocksavage's aged b. h. Charaxus, with Capt. Machell's 6-year-old b.h. Piracus second, and the Baron de Rothschild's 6-year-old b.h. Louis d'Or third.
WASHINGTON, July 31.--The report of Gen. Newton, the Engineer in charge of the improvements of rivers and harbors in the New-York District, was received at the War Department to-day.

It is sad to see any man giving open aid and encouragement to immorality, but when a Cabinet officer makes use of his position to make war against the institution of marriage and to break up the families of his subordinates the human mind shudders with horror.

Gen. Sir Fenwick Williams, stationed in Montreal during the Trent affair, resided at the St. Lawrence Hall for three years with his two aides-de-camp, Col. De Winton and Capt. Grant, of the Royal Engineers.

Those members of the colored population of Melrose who profess to have any religion at all attend services every Sunday at the little colored Baptist Church in that village, and usually nothing occurs to interfere with their worship. Unbelievers are rigidly excluded from these gatherings, as the Elders think that their presence would have a demoralizing effect upon the congregation and excite remarks by the community at large.
LONDON, July 31.--Special dispatches state that there were eight deaths at Alexandria from cholera yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 31.--Gov. Hamilton publishes an article four columns in length to-day defending himself against the charges of corruption made by the State Register, of Springfield, and alluded to in a dispatch to THE TIMES.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 31.--William M. Springer continues to advertise himself as a candidate for Speaker.

WASHINGTON, July 31.--Surgeon Godfrey, of the Marine Hospital Service, reports that the rumor that two men had escaped from the Ship Island quarantine and landed in Mississippi is entirely false. The suspected men came from Cat Island.

The steam-ship Glenarvon, which was sent back from Lower to Upper Quarantine on Monday, was allowed to come up to the City yesterday. Capt. Donaldson reported that there was no sickness on board during the voyage.

The National Education Assembly for 1883 will meet at Ocean Grove on the 9th, 10th, 11th, and 12th of this month. Gov. Pattison, of Pennsylvania, will preside at the first session, and Gen. John Easton, United States Commissioner of Education, will deliver the first address.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31.--The Central Pacific Railroad Company will, on next Wednesday, open a bureau under its own management, whereby specimens of California products will be distributed through the East and Europe free of charge for the purpose of drawing attention to the advantages of California, its climate, and soil. The specimens will be exhibited at the Eastern State fairs.

HARRISBURG, July 31.--No such apathy on the eve of a Democratic State Convention is remembered as that which exists among the delegates gathered here tonight. Although three-fourths of the delegates are on the ground and the city is filled with politicians, there is no ...

PHILADELPHIA, July 31.--Notice of a general advance of 10 cents per ton in the tolls on coal shipped both by rail and canal was given to-day by the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Comnany, to take effect Aug. 1.
A new secret society is to be formed in Yale College, a rival of the Skull and Bones and the Scroll and Keys.

SARATOGA, July 31.--This was the fifth day of the regular races. There was a very large attendance. The weather was cloudy and warm, with occasional light showers. On the back stretch the track was a trifle heavy, one of the results of the recent heavy showers, otherwise it was in very fair shape. The betting was the heaviest of the meeting so far.

GRAND FORKS, Dakota, July 31.--News has reached here of the murder of George Inkster, a widely known farmer of this county. He was herding his cattle, when they became mixed with a passing herd. In trying to separate them he got in trouble with the owners of the passing herd, who riddled his body with bullets.
An exhibition of various articles which be longed to Martin Luther will be held on Nov. 10 at the Brandenburg Provincial Museum in Berlin.

PROVIDENCE, R. I, Aug. 1.--The annual convention of the Civil Service Reform Association continued its session this morning at the Channing Memorial Church, Newport. It was attended by a large crowd of ladies and gentlemen.
About 200 prominent men have accepted invitations to attend the ceremonies in honor of the completion of the Northern Pacific Railroad.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug.1--The steamer Capri, four days from Vera Cruz, auchored to-day a mile off Port Eads with one case of yellow fever on board. The Quarantine Inspector at Port Eads has been ordered not to allow the Capri to come in and to warn all boats against towing or piloting vessels from infected ports.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1.--Henry Waggoner, an old and crippled soldier, formerly an inmate of the Soldiers' Home, and recently confined in the Work-house as a vagrant, was arrested to-day on his own confession of having set fire to the barn of the Home on the night of July 4 last.
CLEAVELAND, Aug.1 --The first heat of the 2:40 trotting-race was won by Duquesne in 2:19 , Phallas second. Index would have been shut cut if distance had not been waived by consent.

A circular in reference to this subject has been issued by the Protestant Alliance. It states that "while the tendency of recent legislation has been to free education in England from the trammels of denominational and sectarian influences.

The remains of Mrs. F. R. Seager, of No. 140 Bridge-street, who was run over and killed by a train of cars on Friday, were taken to the home of her parents, in Bedford, for interment.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 1.--At the second day's session of the National German-American Teaches' Association, a lecture was given by Prof. H. H. Fick, Superintendent of Drawing in the public schools of Cincinnati, on "Poetry in GermanAmerican Schools."
The body of a newly born infant wrapped up in a piece of paper was found yesterday morning under the washstand in the ladies' toilet-room at the railroad station, Peekskill, Westchester County.

HOTEL PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 1.--Gen. and Mrs. Grant and niece, Gen. and Mrs. Sharpe and daughter, and Justice and Mrs. Strong arrived at the Hotel Kaaterskill this evening, where they will remain several days.

The Rev. John Drumgoole, of the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin, in Lafayette-place, this City, is erecting an extensive institution on the shores of Prince's Bay, Staten Island, where he expects to provide accommodations for 2,000 chlidren.
WASHINGTON, July 29.--Consul-General Merritt, at London, has made the following report upon the alleged Bradford estate in Great Britain:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1.--Minnie Abraham, 11 years old, residing at No. 616 Wayne-street, this morning used oil in kindling a fire. An explosion followed and the child was so severely burned that she died soon. Her mother and a young man named Samuel Lorensky, who went to the child's assistance, were also badly burned.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 1.--Simon Cunningham, a farmer, riding in a wagon with his wife and 4-year-old child near Essex Centre, this evening, attempted to cross the railroad track, when the vehicle was struck by a passing train. Mr. Cunningham was instantly killed, his wife fatally injured, and the child had a leg broken.

ST. LOUIS, Aug.1.--The coopers in nine different shops in North St. Louis to-day struck for higher pay. they demand 7 cents for hooping and 10 cents for making full hand-made barrels. They have been getting 5 and 8 cents. About 90 men are on strike.
In the year 1866 the late James S. Thorn, who was the city editor of this paper, was lying upon his death-bed, slowly succumbing to the inroads of that fatal disease, consumption.

The attention of Officer Sprague, of the Thirty-third Precinct, was called yesterday afternoon to a noble-looking man of middle age who was acting irrationally in a Morrisania car. The driver said he had ridden twice to Harlem bridge, and had refused to pay his fare.

OCEAN GROVE, N. J., Aug. 1.--At a meeting held at Key East to-day, E. Batchelor, the proprietor of the place, offered a twenty-thousand-dollar lot for purposes of assembly like that of Chautauqua. and the same was voted upon and accepted. Lewis D. Vail, of Philadelphia, and E. G. Harrison, VicePresident of the Pennsylvania State Sundayschool Association, made addresses.

MACON, Ga., Aug. 1--This morning in Jones County, 23 miles from Macon, two farmers named Green while engaged in digging a well, were suffocated by gas. Both bodies were drawn up as soon as possible, but life was extinct.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1.--A large representation of the sporting fraternity took hacks at 3 o'clock this morning to witness a prize-fight between two men named O'Connor and McCune.

Gov. Butler was invited to be present at the presentation of a sword by the Pastors' Aid Society, of Boston, to Thomas H. Younge, commander of a colored branch of the Grand Army of the Republic, in Boston, on Monday evening.

OCEAN GROVE, N. J., Aug. 1.--J. H. Knowles, Presiding Elder of the Newark District, is here. In reply to the Rev. George R. Bristor's leter he has only to say that Bristor, after 48 hours' reflection, voluntarily surrendered his...
At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, President Reilly in the chair, the selection of two papers in which to publish the session laws was made.
NAPLES, Aug. 1.--King Humbert has decided that the search for victims of the earthquake shall continue. Six persons were rescued to-day.

READING, Penn., Aug. 1.--Robert Bryan Post. No. 80, G.A.R., colored, of Philadelphia, visited this city to-day. They were escorted through the principal streets by McLean Post, of this city, to the City Hall, where an address of welcome was made by Mayor Rowe. The visitors spent the day at Lauer's Park, holding a camp-fire in the evening.
HALIFAX, Aug. 1.--Her Majesty's war-ship Canada, with Prince George of Wales on board, has arrived in this harbor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1.--The Hon. Henry L. Dawes, United States Senator from Massachusetts and Chairman of the Senate committee which is about to visit the Indian reservations in the Northwest, reached this city yesterday.
CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 1.--The quarterly meeting of the Board of Directors of the Chicago and Alton Railroad was held here to-day. A semiannnal dividend of 4 per cent. was declared, payable on Sept. 1.

Yesterday John Devoy, the incarcerated editor of the Irish, Nation, was visited on Blackwell's Island by the following gentlemen: Messrs. Alexander Sullivan, Chicago, President of the Irish National League; the Rev. J. A. O'Reilly, Detroit.

TROY, N. Y., Aug. 1.--A terrible collision between two freight trains occurred this morning on the Troy and Boston Railroad, between Petersburg Junction and Pownal, Vt., by which six men were killed. One train was made up of 45 cars, and the other of 25 cars. Fifty cars were derailed, and some of, them fell into the Hoosick ...

GUAYAQUIL, Aug. 1, via Galveston.--The interior Government of Alfario are making arrangements as to the number of troops from each army to be left here for the support of the Guayaquil Government.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 1.--In 1845 John Riddle, Sr., being desirous to promote the interests of religion and public education, conveyed to James Hopple and other Directors of the Ninth School District of Mill Creek Township certain real property in trust, to be used for the purpose of building ...
An unknown drunken laborer who had twice been put off the Long Branch steamer St. John attempted to jump on the boat as she was leaving her pier at the foot of Rector-street Tuesday afternoon.
