BOSTON, Aug. 1.--Charles H. Ward, boot and shoe manufacturer, at No. 35 High-street, one of whose notes went to protest yesterday, made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors today, and three of the country manufacturers for Copeland Co. suspended.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 1.--In Hempstead County a few days ago two white men named Wyatt and Montgomery had a row about some land with a couple of negroes. One of the white men broke the stock of a shot-gun over one of the negroes' heads. On Tuesday a band of negroes went to a school-house where Wyatt was teaching and shot him dead.

DETROIT, Aug. 1.--The operators in the Mutual Union office at Grand Rapids, in obedience to orders from the Executive Committee of the brotherhood, left their instruments this morning. The railroad operators, about 40 in number, also received orders not to do any commercial work.

The committee of seven called for in a resolution adopted by the Produce Exchange last week, at a meeting to consider the condition of affairs resulting from the telegraphers' strike, was appointed yesterday by President Herrick.
RICHMOND Va., Aug. 1.--Great dissatisfaction exists between the Western Union Company and its present employes. The men were promised double pay for all extra time put in during the strike.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 1.--There is trouble in store for the fox (?) hunters. The society with a long name is determined, if possible, to stop the sport, and will make a determined move in this direction at a very early day.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 1--A severe gale this afternoon in East Hartford destroyed Edgar Brano's large tobacco barn. worth $6,000. Several other buildings of little value and a number of trees were destroyed.
The new Stock Clearing-house increased the number of stocks handled by it yesterday to 24 and the day's business showed a considerable increase over the business of any previous day.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 1.--At a meeting of the citizens of Asbury Park held a few days after the visitation of last week's terrible cyclone a citizen's relief committee was organized to take steps to raise a fund for assisting those whose houses were wrecked or who otherwise suffered by the tornado, both in the Park and Ocean Grove.

At the inquest yesterday in the case of Lawrence Nichols, who was fatally stabbed on Saturday night by Daniel Lillis, at Watts and Canal streets, Officer Nichols testified before Coroner Martin that he found Nichols in a basement on Hudson-street after the affray, and he said that Lillis had stabbed him.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 1.--A medley, horribly discordant and doleful, by the Hummelstown Brass Band, greeted the Democratic delegates as they flocked into the Opera-house this morning.
BROCKTON, Mass., Aug. 1--The body of Mary J. Baker, who has been missing a week, was found in the woods to-day by a party of gunners.
Annie Davis, an extremely pretty, intelligent-looking girl, 19 years old, was found by Officer O'Reilly wandering through Greene-street on Tuesday night in a partially intoxicated condition.

Trouble broke out again between the Gills and Woodhalls on Tuesday when attorneys for the Woodhall girls sent trucks to remove the furniture and personal property remaining in the Twentysixth-street house, which was formerly occupied by Mr. Gill in company with the Woodhall sisters.

The Polk trial has had the effect of reviving the discussion about trial by jury, which of late years needs very little to set it going. The verdict is accepted as a kind of offset in favor of the jury system to the Dorsey case and the Dukes case.
The Custom-house authorities are still waging war on the importation of adulterated teas. Examiner Davis yesterday seized 175 packages of very shiny green tea consigned to this port from London.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1--the leading produce markets were less active to-day, with ahother season of weakness in provisions, and an easier feeling in grain. The markets were largely dependent upon the early deliveries On August contracts. These were large in lard, short ribs, and wheat; small in corn and pork, and very light in Oats.

The Executive Committee of Seven, of the Irish National League of America, held a long meeting at the Manhattan Beach Hotel yesterday, all the members being present and in addition Patrick Egan and Matthew Harris, of Ireland.

At a meeting of the German Emigration Society yesterday the Treasurer reported that during the past half-year $9,808 36 of the funds had been expended for charitable purposes.

Sportsmen and pot-hunters alike everywhere disregard the foolish-Connecticut law which prohibits the shooting of woodcock until the first of October, or rather they would snap their fingers at it if there were any of these game birds to be found.

The "statement" which has been sent to Mr.GLADSTONE on behalf of the Irish landlords looks like a pretentious political sarcasm. Lord DUNRAVEN, who is one of the signers, is quite capable of organizing a joke of these dimensions, and of getting some landlords to sign it in a spirit of mockery and others in a sad sincerity.

There was no change of importance in the situation of affairs in the telegraphic war yesterday. The Western Union Company resumed its telegraphic money order business between a few points yesterday as another card in the game of bluff which it is playing with the public and the operators formerly in its employ.
LONDON, Aug. 1.--The new act relative to the conveyance of parcels by post came into operation to-day and promises to be a great success.
The steam-ship City of Merida, of the Alexandre Line, arrived yesterday at Lower Quarantine, where she was detained by order of Health Officer Smith.

READING, Penn., Aug. 1.--A vagrant named John Eby was brought here to-day from Lebanon. Upon being searched he disclosed the proceeds of a robbery committed some time before on a country woman while she was attending church. He had stolen $40 in gold, $70 in silver, and $90 in banknotes, besides old coins.

The injunction order obtained by Messrs. Callanan Kemp, of No. 41 Vesey-street, to restrain their neighbor, George F. Gilman, from using a plank or bridge over the sidewalk when he is loading or unloading wagons--which plank or bridge they regard as a public and private nuisance --was vacated by Judge Ingraham, in the Superior Court, Chambers, yesterday.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 1.--This morning Commissary Sergeant Charles Wernan committed suicide by shooting himself through the head with a pistol at Jackson Barracks, this city.

It was decided by Judga Cullen, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, that the police pension fund is subject to the demands made against it by members and ex-members of the police force who are seeking to recover money deducted from their salaries when they were absent from duty on account of sickness.

Miss Clara Louise Kellogg will leave Europe for this country on the 11th of this month. In the latter part of September she will begin a series of farewell performances in the principal cities of the United States.

ST. Louis, Aug. 1.--The delay placards were taken down in the Western Union main and branch telegraph offices to-day, and the managers stated that they had such a satisfactory force on hand, and there were so few weak points now throughout the country, that it would be a very easy matter to notify senders where delay might possibly occur.
BOSTON, Aug. 1.--A special from Newport Vt., says: "The express train on the Southeastern Railroad from here to Montreal was derailed three miles from North Troy.

LONDON, Aug. 2.--The Allan Line steam-ship Phoenician, Capt. Brown, from Boston July 21, has arr. at Glasgow. The steam-ship Viking, Capt. Christie, from Montreal July 19 and Quebec 21st, has passed the Lizard, on her way to this port.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 1.--"Babe" Jones, the colored boy murderer, who in an unprovoked attack killed John Foster about a year ago, has been sentenced to be hanged on Thursday, Oct. 4.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1.--Henry Green, the Town Marshal of Brooklyn, a colored village situated three miles north of East St. Louis, on the Ameri can Bottom, and Macy Jones, a desperado who has served two years in the Penitentiary last night ...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 1.--The railroad telegraph operators on the Louisville and Nashville line who receive Western Union messages were to-day ordered by the brotherhood to join the strikers, and the other railroad telegraph operators were ordered to contribute $10 each to the support of the striking members of the brotherhood.

ALEXANDRIA, Aug. 1.--In consequence of the prevalence of cholera at Rosetta, railway traffic between that town and Alexandria has been suspended. There were 3 deaths from cholera here yesterday and 320 at Cairo.
Mrs. Lucy Marks, of No. 115 East One Hundred and Thirteenth-street, hailed a vegetable vendor yesterday afternoon and bought some potatoes.

OGDEN, Utah, Aug. 1.--The road agents who stopped the Deer Lodge and Helena coach a few days ago were arrested to-day by Deputy Sheriffs near Gallatin City, Montana. Part of the stolen property was recovered. The robbers were brought here on this evening's train, and are now lodged in the County Jail.
Mr. Stephen H. Provost, Secretary of the New-York Sunday Closing League, has sent several communications to the Police Commissioners and they have been referred to Superintendent Walling.

Two little girls, twins, got separated while playing and one of them began looking for the other. She went to her grandmother's to look, and on approaching a window which reflected her own likeness did not recognize herself, but exclaimed with delight: "Why Ethel, I didn't know you were here!" The grandmother, who witnessed the incident, broke out in a hearty laugh, when the little girl discovered her mistake.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 1.--The situation is exceedingly perplexing to-night and discouraging to those who have hoped that good sense and better counsels would combine to remove factional spirit and persistent adherence to favorite candidates.
NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 1.--Treasurer Burke announces that the semi-annual coupons on Lonisiana 3 per cent. "baby" bonds will be cashed on presentation at the State National Bank, at NewOrleans.

The interview between a correspondent of the Evening Post and Felix Lynch, of Rochester, in which the latter stated that O'Donnell, the slayer of Carey, the informer, was a member of the Irish Invincibles, was shown to Mr. P. J. Sheridan, of the Irish World. He smiled as he read it.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 1.--A meeting of the Continental Guards was held to-night, at which the dirty linen accumulated on the Northern trip was washed. It was announced that the losses incurred by the trip had been made up. Capt. Thiel tendered his resignation, which was accepted.

Gen. E. F. Winslow, Gen. Horace Porter, and other officers of the New-York, Buffalo, and West Shore Railroad Company left this City last Monday evening for a trip of inspection over the completed road as far as Syracuse.

Second Assistant Postmaster-General Elmer reportrs that during July the increase in star mail service was $62,145 and the decrease $65,624, making a net decrease in cost of $3,479.

BOSTON, Aug. 1.--The will of the late Martin Milmore, the sculptor, gives $1,000 to the Little Sisters of the Poor and $500 to the city of Boston in trust, the income to be used annually to aid in clothing the poor children who attend the Brimmer School. Several small beqnests are made to personal friends, and the remainder of the estate is given to his mother and brothers.
LONDON, Aug. 1.--James Carey was shot at 4 o'clock Sunday afternoon. The steamer Melrose, on which the shooting occurred, arrived at Port Elizabeth at 2 o'clock Monday afternoon.

Capt. W. P. Joy, of the American ship St. Nicholas, visited Collector Robertson's office yesterday in response to an invitation from the Collector, and was presented with a very handsome silver tea and coffee service as a token of the appreciation of the British Government of a brave and humane act.

An unusually long list of securities was offered for sale at auction in the Exchange Salesroom, No. 111 Broadway, by Adrian H. Muller Son, yesterday at noon. There were a large number of buyers present and the bidding was quite spirited.

For the further improvement and extension of its lines and facilities the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company yesterday secured a loan from the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of $300,000, for which it has issued 300 of its own bonds of the denomination $1,000 each.
UTICA, N. Y., Aug. 1.--Two months ago two students of telegraphy here applied to Superintendent Gifford, of the Western Union office, for employment.

LYME, Conn., Aug. 1.--Chief-Justice Waite, of the United States Supreme Court, is now enjoying a quiet resting spell with his family at his Summer residence in this pleasant place, which is across the river from the venerable Saybrook.

The shad, although until seven years ago a stranger on this coast, has multiplied since its introduction to an extent truly remarkable. They are now to be found all along the coast of this State, and northward are rapidly making their way.

SARAGOTA, Aug. 1.--The weather was threatening again to-day, but the racing was of an excellent character and there was a large crowd present to enjoy it. The track was in good shape and the betting active. The winners were Imogene, Capias, Ella Warfield, and Disturbance.

LONDON, Aug. 1.--At Goodwood to-day the race for the Visitor's Plate (handicap) was won by Mr. Gerard's 4-year-old b. c. Sweetbread, with Mr. T. F. Walton's aged Sutler second, and Mr. Keene's 3 year-old b. c. Bolero third. There were nine starters.

According to the testimony Of CAREY, the informer, the number of the Invincibles was limited, and was not intended for general circulation, so to speak.

The Democratic Convention which was held at Harrisburg, Penn., yesterday, was chiefly remarkable for the absence of the leading men of the party in the State, and for the successful repression of a tendency to divide on the merits of the Pattison administration.
LOUISVILLE, Aug. 1.--At 12:35 o'clock today President Arthur pulled the silken cord which opened the throttle of the great Corliss engine and the machinery of the Southern Exposition was in motion.

GALVESTON, Aug. 1.--Yesterday morning the case of F. B. Ames. one of the Brotherhood of Telegraphers, who was charged with striking William Gaines, who was temporarily filling a vacancy in Galveston, was dismissed, the affidavit not being sustained.

ALBANY, Aug. 1.--Superintendent of State Prisons Baker makes the following report for the month of July: Auburn--Earnings, $10,060 92; expenses, $9,911 72. Sing Sing--Earnings, $19,091 43; expenses, $14,080 78. Dannemora--Earnings, $3,214 92; expenses, $7,107 05. Surplus in the three prisons, $1,267 72.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 1.--The managers of the Western Union Telegraph office say that as far as they are concerned the strike is practically at an end.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 1.--The statement in Eastern papers that President Arthur's trip through Virginia and to Kentucky was in the interest of his nomination next year has caused considerable gossip here to-day.
CINCINNATI Aug. 1.--The striking operators gave a picnic to-night at Price's Hill, which will put $1,200 or $1,300 in their treasury. They are still firm and confident.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Aug. 1.--A heavy squeeze of the surface has been gradually breaking the timbers and crumbling pillars at the Star Colliery, at Shamokin. This morning the proprietors decided to abandon the colliery, being satisfied that they could not protect the mine. All the men were dismissed except a few who are engaged in getting out the machinery.

A woman, known as Mrs. Moore, at the Astor-Place Hotel, where she often slept, and who was about 50 years old, was found dead yesterday in a room which she had hired on Sunday, when she was last seen alive.
The will of the late Col. Frank G. Allen, filed for probate yesterday, expresses most liberal and beneficent intentions, the accomplishment of which would be alike surprising and gratifying.

LOWELL, Mass., Aug. 1--The basis of the consolidation of the New-England telephone companies has virtually been agreed upon. The American Bell Company, holding one-half of the stock, $8,000,000 the balance of the $16,000,000 will represent the property, except $1,000,000 held in the treasury for construction. It is believed that the business will be completed by Aug. 15.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1.--The fourteenth day of the operators' strike finds both sides apparently confident of ultimate success. The restriction, "subject to delay," was removed from the main office of the Western Union here to-day.

Montpelier is situated on the Virginia Midland Railroad, four miles from Orange Court-house, and about 80 miles north-west from Washington. Formerly it was only accessible by riding from Orange Court-house, but the present owner recently erected a station opposite the estate, and trains now stop very near the grounds.

Tenn., just preceding the American Kennel Club field trials.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 1.--The Cincinnati Sulky and Buggy Company to-day made an assignment to Thomas C. Campbell and William S. Rowe. The liabilities are $12,000; assets estimated at $22,000.

The Catholic Total Abstinence Union of America held their thirteenth annual convention yesterday in the hall attached to St. Mary's Church Star of the Sea, Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Aug. 1.--The arrest was effected to-day of four members of an organized band of barn-burners, who for the past six or eight months have plied a nefarious vocation throughout Albany and Rensselaer Counties.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 1.--The Lancaster Watch Factory closed its doors last evening, and when the employes went to work this morning they found notices posted that the factory would not be opened, and that they would be paid in advance of the usual pay-day as soon as the pay-rolls could be made up.

Henry Lee began a suit about a week ago in the Supreme Court for the annulment of his marriage with Mary Lee, alleging that he had been forced to marry her. An answer was put in by Mrs. Lee, denying her husband's assertion.

The remains of the late Senor Francisco Barca, Minister of Spain to this country, who committed suicide at the Albemarle Hotel on Sunday, were taken yesterday morning to the pier of the French Steam-ship Company at the foot of Mortonstreet and placed in the hold of the steamer Normandie.

The Standard says this committee consisted of servants and small tradesmen. The Paris Temps treats the matter as without importance.

LONDON, Aug. 5.--On Saturday three persons died from cholera at Alexandria, and two at Ramleh, one a British soldier.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Aug. 5.-- Seventeen more Chinamen were smuggled in from British Columbia, near here, yesterday. An attempt to capture them was unsuccessful. This makes the third lot smuggled over the border within a week.

The French-Canadian papers are very much exercised over the assertion that Mr. Vermond, the French Deputy of Seine et Oise, who came out with Mr. Senecal, inadvertently declared himself to a reporter to be "a clerical in Canada, but a liberal in France." Parties interested have sent the paper containing this statement to France.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Aug. 5.--The President's train arrived at Omaha at 4 o'clock yesterday morning, stopping only long enough to drop the locomotive and equipment of the North-western Railroad and take on that of the Union Pacific. General Superintendent Nichols has been in charge of the train up to this point.

LISBON, Aug. 5.--It is reported here that a military rising has taken place in the Spanish Province of Badajoz, on the Portuguese fron tier, and that the regular authorities have been arrested. Telegraph and railway lines between Badajoz and Portugal are interrupted.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 5.--Great excitement was caused hers this evening by a runaway accident near the West End Hotel, a young lady and gentleman being thrown from a dog-cart and the vehicle being broken to places. The couple were only slightly injured, much to the surprise of all who witnessed the accident. They refused to give their names, and returned to New-York.
BUFFALO, Aug. 5.--The strike of the Lackawanna Railroad operators, which is to occur at noon to-morrow, is the subject chiefly discussed by those interested in telegraph mat ters to-day.
No business was transacted at the Exchange on Saturday, Aug. 4.

BOSTON, Aug. 5.--The steamer Berkshire,, Capt. Hawes, from Baltimore Aug. 2, went ashore on Lovell's Island, Boston Harbor, at 5:30 o'clock this afternoon. It is stated that she has not sustained much damage. She had 55 passengers, 10 of whom were taken ashore by a tug. The others remained on board. It is expected that she will be not off at the next tide.

The Mary Commandery, No. 36, Knights Templar, of Philadelphia, about 200 in number, started on Saturday for San Francisco. The Triennial Conclave of the Grand Encampment of Knights Templar of the United States are to meet in that city.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 5.--A band of Kukluxers have posted notices in Bledsoe County notifying a number of prominent citizens to leave the country or they will be murdered and their houses will be burned. The parties threatened are witnesses against a large number of Moonshiners. Great excitement prevails.

John Schick, of Main-street, Town of Union, at the north end of Hudson County, N.J., had a quarrel with his wife yesterday, and his ungovernable temper suddenly developed into insanity. Procuring a gun. Schick informed his wife that he intended to kill her. She fled to a neighbor's house for protection.

A general alarm was sent out from Police Head-quarters on Saturday for a horse and express wagon and a trunk containing male and female apparel, jewelry, and other articles worth $700, which were stolen in Third-street.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 5.--Advance sheets of the State Treasurer's annual report show the entire debt to be $175,000, of which $135,000 is bonded. The receipts for the year were $583,600 and the disbursements $532,670.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 5.--Tuesday next is the opening day of the tenth annual Assembly at Chautauqua, N.Y. At 11 A.M. Dr. D. A. Goodsell, of Trinity Church, New-Haven, Conn., will deliver his popular lecture on "Peter the Hermit and the Spirit of the Crusades."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5.--Another fatal shooting by a policeman occurred here last night. While Officer Godfrey was walking his beat in the neighborhood of Wash and Twenty-third streets, he observed three men acting in a suspicious manner, and when he attempted to arrest them they broke and ran.

Mauch Chunk is in the mountains of Cameronsylvania, once known as Pennsylvania, and is a mere apology for a village. CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 5.--For several months in Lexington County, S.C., the opponents of the stock law have been committing deeds of violence. The torch and shot-gun are being used with considerable effect, and in different parts of Black Creek Township barns, stables, and farm buildings have been burned.
VICTORIA, British Columbia, Aug. 5.--The steamer Eureka, which arrived here this morning from the North, brings news of a horrible tragedy at the Dakan mine, near Harrisburg, Alaska.

An effort is being made to establish a permanent Presbyterian Mission, at No. 202 East Seventy-seventh-street. Dr. Joseph Moorehead, Robert Smith, and John Noble are taking the lead in the movement, and the Rev. Samuel Dodd has been temporily engaged as missionary Pastor. The first meeting was held last night and the little hall was completely filled with people.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5.--An exciting race between 11 sloop-rigged yachts, pronounced the finest contest of the kind ever seen at this port, took place yesterday. The yachts went 10 miles in the direction of Michigan City and returned.

LONDON, Aug. 5.--The murder of James Carey, the informer, continues to be the sole subject of conversation in Dublin. Carey himself chose to go to Natal. He would not go to Australia, because he knew that many Fenians fearing arrest had escaped to that country.

TROY, Aug. 5.--While Officer Bender was assisting Officer Peterson to make an arrest tonight, one of the mob threw a stone, which struck him on the head, fracturing his skull and inflicting injuries which will probably prove total. The affair occurred on Ida Hill.

Several felonious assaults, where no prisoners were made, occurred between Saturday night and Sunday morning. Philip Smith, a vagrant, received two cuts in the right arm in the early morning, and was taken to the New-York Hospital. A man whose name is supposed to be Patrick Sullivan was his assailant, and the police of the Sixth Precinct are looking for him.
The new Cuban patriotic association met yesterday afternoon at Clarendon Hall to perfect its organization. The members have adopted the title of "The Independencia Club, No. 1."

HAVANA, Aug. 5.--Gen. Prendergast, exCaptain-General of Cuba, sailed on the Spanish mail steamer to-day for Spain. He was serenaded at his Summer residence last night. Eleven persons out of the twelve left here sick with the yellow fever by the Ciiy of Merida sailed on the steamer British Empire yesterday for NewYork. Mr. West, the first engineer of the City of Merida, was the only patient that died.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 5.--Fifty-two yachts are in Newport Harbor to-night. From appearances the wind will change to north-east by tomorrow morning, so that the race for the Goelet Cups will be sailed to the Vineyard light-ship.

MONTREAL, Aug. 5.--A pastoral of Mgr. Fabre on the Laval University and Victoria College question was read in all the Catholic churches here to-day. The plaintiff in this case, heard yesterday in the Queen's Bench Division, before Mr. Justice Williams and a common jury, was Emma Tyler, and she sued the defendant, William Kirby, for a breach of his promise to marry her; the defendant pleaded denying his promise, and also asserting that he had been exoneratad from its performance.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 5.--Cotton worms have appeared in some sections, doing much damage. General rains within the next 10 days may materially change prospects. Early corn made, and is a full crop. Late corn is a total failure in some sections.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 5.--A wager of $200 a side between Hanlan, the champion oarsman, and a man named O'Brien, of Excelsior, on Lake Minnetonka, that the the latter could not take Plaisted's shell, deprived of its outriggers and sit or stand in it and paddle around one minute without upsetting, was won by O'Brien, who succeeded in managing the shell both sitting and standing.
Southey's beautiful description of the South American fire-flies does not ill apply to the midsummer night festivals held in our own parks and fields by these diamonds of the night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5.--The Washington Park Club, the new turf organization which is fitting up an elegant and costly track and grounds on the South Side, and which will be devoted exclusively to the running horse, announces a meeting to cover June 5 to 12, 1884, and has opened seven stakes, to close Oct. 15 next, and will open nine more to close Jan. 15, 1884.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 5.--A child of George Lawson, the gasman of the Ocean Hotel, was fatally burned last night by its clothing catching fire when the furnace door was open.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 5.--Jasper Carter, colored, was instantly killed this afternoon by a train of the Western Maryland Railroad at St. George's Station. He attempted to get on the train after it was in motion and was thrown on the track. Both arms were cut off near the elbows, and his body was almost entirely severed. He resided in Baltimore.

The quaint charms of our French-Canadian villages are fast giving way to modern ugliness. A very painful example of this is the approaching removal of one of the most attractive landmarks on all the St. Lawrence, the old church of Varennes, whose glittering spires have for just 100 years glorified the evening landscape as seen from the higher parts of Montreal.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 5.--The suspension late on Saturday of the leather firm of Hersey, Whittier Wyman naturally causes considerable uneasiness, as on the surface it would seem to indicate a general tendency toward demoralization in the shoe and leather trade of this city.

MILFORD, Penn., Aug. 5.--Abram King, an attorney doing business in New-York City, and recently stopping at this place, has brought suit against Jacob Schorr, the well-known driver of the stage from Port Jervis to this Summer resort, claiming damages of $250. While out riding a few days ago his carriage came in collision with the stage.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 5.--Frank Hess, of Albany, was found at Martin's Lake, a short distance from Troy, at an early hour yesterday morning, with his head in about a foot of water at the edge of the lake and his body lying on the shore. From marks found upon his body it is thought that he was murdered. About $5, which Hess had on his person the night before his body was found, of missing.

One of the most open breaches of the Sunday laws which has been perpetrated within the limits of this City since the new Penal Code went into effect was made yesterday afternoon in the Castle Garden rotunda. The clerks and Inspectors had gone for the day, and about 100 benighted immigrants had been left to themselves in the rotunda.

The race for the championship of the baseball League is growing closer and more interesting as the season advances. At present the Providence Club is in the lead, but it is closely pursued by the Cleveland, Chicago, Boston, and Buffalo Clubs. The last named club has played a steady game lately, and, to the surprise of the base-ball public.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 5.--Charlie Ford, who was arrested on a charge of complicity in the Blue Cut train robbery late yesterday afternoon, has been released on $5,000 bail.

LONDON, Aug. 5.--The Jewish residents of Ekaterinoslav, Russia, were attacked by a mob on Aug. 2. The soldiery had to be called out to disperse the rioters, 10 of whom were killed and 13 wounded. The trouble was caused by a Jew insulting a peasant woman.

SIR: I have considered the papers submitted to me with reference to making a through waterway communication between the Mediterranean and the Red Sea for ships of the largest class along the depressed gorge of the River Jordan and the Dead Sea by means of two communicating canals.
SANTA FE, New-Mexico, July 23.--One's ideas of what an Indian should be are filled when he sees the band of Apaches who have come here from the Mescalero agency in charge of Major Liewellyn.

It seems possible now, after the ruling of Chief-Justice Morton, that Freeman, the childmurderer, acting under a supposed religious mania, will be released and escape trial. It was claimed at the time of the murder that Freeman was insane, and he was incarcerated at Danvers.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5.--The working men of this city made great preparations for an extensively advertised demonstration to take, place at Fairmount Park to-day, but it did not take place.

There will be a great abundance of peaches in the market this week, and although most of them will be small they will in all probability be of good flavor and ripe. The last and best of the Hale's Early from Delaware will be all marketed before Saturday, and the greater portion of the peaches that will be sent here from Maryland and Delaware will be Troth's Early.

A pale young man sat on a seat facing the boat landing at Glen Island last evening waiting for the 8:30 o'clock boat to this City. The new moon east a faint light on the little strait between the island and New-Rochelle, and the incoming tide lapped softly against the sea wall.

There is a new danger in the telephone. It has generally been supposed that a message over the telephonic wires was trustworthy and as much to be depended on as one's business autograph. That this is not the case a moment's reflection will show.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5.--The annual meeting of the American Society of Microscopists will begin here on Tuesday next and last four days. A large number of papers will be read.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 5.--The American bark Ganialiel, Capt. Anthony, from Rio. with coffee, with all on board well, and having had no sickness on the trip, arrived off South Pass on Saturday night, and was refused admission into the Mississippi River under Gov. McEnery's orders of strict nonintercourse. She reported short of provisions and water. Yesterday she obtained supplies, having them delivered over the ship's sides, and sailed forth with for Baltimore.

The view to be taken of the effort which the cadets of the Military Academy have made for the restoration of their dismissed comrade, HARTIGAN, must largely depend on the real character and gravity of his offense.

Annie Quinn, 17 pears old, the daughter of Felix Quinn, an engineer, of No. 3 Washingtonavenue, Paterson, N.J., ran away from home a few days ago. Her father told the New-York police that she sang fairly, and that they might find her in a concert saloon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5.--The Citizens' Association it is said will begin action on a quo warranto against the leading saloon-keepers of this city to determine the question of the validity of the cheap saloon licenses issued by authority of the Concil in order to avoid the operation of the State highlicense law. This course is taken in order to force the issue speedily to the Supreme Court.
When SAMUEL J. TILDEN and JOHN KELLY determine that there shall be entire harmony in the Democracy of this City, the feuds of Tammany and Anti-Tammany will disappear--not before.
The Democratic State Committee is called to meet at the Grand Union Hotel in Saratoga on Thursday, 23d inst.

In the Zoological Gardens can now be seen in all the veivety sheen of its first splendor a python that has just cast its skin, and the great snake is a very miracle of reptilian loveliness. Not even the birds of paradise can compare with its purples, blues, and gold, while an infinite interest underlies those fridescent charms, from the fact ...
John McGinn, 27 years old, of No. 547 West Twenty-sixth-street, was drowned yesterday while bathing in the North River at Twenty-seventhstreet.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5.--The Mary Commandery of Knights Templar of Philadelphia, 100 strong, passed through this city to-day en route for San Francisco, to take part in the coming Triennial Conclave.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5.--A very clever capture of the ringleaders of a desperate gang of cattle and car robbers was made last night at Brooklyn, the colored village north of East St. Louis, where, last Wednesday, the desperate affray occurred between City Marshal Green and the desperado Jones, of which affair last night's capture was the sequel.

A correspondent, whose letter we printed on Thursday last, complains bitterly of the treatment which the Republicans of Virginia have received at the hands of the President. The absolute disposal of Federal patronage in that State has been placed in the hands of Gen. MAHONE.
LONDON, Aug. 6.--The steam-ship Finsbury, (Br., Capt. Jenkins, from New-Orleans July 13 and North Sydney July 25, for Hamburg, has put into Falmouth for coal.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 5.--William H. Shehee was drought here to-night from Eagle Bridge and lodged in jail. He was arrested for striking conductor Mathew Riley, of Boston, Hoosac Tunnell and Western Railway, over the head with a shackling pin. The conductor is fatally injured.

At the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday Mary J. Mole, of No. 238 East One Hundred and Thirteenth-street, appeared aginst her husband, Charles Mole, a machinist, 35 years old, who declined to say where his present occupation and residence are.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 5.--Edward Lachenmeyer, a leader among the German population, proprietor of the famous Redwitz beer saloon, and a member of the choir of the Jesuits' Church, died suddenly to-day of apoplexy. He was born in Bavaria in 1831, came to New-York in 1857, and here is 1860.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5.--A local newspaper caused something, of a sensation here to-day by asserting that an extraordinary secret political treaty has been made between Mexico and Germany, under which the two nations have entered into an offensive and defensive alliance.
BOSTON, Aug. 5.--The second mate and 12 seamen of the whaler Merlin, of New-Bedford, which was wrecked last April on the south-west coast of Africa, arrived to-day on the Cunard steam-ship Samara.

A large, dark-complexioned man, with regular features and, straight blank hair, leaned nonchaiantly over the rail of the veranda at Lerey's Hotel, Coney Island, yesterday afternoon, and idly struck at pedestrian insects with a light bamboo stick. He was surrounded, at a respectful distance, by a throng of men, women, and children, ...

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5.--William A.J. Fiss died in the Norristown Insane Hospital this morning, where he was brutally beaten by James Gaffey, one of the attendants, on July 5. A Coroner's incuest will be held to-morrow, and efforts will be made to have Gaffey, who is at large, arrested.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6.--The Secretary of War has declined to revoke the order for the trial by court martial of Lieut. W.C. Robertson for duplicating his pay accounts, and he will be tried at the time and place designated.

A mass-meeting of the liquor-sellers and labor agitators of the Eighteenth Ward Citizens' Club of Brooklyn was held in the Brooklyn Labor Lyceum, Nos. 61 to 67 Myrtie-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, last evening to protest against the Sunday and Excise laws of that city.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug., 6.--Many foolish and sensational rumors, reports, and insinuations are being circulated to the effect that the leading cottagers are quarreling among themselves, and that the Astors, Vanderbilts, Belmonts, Kernochans, and other equally well-known families do not "hitch horses," The Vanderbilts are the recipients of as ...

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 6.--On Saturday afternoon the boiler of a portable engine employed in cutting wood for the Michigan Central Railroad Company, near Ogemaw, exploded, killing three men. The names of two of the men are Ira Brand and F.O. Willet. The name of the third is not known.

CHARLESTOWN, S.C., Aug. 6.--The ladies of the Baptist Church at Camden, S.C., gave an icecream entertainment on Friday evening, which was largely attended. On Saturday morning and yesterday 59 persons were taken violently ill, and every physician in the village has since been attending them.

An unusual feature of Summer travel which has been especially noticeable to-day is the early return to the cities of many families on account of the cold weathar. The train over the Concord and Claremont Railroad this morning was a heavy one, and carried several families returning from the resorts along the line of that road.

READING, Penn., Aug. 6.--The petition of the new Pennsylvania and Schuylkill Valley Railroad Company to the City Council for right of way through the streets of Reading was unanimously granted by both branches this evening.

LONDON, Aug. 6.--To-day is a regular bank holiday, and all the Exchanges are closed. The Times, reviewing the harvest prospects in England, estimates that wheat and barley will be below the average crop.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 6.--Frank W. Smith, formerly a prisoner of war at Andersonville and Millen, Ga., Black Sheen, Fla., and Florence, N.C., now General Secretary of the Railroad Young Men's Christian Association of this city, will hold a religious service next Sunday at the famous Providence Spring, which broke out within the ...

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 6.--Thomas Hamilton, of Beaufort, one of the most prominent negro politicians in this State, has written a letter to the News and Courier roundly denouncing the Republican Party, and insisting that the negro has rights which must be respected. He says:

It is said that Director BURCHARD, of the Mint, has devised a scheme by which innocent holders of mutilated coins can obtain as much for them as if they were unmutilated. At the same time, Mr. BURCHARD intends to prevent all frauds upon the Treasury in connection with mutilated coin.

The new strike at the cigar factory of S. Ottenberg Brothers after the men had returned to work caused a great deal of indignation among the members of the Cigar Manufacturers' Association, who called a meeting yesterday afternoon at the Belvidere Hotel to discuss ...
MONTCLAIRE, Ill., Aug. 6.--A brutal murder was committed here last evening about 6 o'clock. Mr. Stanley Lovett had just returned from Sunday-school and was preparing to take tea with his family.

It is a little unfortunate for the promoters of harmony in the Democratic Party that, just as Tammany and Anti-Tammany, Tilden and anti-Tilden men are getting ready to sit down to a love feast, somebody has started the puzzling question, Who defeated ...

The Bradlaugh case has had the effect of showing, in a very vivid way, how far the House of Commons is, in spite of all the widenings of its basis that have been made within the past fifty years, from representing the British populace.

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Aug. 6.--The bark Octavia, belonging to Baird, Johnson Co., of Greenock, 225 tons burden, which sailed hence for Sydney, Cape Breton, was on Friday wrecked at Ferryland during a dense fog. The crew were saved. The ship was insured.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 6.--Referring to the cable dispatch stating that papers of American citizenship, dated Toronto, November, 1876, were found on O'Donnell at Cape Town, the Clerk of the Peace here says no person named Patrick O'Donnell was ever naturalized in Toronto. A long examination by the united States Consul here failed to reveal any trace of O'Donnell having taken out papers here.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6.--The striking operators all have an air of confidence to-day, and prophesy that just as soon as the railroad operators quit work the Western Union and Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Companies will be so completely demoralized as to render further warfare with the brotherhood impossible. The strike of the railroad employes was the "trump card" as hinted at in THE TIMES's dispatches from this point.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 6.--At a late hour this afternoon a well-dressed stranger hired a skiff and rowed out into the lake several hundred yards. Placing the oars in the boat, he divested himself of his clothing and deliberately jumped into the water. He left a note for some unknown person, but gave no cause in it for his deliberate suicide. His body has not been found.

Alma-Tadema publishes in the Frankfort Gazette a letter which he has addressed to the Committee of the International Exhibition of Art, at Munich. As the distinguished artist has been scurvily treated by his German confreres, the facts ought to be made known in this country, where he is justly appreciated. I therefore print a translation in full of his letter:

The Police Department was well represented along the Harlem River yesterday. A medal valued at $80 had been offered for the police swimming championship of the United States, and several of the swimmers among the patrolmen were aspirants for the prize, Capt. Capt. Freeman, of the steam-ship Hudson, which arrived last evening from Havana, reports that last Thursday evening when off the Tortugas, a colored woman named Clemerien Rodriguez, who had taken passage in the steerage, disappeared, and was supposed to have committed suicide by jumping overboard.

WHEELING, West Va., Aug. 6.--A serious and fatal accident, which narrowly escaped being followed by a desperate affray, is reported from Sistersville, Tyler County. While two gangs of laborers were at work on the road-bed of the Ohio Valley Railroad, just north of the town, it became necessary to fire a blast in a large rock.

The pardon of Grove Kennedy will give cause, as we think, to even severer criticism than that of Ferguson. We do not often put such men in the penitentiary, and it seems when they get there the labor and the confinement are irksome and the effect on health is injurious.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6.--The autopsy on the body of William A.J. Fiss, formerly a wellknown tobacconist of this city, who died in the Nerristown Insane Hospital yesterday, mainly from a supposed brutal beating by an attendant, was ...

A nurse's golden reception was held at the Mothodist church at Hingham on Wednesday evening, Aug. 1, complimentary to Miss Mary Patterson, a lady well known in families in Boston and vicinity, who during her eventful life has officiated as nurse for 374 children.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 6.--This city was startled yesterday morning by the report of a terrible tragedy which occurred at Deep Creek, in Norfolk County, about 8 o'clock on Saturday night, which created a most profound sensation among the friends and acquuintances of the actors in the sad and painful drama.

We print this morning a suggestive communication from Col. Sterling R. Cockrill, formerly of this cily, now Vice-President of the Cotton Planters' Association, a cotton planter of 40 years' experience and now planting in Arkansas.
The Kentucky distillers are soon to hold a meeting, and they have modestly agreed as to the legislation which, in their opinion, the trade demands.

ST. PAUL, Aug 6.--M. W. McNair, who was nominated for Governor by the late Democratic Convention, declines to accept the nomination, and his successor will be chosen by the State Central Committee, which has not yet been appointed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6.--Reports received here from various quarters point to serious trouble to-morrow from the further extension of the telegraph strike along the Gould and Garrett railroads.

A remarkable accident occurred on the Jersey City ferry-boat John S. Darey last night on her 9 o'clock trip. When she was about two-thirds of the way across the river the packing of the boiler blew out, filling the engine-room with steam and driving the engineer from his post.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug, 6.--One operator deserted from the brotherhood to-day, and resumed his old place in the Western Union office. The others remain firm and his defection had been expected. Two strikers have accepted positions in business houses. The Western Union office has one operator more than it had before the strike, few of whom are said to be first-class men.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 6.--About a year ago Albert Voss, a bright, well-mannered young German, who is believed to be well connected in Germany, took up his abode in Castleton, a Hudson River village, 14 miles from here.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 5.--In December last, two days before Christmas, Sherman W. Platt, residing with his father, Wenzar Platt, a well-to-do farmer of Morgan's Four Corners, town of Newtown, 23 miles distant from this city, fell asleep after retiring early, as was his habit.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 6.--An opinion of great interest to turfmen was rendered to-day by Judge Reed, of the Circuit Court, in the case of the Nashville Blood Horse Association against the Rock City Blood Horse and Stock Association. The Nashville Blood Horse Association was chartered by the Legislature 18 years ago, and the Legislature ...

BALTIMORE, Aug. 6.--Edward Carr, the tramp who outraged Gertrude, the little daughter of Cornelius Mr. Virts, of Weverton, was captured about 9 o'clock last night near Knoxville, Frederick County, about two and a half miles from where the deed was committed.
ALEXANDRIA, Aug. 6.--One hundred and ten British soldiers have died of cholera in Egypt since the outbreak of the disease. Seven persons, most of them Europeans, died here yesterday.

If Mr. Herbert Spencer happens to want any new instances of the "sluggishness of officialism," he cannot do better than make a note of some facts which have been put before me concerning the way in which business is conducted in the office of the Administrator-General of Bengal, at Calcutta.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6.--Magistrate Pole, to whom Coroner Janny had referred the case of little Eddie Trodden, the boy who killed Willie Walker with a knife a week ago, to-day committed the child to the House of Refuge. He made the commitment on the advice of Assistant District Attorney Bregy, who says if the District Attorney should desire to arraign the young murderer before the Grand Jury he can easily secure his release from the institution.

The Clay Manufacturing Company occupied the fourth floor in the Munro Building, No. 23 Vandewater-street, which was destroyed by fire on July 23, and after the fire their property was placed in charge of Fire Patrolman No. 91, Louis M. Harned. Last Friday night Mr. Charles F. ...

OTISVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 6.--The Hon. Charles Woodward died at 3 o'clock this morning, at his residence in the town of Mount Hope, N.Y., of paralysis, at the age of 70 years. He was a native of Otisville, but spent his early years in New-York City in a mercantile establishment.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 6.--Manus Dougherty, of Bethlehem, while attempting to board a train on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad on Saturday, fell under the cars and had his left leg cut off. He was removed to the hospital, where he died at midnight.

The fishing season for the wheels at the Cascades is at an end, not because there is a scarcity of fish, but because the water has become low and clear and the fish see the wheels and avoid them. The number of salmon which have gone up to the spawning grounds this season must be very large, as the immense run which came into the river a ...

CHICAGO, Aug. 6.--To-day the leading produce markets were rather slow, and most of them were easier. Corn was firm and hog products weak. The weather was fine, and the fact of a holiday in British commercial circles made the foreign trade dull. There was great uncertainty here with regard to the ...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6.--It is reported here that the telegraph operators on the Shenandoah Valley Railroad struck this afternoon.

As I have not been consulted by those who are now endeavoring to effect an arrangement with the United States, and as I am not in ...

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 6.--The wheat yield is the largest known in this section for years. It was well headed, stood heavy, and was free from rust. Some farmers near Norwalk, who have thrashed, say that it will average 20 to 25 bushels to the acre. One field of Winter wheat will make 30 bushels to the acre without any doubt. The oat crop is also as good as has ever been known.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 6.--Benjamin Legg, a farmer living near Centrevilie, Md., had a quarrel with a negro employe on Saturday afternoon, during which, it is alleged, the negro struck Legg, who then went to his house, obtained a gun, and shot the negro dead. A warrant was issued for Legg, but he has not been arrested.

HAVANA, Aug. 6.--The Gaceta (official paper) of a recent date contains the following details of a dispatch from the Minister of the Colonies to the Governor-General of Cuba: "All country property now pays 2 per cent., without distinction.

Capt. Jack Hussey, the Castle Garden gatekeeper who rescued an old man from drowning near Pier No. 1 North River on Thursday last, was presented yesterday afternoon by the Castle Garden employes with a large crayon portrait of himself in recognition of his gallant conduct. The presentation took place in the Garden rotunda. In reply Capt. Hussey said: "Gentlemen and fellowcitizens, I did my duty like a man, and I'm willing to do it again."

LONDON, Aug. 7--A dispatch to the Standard from Hong Kong says: "Everything is ready for the attack on Hue. The heat alone delays the advance. The boldness of the enemy is increasing. A battery of the enemy cannonaded Hanoi without result on the 1st inst. Two Japanese attaches have arrived at the French camp."

SARATOGA, Aug. 6.--The programme presented by the Saratoga Racing Association to-day, together with the delightful weather, brought an immense number of people to the race-track. The racing was of an excellent nature. Welcher and Hanap ran a dead heat in the first event. In the run off after the fourth race Welcher won.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Ang. 6.--Congressman William Walter Phelps, of this State, in an interview in reference to the use of his name in connection with the Republican nomination for Governor this Fall, says:

BALTIMORE, Aug. 6.--Delegates to the Grand Commandery of the United States Knights Templar, at San Francisco, will leave at 8 o'clock to-morrow morning by a special train over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 6.--Mayor Vroom today issued an order forbidding the Salvation Army to parade hereafter with any kind of music. So many complaints have been made against the members of the army by citizens that it became necessary for the Mayor to take action.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6.--The Citizen's League began quo warranto proceedings to-day against John B. Drake, in order to test the validity of the ordinance passed by the Council a few days before the State license law went into effect, fixing the prices of saloon licenses at $100 instead of $500, as prescribed by the State law. This was done to bring the matter to a speedy issue. The saloon-keepers thus far are fighting for delay.
The racing at Brighton Beach yesterday was very exciting, and the knowing ones were very badly hurt, as the rank outsiders were victorious, the mutual pools paying extraordinary dividends.

LONDON, July 25.--America has taken much more interest in the shooting at Wimbledon than is manifest on this side. During some years past the national meeting has been regarded as more of a business affair of the volunteers than a festival.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 6.--The Photographists' Association of America will meet in annual session in this city to-morrow morning. The sessions will be held in the Exposition Building, and will last six days.

Bibb County has a Court-house that cost $130,000. She is able to afford it and would not put up with a poorer building. Fulton County has recently finished a new Court-ho se at a cost, we suppose, of $150,000. This is well. Other counties in the State have evinced public spirit on the same scale.

FRANKFORD, Ky., Aug. 3.--Gov. Blackburn to-day pardoned Ben Garrity, an ex-policeman of Louisville, who was convicted last May and sentenced to the penitentiary for one year for obtaining money from the State Treasury on fraudulent claims. Garrity has been at work on the railroad as time-keeper since he was sent here and will be brought to the city to-morrow to be released and sent home.

Daniel J. Curren, of Jackson Court, Brooklyn, was standing on the dock at the foot of Goldstreet, in that city, yesterday afternoon, when he saw a man clinging to a skiff near the dock. Curren jumped overboard and swam toward the skiff to render assistance, but before he reached it the man had disappeared.

Bernard T. Brogan and William E. Morris, who were arrested for assaulting Charles B. McManus during a political meeting at Clarendon Hall last Thursday night, were arraigned before Justice Duffy in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday afternoon.

The Hon. David Davis saw the valley in a sensible fashion. His immense avoirdupois would not permit him to gad about on a horse's back, so he drank in the scenery from the porch of his hotel, while his more ambitious spouse "did" some of the commoner points in the valley.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6.--A number of delegates to the convention of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers arrived here today. The convention will be called to order tomorrow morning, and will, in all probability, continue a week or 10 days. It is estimated that there will be 200 delegates present, representing every branch of the order in the country. The convention will be strictly private.

Mr. H.M. Pitt appeared at the MadisonSquare Theatre last evening as Wyncot, in "The Rajah." Mr. George Clarke was his predecessor in this role. Mr. Pitt wore pictureseue costumes and acted with earnestness and discretion.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, Aug. 6.--The Middlesex County Jail at New-Brunswick has been placed in a state of seige, owing to rumors of a raid said to be contemplated by the friends of Frank Moore, a prisoner awaiting trial on a charge of being the leader of a gang of train-robbers.

Controller Grant was engaged yesterday in signing a large number of warrants which had accumulated since the resignation of Mr. Campbell. He has asked the Commissioners of Accounts to submit to him in writing any views they may possess as to improvements in the method of bookkeeping in the department.
MONCTON, New-Brunswick, Aug. 6.--The telegraphers' strike ended here to-day. The men voluntarily returned to work.

The bodies of Lena and George Sonst, the children of Philip Sonst, an unemployed butcher, living with his invalid wife at No. 525 West Fortieth-street, who were drowned on Thursday night last by the upsetting of a boat in which they were with Patrick Quinn, a boatman, were found yesterday floating in the North River.

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Aug. 6.--Two American fishermen, Charles Taylor and Edward Landry, belonging to the schooner Challenge, of Gloucester, recently got astray from the vessel on Grand Banks and landed at Trepassey, after being five days and nights on the water. They were all that time without food or water. The men are terribly exhausted.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6.--Outrages upon women in the suburban and badly lighted parts of the city have been very frequent recently. The latest case came to light to-day.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 6.--The Star this evening printed an interview with Charlie Ford, who is now under $5,000 bonds on a charge of complicity in the Blue Cut train robbery, in which he recounts his connection with the James gang and the negotiations with the authorities which led to the killing of James.

The monument, as it will be when placed in position, is of two parts. The base is 5 feet 6 inches square and 12 inches in height, with beveled edges, the sides and top dressed in style known as "cut work," leaving the stone in the same color as it appears in the ledge.

The steam-ship Helvetia, from Liverpool, landed 298 immigrants yesterday at Castle Garden. The eighteenth annual excursion of the Sunday-school of the Church of the Sea and Land to Oriental Grove takes place to-morrow.
NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario, Aug. 6.--Levi D. Jarrard, the absconding Treasurer from New-Jersey, has been arrested here. Proceedings for his extradition are in progress.

District Attorney Catlin and Police Inspector Jewett, of Brooklyn, had a consultation yesterday in reference to the death of Mrs. Boyd, otherwise Kennedy, who died 10 days ago on Meadow Island, near Freeport, Long Island. Her death is said to have been hastened by ill-treatment at the hands of her son-in-law, a ...

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 6.--Returns from the State election to-day come in slowly and with difficulty. One-half of the State forecasts the election of J. Proctor Knott, (Dem.,) over T. Z. Morrow, (Rep.,) for Governor by a safe majority, but its size cannot be estimated.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 6.--The steam-ship Wanderer, Capt. Reid, from Belize, Honduras, reached the wharf this morning. She brings the intelligence that Seffor Don Safino Barrios, President of Guatemala, has grossly and publicly insulted the British Ambassador and that the latter has left for England.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6.--Speaking of the notification served on the railroads asking for increased pay, , for the railroad telegraph operators, Mortimer Shaw, Secretary of the brotherhood's Executive Board, said to-day:
CORNWALL, Ontario, Aug. 6.--The barge Argo, of Ogdensburg, N.Y., ran into and broke two gates of Lock No. 19 at 4 o'clock this morning. Navigation will consequently be suspended for 48 hours.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 6.--The report that Judge Henry Hilton is about to erect a mammoth hotel here has a foundation in fact. Several years ago Judge Hilton and a party of wealthy New-York capitalists formed themselves into an association and purchased a large tract of land at the head of the Highlands of Navesink, near Bay ...

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 6.--The success of the free canal system is pretty well established by the report of tonnage during the last three months compared with the report for the same time last year, now just issued by the Canal Superintendent. The increase is 202,164 tons.

MADRID, Aug. 6.--The outbreak among Spanish troops reported from Portugal occurred in the city of Badajos, capital of the Province of the same name. The garrison of the town, numbering 700 men, pronounced for a republic, the Constitution of 1869, and Ruiz Zorilla for President.

Any amount of excitement was caused last evening by a sensational report to the effect that the man O'Donnell, who killed Carey, the informer, on the steamer Melrose, between Cape Town and Port Elizabeth, on July 29, was none other than Capt. Thomas Phelan, of this city, and some of his best friends were fearful last night that there might be some truth in the sentational report ...
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 6.--The NewYork Yacht Club's race for the Goelet Cups to-day was successfully sailed.

The Postal Telegraph Company opened its line to Chicago yesterday morning, and business was reported to be brisk all the day. Messages were sent at the rate of 25 cents for 20 words, and 10 cents for each additional 10 words or less.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 6.--The Grand Commandery of the Sons of Veterans met here to-day, all the 25 divisions being represented, including the Northern States and Kentucky.

A motion for a stay of proceedings on an interiocutory judgment in favor of Eliphalet Nott, a stockholder of Las Nueve Minas de Santa Maria Gold and Silver Mining Company against Henry Clews, John B. Alley, Frederick D. Grant, Abia B. Selover, and others, the Directors of the corporation, was denied yesterday by Judge Cullen in the Supreme Court, Chambers.

LONDON, Aug. 7.--The Allan Line steam-ship Scandinavian, Capt. Park, from Boston July 26, has arr. at Glasgow. The steam-ship Sarnia. (Br.,) Capt. Lindall, from Montreal July 26, has arr. at Liverpool. MOVILLE, Aug. 7.--The Anchor Line steam-ship Italia, Capt. Allen, from New-York July 21, for Glasgow, has arr. here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6.--To-morrow or the day following the Civil Service Commission will inform candidates for departmental clerkships throughout the country of their standing, and will inform heads of departments that they are ready to certify candidates on requisitions to fill vacancies.

An interesting contribution to the history of railway land grant legislation has been made by the Hon. E. JOHN ELLIS, Democratic Representative in Congress from the Second District of Louisiana. Mr. ELLIS ...

BOSTON, Aug. 6.--The only suspension in the shoe and leather trade annonuced to-day was of H.F. Crawford Co., a shoe firm of Brockton, whose factory in that place was shut down this morning for an indefinite period. This suspension is a result of the failure of C.W. Clement. The firm manufactured a medium grade of goods especially for Mr. Clement. The suspension is only temporary.
The Committee on Education and Labor of the United States Senate met in Room No. 100, in the Post Office Building, yesterday morning, prepared to take testimony.

For the eighth time this season the Metropolitan Club defeated the Allegheny nine, of Pittsburg, yesterday, on the Polo Grounds. The game was a rather one-sided affair, the "Mets" taking the lead in the first inning and holding it throughout the contest.

SEA ISLE CITY, N.J., Aug. 6.--A bottle was picked up yesterday near life-saving station No. 34, in which was a paper bearing the following message: "Off Jersey coast. Lost at sea June 21, 1883, bark Atlanta, bound from Genoa to New York. Have been without food for three days. Send us help or we are lost. Have buried Captain, mate, boatswain, and all but three sailors. Help us or we perish."

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 6.--A special dispatch to the Picayune from Jackson, Miss., says that fusion was carried at Raymond today after a hard fight in the Democratic and Republican Conventions. The proposition made by the Democrats was unanimously adopted by the Republicans.

Henry Hamilton and others claim the exclusive right to run stages on surf-avenue, Coney Island, to the Brighton Beach Hotel, and obtained a temporary injunction restraining four hackmen, named, respectively, Cook, Casey, Schaffer, and Bray, from soliciting patronage from the steps of the hotel. Judge Barnard yesterday heard argument in the case in the Special Term of the Supreme ...

County officials are so derelict in furnishing reports to the State Statistical Bureau that the efficiency of that office threatens to be permanently impaired. Incomplete or inaccurate statistics are worse than useless, and this is just what the next report of the bureau promises to be from the present outlook.

The discovery of a manuscript nearly three thousand years old and containing, among other things, a version of the Ten Commandments differing to some extent from the version given by the writer of Exodus is an event of the utmost interest and importance.

Very little additional could be learned yesterday concerning the shortage in the accounts of Mr. L.F. Booth, the joint agent of the trunk line railroads in Castle Garden, who has not been seen in his office since July 27.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6.--The Post will publish to-morrow an interview with Dr. Manuel de Mesa, who was Gen. Santa Anna's private secretary, touching the story of a treaty said to have recently been entered into between Germany and Mexico.
Walt Whitman sent the following letter to the managers of the tertio-millennial celebration in Santa Fe, New-Mexico.

William Elliott, the ex-champion sculler of England, and George Gaisel, the champion Harlem oarsman, rowed a three-mile sculling race, with turn, on the Passaic River, at Newark, yesterday afternoon, for $300 a side.

NAPLES, Aug. 6.--Nineteen persons who were injured by the disaster on the Island of Ischia died in the hospitals here during last week. One hundred others who were also wounded were discharged from the hospitals cured. A child who was buried in the ruins at Casamicciola at the time of the earthquake on July 28 was rescued alive last Saturday.
CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 6.--The first annual meeting of the Association of Union Paymasters of the War was held this evening at the new Columbia Hotel.

The American Steam Yacht Club's Board of Trustees endeavored to have a meeting yesterday at the office of George S. Scott in the Mills Building. Mr. Rufus Hatch and the Secretary, Mr. Henry A. Taylor, were the only members on deck at the appointed time.
A letter has been received by Mr. F.W. Chesson, Secretary to the Aborigines Protection Society, from the Earl of Derby, in reply to a communication from the committee on the subject of Zulu-land.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 6.--The annual report of the Treasurer of the Ocean Beach Association shows that the entire indebtedness of the association has been paid, leaving a balance of cash and negotiable securities of over $16,000. From the President's report it is learned that the association still owns 375 lots in various parts of the tract.

Jennie and Kate Kane, sisters, have charge, respectively, of the laundry and linen rooms in the Osborn House, at the Isle of Wight, a new watering-place on the Long Island coast between Long Beach and Far Rockaway.

BUFFALO, N.Y. , Aug. 6.--Most of the operators employed on this division of the Lackawanna Road struck at noon to-day. The company was considerably inconvenienced, but all trains were able to run as usual. It is said that 85 out of 100 operators joined the strikers. The striking operators had a benefit at the Academy of Music to-night and realized a handsome sum.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 6.--The Customs authorities at Plattsburg having recently detained a Canadian steamer for towing barges to Whiteball, the owner at Ottawa reported.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6.--The Prosecuting Attorney issued 104 warrants to-day against persons who violated the Sunday law yesterday. The total number of cases reported shows that there was a far more general observance of the law than on the previous Sunday.

Judge Reynolds, in the Brooklyn City Court yesterday, appointed the Rev. J.G. Butler Receiver of the affairs of George E. Twitchell in the suit against him to recover $190 due for groceries. Mr. Twitchell is a stockholder in a mining company, and when the case first came before the court Mrs. Twitchell appeared for her husband.

A phenomenon is reported from Calistoga in the extraordinary rapid growth of trees this season. Nearly all kinds show even thus far nearly double the growth of last season. Mulberry trees particularly have grown rapidly and made more wood than during the last two preceding years. The tops of young trees have formed so rapidly in many cases that some of the branches have to be removed to keep the body in proper shape.

BERLIN, Aug. 6.--The ex-Empress Eugenie has arrived at Carlsbad. A special Chinese Envoy has arrived here. RAVENNA, Italy, Aug. 6.--A congress of Socialists met here yesterday. The police, being refused admittance to the hall, broke down the doors and dispersed the meeting.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6, 1883. The Treasury Department has paid out nearly $1,000,000 on account of pensions since the 1st inst.

Two very busy men ran in and out of the Manhattan Hotel yesterday at all hours of the day and evening. They were John Campbell, Grand Master Workman of the Telegraphers Brotherhood, and Eugene J. O'Connor, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the same organization.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Aug. 6.--The Vermont National Bank of St. Albans, of which the Hon. Bradley Barlow is President, closed its doors this morning, causing great consternation among its depositors. Mr. Barlow is also President and owner of the South-eastern Railway of Canada.
POINT CHAUTAUQUA, Aug. 6.--At a meeting of the Directors of the Point Chautauqua Baptist Union held last Saturday the following officers were elected for the ensuing year:

This very bright and popular theatre, celebrated as Harrigan Hart's, was opened for the season last night. The building was crowded, and the audience had that sympathetic quality which audiences at this theatre have invariably.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 6.--The Boston Commandery of Knights Templar passed through this city at 1 o'clock this morning on their way West. A dinner with which it had been intended to regale the members was dispensed with, the commandery being behind the schedule time of their trip.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6.--There was no evidence adduced at the Coroner's inquest to-day to show that little James Snell met his death at the hands of Howard Shaw, his playmate. Nobody testified to anything about a stone having been thrown, but David Buckley swore that he saw the children running down the street together and when they reached the house, No. 1,128, Petersstreet, the Snell child fell and struck against the ...

Our Chicago dispatch says it is reported in that city that the strike among the railroad telegraph operators will become general to-day. There seems to have been an expectation that such a strike would take place yesterday on several railroads running to this City.

Edward Pride, an alleged lunatic, was brought from the Flatbush Insane Asylum yesterday before Judge Reynolds, of the Brooklyn City Court, to be discharged from custody. In reply to Judge Reynolds, he said: "You ought to know me, Judge; I am a lawyer and have practiced before you more than once."

Detective Sergeants King and Lyons have for some time been watching the movements of Augustus Gilbert, a clerk in the employ of John P. Moore's Sons, gunmakers, at No. 302 Broadway, with a good deal of interest.

SELMA, Ala., Aug. 6.--The first bale of the new cotton crop was received here yesterday morning. It was raised in this (Dallas) county on the plantation of Woodruff North, prominent cotton factors of this place, and was consigned to ...

RICHMOND, Aug. 6.--The operators between Charlottesville and Clifton Forge, on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, numbering about 25, struck at noon to-day. Others on this end, it is said, will positively strike to-morrow, seriously crippling the running of trains.

Yesterday was the the tenth day of the midsummer meeting of the Monmouth Park Association, and a good day's sport was witnessed by a crowd moderate in numbers but very enthusiastic, the races being generally closely contested.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 6.--For the past few days the heat has been excessive, but not a case of yellow fever has occurred, nor any case to give rise to suspicion. The death list of the past week foots up 138, of which 23 were of consumption, 13 of small-pox, 8 of malarial fever, and 2 of sunstroke.

NEWTON, N.J., Aug. 6.--The army worm has made its appearance in certain parts of Sussex County, N.J., and is doing considerable damage. It appeared over two weeks ago in Warren County and has worked its way northward, and is now ravaging the farms in Byram, Greene, and Sparta Townships, and in the neighborhood of Huntsville. The injury being done is great.

The police reported yesterday afternoon that Michael Brady, aged 26, of No. 232 Delanceystreet, had accidentally fallen down near his home while drunk and fractured his skull. Last night detectives learned that an unknown man had pushed him down in a brawl in front of Doran's liquor store, at Delancey and Willis streets. He was lying unconscious at Bellevue Hospital late in the evening, while the detectives were searching for the man who pushed him.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6.--The short married life of Frank C. Bangs, the actor, and Mrs. Alice Singer Lagrove, one of the 29 daughters of the sewing-machine manufacturer, and a would-be actress as well, seems to be at an end.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 6.--Owing to the inability of the four-oared crew of the Toronto Rowing Club to represent Canada at the annual regatta of the National Amateur Oarsmen's Association, at Newark, N.J., to-morrow, the Canadian Association has selected the Ottawa crew instead. They left for Newark this morning.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6.--I.D. Crawford, proprietor of the Crawford House, confessed judgment to-day in favor of Charles E. Turk, of Chicago, for $10,034, and in favor of Otto G. Schulenberg, of St. Louis, for $23,749. These are understood to be about the extent of his liabilities. His assets are estimated at $40,000.

GUAYAQUIL, Aug. 6, via Galveston.--Miguel Valverde has been appointed a member of Alfaro's Cabinet as successor of Senor Semblantes.

Andreas Kleinlein, a German immigrant, who arrived by the steam-ship Neckar, from Bremen, on Aug. 4, complained yesterday at Castle Garden that he had been swindled by the runner of one of the Greenwich-street employment agencies. Andreas stated that he went to a Morris-street boarding-house after his arrival, and purchased a ticket for ...

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 6.--Felicitos Mejia, the famous bull-fighter, was fatally hurt while engaged in a bull-fight yesterday, three miles outside the city. He was tossed into the air by a bull, which again caught the man on his horns as he fell. The building was crowded at the time, and the greatest excitement prevailed.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 6.--The threatened order to the telegraph operators on the Wabash Railway for them to leave their places went into force at noon to-day. Superintendent Selden has advices that four men only in the entire system under his management obeyed the summons, and their places have been filled. Superintendent Selden is confident that this will be the extent of the defection on that road.

Massachusetts has had but few Democratic Governors, and she has never manifested much desire to keep or indorse those she had. Her first Democratic Governor, James Sullivan, was chosen in 1807, and re-elected in 1808. Dying in 1808, he had no opportunity to try for a third term.

The stem-ships Fuida, of the North German Lloyd; Amerique; of the French Line; Bothnia, of the Cunard Line, and P. Caland, of the Rotterdam Line, will sail for Europe to-day.
LONDON, Aug. 7.--The meeting at Brighton began to-day. The race for the Brighton Stakes (handicap) was won by Mr. R. Jardine's 4-year-old b.f. Whin Blossom, with Sir F. Johnstone's 5-yearold ch. m.

LITTLE ROCK, Aug. 7.--An Indian Territory special says that at the election in the Cherokee Nation yesterday a principal chief, assistant chief, three Judges for the Northern, Southern, and Middle Judicial Circuits, Judge, Clerk, Sheriff, and Solicitor for each of the districts ...

LONDON, Aug. 7.--The commander of the British troops in Egypt telegraphs, referring to the cholera, that the improvement in the situatian is maintained, and that no fresh cases of the disease are reported.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 7.--To-day five Chinese convicts were brought to the State prison in this city from Paterson, where they had been convicted of atrociously assaulting a fellow Celestial. They were given the option of paying a fine of $500 each or serving the State for one year, and either on account of their love of the almighty ...

MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 7.--McPhelan, charged with uttering forged notes, was handed over to United Stated detectives this mornings under an order of extradition and started with his keeper for Boston, where he will be tried.

Mr. THOMAS HAMILTON, of South Carolina, who is said to be one of the most prominent politicians of that State, has written a letter denouncing the Republican Party, and commending the Democracy as the political organization that has done most for the elevation and education of the colored race.

An attempt was made to sell the newspaper Le Messager Franco-Americain, published by Lallemand Martin at No. 43 Murray-street, yesterday morning. The paper was established by Mr. H. de Marell in 1859, and had been conducted successfully until last February, when Mr. de Mareil sold ...

Robert Franklin, of Washington Territory, who was on his way to this City, was yesterday robbed on an Erie train near Paterson, N.J. He had recently sold his property in Washington Territory, placed the proceeds, $2,700 in twenty-dollar ...

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Aug. 7.--Though the wind to-day was at first moderate it increased to a good yachting breeze after passing Brenton's Reef, and the New-York yacht squadron made a fine run from Newport to the Vineyard. The schooners Fortuna, Magic, Intrepid, and Estelle, and the sloops Winona and Julia, were leaders and arrived in the order named. The fleet departs for Marblehead at daylight to-morrow.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 7.--The United States steamer Despatch cast anchor off the breakwater at Block Island at about 11 o'clock this morning, and a boat made for the shore with a party, who proceeded first to the Post Office for letters and then to the Ocean View Hotel.

Vice-President King's daughter, who is traveling through the Eastern cities en route to Washington, in straitened circumstances, journeys slowly. She was in Louisville as long ago as 1876, , telling the same story that secures her sympathy now. It was very improper in a Vice-President to leave his daughter unprovided for, especially in view of the fact that he lived and died a bachelor.

CAMDEN, Me., Aug. 7.--H.M. Bean to-day launched the three-masted schooner William H. Allison, of 450 tons burden. She will be commanded by Capt. E.C. Kunnison, of Rockland.

Because relics of certain saints were sold at auction at very low prices in Tuscany, the other day, a number of secular and Protestant papers have assumed that the Italians are losing their faith in relics.
