CARLISLE, Penn., Aug. 7.--Edward L. Frederick, age 15, living with a farmer near this place, committed suicide last night by shooting himself through the heart with a revolver. He died almost instantly. No motive is assigned for the act.

There was great excitement in the Stock Exchange yesterday, about half an hour after the opening, when the market made a bad break, the Wabash and South-western stocks leading in the general drop, and the former rapidly falling from 22 to 19.

Perhaps the most important stage in the political action of the people is that involved in what is known as the primary elections, or the party meetings at which delegates to nominating conventions are chosen.

J.G. Farnham, a conductor on the West Haven horse railroad, is critically ill at his home in West Haven. Ten days ago he became thoroughly drenched in the rain and did not leave his ...
BUFFALO, Aug. 7.--The situation at the Western Union office here is apparently unchanged, but no outsider knows just what it is.

According to the Diario Official 5,309 foreigners have become naturalized in Brazil (not including colonists) in the period between 1825 and 1882--a period of 57 years. There is a significance in this result which the Diario probably overlooks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7.--Commissioner of Pensions Dudley is at work prosecuting three cases of violation of the pension laws, two of which involve the defrauding of pensioners by persons who assisted them in securing their pensions.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 7.--Rumors regarding the insolvency of the Second National Bank of Elmira have been freely circulated throughout Western New-York during to-day and yesterday, and have created considerable excitement in financial circles.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7.--The national convention of delegates of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers met at the Assembly Buildings, at Tenth and Chestnut streets, at 10 o'clock this morning. The appearance and bearing of the delegates showed that they were representative men of their class.

The regular weekly meeting of the Passenger Agents of the trunk lines was held in Commissioner Fink's office yesterday, Commissioner Pierson, of the passenger department, presiding. The main subject of discussion was the disappearance of L.F. Booth, the agent of the trunk lines in Castle Garden.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7.--The Philadelphia nine, after a month's absence in the West, reappeared at Recreation Park to-day and were defeated by the New-York Club by a score of 4 to 1.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 7.--There is an apparently well-authenticated report here that the Post Office question which has been the topic of conversation among prominent Republican politicians for some time past has finally been settled by the removal of the present incumbent.

Mrs. Mary E. Wolf, the wife of Charles Wolf, a gas-fitter, living at No. 872 Third-avenue, was brought to the East Fifty-first-street police station last night, suffering from five serious stab wounds inflicted by her husband.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7.--The sixth annual session of the American Society of Microscopists was begun this morning in Archer Hall, Jackson-street and Wapash-avenue. Dr. Lester Curtis, the retiring President, opened the proceedings with a short address of welcome, and introduced ...

The nineteenth excursion of the Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild in its Summer work for sick children was made yesterday, in which 900 sick children and mothers participated. Many of them were taken to the Sea-side Nursery at Staten Island for a few weeks to enable the children to recover from their illness.

SARATOGA, Aug. 7.--The principal feature of to-day's racing was the defeat of Miss Woodford by Empress in the Pocahontas Stake. Miss Woodford was so great a favorite that she was barred in the auction pools, and only one bookmaker would lay against her.
SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 7.--The annual convention of the National Grand Lodge of the Junior American Protestant Association met here to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 7.--The subscription dinner at the Casino last night was a queer affair, if all reports are true. The guests, who, it should be stated, were not under the influence of liquor, were quite hilarious and indulged in a pretty lively hazing.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Aug. 7.--A new move in the Vanderbilt-Pennsylvania Railroad war is developed by the institution of legal proceedings on the part of the Pennsylvania and Western Railroad against the Beach Creek and Southern Railroad for alleged trespass by the latter upon the rights of the former.

LIVERPOOL, Aug. 7.--James McDermott was arrested here yesterday on his arrival from America on board the steamer City of Montreal. A warrant for his arrest was issued in Cork, where he had been seen in company with O'Herlihy.

YORK, Penn., Aug. 7.--Charles Davis and Edward Wilson, notorious burglars, who were awaiting trial on a numbar of charges, escaped from the York Jail early this morning. They lowered themselves to the ground by means of a rope made from bed-clothing.
The eleventh day of the midsummer meeting at Monmouth Park was well attended and a really good day's sport was had, although there was a walk-over for the Trenton Selling Stakes.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 7.--The Board of Managers of the International Cotton Centennial Exhibition, to be held in this city next year, met tonight and elected Major E.A. Burke General Manager, at a salary of $10,000 a year.

PORTLAND, Oregon, July 23.--Some misguided traveler recently advertised in a NewYork-paper and his remarks were telegraphed in substance across the continent that he had passed through Montana, Northern Idaho, ...

BOSTON, Aug, 7.--To-morrow's Advertiser will say that a powerful New-York and Boston syndicate has been formed to control the Drawbaugh telephone rights, in view of the anticipated result of the litigation against the Bell Company. The details of the procedure are kept secret, but it is learned that the New-England, Middle and Western territories are already acquired.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 7.--To-day, for a change, the Clevelands played a good game of ball and defeated the Buffalos.

PHILADELPHIA Aug. 7.--Coroner Samuel Atkins, of Norristown, held an inquest to-day on the body of William A.J. Fiss, who died on Sunday morning last from injuries received at the hands of James Gaffey, an attendant in the Norristown Hospital.

Three children of one family, residing on Bremen-street, East Boston, have within two weeks died of diphtheria, and three older children are now down with the same disease. It is believed that the disease was communicated by a young physician who visited a patient in the family a little while before his own death two weeks ago.

BUFFALO, N.Y. Aug. 7.--The eighteenth annual meeting of the Buffalo Driving Park Association began to-day under very favorable auspices. The weather was all that could be asked for--clear, but a trifle cool--while the track was in splendid ...

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 7.--A dozen years ago, when the tracks of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey through the city of Plainfield were elevated, the eight or ten streets crossed by the road were spanned by heavy iron bridges. These were supposed to be sufficiently strong to bear the weight of any train that could be put upon them, but recent tests show ...

A gentleman whose letter appears in another column asks whether Mr. JAY GOULD "thinks there is any hereafter." We presume that Mr. GOULD thinks, often upon this grave subject, and perhaps thinks deeply.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7.--A match game of base-ball has been arranged between a nine representing the Interior Department and one chosen from the inmates of the Government Insane Asylum. The game is to be played on the grounds of the asylum, and after the match the visitors are to be given a dinner by the inmates.
M.W. Bull, W.L. Cash, S.D. Dickinson, T.J. Dolan, J.M. Pollard, S.J. Scott, and George Joiner, of the American rifle team, were passengers on the Abyssinia, which arrived last night.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7.--Something of a sensation was caused to-day in a boarding-house at No. 53 West Lake-street. On Monday evening the boarders began to feel symptoms of serious illness.

This evening a promenade concert will be given in the Garden in aid of the Brotherhood of Telegraphers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7.--The Crawford House, at the corner of Wabash-avenue and Jacksonstreet, has been seized by the Sheriff to satisfy judgments and claims by Mrs. O.G. Schulenburg, of St. Louis, for $23,749, and Charles L. Luerk for $10,034. Mr. J.D. Crawford was seen this morning and talked quite freely of his present embarrassment.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7.--A special dispatch from Fort Washakie, Montana, announces that President Arthur and party arrived there this afternoon. To prevent intrusion, prior to the arrival of the Presidential party, all civilians were ordered off the reservation.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7.--At the Southern Hotel are Gen. J.H. Devereux, President of the Bee Line; James Tillinghast, Assistant President of the New-York Central; John R. Duff, of Boston, and Judge R.P. Ranney, of Cleveland ...

Judge McCrary, of the United States Circuit Ceurt, has been applied to for the appointment of a Receiver of the St. Joseph and Western Railroad by Messrs. Isham and Burry, of Chicago, and William Strauss, of this City, acting as counsel for E.C. Benedict Co.
MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 7.--No News has yet been received of the steamer Ludwig, which is now three weeks overdue.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 7.--In the House to-day the Ammerman resolution was adopted authorizing the appointment of a free conference committee of five from each house to consider the subject of Congressional and legislative apportionment. The Lowry Congressional Apportionment bill, giving the Republicans 17 and the Democrats 11 districts, passed finally. The Jamison Legislative Apportionment bill passed its second reading.
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 7.--The Legislature today passed a general local option law for the State.

Mr. Amasa Stone, of Cleveland, Ohio, died on May 11, of the present year, leaving an estate valued at several millions of dollars. His wlll provided for the distribution of large sums for educational purposes and as bequests to relatives and others.
A general election was held in Utah on Monday last, at which members of the Legislature, Probate Judges, Sheriffs, and other local officers were chosen.

LIMA, Aug. 7, Via Galveston, Texas.--Today's Tribune states that Iglesias, having organized a division of 1,000 men at Cajamarca; is now marching on Trujillo, which he expects to reach about Aug. 20, and will provisionally occupy that city.

LONDON, Aug. 8.--Persistent reports are current that Cetywayo is alive. The son of the late Bishop Colenso telegraphs from Maritzburg that Cetywayo demands an inquiry into his treatment by the Government. The British agent at Maritzburg discredits the reports.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7.--The record of the court martial in the case of Lieut.-Col, Ilges has been received by Judge-Advocate-General Swaim, who will review it and make a report thereon to the Secretary of War.
LONDON, Aug. 7.--In the House of Commons to-night the National Debt bill passed its second reading by a vote of 149 to 95. The bill proposes to replace terminable annuities expiring in 1885.
LONDON, Aug. 7.--Many members of Parliament will go to America during the coming recess.

OGDEN, Utah Territory, Aug. 7.--The election yesterday passed off quietly, but little interest being taken in it. The Mormon ticket was elected in each district throughout the Territory, with the exception of Summit County, which is in doubt. The majority of the Gentiles refrained from voting. A large majority of the Mormons would, it was known, vote solidly as directed by the Church, and this fact deprived the election of any element of a contest.

JOHNSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 7.--A post-mortem examination was held Saturday of the body of Samuel Murray, who died early that morning as the result of a blow on the head given him by George P. Cole a few evenings before. It was found that the frontal bone was fractured in several places.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 9.--Explorations of a recently discovered cave at the base of Lookout Mountain, opening at low water on the edge of the Tennessee River, three miles from this city, have developed a wonderful cave of unknown depths. Many other interesting phenomena were also discovered.

ALBANY, Aug. 9.--Speaker Chapin said today, in regard to the chair and desk allegation, that while every speaker since the opening of the new Capitol had taken his chair and desk home, he alone was the only one accused and as well the only one innocent.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 9.--The strike at the Woonsocket Company's mill has ended, the weavers returning to work this morning. They demanded 20 cents a cut, not 21 cents, as before reported, and this demand was granted. This is as advance of 1 cents per cut.

The Exposition is daily growing in importance and completeness.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Aug. 9.--The reunion of the survivors of the battle of Wilson's Creek, at which Gen. Nathaniel Lyon was killed, began here to-day. All are having a splendid time and the most cordial feeling prevails. To-morrow will be the chief day of the reunion.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 9.--Ferdinand Schrieman, alias William Hartman, and wife, of New-York, who were recently married, arrived here last night on their wedding tour. She is in great distress, and has applied to the police for protection.

MARIETTA, Ga., Aug. 10.--Mr. Curtis, of the North Georgia Railroad Shops, while going home, was waylaid by three men, who demanded his money or his life. There is no clue to his assailants.

BUFFALO, Aug. 11.--The eighteenth annual trotting meeting was brought to a close this morning, Monroe Chief winning the fourth heat and race, of the 2:18 class, without much effort.
Professional cricket is now a most important industry. Vast numbers of men make high weekly wages by it during the Summer months, and some secure large incomes.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 11.--The steamer Brantford City, Capt. Aldersen, went ashore at Little Harbor, near Lockport, at 3:30 o'clook this morning, in a dense fog. At last report she had 12 feet of water in her hold. Besides some cargo from London for Boston, she had on board about 10,000 cases of canned lobster shipped here for London. There are no passengers aboard.

LONDON, Aug. 11.--A dispatch to the Exchange Telegraph Company from Paris asserts that Ruiz Zorilla is in Spain, where he is personally directing the risings in that country, which, it is declared, are spreading.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11.--The force at the Western Union main office here was to-day increased by three operators, one of whom was a striker at Richmond and another a striker at St. Louis.

MOUNT WASHINGTON, N.H., Aug. 11.--Mr. C.E. Heath, of Chicopee, Mass., rode down Mount Washington this morning from the Summit House to the Glen House on a tricycle. The distance eight miles, was made in 65 minutes. The previons record on a bicycle over the same road was 1 hour and 15 minutes.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 11.--The NewHaven Yacht Club left New-Bedford this morning for Vineyard Haven. Twelve vessels started. The smaller ones were obliged to anchor in Robinson's and Tarpaulin Coves on account of a heavy northeast gale. Half a dozen of the larger yachts reached Vineyard Haven between 3 and 5 o'clock.

Buttermilk is becoming a favorite bar-room drink in some parts of the country. Men who drink it persuade themselves that it aids digestion. It seems to us that Prof. Rains once proved that certain forms of buttermilk, in Augusta, were as dangerous as dynamite.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 11.--Just before daylight this morning a colored Custom-house Inspector named Philip D. Nixon, while sitting on the Third District ferry wharf at the head of Esplanade-street, fell into the water and was drowned.
LONDON, Aug. 11.--The correspondent of the Times at Durban says that Cetywayo, the Zulu King, is now on his way to Pietermaritzburg.

It is announced that the Duke of NORFOLK has given up his intention of selling his yacht. His rent roll of 269,698 will permit him, he finds, to indulge in the double luxury of building and "running" cathedrals and steam yachts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11.--Passed Assistant Surgeon A.A. Austin has reported his return home, having been detached from the Richmond June 26, and has been placed on waiting orders.

CAMP VEST, ON SPRING CREEK, Wyoming, Aug. 10, via Fort Washakie, Wyoming, Aug. 10.--The day so far since leaving Camp Rollins, at Bull Lake Fork, this morning at 7 o'clock, has been very uneventful.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12.--The weather here to-day has been very cool and disagreeable, necessitating fires at the hotels.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 12.--Dr. F. Finnie, in charge of the Ship Island Quarantine Station, reports to Dr. John Godfry, the Marine Hospital Surgeon at New-Orleans, that during the past week three vessels arrived at the station with clean bills of health.

FORTRESS MONROE, Virginia, Aug. 12.-- Some 200 members of John A. Rawlins Post, No. 1. G.A.R., arrived here to-day from Washington on a visit to Maher Post at the Hampton Soldiers' Home. They were met here by a delegation and a band, and were escorted to the Home, where they were received by Gov. Woodfin and Capt. Thompson, and handsomely entertained. They returned to Washington to-night.

McKINNEY, Texas, Aug. 7.--At 7 o'clock this morning a terrible rain commenced, and continued without ceasing until 9:30. At that time fully seven inches of the stickiest of mud covered the ground, and locomotion on the streets was nearly impossible.

PARIS, July 30.--The French republican press has no confidence in the results of that Anglo-French alliance which was the aim of the old "opportunist clan's" policy. "Since we made up our old quarrel," says the Evenement, "we have rendered incomparable services to England.

The oldest, brashest logs are selected for shingles, provided always they are not sound. If they are sound, they will make lumber; if they are doty, worm-eaten, fire-burnt, and disreputable generally, they are worked up into shingles. The prime consideration in shingle timber is to get wood that is sound and brash.

Fairfield County is now the onion garden of the State. The land there is adapted to the cultivation of onions, and they have immense yields. A resident of Southport boasts that from six pounds of seed he got 1,000 bushels of onions from a single acre of land.

Two large black bears were rolled into the river by the cow-catcher of an engine on the Philadelphia and Roading Railroad, near Catawissa, a few days ago.

OGDEN, Utah, Aug. 12.--The Denver and Rio Grande Railway is again temporarily blockaded by a wash-out near the Colorado line. It is expected that traffic will be resumed in a short time, the interruption not being as serious as the one recently created.

BERLIN, Aug. 12.--A letter from Crown Prince Frederick William to Prince Bismarck is gazetted. The Crown Prince says he is convinced that Germans are desirous of giving succor to friends in adversity, and he and his wife have therefore placed their names at the head of a subscription list in aid of the people who suffered by the recent earthquake in Ischia.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 12.--The Kimball House, the largest hotel in the South, was destroyed by fire this morning and not a vestige is left except the crumbling walls.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., Aug. 12.--D.O. Mills has presented the State with a magnificent piece of statuary representing Columbus at the Court of Queen Isabella. The work of art is 9 feet high and cost $35,000. It will be placed in the rotunda of the Capitol at Mr. Mills's expense.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 12.--The developments of to-day gave nothing of importance or interest to add to the chronicle of the bank troubles. Mr. Depauw went home last night, and matters connected with the First National remain in statu quo.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 12.--The Sunday-school for children to-day was conducted by the Rev. Victor Cornell, of Chautauqua, and that for adults in the amphitheatre by William A. Duncan, of Syracuse. There was an aggregate attendance of about 3,000 persons.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 12.--The crush at this place continues unabated. A great many of those who were here in the early part of the Summer have gone, but their places are being constantly filled by others, who come in from the mountains and other inland resorts.

LINCOLN, Neb. Aug. 12.--A heavy thunderstorm prevailed here yesterday. Three boys, named Robert Miller and William Miller, brothers, and Ernest Smith, who had taken refuge under a tree, were struck and instantly killed by lightning. Several houses were struck and four persons were injured. The Telephone Exchange was set on fire, but the flames were extinguished before much damage was done.

The Cleveland Club now holds the lead in the race for the championship of the League. Providence fell away to second place. This setback for the Rhode Island players is the result of defeats received at the hands of the Buffalo and Boston Clubs.

Wednesday next is the great stake day, and the owners of thorough-breds are busy preparing their entry lists for the large array of stakes. All the leading associations of the Eastern circuit close their stakes on Wednesday, and the managers have reason to expect a large list of entries.

The National Education Assembly at Asbury Park, N. J., closed last night. During the four days 12 sessions were held, and the attendance ranged from 2,000 to 6,000. The enthusiasm continued till the end.

The body of the headless man found on Plum Island beach on the 23d of July was on Friday last identified by the clothing and articles found upon it as Peter Nelson, a guide, employed in the millstone quarry at New-London, Conn. On the 16th of July Nelson went to New-York with John Johnson and John Benson, two of his countrymen.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12.--The propeller Nellie Torrant was entering the harbor this evening very much overloaded, and owing to the strain she cantered over on the port side, and the water began washing into her gangways. She was taken in two, and kept afloat until she arrived abreast of the pier when the boat suddenly filled and sank, creating some excitement although no one was lost.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 12.--The surf was so strong to-day that the steamer Plymouth Rock did not venture out of the harbor, but landed her passengers at Sandy Hook, and they came down over the New-Jersey Southern Railroad.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Aug. 12.--A painful uncertainty still exists in regard to financial matters. Mr. Barlow is reported as saying incidentally last night that he felt pretty sure the depositors in the Vermont National Bank were secure.

TOMBSTONE, Arizona, Aug. 12.--A report reached here yesterday from Heamosillo, Mexico, stating that the soldiers who were encamped 45 miles north-east of that place had mutinied on the 8th inst., killing their Captain and First Lieutenant. The mutineers fled to the mountains, taking their arms and ammunition. Gen. Topete left on Friday night for Ures with infantry and cavalry.

MOUNT WASHINGTON, N.H., Aug. 13.--W. H. Vanderbilt, wife, and party left the Glen House to-day. They will spend the night at Fayban's arriving at Saratoga to-morrow evening. George Vanderbilt. W.D. Stone, and H. McK. Twombly and their families will remain at the Glen House for the season.

CONCORD N.H., Aug. 13.--Stilson Hutchins, editor of the Washington Post, in an interview this morning, contradicted the statement that he is a candidate for the Clerkship of the next national House of Representatives. The Bakersfield Californian has joined Col. Hollister in discouraging men of small means from engaging in farming in this State. CLEVELAND, Aug. 13.--The Western Union to-day resumed its money order business to all points. The strike is very quiet and attracts but little attention. H.W. Jeffers, one of the original strikers, returned to work to-day at the Western Union office. He had received $40 from the brotherhood.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13.--Henry B. (or Buffalo) Miller, who was in the city this morning, unloosed himself to a reporter on the subject of the distillers and the part they propose to play in the next campaign.

On Sunday night an Italian limped into the Stagg-street police station, Brooklyn, and said he had been refused admission to St. Catharine's Hospital, although suffering from a bullet wound in the leg and a stab-wound in the shoulder.

A partial investigation into the causes leading to the suicide of young Patrick Kirby, of No. 495 Fifth-avenue, was made by Coroner Levy yesterday.
BOSTON, Aug. 13.--The British steamer Amethyst, from Havana, reports that at noon on Aug. 5 the port coal bunker was found to be on fire.

An ambulance was summoned early this morning to No. 26 Hamilton-street for John Gustave, a Swedish sailor, aged 21, who boarded there. At 11:30 o'clock last night he was returning home, and when two doors from his house he was assaulted by three men, who attempted to rob him.

The Brighton Beach track was dusty yesterday, and clouds arose at every movement of the horses. Precaution had been taken to sprinkle the stretch in front of the grand stand, so that the spectators were but slightly annoyed.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 14.--The text of the treaty of commerce and amity between Mexico and Germany has been officially published.

CAMP STAGER, ON TERRY'S LAKE, WYOMING, Aug. 12, via Fort Washakie, Aug. 13.--It was determined last night to move out camp this morning a few miles to a point where there would be more abundant grazing for the horses and mules.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 14.--This being the Grand Prize of Saratoga day the races were witnessed by the largest number of spectators of the reason. The programme warranted the large attendance, and those who were fortunate enough to be present witnessed four excellently contested ..

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 14.--Latest advices from the Gasport well, six miles east of Lockport, show no further indications of oil than that involved in striking a gas vein. The stockholders, however, seem to be encouraged, and declare that the poorest result will be a supply of gas for the village.
The assertion that the rivers and brooks in New-England are much smaller than formerly appears to be true in some cases.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 14.--A special from St. Albans to the Journal says: "The first meeting of the Directors of the South-eastern Railway Company since the Barlow failure was held to-day. There were present President Barlow and F.A. Metcalf.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 14.--A dispatch from Delphos, Ohio, to the Commercial Gazette says: A passenger train on the Toledo, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad was thrown from the track to-day near Abanaka Station. Engineer Melville Clark is thought to be fatally scalded. No other persons were hurt.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 14.--The spectators at the base-ball game to-day numbered 1,115. Both clubs batted hard. Providence leading with the stick, but losing the game through wretched fielding, and making inexcusable errors.

BRADFORD, Penn., Aug. 14.--A well-known Pennsylvania oil operator, who has recently returned from a visit to the petroleum districts of the Pacific coast, gives some interesting information in relation to them.
A sharp blow from the Chairman's solid litle hammer caused an abrupt cessation of business in the crowded Stock Exchange just before noon yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14, 1883. The acting Controller of the Currency has authorized the First National Bank of Perry, Iowa, to begin business with a capital of $50,000.

LONDON, Aug. 14.--A dispatch to the Standard from Madrid says that several Sergeants who took part in the revolt at Santo Domingo have been put to death at that place. They refused to make any disclosures in relation to the revolutionary plot.

In a letter from Loring A. Lothrop, dated at the United States consulate, Bristol, England, July 31, 1883, and published yesterday morning, complaint is made that "a most contemptible advantage is continually being taken in New-York and Montreal of the ignorance and poverty of certain men, who are induced by cattle shippers to accompany their consignments to this port."
MONTREAL Aug. 14.--The Prince of Hohenlohe, of Germany, the Earl of Latham, and Lord Elphinstone, of England, arrived here to-day, and intend to visit the North-west.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 14.--The steamer Mariposa, from Honolulu, arrived here this morning. Among her passengers were the Royal Hawaiian Band, consisting of 30 members, who are to participate in the conclave festivities.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 14.--Two unusual cases were reported at Police Head-quarters to-day. A watch was missed a few days ago from the residance of P.L. Netterhouse, in Fairmount. The theft was reported to the police with a description of the watch.

The Stock Exchange and college players of the Staten Island Club gave the Brooklyn professionals a very close fight at Washington Park yesterday, the amateurs coming within an ace of defeating the home team, though the former had not the services of their noted pitcher and short stop.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14.--An extra day's racing was given by the Pacific Coast Blood-horse Association yesterday. The first race, three-quarters of a mile, was won by Jim Renwick, with Douglas second and Joe G. third. Time--1:14 .

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 14.--A largely attended meeting of the stockholders of the Southern New-England Telephone Company was held in this city this afternoon for the purpose of empowering the Directors to ratify the proposition for a consolidation of all the New-England telephone companies.
WAUKESHA, Wis., Aug. 14.--All the facts in the case of the successful attempt of confidence men to rob Mr. William Young, President of a bank in Reading, Penn., are made public to-day.
The Western Union Telegraph Company, voting presumably upon the advice of its attorneys, resorted to a novel dodge yesterday in its struggle with its striking operators and linemen.
LONDON, Aug. 15.--The steam-ship Crane, (Br.,) Capt. Robinson, from Quebec, has arr. at Dover.

CHICAGO Ill., Aug. 14.--The party of prominent foreign officials and representative business and professional people from the East en route for the Yellowstone Park under the guidance of Rufus Hatch reached here this morning. They depart for the North on Thursday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14.--The wicket in the Eastern Penitentiary door swung open at about 7 o'clock this morning, and two middle-aged men, after peeping cautiously out like rats watching for a cat lying in wait, stepped into the street and started to walk rapidly toward Twenty-thirdstreet.
A mass-meeting of cigar-box makers was held last night, under the auspices of Union No. 1, at No. 28 Avenue A. Union No. 1 has 91 members, all of whom are employes of William Wickes ...
OTTAWA, Aug. 14.--The Hon. James Cockburn, ex-Speaker of the Canadian Parliament, died at his residence in Ottawa at 9 o'clock this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 14.--The Philadelphia Times has information that James Graham, of Darby Township. Chester County, was on Sunday night attacked by his stepson, John Wright, and so frightfully beaten with a heavy ash base-ball bat that he has been insensible ever since.

The complete programme for the excursion in celebration of the opening of the Northern Pacific Railroad has been issued, and it provides for a very interesting trip extending over a period of about four weeks.
MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 14.--An Ontario shipper of cattle has contracted with the Allan Line for taking across the ocean 10,000 head of cattle via this port and Boston this Fall.

The meeting of the Republican State Committee at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, at noon today, promises to be brief and uneventful. The only business for it to transact is the fixing of the date and place for holding the State Convention.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14.--At the session this morning of the Amalgamated Iron and Steel Workers' Convention the reports of the Committees on Ways and Means and Claims were read.
DENVER, Col., Aug. 14.--The general Grand Chapter of the Royal Arch Masons of the United States was in session here to-day, and elected the following officers: Alfred F. Chapman, of Massachusetts,...

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 14.--At the anniversary of the founding of the Women's Home Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church here to-day Bishop Harris presided. Mrs. R.S. Rust, of Cincinnati, Corresponding Secretary.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 14.--The Senate Apportionment Committee to-day negatived the Lowry (House) Congressional Apportionment bill.
VIENNA, Aug. 14.--A telegram has been received from Fvohsdorf announcing that Count de Chambord is wrestling with death.
The passengers of the steam-ship Newport, of the Ward Line, which arrived at Lower Quarantine Monday evening, were allotted to land yesterday. After she had been fumigated.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 14.--Four hundred fresh air fund children from New-York arrived here by special steam-boat this morning. After breakfast at the Temperance Rooms 59 went west to Sand Lake, Rensselaer County, and the others to Clinton County.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 14.--The Clevelands lost to-day's game in the first inning by making four errors and allowing the visitors to pile up four runs.
W.H. Chesebro, a young Stoningtonian, is in luck. A few days ago he went outside of Sheffield's Reef on a fishing trip, and succeeded in catching only one little chub mackerel.

The steam-ships Canada, of the French Line; Greece, of the National Line; Oder, of the North German Lloyd; Pavonia, of the Cunard Line, and Amsterdam, of the Netherlanas Mail, will sail for Europe to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14.--When the news of the failure of George William Ballou Co. was received in the stock market today for a minute or two there was a panic.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 14.--Carlos Day, of West Avon, aged 75 years, while entering his house on Monday afternoon, was struck by lightning and instantly killed.

A man's clothing was found on the sea wall of the Battery Park by Officer Murray, of the Newstreet station yesterday morning, and not long afterward Edward Cody, a boatman, discovered off Pier No. 1 the nude body of a man of 65 years of age.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 14.--Staff Commander Boulton, appointed by the Lords of Admiralty to survey the Georgian Bay, has arrived here and reported to the Deputy Minister of Marine and Fisheries, who will give him the necessary instructions for the commencement of his work.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 14.--W.P. Edgarton, Chief Postal Inspector of this district, has received a telegram from the Postmaster at Tishomingo, Indian Territory, stating that his office had been fired into by a gang of Indian desperadoes, who tried to murder him, and that he had fled to Muskogee.

NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario, Aug. 14.--Don Luis L. Dominguez, Envoy Extraordinary of the Argentine Republic, with his secretary and members of the Legation, and Joshy Teraschima Munsnore, the Japanese Minister, are here.

WATKINS, N.Y., Aug. 14.--Owing to rough water the rowing-races fixed for to day were postponed until 9 o'clock to-morrow morning. Courtney, Edward and Wallace Ross, Lee. Griffin, and Plaisted are in the first heat, and Hanlan, Teemer, Sharlow. Ten Eyck, and Hosmer in the second.

The second day of the second Summer meeting at Monmouth Park was well attended, and over a fast track there were six food races, and only one favorite was successful during the day. The mutual pool dividends were therefore fairly remunerative, and paid $19.75 on the first race, ...

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 14.--Charles A. Knoblach, a confectioner here, has his wife arrested yesterday for assault. At the hearing in the evening Mrs. Knoblach told a pitiful story of the life she had led for some time past.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14.--The Treasury Department now has under consideration the question of the duty on sulphate of cinchonidia under the new tariff act.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14.--The Western Union Telegraph Company to-day filed in the United States Circuit Court in this city its demurrer to the suit brought by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania for over-reaching its legal rights in consolidating with different competing companies and monopolizing the business of telegraphy in this State.
TITUSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 14.--Grandin, No. 6, Balltown District, was drilled into sand this afternoon, and at first gave indications of being a very small well.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 14.--Advices received by the steamer Mariposa, which arrived today from Honolulu, state that sharp shocks of earthquake have been felt at Plo and Kahola, fortunately resulting in no damage. Copious rains have fallen recently, improving the prospects of the sugar crop. Major Gulick has been appointed Minister of the Interior.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14.--At a meeting of the World's Arbitration League held here this evening the following-named gentlemen were elected Vice-Presidents for their respective States; Dr. Joseph Ramsey, Tennessee;
CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 14.--The Sanitary Council has ordered that vessels arriving from Smyrna be subjected to observation for 24 Fours in the Dardanelles.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Aug. 14.--The labor difficulty at the Bethlehem Iron-works came to an abrupt termination to-day. The Andrew Lee branch of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers having collapsed, the President of the local branch visited Philadelphia yesterday to have some of the promises of financial aid made ...

The contract for laying the foundation of the pedestal of the statue of Liberty Enlightening the World was yesterday awarded to F. Hopkinson Smith at $3.94 a cubic yard. The whole cost of the work will be $51,000 or $52,000. The contractor will furnish all the material except the cement.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 14.--One of the wooden buildings of the powder-works at Hazardville was blown to pieces this morning and an employe named James Leonard was killed. The cause of the explosion is unknown, but is supposed to have been carelessness. About a ton of powder exploded. The lose is small.

Ex-Excise Commissioner Morris Friedsam, now a Collector of Internal Revenue in the Third District, has written to Mayor Edson concerning the alleged defects in the business methods of the old Excise Board to which the Commissioners of Accounts called attention.
LAREDO, Texas, Aug. 14.--On Saturday night "Jeff" Miller, of Laredo, who had been on a protracted spree in Monterey, Mexico, mistook a private residence for a house of ill-fame.

The resignation of United States Marshal Joel B. Erhardt as President and Director of the Postal Telegraph Company will be accepted at a meeting of the Directors to-day, and John W. Mackey, the California millionaire, will be elected a Director in his stead.
The accounts of ex-Collector Buell, of the Thirtieth New-York Revenue District, have this day been balanced and referred to the accounting officer of the Treasury Department.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 14.--Frederick Lehman, a brick-layer employed on the new Park Theatre, made a misstep this afternoon and fell the height of five stories, a distance of 80 feet, to the basement below. His neck was broken and he died almost instantly. He leaves a family.

LONDON, Aug. 14.--The Kempton Park August racing meeting opened to-day. The race for the Kempton Park Mid-weight Handicap Plate was won by Mr. W.M.Redfern's 4-year-old b.f. Galvanic. Mr. L.H. Wilkinson's 8-year-old b.f. Snapshot came in second, and Mr. F. Hardinge's ...
CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 14.--A Mr. Peacock committed suicide in Barnwell County, S.C., on Saturday by taking 30 grains of morphine. No cause is known for the act.

About 40 sporting men assembled in the back-yard of Harry Hill's residence in Flushing, Long Island, at suprise yesterday morning, to witness a prize-fight between John Dempsey, of this City, and John Boylan, of Engand.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14.--The leading produce markets were less unsteady to-day, and less weak, if not all stronger. The feeling at the outset was very uncertain, with much more than the usual anxious watching of the news from New-York.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 14.--A prize-fight between William Wagner, of Pittsburg, and Albert Cannaup, of New-York, was fought this morning at White Hall, a few miles from this city. It resulted is a victory for Cannaup, who knocked Wagner out in the fourth round.

FAIR VIEW. N.J., Aug. 14.--A sad drowning accident occurred in the river near Herbertville this morning.

YORK, Penn., Aug. 14.--Judge Jere S. Black, who is suffering from a urinary affection, is seriously ill, but at 11 o'clock to-night is resting quietly under the influence of oplates. No immediate danger is apprehended by his physicians.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14.--The Washington regatta held today was one of the most interesting events ever seen upon the Potomac River. The weather was cool and cloudy and the water smooth.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 14.--President Marco A. Soto, of the Republic of Honduras, last night received intelligence of the serious illness of his wife at San Francisco, and immediately started for that city.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14.--Commander Pearson, commanding the Wachusett, reports to the Navy Department the arrival of that vessel at Apia, Samoan Islands, May 10, 23 days from Honolulu.

Persons interested in the importation, manufacture, and sale of spirituous liquors have organized the "Distillers' Wine and Spirit Exchange," of this City. Several meetings have been held and more than 100 dealers have joined the organization.

LE ROY, N.Y., Aug. 14.--C.R. Witters is an old and prominent farmer living 10 miles from this village. His farm is worth $12,000, and he is probably worth as much more. His family is highly respected, consisting of a wife and several grown-up daughters.
CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y, Aug. 14.--The Rev. Frank Russell, of Mansfield, Ohio, conducted the advanced normal review this morning in the Congregational House.

The examination of the charges against District Attorney Downing, of Queens County, commenced yesterday before ex-Attorney-General Fairchild, who was appointed by Gov. Cleveland as a Commissioner to take the testimony in the case.

LONDON, Aug. 14.--There was a long debate, characterized by much obstruction on the part of the Irish members, in the House of Commons last night on a vote for the legal expenses incurred in the recent criminal prosecutions in Ireland.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 14.--The Funding Board is still engaged in examining and classifying bonds to be funded. A large amount, both of the State debt proper and railroad bonds, is on hand. Up to date there are as many bonds of the last named series as the State debt proper bonds receipted for.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 14.--Prof. A. Muller Neuhof, of New-York City, was to-night unanimously elected conductor of the Cleveland Gosgoerlin.

BUFFALO, Aug. 14.--The sixth annual meeting of the American Library Association opened in this city to-day. Some 60 of the best known librarians of the country were present. Mr. Justin Winsor, Librarian of Harvard University, is President of the association, and occupied the chair.
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 14.--The State Agricultural Society met here at 10 o'clock this morning, President Thomas Hardeman presiding.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 14.--The Right Rev. L.Z. Morean, Bishop of St. Hyacinth, has issued a pastoral to the people of his diocese threatening excommunication to any Catholic who may connect himself with the Faculty of Victoria or any other Protestant university.
SARATOGA, Aug. 14.--The hotels in Saratoga are rapidly filling up, and the last month of the season at this fashionable resort promises to be as lively as the first two months were dull.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 14.--George Blair, of NewYork; Assemblyman Godfrey Ernst, of Buffalo; Assemblyman David Healy, of Roshester; Charles W. Miller and T.W. Clark, of this city, composing the Executive Committee of the Central Labor Union, had a secret meeting at the Globe Hotel today.

LIMA, Aug. 14, via Galveston, Texas.--El Pueblo of yesterday published a decree by Gen. Iglesias that all Peruvians between the ages of 21 and 60 years, and all foreigners over 1 year of age, must pay a poll tax of 1 silver sol.

LONDON, Aug. 14.--The standard states that the dispatches received from Madagascar fully confirm the first accounts of the differences between the French and English at Tamatave. "Should France," says the Standard, "not offer explanations England, no doubt, must demand them."

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 14.--The Captain of the Government steamer Newfield, now on the way to Hulifax from Pictou, has received instructions from Ottawa to lay the Cape Sable Island cable to the main line, and also to proceed to Grand Manan to repair the cable there, which has been out of order for some time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 14.--Father Prendergast, Vicar General of this diocese, speaking on the subject of the appointment by the Pope of the Rev. P.W. Riordan, of Chicago, as coadjutor to Archbishop Alemany and the statement ...

The State Council of the Order of United American Mechanics met yesterday in Masonic Hall, No. 117 West Twenty-third-street. About 200 delegates from the 93 lodges in the State were present. The order was founded in Philadelphia in 1856 and has benevolent aims.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 14.--The jail at Chatham, Va., eontaining the three negro prisoners who killed a man because he refused to give them a ride, continues under the surveillance of the Danville Grays.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 14--Slade, the pugilist, accompanied by Jack Brighton, his trainer, and Rice, his manager, arrived at Independence, Mo., yesterday. Slade will go into training at once.

WASHINGTON, Aug 14.--Gen. E. Whittlesey, who with Clinton B. Fisk, was sent by Commissioner Price to the Creek Nation to see if the two hostile factions in that tribe could not be harmonized, returned to this city to-day with the very satisfactory treaty of peace which has been concluded.
BOSTON, Aug. 14.--The first intimation of the embarrassment of the banking firm of George W. Ballou Co. was received here at about noon to-day, in private dispatches from New-York.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug 14.--Washington R. Christian is in jail here on a commitment by Justice Cubberty. He is charged with stealing, at Bordentown, on Sunday night, the steam propeller City of Detroit. The vessel had been in his possession at Philadelphia some days previous, but ...
ROCHESTER., N.Y., Aug. 14.--The August races opened here this afternoon. The weather was fine and the track was in fair condition. The attendance was as large as on former opening days.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Aug. 14.--Jacob H. Starin, a prominent resident of Fultonville, and brother of the Hon. John H. Starin, of New-York, had his skull fractured by a horse's kick to-day. Seven pieces of the skull were removed, and he is dying.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14.--Capt. Pearson, commanding the Wachusett, in a report from Apia, Samoan Islands, gives a description of a terrific storm accompanied by shocks of earthquake which visited the Samoan group on the night of March 24, wrecking several merchant vessels and causing considerable damage on shore.

Last evening there was a large attendance at the California Academy of Sciences, when H.W. Harkness, M.D., read a very important paper on the fossil footprints of the so-called prehistoric Nevada man, named by him Homo Nevadensis. The paper was of special interest and was applauded at its close.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Aug. 14.--A mysterious light appears nightly about three feet above the railroad track at Palatine Bridge, and some declare that a human hand has been seen above it.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14.--Cornelius Vanderbilt and wife gave a picnic to-day on Gooseberry Island. Luncheon parties were given by Mrs. George W. Wales and Mrs. Thomas Hunter. Dinner parties were given this evening by E.L. Winthrop and Mrs. William Astor.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 14.--News was received here to-day that the schooner Challenge, Capt. Hodgdon, is ashore on Long Beach, Cape Race, Newfoundland. Her cargo of 60,000 pounds of fish has been dammed. The vessel is owned by J.G. Tarr Co., and is insured here.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 14.--The State Library Building was sold to James W. Eaton Co. for $800. The only other bid made was $537, by Andrew J. Calvin. The building originally cost $70,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14.--Capt. Conner, of the Pennsylvania pilot-boat Howard, reported a sunken wreck bearing west-north-west 25 miles distant from Cape Henlopen. The wreck consists of a small schooner, with spars and sails, the mainsail appearing to be set. It is dangerous to navigation.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 14.--Miss Elizabeth R. Phillips, a niece of ex Mayor Phillips, began a suit to-day in the Circuit Court against Ernst Meincke, one of the wealthy carriage manufacturers, for breach of promise, claiming $5,000 damages.

CAPE MAY, Aug. 13.--It is easy to see the minute you set your foot in the town that it is not a New-York place, and just as easy to see why people from the Metropolis do not put themselves out of the way to come here.

Julius Schneitzlein, of No. 24 Greenwichstreet, this City, yesterday complained to the Jersey City police that Herman Tremborn had robbed him of $650, and, he suspected, had taken refuge in Jersey City.
ROME, Aug. 15.--The Pope has sent a messenger to Spain to confer with the Nuncio in that country on the agitation there and to deliver an autograph letter from his Holiness to King Alfonso.
Over 3,000 people visited Washington Park, Brooklyn, yesterday in the full expectation of seeing an exciting contest between the Brooklyn American Alliance team and the St. Louis American team.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 15.--A Little Rock special to the Gazette says that Pine Bluffs was visited at 4:30 this afternoon by a heavy wind and rain storm. Several houses were unroofed, and a number of unfinished brick buildings were partly wrecked. A colored woman Cora Lee, was killed by a falling awning.

One of our retired divines has instituted suit against a prominent attorney for funeral fees and salary subscriptions, but the case will probably be tried in East Lucas, as our Justices are both barred on technical grounds. We await developments.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 15.--The secret Irish national organizations of Chicago, mainly those of the Clan-na-Gael, held their seventh annual demonstration at Ogden's Grove this afternoon to raise funds to carry on the agitation in Ireland.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 15.--W.U. Hensel, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee; Joseph Powell, the Democratic candidate for State Treasurer, and Robert Taggart, the candidate for Auditor-General, arrived in this city this afternoon.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 17.--A rumor was current this morning that the Pittsburg and Western Railroad, a connection of the Wabash system was in financial difficulty, and that notes or James Callery, the President of the road, had gone to proest.

Numerous complaints have been made concerning the custom of charging storage fees for baggage left is certain railroad stations longer than 24 hours. Yesterday afternoon a TIMES reporter visited the various stations in this City and Jersey City to ascertain to what extent the custom prevailed.

WARWICK, N.Y., Aug. 15.--Ezra Sanford, one of the veterans of the war of 1812, died at his residence here yesterday afternoon. He was in the ninetieth year of his age, and had been a successful business man for 70 years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15.--Gov. Cameron came to this city to-day, it is said, to meet Senators Mahone and Riddleberger, and have a conference with them on the political situation in Virginia.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 15.--The great boom that Louisville expected with the opening of the great Southern Exposition has not yet arrived, but the local press announces daily that it is on the road and coming fast.
The Louisville Courier-Journal prints the following extracts from a letter from Major Anderson, written three weeks before the attack on Fort Sumter:

SARATOGA, Aug. 15.--Saratoga was thrown into great commotion about 2 o'clock this after noon by an alarm of fire, and simultaneously smoke was seen rising from one of the stores in the Grand Union Hotel block.

Judge HOADLY has made what may be called a double-barreled denial of the story that he paid $50,000 for his nomination to the Governorship of Ohio. Confronted by a correspondent of the New-York Herald, he expressed a certain sense of indignation that this was the first representative of any newspaper in the United States that has ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 15.--At noon to-day, in front of the Post office, Dr. Stanhope Jones administered a severe flogging with a cowhide to Dr. Gustave Devron. Devron cried "Watch" and "Murder," and started to run, when Jones drew a revolver.

An attachment against the property of George W. Cecil, Amasa D. Ward, and L.M. Cornish, of the firm of Cecil, Ward Co., bankers and brokers, who suspended last Monday, was granted by Judge Potter in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, upon the application of the Wall-Street National Bank.
John Griffin, of No. 123 Ninth-street, Jersey City, yesterday undertook to chastise his wife with a poker, but missed her and struck his 6-year-old son James on the head, inflicting a severe wound.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15.--At the session of the convention of the iron and steel workers today the report of the Committee on Constitution gave rise to a lengthened discussion, whose only result at the hour of adjournment was the fixing of Oct. 1 as the time for assuming once in the association.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Aug. 15.--The funeral services of the remains of Mrs. W.B. Allison were held at the family residence this afternoon at 3 o'clock, and were attended by most of the principal citizens of Dubuque.

A delegation of residents on Washington Heights called upon Park Commissioner Viele at his house on Tuesday evening and presented a plan for connecting the Washington Heights region with the annexed district and the rapid transit system.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15.--The anthracite coal tonnage of the various carrying companies for July aggregated 2,615,686 tons, being a decrease as compared with the corresponding month of last year of 141,564 tons.

George William Ballou, the head of the NewYork and Boston banking-house which suspended payment yesterday, was formerly Cashier of the First National Bank, of Greenfield. and is personally known to the officers of the Third National Bank,....

Dr. C.E. Martin, of Bailey-avenue, King's Bridge, was rowing his wife on the North River at Two Hundred and Twentieth-street, yesterday afternoon, when an object in a bunch of eel-grass attracted the attention of Mrs. Martin.

The sub-committee of the United States Senate Committee on Labor and Education continued the taking of testimony from telegraphers yesterday in the Federal Building. Mr. John S. McClelland, the Secretary of the Executive Board of the Kights of Labor, was racalled, and submitted specimens of iron-clad oaths which the committee had requested him to furnish.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Aug. 15.--The Directors of the St. Albans Trust Company have issued a statement to the effect that the Vermont National Bank owes the company $55,000, which is secured by stock of the bank, and a considerable portion of this may yet be saved.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 15.--An open letter has been addressed to Capt. J.D. Rhodes by the Canadian authorities stating that any attempt by him, or any other persons, to swim the whirlpool rapids will be looked upon as coming from an insane person, and that he will be prevented from ...

CHARLOTTE, Mich., Aug. 15.--A collision occurred on the race-track here this morning between the trotting horses Raymond and Banker Rothschild. Raymond was killed outright and the other horse was dangerously injured. An offer of $8,000 had been refused for Raymond.
TOMBSTONE, Arizona, Aug. 15.--A special courier from the head-quarters of the army operating against the Indians in Oposura, Sonora, Mexico, says:

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug.15.--At the adjourn ed joint meeting of the coal operators and miners to-day a committee of eight were chosen to lay be fore the next Legislature the question of securing coal. A standing arbitration board of two miners and two operators was also chosen who are to select a fifth man when any matter demands arbitration.
The Italian bark Maria, with a cargo of rags from the Mediterranean, arrived at Upper Quarantine yesterday.
HARTFORM, Conn., Aug. 15.--Two burglars named Hauer, who were held for trial in the Tolland County jail, broke out this afternoon with another prisoner.

From time to time there are received at Washington, by the Government, statements from its oven officers in the South of a condition of lawlessness in the regions with which they are connected. The substance of these frequently finds its way to the press of the North.

There was a noticeable absence of exciting influences in Wall-street yesterday, and toward the close of business hours the stock market assumed a steadier tone than had characterized it on the three previous days.
Moses Hawkins, of Sullivan, and his brother, Dexter A. Hawkins, of New-York, recently had an exciting race with a large bear.

The Hotel Bristol, at the north-west corner of Fifth-avenue and Forty-second-street, is composed of three buildings, one of which stands on a parcel of land, 37 by 100 feet, leased by its owners, Robert J. and Louisa M. Livingston, to William H. Webb, for a term of 18 years and 6 months, beginning October, 1862.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 15.--The Detroits won to-day's game in their last inning by a piece of batting which brought them 4 earned runs.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 15.--Gov. Hendricks, of Indiana, arrived here this afternoon and has taken rooms at the Grand Union. He comes direct from Indianapolis, and is accompanied by Mrs. Hendricks.
Bark Grad Senj, (Aust.,) Tichiaz, Lisbon 36 ds., with iron ore to order--vessel to Bela Cosulich.

Assurances were made by members of the firm of George William Ballou Co. yesterday that that firm would emerge from its prospective liquidation with clean hands and with the ability to resume business.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 15.--Returns to the Railroad Commissioner show that during the six months ending Aug. 1, 160 persons were killed and 401 injured on the railroads of this State.

There is an attractive sound some way to the title "Point of Pines," We desired rest, the quiet of the forest that the above name seemed to imply that we should find on the one hand and the grand old ocean on the other.

LULING, Texas, Aug. 15.--Yesterday afternoon Lawrence Denman met the Rev. R.G. Sewell on the street, and, drawing a 44-calibre navy revolver, fired at the minister four times, inflicting wounds which in a short time caused his death.

BOSTON, Aug. 15.--Lieut.-Gov. Oliver Ames, in an interview, corrects some misstatements made by a correspondent of the Tribune regarding his position in the last campaign and his attitude toward Gov. Butler. He says:
We are enabled to give the text of the telegram received in Stockholm this week from the Swedish circumpolar observation party, which has wintered at Spitzbergen.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15.--A bill was filed in the Superior Court to-day by Robert J. Speck and James Dunn, of Hull, England, against the Pullman Palace Car Company, which involves the title to a tract of land contiguous to the town of Pullman, the Pullman Company being charged with fraud in obtaining deeds and a title to it.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 15.--The Republican-Straight-out Convention met to-day in this city. A platform was adopted favoring a strict adherence to Republican principles and a protective tariff, and indorsing James G. Blaine for the Presidency.

SARATOGA, Aug. 15.--Although the entries for the four races announced to be run to-day by the Saratoga Racing Association only numbered 22, there was an unusually good attendance at the course when the bell rang for the first race.
Justice Rusch, at Hoboken, on Tuesday night, dismissed the complaint against Edward P, Reichhelm, who was charged by Sophie Behnke, a discharged domestic, with felonious assault.

The Republican State Committee has performed the duty of calling the next State Convention in a quiet and perfunctory way, which shows that its experience in directing one State campaign has subdued its spirit.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 15.--The Essex Savings Bank has foreclosed a mortgage of $70,000 on St. Mary's Church Lawrence, on account of the inability of the priests to raise sufficient funds to pay the interest, and the property will be sold at auction on Sept. 6. This is a portion of the property owned by the Augustinian Society. The structure originally cost over $200,000.
We are told that there is a gentleman living across the river in Brownville who is the father of 28 children.
Ex-Congressman John M. Davy, of Rochester, is at the Gilsey House. William H. Seward, of Auburn, N.Y., and Edward S. Isham, of Chicago, are at the Windsor Hotel.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 15.--Thomas G. Hunt, the New-York merchant who mysteriously disappeared in June and who was reported as being in Cambridge, England, has turned up at Elizabethtown, Essex County, this State.
Mrs. Matilda Schultz, aged 46, the wife of John Schultz, a dyer, residing at No. 66 Raymondstreet, Brooklyn, attempted to commit suicide at Brighton Beach, Coney Island, on Tuesday evening.

WATKINS, N.Y., Aug. 15.--That which was suggested in THE TIMES to-day as a possibility that Hanlan and Courtney would not meet on the water at this place name to pass. Courtney was beaten, many persons thought, by foul rowing on Lee's part in the first trial heat, he finishing third.

The police of the Fifth Precinct sent the following message to Police Head-quarters yesterday: FIFTH PRECINCT, 5:13 A.M.--R.W. Towle of Clinton, Fla., found sick in street and sent to Chambers-Street Hospital.
ALEXANDRIA, Aug. 15.--The number of a deaths here yesterday from cholera was 40. LONDON, Aug. 15.--There were 376 deaths from cholera in Egypt on Tuesday.

LAKEWOOD, N.Y., Aug. 15.--The Cleveland Grays, the company that escorted Garfield in the inauguration procession, and acted as his bodyguard at the obsequies, is spending 10 days in Camp Oriental. To-day 100 Sir Knights of Oriental Commandery, of Cleveland, with many ladies, came to spend the remainder of the week.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 15.--The thirtysecond annual meeting of the Association for the Advancement of Science met at the University of Minnesota at 10 o'clock. At 9 o'clock the members of the Standing Committee met in secret session to perfect the organization and to further plans for the present session.

An indignant bull was quoted in yesterday's TIMES as denouncing a broker who, when Western Union was selling at 74 on Tuesday, suddenly offered to supply any gentleman with that security at 73 , whereupon, of course, the price fell to the figure which he named.

John J. Reily, a telegraph messenger employed at the Western Union branch office at No. 852 Broadway, delivered last Monday to Mrs. Anna Davis, of No. 47 West Sixteenth-street, a dispatch purporting to be from Mr. William Hutchinson, asking her to call at No. 195 Broadway, and receive some money which had been sent her by telegraph.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 15.--The first returns from the recent State election coming from counties adjacent to Louisville, or from along the lines of the railroads, seemed to indicate that at last a goodly majority of the electors of Kentucky had voted in favor of a ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15.--A decision was rendered to-day by United States Commissioner Bundy in the case of Alpha B. Beall, who was charged with a violation of the pension laws, in having taken an excessive fee for obtaining a pension for the mother of a soldier killed during the late war.
An excursion under the auspices of Thaddeus Stevens Post, No. 255, G.A.R., to Newburgon-the Hudson, will be held on Wednesday, Sept. 5.
This will be the third day of the second Summer meeting at Monmouth Park, and six races are to be decided.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 15.--Late last night James McDonough was fatally shot by John W. Doy in Frank Kelley's saloon, near the City Hospital. McDonough, who was drunk, entered Doy's bedroom in a threatening manner, and accused Doy of having robbed him on the previous night.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 15.--Highly sensational reports have been sent from this city of the drowning of Mrs. Anne Knablauch in the canal on Tuesday morning.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 15.--Complaint was made to-day before Police Justice Caine by Stephen C.B. Fish against Lieut. William Black, of the Salvation Army, for committing an assault upon himself and wife at one of the drills of the army at the barracks in Freeze Hall.
TITUSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 15.--The market to-day has been very excited, especially on account of the opposite direction to that expected taken by business.

LONDON, Aug. 4.--"The season is dead! Long live the season!" Its successor is getting ready to be crowned next year. The new season is an infant in the country, imbibing strength from moor and mountain.

The brokers who have endeavored to infuse life into the New-York Stock Clearing Association met yesterday afternoon in the office of Kidder, Peabody Co. and determined to abandon their efforts for the time being.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15.-- People of this village are elated by the news from the Republican State Committee. Not a man is found who does not assert that a better place for the meeting could not have been selected.
OTTAWA, Aug. 15.--The report cabled that a disease of virulent type had broken our at Bristol, England, among Canadian cattle is generally discredited.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 15.--A tornado swept over the city this afternoon. Great damage was done. Three railway stations were unroofed within a radius of 200 feet, and two business houses, a boarding-house, and a large foundry suffered serious damage in the same block. Twenty buildings were partially unroofed and seven blown entirely down.
CHICAGO, Aug. 15.--In spite of the signs of the coming end of the strike the strikers profess to be as confident as ever of an ending of the trouble that will be satisfactory to them.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15.--The following circular, with regard to the payment of bonds embraced in the one hundred and twenty-first call, was issued at the Treasury Department this afternoon:
The healthful tendency of the stock market was not disturbed yesterday by the announcement of the suspension of E.C. Stedman Co., bankers and brokers, No. 36 Broadstreet.

SARATOGA, Aug. 15.--The announcement that Samuel J. Tilden has purchased a team of fast horses from Kentucky is accepted by the Democratic politicians here as a final settlement of the question whether he intends to "run" for the Presidency next year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15.--Ex-Congressman Amos Townsend, of Ohio, who declined renomination last Fall, and whose strong Republican district was carried by the Democrats in the landslide of November, in the course of an interview to-day said:

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 15.--A special dispatch to the News from San Antonio says: "Heavy losses of cattle, which have did for want of water, have been reported in the southern and the south-eastern ranges."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15.--Inspector Haworth, who had general supervisory charge of Indian schools, and who recently returned to this city from the West, reports good progress in the construction and equipment of the new industrial Indian schools to be established in accordance with the provisions of the last Indian Appropriation bill.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 15.--The third session of the American Library Association was held here to-day. The attendance was large.

NEWPORT, Aug. 15.--A large and fashionable throng met at the Casino tennis-court this morning for the purpose of witnessing the courttennis-match between Harry Boakes, the Canadian champion, and Thomas Pettitt, the champion of America.

DETROIT, Aug. 15.--The Prohibition State Convention met to-day at Eaton Rapids. The convention voted to raise $100,000 as a campaign fund; indorsed the platform of the National Convention at Chicago; declared in favor ...

YORK, Penn., Aug. 15.--There was no perceptible change in the condition of Judge Black today. At 9 o'clock this evening he was resting easily under the influence of opiates. Dr. Garnet, of Washington, arrived this evening.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 15.--As showing the extent of leprosy in the Hawaiian Islands, the figures received from Honolulu state that the number of lepers admitted to the Hawaiian Asylum between the years 1865 and 1879 was 1.827.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15.--The result of the Census Office lottery was announced today, and clerks are happy or sorrwful as their names appear on the active or furlough roll. The whole proceeding is a very strange one, and its propriety under the civil service rules may well be questioned.

The Aqueduct Commission met in the Mayor's office yesterday afternoon. The Mayor presided, and all the members except Commissioner Spencer were present. Commissioner Thompson presented an elaborate report which had been prepared by the engineers of the Department of Public Works in reply to a proposition.
Lord COLERIDGE is actually on the ocean, on the way to receive those "Impressions of America" which, when they are reproduced in type by the British tourist, seem so uniform and monotonous.

A pigeon-shooting-match took place yesterday on Thomas King's property, about a mile south of White Plains, in which 18 of the best shots in Westchester County took part. Each man shot at three birds with the following result:

ST. Louis, Aug. 15.--There was a collision on the Iron Mountain Railroad this morning, resulting in the loss of life and property. At 9:30 o'clock No. 15 freight train broke down 57 miles below St. Louis.

BOSTON, Aug. 15.--The meeting of the creditors of Shaw Brothers, held here to-day, was largely attended, not alone by Boston boot, shoe, and leather men, but by representatives of the trade in all the New-England States and to NewYork City.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 15.--The town of Middlefield celebrated its one hundredth anniversary to-day. The exercises were held in a tent capable of holding 2,000 people. An address of welcome was delivered by Metcalf J. Smith.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 15.--It is reported that an injunction will be issued against the General commanding the British forces here preventing the military bands from playing on Sundays until the courts decide upon the legality of such music on the streets on that day.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 15.--The election of officers of the General Grand Council of Royal and Select Masons took place yesterday at the Triennial Assembly now in session, with the following result: M.P.G.G.M.--G.M. Osgood, of Buffalo.
LONG BEACH, N.J., Aug. 15.--Theodore F. Sperry, one of the wealthiest and most prominent citizens of Harris's Station, has eloped with the village schoolmistress.

Herman Stehringer, an immigrant who arrived last Monday on the steam-ship Lessing, reported at Castle Garden yesterday that he was swindled at Havre by a ticket agent, who appears to have fleeced a large number of poor immigrants.
CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 15.--The funeral of Major George H. Chandler, of Baltimore, brother of Secretary Chandler, took place at the Unitarian Church, in this city, this afternoon.

Yesterday was the ninth day of the August meeting at Brighton Beach, and a large crowd was present despite the threatening weather. There were six races on the programme and all but one gave satisfaction.

ALBANY, Aug. 15.--The Controller is receiving daily the statements of miscellaneous corporations of their gross earnings for the year ending June 30, upon which to base the tax levied by the corporation tax law of 1881.

UTICA, Aug. 15.--This evening a score or more of men tore up the track of the Utica and Mohawk Street Railroad Company, in the eastern part of the city, in front of the places of E. M. Everst, R.S. Remington, Hugh Davis, and John N. Keliey, the track at these points being laid during the day.

CAMP BISHOP, FORKS OF WIND RIVER, Wyoming, Aug. 14, via Fort Washatie, Aug. 15.--The President and his party are encamped at the Forks of the Wind River, upon the same ground occupied last year by Gen. Sheridan.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15, 1883. Frank W. Lyon has been appointed Post master at Toulon, Stark County, Ill., vice George A. Thomas, resigned.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 15.--The Republicans hold their County Convention to-morrow, and on Saturday the Democrats held theirs. A long, close, and exciting campaign will follow. The Republican primaries were held to-night.

While patroling his beat near the Bronx River, in Tremont, early yesterday morning, Officer Brady, of the Thirty-fourth Precinct, was accosted by an Italian, who said he was searching for a wagon in which to remove a dead body, and he asked the policeman to direct him to a place where he could hire one.

Gen. Robert Lenox Banks, President of the State Forestry Association, accompanied the special committee of the senate, empowered to make an inquiry into the various methods of preserving the woodland of the Adirondack region, during a recent visit to Caldwell, Lake ...
TORONTO, Aug. 15.--The result of the first day's play between the Canadian and United States teams in the international cricket-match resulted in a great surprise.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15.--Shortly before midnight the immense works of the United States Rolling Stock Company, at Blue Island-avenue and Robey-street were discovered to be on fire, and they are now blazing fiercely.
Gustave Ziruth, a convict in the Trenton State Prison, where he is serving a two years' term for conspiracy, was yesterday taken to Newark as a witness in the Smith divorce case.

CAMP GROUNDS, NORTHVILLE, Aug. 14.-- Here in Northern New-York, situated on the west side of the Sacondaga River, and just opposite the picturesque little village of Northville, are the camp grounds of the Saratoga District of the Troy Conference.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 15.--L.W. Johnson, the telegraph operator whose negligence is said to have caused the recent fatal collision on the Troy and Boston Railroad, near Petersburg Junction, by which six lives were lost, was arrested this afternoon at Hoosick Falls, where the inquest was held, and brought to Troy.

LONDON, Aug. 15.--In the artillery meeting at Shoeburyness to-day the prize in the Repository competition, given by the Marquis of Lorne to the detachment shifting a gun in the quickest time, was won by the Canadian detachment in splendid style in 4 minutes 35 seconds.

Mary Murdoch, 42 years old, was killed yesterday by falling from the roof to the yard of No. 366 Madison-street. She had been ill and flighty and, ae she had no business on the roof, which was peaked, it is supposed that she committed suicide while insane.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15.--The Rufus Hatch excursion party, which reached this city on Tuesday morning from Niagara Falls, will leave for St. Paul to-morrow morning after having passed two exceedingly pleasant days in the Western metropo lis.

John H. McCarthy, Captain of the steamtug Mary N. Hogan, which is now detained at this port on a charge that she has been fitted to carry men and arms to Hayti, to aid the revolutionists there, was arrested yesterday by a United States Deputy Marshal on a charge of perjury.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15.--The attention of Commissioner Price was called to-day to a floating item in the newspapers to the effect that Vinita, in the Indian Territory, had been selectad as the scene of the Slade-Mitchell prize-fight, set for Sept. 11.

In responce to the resolution of the Board of Police requesting the different political associations is the County to send in lists of persons whom they desired to be appointed Inspectors of Election for the coming election, a number of lists have been received at the Bureau of Elections.

The Bavarian national festival that was celebrated by the Bavarian residents of this City at Sulzer's Harlem River Park on Monday, Tuesday, and yesterday, proved very successful, and fully realized the expectations of the promoters of the scheme.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 15.--To-day Mr. Wallace, an attorney for the State of Missouri, in the case of Frank James, the noted outlaw, called upon Mrs. Sarah Hite and had a long interview with her in regard to the accused man.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15.--A gentleman who has received two official notices of his having passed a civil service examination remains at a loss to discover just what his standing is.
The steam-ship Egyptian Monarch, of the Monarch Line, which arrived from London yesterday, was in a partially disabled condition when she reached Quarantine.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 15.--The Agricultural Society of Georgia continued its session this morning. An address was delivered by the Hon. L.F. Livingstone on "Diversified Farming." This was followed by an address on "Labor" by Dr. S.W. Leland.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 15.--Stagle, one of the men who committed the triple murder in the railroad camp near Point Burnside, Ky., on the line of the Cincinnati and Southern Railway, on Monday night, was captured yesterday at Monticello, Ky., and returned to Point-Burnside. It is reported that a band is organized to mob him.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 15.--The Senate to-day refused to concur in the amended resolution of the House making final adjournment contingent upon the passage of the apportionment bills. In the House the bill to repeal the act of 1874 relative to apportionment was discussed.
Mr. TILDEN has bought a span of fast horses. Mr. HENDRICKS is at Saratoga talking politics and saying, " I'll see you later." Ex-Sheriff JAMES O'BRIEN proposes an independent party in this City.

Henry McDermott, the brother of James McDermott, the alleged British spy, called at the Brooklyn Police Head-quarters yesterday and informed Inspector Jewett that he was harassed and put in fear of his life by the importunities of agents of some of the Irish political secret societies.

John J. Debaun, of Ramsey's, Bergen County, visited Haledon, near Paterson, on Tuesday, to see a resident of that place. Not finding him in he took a walk along the Haledon Lake and toward evening was seen sitting on a log near the pond.
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday and authorized the Controller to issue bonds for the payment of $116,668.66, the final amount due from the City on the Brooklyn bridge.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 15.--"I'm glad I was not insured!" said Gen. Toombs, as he looked at the ruins of the Kimball House. "If I had been insured, I should have had to sue the rascals to get my money, would have lost the case in a corrupt court, and been mulcted in costs."

Among the passengers who sailed for Liverpool yesterday on the Cunard steam-ship Pavonia were the Lord Bishop of Honolulu and Lieut. T.C. MeLean, of the United States Navy. To-day the steam-ships State of Florida, of the State Line: the Frisia, of the Hamburg Line, and the City of Paris, of the Inman Line, will sail for Europe.
