CHICAGO, Aug. 15.--J. Lozana, P. De Lerantez, and M. Shauez Navarro, of the City of Mexico, arrived at the Palmer House this afternoon, and remained an hour or so before leaving for NewYork, from which port they will sail for Europe.

John W. Mackey, the California million aire, was elected a Director of the Postal Telegraph Company yesterday. He took the place or Joel B. Erhardt, whose resignation as Director and President was accepted.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 15.--The individual members of the Indiana Banking Company will to-morrow make an assignment of their property for the benefit of the depositors.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 15.--Yesterday Mrs. McCall, residing on a farm east of Rose Hill, Mahaska County, was gored to death by a ferocious bull. She and her daughter were milking the cows.

The back of the telegraphers' strike seems to have been broken yesterday. There was considerable wavering among the operators, especially after the news of the failure of the conference between a committee of the operators and linemen and Gun. Thomas T. Eckert, the General Manager and Acting President.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 15.--The case against Paddy Ryan, the pugllist and saloon-keeper who was charged with keeping a disorderly house, was dismissed by Justice Foote to-day with the consent of the prosecution, Paddy having in some ...

Nothing occurred at the session of the Republican State Committee yesterday to suggest that a breach had ever existed in the ranks of the party, or as for that matter between the representative men of the Republican organization of this State.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 15.--To-day the House passed a bill appropriating $1,000,000 for the building of a new Capitol. It will take five or six years to complete the work. The bill will doubtless ness the Senate with minor amendments if any.
Richfield Springs has certainly set an example to all other watering-places in the land. Along the Atlantic coast, at the opening of the Summer season, the sea-serpent is usually descried.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 16.--A statement to a creditors' meeting was made to-day of the affairs of Charles W. Clement, with whom Fayette Shaw was a silent partner, and whose failure was among the largest in the shoe and leather trade.

Thomas H. Slingsby has been appointed Postmaster at Rouse's Point, N.Y. The Treasury Department to-day purchased 369,000 ounces of silver for delivery at the Philadelphia, San Francisco, and New-Orleans Mints.

SARATOGA, Aug. 16.--The flurry in the stock market in New-York produced almost as much excitement here as in Wall-street, and has left behind it a large number of loungers aroud the hotel plazzas who are pointed out as "lame ducks."

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 16.--Officer Gage, in attempting to arrest Edward Maxwell, a noted outlaw, last night, struggled so terribly that he burst a blood vessel in his head and died instantly. The prisoner escaped with the handcuffs on his wrists. The post-mortem showed the brain clotted with blood, as if Gage had been struck. There are some indications of foul play. Coroner Buckbee will hold an inquest to-morrow.

STOWE, Vt., Aug. 16.--Jessa Town and his wife, of this place, with Mrs. Stockwell, of St. Albuns, while driving yesterday, were thrown from their carriage. Mrs. Town died of the injuries she received, Mr. Town is not expected to live, and Mrs. Stockwell's injuries are very serious.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 16.--Joseph N. Hemenway, of Troy, was shot last night at Bennington, Vt., by Charles Rockwood, his father-in-law, while endeavoring to force an entrance into Rookwood's house to see his child. Rockwood discharged a shot-gun, severely wounding Hemenway.

Adele Gould, ch.g. Overman, b.s. J.B. Thomas, ch.g. Josephus, b.g. Wilson, ch.m. Clemmie G. The race will be for a purse of $10,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16.--The fire at the works of the United States Rolling Stock Company late last night, as briefly noted in THE TIMES'S dispatch, has proved even more disastrous than was anticipated before the smoke cleared away.

The medical gentlemen attending the Bishop of Peterborough have given a full history of his illness. It appears that on the 4th of July the Bishop was suddenly attacked with violent pains, which led to the idea of an impacted gallstone.

A lady residing on Queen-street started to laugh at some amusing incident at about 11 o'clock on Saturday morning, and kept on doing so until she attempted to stop, when she found she could not, Dr. Duncan was called in, who said that the case was serious. She is now recovering, but is not quite out of danger.

Cummings, of Fall River, to be Judge of Probate for Bristol County; B.W. Harris, to be Judge of Probate for Plymouth County, and John I. Baker, to be a member of the Harbor and Land Commission.
A great business house in Boston went down a few days ago and dragged several smaller horses down with it. For many years the firm had enjoyed the respect and confidence of business men.

The residence of John W. Mason, on the Sleepy Hollow road, was entered by burglars about 1 o'clock yesterday morning. They got into the house by prying open a window, and carried off a quantity of coats, overcoats, shoes, hats, and eatables, which had been packed up by Mr. Mason, who intended to go into camp in the Adirondacks to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 17.--A meeting of the Railroad Commissioners was held here today to hear arguments in connection with the recent tunnel disaster at Hartford, when a collision occurred between New-York, New-Haven and--Hartford and New-York and New-England trains. Messrs, Baldwin and Boller argued for the New-England Company and George H. Watrous and Judge Hervey for the former road.
A son of E.J. Riggs shot at a rat with the pistol elevated toward the roof.

Richard Willeck, a sailor on the bark R. W. Griffiths, from Havana, who was sent to Swinburn Island, in the Lower Bay, suffering from yellow fever, died there yesterday. The body was buried at Seguine' Point. The bark is still detion. This is the second death from yellow fever in this port this season.

ST. JOHNSBURG, Vt., Aug. 17.--One hundred and forty New-York children left for their home to-day. Most of them have been well clothed since they came here. One has died. The health of the rest has been good.

The strike of the 'longshoremen in Brooklyn was ended yesterday. The strike was caused by F. Woodruff Co. reducing the wages of their men from 25 cents to 20 cents per hour.

ALBANY, Aug. 17.--Frank Blood, 26 years old and only four months married, died at Hawes Cave to-day from fright produced by a dog bite.
CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 17.--The leading produce markets were very dull to-day, and averaged easier without weakness.

PANAMA, Aug., 17. via Galveston, Texas.-- The Star and Herald expresses fears of a civil war in the United States of Colombia.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 17.--The news of the failure of the telegraph strike reached Cleveland at 4 o'clock this afternoon, E.W. Collins, chief executive of the strikers, receiving a telegram to that effect from John Campbell, District Master Workman of the brotherhood.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 17.--A special to the News from Luling says: "At the preliminary trial to-day of Lawrence Denman for the killing of the Rev. Mr. Sewell on the 14th inst. the only witness for the prosecution said that he was walking with Mr. Sewell, conversing about a Spanish edition of the Testament, when Denman rushed out of a drug store and fired, Sewell falling at the second shot, exclaiming, "Don't shoot."

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 17.--A special to the News Journal from Warren, Ohio, says: "The Second National Bank closed its doors this evening. K.M. Fitch, the Cashier, is reported to be a defaulter to the amount of $70,000 or $80,000."

NEWARK, Aug. 17.--New-Jersey this year will elect in November a Governor for three years from January next to succeed George C. Ludlow, Democrat; seven State Senators for a similar term, and a full House of Assembly.

The Lord Mayor, in conformity with an ancient custom, has received from her Majesty warrants for four fat bucks from Windsor Great Park. The Sheriffs at the same time have had three bucks presented to them, and the Recorder Chamberlain. Town Clerk, Common Sergeant, and Remembrancer one each.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17.--The reports of Major C.R. Sutor, Major J.H. Ernst, and Capt. D. W. Rockwood, in charge, respectively, of improvements on the Mississippi and Missouri Rivers and the rivers and harbors in the Grand Rapids (Mich.) district, were received at the War Department today.

MONTREAL, Aug. 17.--It is currently reported here that James McShane, member of the Provincial Parliament, has entered into a contract with the French Government to ship 15,000 head of prime cattle into France, beginning at once.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17.--A heavily-laden southbound freight train on the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad was wrecked at Calvary Station at an early hour to-day.

UTICA, Aug. 17.--The concert given by local talent this evening in aid of the striking telegraphers netted $300. Up to 10:30 o'clock to-night members of the brotherhood have no information of Campbell's surrender.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 17.--Broome Williams the locomotive engineer who was so badly hurt in the accident on Thursday, on the Iron Mountain Railroad, died yesterday.

Postmaster Pearson yesterday discharged from the Post Office a clerk named Henry C. Knapp, who was employed in the Registered Letter Department. LONDON, Aug. 17.--There were 433 deaths from cholera in Egypt on Thursday, including six at Cairo. Two hundred and two persons have died from cholera in Bombay in the last fortnight.
After an up-hill game the Metropolitan Club defeated the Cincinnati team on the Polo Grounds yesterday. There was a large crowd in attendance, and the game altogether was well played by both teams.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17.--A collision occurred on the West Chester branch of the Pennsylvania Road this afternoon at Angora, five miles from this city, between a passenger and a market train. James Welsh, fireman of the market train, was killed by being crushed under the tender. A car containing 25 calves and sheep was overturned and the animals scalded to death by the escaping steam.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17.--The reported sbscrption of the Tide-water Pipe Line by the Standard Oil Company created something of a flurry among the oil men to-day.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Aug. 17.--The fires were again lighted to-night for an incineration in the Le Moyne crematory, which will take place tomorrow evening, upon the arrival of the 4 P.M. train from Wheeling.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 17.--The attendance this morning at the general session of the American Association for the Advancement of Science was much larger than on any previous occasion, the number of visitors being in excess of that of the scientists.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 17.--Constable Legates was yesterday taking two handcuffed colored burglars from Newark to the jail at NewCastle, when the prisoners attempted to escape. A struggle ensued, and the Constable finally shot one of them. Lewis Williams, inflicting a wound which will likely prove fatal. The Constable claims that he shot in self-defense.
Two gangs of boys engaged in a battle with stones in the town of East New-York on Thursday evening. One gang represented the east and the other the west side of the town.

During the present Summer Mr. Alfred Ebner, a druggist doing business at No. 457 Third-avenue, Brooklyn, has been much annoyed by having his door-bell constantly rung at night by the conscienceless youth of the neighborhood.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 17.--The House to-day passed the Amerman resolution for the appointment of a free conference committee to consist of three Republicans and three Democrats to frame a Senatorial and Representative Apportionment bill.

READING, Penn., Aug. 17.--The Controller of the Currency has notified the Directors of the Commercial National Bank, of this city, that the capital of the bank is impaired to the extent of $15,000, and that the amount must be made up according to law.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17.--Henry L. Evans, a young man of 23 years, who has been employed in the Post Office as a stamp-cancellor and distributor of letters, was arrested this afternoon in the pool-room at No. 733 Sansom-street, by Detectives Whiteman and Hulfish, for abstracting a freshly mailed letter containing a check for $35.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 17.--This morning at 10 o'clock the Rev. Dr. Alexander Martin, President of Asbury University, Indiana, lectured on "Philosophizing as to Education." At 11 o'clock the Rev. Dr. Atticus G. Haygood, of Oxford, Ga., President of Emory College, and also President of the John F. Slater fund, addressed the assembly, taking for his subject.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 17.--Consignments of woven wire spring beds and barbed wire made here were shipped to-day to New-Zealand, being the first Canadian manufactures sent to that colony. They will be sold as cheaply as the English or American production.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 17.--Attorneys for the Chicago Tire Manufacturing Company began a suit in the United States Circuit Court to-day to determine the rate at which steel blooms are to be taxed at the Custom-house.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 17.--A. Burmann was nominated by the Democratic Central Committee to-day for Governor in place of W. W. McNair, who declined. Mr. Burmann accepts the nomination.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 17.--The statement that yellow fever has made its appearance at Pensacola, Fla., is incorrect. The navy-yard at which the fever prevails is seven miles from that place.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 17.--Yesterday was the third day of the Pacific Coast Blood Horse Association races. The sport opened with a dash of seven-eighths of a mile, which was won by Ella Doane, with Jim Renwick a bad second.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 17.--This city is on the verge of a water famine. The cisterns are drained, the gardens are dried up, and the effect of the drought is plainly to be seen in the poverty of the vegetable market.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 17.--For three years or more capitalists have been prospecting for coal-oil in the vicinity of Caffon City, in this State, but with indifferent results. On Tuesday night a vein was struck in the Land Investment Company's well which has since yielded at the rate of 40 barrels per day oil of excellent quality, demonstrating to a certainty that coal-oil exists in paying quantities in that vicinity.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 17.--A leak in the Eria Canal at Lock No. 48, just east of this city, requires the drawing off of the water, and will probadly delay navigation from four to six days.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 17.--Harry Hill, of New-York, has been chosen referee in the coming Slade-Mitchell prize-fight. An investigation of the law shows that the restrictions upon prize-fighting are very stringent both in Missouri and Kansas. It is stated that a Missouri statute forbids any one to train in this State for prize-fighting. Slade is now in training at Independence, and this discovery may cause a change in the proposed arrangements.

LONDON, Aug. 17.--The Commandant at Shoeburvness, addressing the Canadian artillerymen at the close of the National Artillery Association's meeting, said he hoped to see a Canadian team there at every meeting.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 17.--Counsel for the Receivers of the Barnstable Savings Bank obtained from the Supreme Court to-day leave to declare a final dividend. When the bank suspended, in May, 1878, its total liabilities were $1,291,302, and three dividends, amounting to 70 per cent., have been paid. The Receivers have now on hand $167,857, and will ask leave to make a final dividend of 12 per cent.

Charlotte M. Rogers, aged 15 years, while under the control of an insane fit, jumped from a third-story window of her home, No. 126 East Ninety-third-street, last night. Her right arm and left leg were broken, and other serious injuries were received by her. She was taken to the Presbyterian Hospital.
LONDON, Aug. 17.--The House of Commons continued in session till nearly 6 o'clock this morning. The discussion was on the Government's estimates.

LONDON, Aug. 7.--There are still several millions of people left in London, and yet the town is spoken of continually as "positively empty." And, indeed, you might think it somewhat deserted if you wandered through some of the fashionable West End streets and squares. Mansion after mansion you would find closed, blinds down, shutters up.
The North German Lloyd steam-ship Werra, which arrived last evening from Bremen and Southampton, made the quickest trip on record from the latter port.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 17.--A large exodus of lumbermen is now going on from this district to the United States. Two hundred mill-hands will leave in a day or two for Potsdam, N.Y. Over 100 shanty-men have already left for Michigan.
QUEBEC, Aug. 17.--The Captain and officers of the frigate Vandalia were entertained at dinner last night by the officers of the Citadel. A large number of citizens visit the Vandalia daily.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 17.--The Grain Exchange Committee has issued a statement showing that the wheat yield in the various counties of California the present year is 53,000,000 bushels, an increase of 14,000,000 bushels over last year. The total barley yield this year is 15,000,000 bushels, an increase over last year of 2,500,000 bushels.

CHATTANOOGA, Aug. 17.--The mutilated remains of Deputy Sheriff Chitwood were found at Chitwood station, on the Cincinnati Southern Railway, in Scott County, Tenn., to-day. It is thought he was murdered, and his remains were placed on the track.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 17.--The infantry drill in the free-for-all contest was a feature of the encampment this morning.

The General Passenger Agents or the leaning railroads of the country are showing more interest in the earnings of their department than in former years, and on many roads passenger earnings are footing up as large, if not larger, than freight earnings.

The consecration services of the new synagogue of the Congregation of the Shaarai Berocho, of the Gates of Blessing, at No. 240 East Fortyfifth-street, occurred yesterday afternoon in the presence of a large audience.
Two batches of male prisoners, numbering four, were locked up at Police Head-quarters last night by Detective Sergeants King, Charles O'Connor, and Slausson.
TROY, N.Y., Aug. 17.--The Bennington Battle Monument Association to-day adopted a design submitted by Prof. Weire. The monument will cost $100,000.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 17.--A boiler at the Falls City Brewery, situated outside the city limits, exploded yesterday morning, tearing out of the boiler-house, passing through an adjoining shed, and rising 200 feet in the air. In descending it struck a slaughter-house, crushed through the roof and one floor, and lodged in the cellar. Although several persons were about the boiler, no one was injured.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17.--Plans and specifications have been prepared for a new steamer for the use of the Fish Commission, and several bids for her construction have already been received.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 17.--Duly Stormer, a young lady 17 years old, was caught by her apron and wound around the driving shaft of the engine at the Trucksville Woolen Mills last evening. The foreman of the mill and others tore her from the machinery by main force. Her spine was injured, and she was removed in a paralyzed condition. She cannot survive.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 17.--A file and a case-knife with saw teeth filed in it were found in Theodore Hoffman's cell this evening by Jailor Duffy, also a letter bidding the Sheriff good-bye. Hoffman is convicted of murder. His cell was cleared out, and then a diagram of the cell door key was also found. Hoffman had undoubtedly expected to saw his way out.

Mr. Francis J. Sabine, of 338 Adelaidestreet West, is the father of a little 2-months-old daughter who possesses no less than 12 toes on its two little pedal extremities. Mrs. Benjamin Crittenden, of Enniskillen, shortly before July 12, while weeding in the garden, accidentally caught hold of a snake. The result of the fright was a fever, to which she succumbed on Friday morning, after an illness of three weeks.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 18.--Charles Ingram was probably fatally shot last night in a street near his residence, in the western part of the city, by his brother-in law, C.W. Richardson. PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19.--George W. Bromley, a soldier of the Mexican war, and who, it is claimed, killed the Seminole chief Oseeola in the Florida Indian war, was buried at Darby, a suburb of this city, to-day. MAYSVILLE, Ky., Aug. 19.--Peter Smith, of this city, a turnpike contractor, was killed on Friday evening, near Helena, Mason County, by a blow from a board in the hands of Pres Lawson, one of his employes. The quarrel was a hasty and foolish one, and a murderous assault was evidently not intended. Lawson escaped.

MONTREAL, Aug. 19.--A telegraph operator in the Great North-western office, named England, was attacked this morning while on his way home by four strikers, who knocked him senseless and then tried to strangle him, but were frightened off by the approach of policemen. England's wounds are dangerous, but it is thought he will recover. His assailants escaped.

Mr. Talmage is strictly temperate, or a teetotaler as far as intoxicating liquors are concerned. At the Phoenix Hotel, Lexington, the servant offers, free of cost, wine to all who will partake. Mr. Talmage declined. "It is pure native wine," said the servant. "No intoxicating ingredients?" he asked. "None whatever." The glass was filled, but still he did not partake.

The Coney Island hotel-keepers were in better spirits yesterday than on any previous Sunday this Summer. They had the largest crowd of visitors to entertain than on any other one day of the season.

MADRID, Aug. 19.--King Alfonso was warmly received at Valencia. He was loudly cheered by crowds of people along the railway route from Madrid. The King attended a Te Deum at the cathedral in Valencia, and reviewed the troops stationed there. He will proceed to Barcelona on Monday.

CAMP GROUNDS, NORTHVILLE, Aug. 18.-- Yesterday witnessed the largest influx of visitors to the Sacondaga camping grounds thus far noted. From early morning until late in the afternoon the incoming trains deposited over 6,000 persons on the grounds and a general estimate made on the spot was that 10,000 visitors were present.

Dr. Norvin Green, President of the Western Union Telegraph Company, who has been in Europe since April last, arrived in this City on the steamer Alaska yesterday and took up a temporary residence at the Albemarle Hotel. There he was seen last evening by a TIMES reporter, with whom he talked freely about his visit abroad.

QUEENSTOWN, Aug. 20.--The White Star Line steamship Baltic, Capt. Parsell, from New-York Aug. 11 for Liverpool, was signaled off Fastnet at 1 A.M. to-day.

READING, Penn., Aug. 19.--A terrific thunder-storm passed over this section of the State at noon to-day. A large number of Western Union wires are down, while several buildings were struck by the cyclone with slight damage. There were many trees levelled to the earth by force of the wind.
In the race for the championship of the Baseball League the Cleveland Club is now in the lead, having won 45 games to 44 by its opponents from Providence.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 19.--To-day Dr. J.H. Vincent preached the Baccalaureate sermon to the members of the Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle. Six thousand persons were present. Dr. Vincent's text was from James, iv.: 3.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 19.--The announcement will be made by the canal officials tomorrow morning that the water will be drawn off from the Erie Canal next Thursday morning at 6 o'clock. All locking will cease at that time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 18.--The Bulletin publishes a letter brought down on the steamer Saint Paul, which arrived this evening from Ounalaska announcing large gold discoveries on the Yukron River, Alaska. Schefflin, who made a big discovery in Arizona, and who cleared over $1,000,000 in that section.

In an attack of delirium resulting from consumption Michael Hearn, a young man 28 years of age, attempted last evening to throw himself out of a window at his residence, No. 154 West Eighteenth-street. He succeeded only in dashing his right hand through a pane of glass, severing the artery at the wrist. He was taken to the New-York Hospital, and thence to the insane pavillion at Bellevue Hospital.
BOSTON, Aug. 19.--Judge Nelson has delivered an elaborate decision in the case of Ah Shong, the alleged Chinese laborer landed at this port by the Captain of the British bark Eme.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17.--The internal Revenue Collectors on the 1st inst. furnished the brewers with a revised form of monthly returns required to be made by them under the present law.

Lives of six famous composers have appeared in Mr. Huefer's series--Bach, Wagner, Weber, Rossini, Schubert, and Purcell. A seventh volume dealt with English church composers. Volumes are promised on Mendelssohn, Handel, Beethoven, and the little-known Venetain composer Marcello.

A party of nine clergymen, with ladies, two of the reverend gentlemen being from Rhode Island, feasted upon baked clams at Nantasket Beach a few days ago. SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19.--Even the weather is doing its best to make the Eastern Knights Templar feel at home. The thermometer this morning recorded 77 , with a prospect of a further rise for the procession to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19.--Your correspondent had an interesting talk recently with Assistant Treasurer Graves, a strong and consistant advocate of a reformed civil service, in which he claimed that the more technical the duties attached to any vacant place the better the vacancy could be filled by a competitive examination, such as is provided under the new law.

LONDON, Aug. 9.--Parliament is working hard with a view to put in evidence something like a substantial legislative record prior to the adjournment in two weeks' time. Mr. Gladstone has made a definite and formal statement in connection with Egypt.

VICTORIA, British Columbia, Aug. 19.--The Island Railway contract has been signed, and the syndicate agree to build the road within three years. They practically secure the only true coal seams yet discovered on this coast.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19.--Pending the return of the Secretaries of War and the Navy a number of court-martial cases have accumulated, as they cannot be finally disposed of in their absence. With some of them the public is familiar; others have made less stir.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 19.--Gov. Foster spent a short time in Cleveland during the past week, and in conversation on the political situation expressed himself very much pleased with the outlook.

Louis Reil has relieved the apprehensions of loyal citizens of Manitoba by returning to Montana and proclaiming that he intends to remain there.

SARATOGA, Aug. 20.--Before noon to-day the sky was obscured by threatening clouds, and before 1 o'clook a heavy shower fell. Later there were several showers, which made the walking around the paddook anal betting quarters very unpleasant, and also rendered the already heavy track very muddy.
There was another decline in stocks yesterday on the whole list of from 7/8 to 5 . Denver and Rio Grande suffered the heaviest fall. It opened at 28, went down to 22 , and closed at 23 .
CHAUTSUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 20.--This morning at 10 0'clock Rev. J.S. Jewell, of Chicago, lectured on "The Structure and Modes of Action of the Nervous System."

Capt. Halsey, of the steam-ship New-Orleans, of the Cromwell Line, which arrived yesterday from New-Orleans, reports that when 20 miles south of Long Branch he saw a brig-rigged British steam-ship ashore.
LONDON, Aug. 20.--The Daily News intimates that Mr. Shaw, the British missionary in Madagascar, who was imprisoned by the French there on a charge of concealing two Hova spies, has been released.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20.--The grand procession of Knights Templar which took place this afternoon was admitted to have been an unqualified success. The entire population of San Francisco and 70,000 strangers have declared it so. Cheers were heard along the entire route.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20.--The leading produce markets were more active today in the aggregate and averaged stronger. There was not so much life as many expected, and certainly not so much weakness.

SARATOGA, Aug. 20.--The dispatches sent from this place this afternoon announcing the sale of the Saratoga race-track are pronounced by Mr. Charles Reed as willful and malicious falsehoods. Mr. Reed says that no offer for the purchase of the track would receive the slightest consideration. The track has been successful this season, and there is no reason whatever to place it on the market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20.--Third Assistant Postmaster-General Hazen said to-day that from the returns now at hand he estimated the surplus of the Post Office Department for the year ended Jnne 30, 1883, would be in the neighborhood of $2,500,000. WASHINGTON, Aug. 20.--Assistant Secretary of the Treasury New said to-day that a competent expert, J. R. Green, of the Walworth Manufacturing Company, of Boston, was now engaged in measuring up the work of Messrs. Bartlett and Hayward in the Chicago Custom-house. ALBANY, N. Y., Aug. 20.--The National Telegraph Company was incorporated to-day. The capital stock is fixed at $25,000, with the provision that it may be increased to $10,000,000. The stockholders are Calvin S. Brice, of Lima, Ohio; Frank F. Worcester, of Brooklyn, and John W. Simpson, Herbert L. Terrill, Walter Katte, and James E. Childs, of New-York.

TROY, N. Y., Aug .20.--Delegates to the Grand Lodge of Odd-fellows are arriving on every train, and it is expected that 600 will be present to-morrow. A special session will be held to-night to confer the Grand Lodge degree, at which Grand Master Sohlaab will preside.
PITTSBURG, Aug. 20.--After a suspension since the 1st of July work was resumed this morning in all the flint-glass factories of this vicinity.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 20.--The body of the man found recently in a field near West Valley, on the line of the Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad, has been identified as that of Nelson Odin, keeper of a boarding shanty.

CAMP TETON, Aug. 19, via Fort Washakie, Wyoming, Aug. 20.--Promptly at 6:30 o'clook this morning the horses were mounted, and not without longing, lingering looks behind the party rode away from Camp Arthur.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 20.--The Steamer Magenta, having on board the young Men's Christian Association of Newark, N.J., broke her walking-beam off Danskammer this afternoon. She drifted to New-Hamburg, and was towed to Newburg by a tug which had been telegraphed for. When the steamer arrived there 100 of the excursionists took the West Shore Road for home.

LONDON, Aug. 20.--Cetywayo, the Zulu King, has recovered from the wounds received in the late engagement between his forces and the insurgents, and has made a request of Queen Victoria that she will have full inquiry made into the treatment he has received.
HAVANA, Aug. 20.--Leopoldo Carbajal has been re-elected President of the Casino Espanel Club, and Count Lagunillas Vice-President.

LIMA, Aug. 20. via Galveston, Texas.--It is thought that the members of the Government of Gen. Iglesias will not be positively known until the return of Castro Zaldwar from Trujillo, the names already given being merely speculative.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 20.--Arrangements have nearly been completed for the regatta which will take place here in the last week of September. Two thousand dollars will be given in prizes, and nearly all the principal oarsmen in the country, including Hanlan, Courtney, Lee, Hosmer, and Elliet, have signified their intention of participating.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 20.--The season is booming in earnest, and it promises to be a financial success at least. Every hotel and boardinghouse was full on Sunday, and at the Ocean House it was impossible to find accommodations.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 20.--A white man named Ballhis was run over and killed by the north-bound Virginia Midland express last night at Whittles, Va. It is supposed that he was drunk and unconsciously wandered on the track, and was unable to get any further.

GALVESTON, Aug. 21.--Special dispatches to the Galveston News from a large number of points throughout the State show that, except in a few localities, further rains could be productive of no marked benefit to the cotton crop. In a majority of cases it would result in injury.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 21.--The Mexican Navigation Company recently sent an agent to England to buy two ready-built steamers for their their New-Orleans line. The agent failed to purchase the steamers and the Government has extended the time for the commencement of operations until the steamers can be built.

The Yonkers police are investigating an alleged case of abduction and felonious assault, in which Emma Treusdale, of that city, aged 15, was the victim. On Saturday evening last Miss Treusdale, while walking along the beach, was induced to enter a boat in which two young men were rowing.

LOCKPORT, Aug. 21.--Niagara is nothing if not sensational, and the public interest excited in the whirpool and the adjacent rapids by Capt. Webb's fatal attempt has put into the heads of several speculators at Niagara Falls and Suspension Bridge to send a boat down through the whirlpool for a public exhibition, in humble imitation of Joel Robinson's daring feat with the Maid of the Mist in 1861.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 21.--Mr. McCullough, the tragedian, opened the season at the Tabor Opera-house last night. His reception was a perfect ovation. The house was crowded to suffocation, and a grand impression was created by his rendition of Virginius. The sensational stories of his ill-health are without foundation, and he will doubtless be able to fill all his engagements of the season.

It was a piece of current news at Police Head-quarters yesterday that Inspector Byrnes had been applied to for police protection for Lord Chief-Justice Coleridge during his stay in this City, on account of threats that had been made against him by members of the "dynamite" faction of the Irish Nationalists.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 21.--The authorities of the Insane Retreat here decline to affirm or deny the correctness of the rumor that Gen. Harnes, who recently died in that institution, committed suicide.

PORT JERVIS, Aug. 21.--Intense excitement prevails here on account of the attempted murder to-night of Isaac Brown and wife, an aged and respectable couple of this place. Mr. Brown, who is a storekeeper, closed his place at about 9 o'clock. Turning out the lights in the store, he took a small hand lamp and started for a room back of the store, through which he had to pass to his rooms overhead.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21.--The American Institute of Christian Philosophy opened its fourth Summer school at Richfield Springs this morning. The chapel was found too small, and the audience adjourned to the Presbyterian church. Dr. Deems presided, and the Rev. Dr. Cattell, of Lafayette College, conducted divine services.

The Iowa opponents of secret societies are to hold a three days' convention in Albia, that State, beginning on Tuesday 28th inst. The announced topics for discussion are secret societies. Divine recognition in Government, the Sabbath, and constitutional prohibition. The speakers engaged are ex-Senator Samuel C. Pomeroy, of Kansas; Charles A. Blanchard, the Rev. William Johnson, and others. The call says all are invited; without respect to sex, color, or previous condition.

A Triana, a student at the Philadelphia Medical College, was a passenger on the steam-ship Saratoga, which arrived from Havana yesterday. He brought a big Saratoga trunk with him. When Inspector Brennan opened the trunk he found it full of white shirts, stiffly starched and neatly done up.

It appears that the Germans are not the largest consumers of beer and other malt liquors, as has generally been supposed. The editor of the Chemical Review, of this city, has collected the statistics in regard to brewing from most of the leading countries in the world.
NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 21.--Nothing additional has been heard of the missing yacht Mystery and her crew. Today a man was sent along the shoreline on the look-out, and another man started from Nantucket.

A stabbing affray took place on board the Norwegian bark P.A. Munch last Monday afternoon, when the vessel was off Sandy Hook. She had come from Barbados with a cargo of sugar. During the voyage John Osolsen and another seaman had several quarrels about petty affairs, which did not result in any serious encounter.

Fire was discovered by Officer Kieling, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, issuing from the top floor of the white marble building No. 53 Warrenstreet at 12:30 this morning. An alarm was immediately sent out, and, running a line of hose up the stairs, the firemen soon had the fire under control.

Twenty-two years ago yesterday the First Regiment, New-York Volunteer Cavalry, went to the war. It was known as the Lincoln Cavalry, and it spent four years in the field. The surviving veterans decided to commemorate yesterday, and about 50 of them went to Glen Island.

SARATOGA, Aug. 21.--This being a regular day there was a very large attendance at the races. The weather was clear and warm. The chief interest was centred in the stake races, several stables having sent their fast horses from Long Branch to meet the Saratoga cracks.

WARSAW, N.Y., Aug. 21.--About 9 o'clock this morning, two handsome young girls, aged about 16, named Mattie Rudd and Mamic Karns, residing at Perry, a village a mile and one-half from Silver Lake, left their homes to attend the picnic of the Baptist churches from the surrounding towns, which was held at that resort to-day.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21.--The eight libel suits pending against the Chicago Herald and its publishers were all dismissed to-day at defendants' costs by stipulation of the parties.

WASHINGTON, Aug 21.--Second Lieut. James B. Erwin, Fourth Cavalry, now at St. Louis. Mo., has been ordered to proceed to Jefferson Barracks, Missouri, and report in person to the Superintendent of the Mounted Recruiting Service for temporary duty.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 21.--The Grand Lodge of the Knights of Pythias of Pennsylvania is in session here. Over 500 delegates are present representing over 31,000 members. Mayor Powderly welcomed the Knights in a complimentary speech.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 21.--About the time open war was made upon State aid to railroads, north-east Georgia was clamoring for the building of a line from Marietta through the mountain counties to Murphy, N.C. The appeals were such that they could not very well be ignored, and the Legislature made a compromise with the public conscience by giving the company building the proposed roads a number of convicts in lieu of money.

The Shakers, which are confined exclusively to this country, now have 17 branches or "families" in various parts of the Union. A member says that no one is allowed to sign the covenant under the age of 21 years, although children are sometimes taken on probation.
LONDON, Aug. 22.--The steam-ship Bavarian, (Br.,) Capt. Lazzolo, from Boston Aug. 11, has arr. at Liverpool.

In his complaint, in the Supreme Court, where he is seeking a decree annulling his marriage with Margaret Ann Brown, George Henry Brown declares that he was induced by threats and a fraudulent promise to marry the woman.

The police are making search for James E. Walker, a commercial traveler, who has been missing from his home, No. 247 East Thirty-fifth-street, for 10 days. His wife is in great distress at his absence. Walker is 43 years of age and a native of the North of Ireland.

Several more of the striking telegraph operators returned to work at the Western Union Telegraph Company's office in this City yesterday. Some of them were operators whose offense against the company had been very rank, and whose chance for a return to their desks was considered almost outside the range of possibilities.

A number of little sticks of wood, covered with red paper, upon which are printed Chinese hieroglyphics, were delivered to the merchants. lodging-house keepers, coolies, , in Chinatown a few days ago.

Tolono is threatened with sudden wealth. It is a pretty little town in the Vermillion Valley, 137 miles directly south of Chicago, on the line of the Illinois Central Railway. The way the wealth threatens to come is through an oil well.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21.--Commodore English, Acting Secretary of the Navy, has received a telegram from the commandant of the Pensacola Navy-yard, requesting that a court of inquiry be ordered to inquire into the origin of the yellow fever at the yard.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 21.--The shops of the Holly Manufacturing Company in this city have been thronged to-day by persons who availed themselves of the privilege of inspecting the enormous engine just completed for the city of Columbus, Ohio, to be used for forcing water through the city.

The few persons who know the facts of the case are always amused when recalling the "grand ovation" offered to Mme. Patti in Brooklyn last Winter. On the occasion of her first appearance for the season the horses were taken from her carriage after the conclusion of the opera.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 21.--A visit to the Niagara County Poor-house shows that the crops on the county farm of over 100 acres are good, except the wheat crop. The number of inmates is 100, of whom 40 are old and decrepit house inmates. The others labor on the farm.
The fourth annual meet of the American Canoe Association, now in progress near Peterboro, Canada, is an illustration of the rapid growth of canoeing in this country.
Mr. Sam Weller avowed himself unable to decide whether the alibi or the habeas corpus was the chief palladium of the liberties of the subject.
The Metropolitan Club easily defeated the Columbus Club on the Polo Grounds yesterday in the eighth game of their series of 14. This was the sixth victory for the Mets over their Columbus rivals.

Gwin delegate to the Kentucky Educational Convention, he having been California's first Senator in Congress and a most conspicuous advocate of popular education in the State. Gen. Gwin has accepted the appointment, saying that he had intended never again to accept a public position, and adding: ...

Chicago, Aug. 21.--The leading produce markets were generally dull to-day, with much less doing than usual, and the average feeling was weak. A fire in the Western Union offices prevented the delivery of a good many business telegrams, and left the trade for the nonce in even a worse position than that due to the strike.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21.--Congressman Finerty to-night delivered a fiery speech before the Eighteenth Ward branch of the Irish National League. He said that if the Irish people were able to rise in rebellion they should do it.
The story of sea life and adventure, without having the romance element in it, like in the author's "Wreck of the Grosvenor," has nevertheless many distinguishing merits.

PARIS, Aug. 21.--The expulsion from France of M. Boland, the Belgian journalist, who failed to prove his charge of having bribed French Deputies, has been deferred until the Council of Ministers has approved the decision in his case.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 21.--It is estimated that fully 15,000 people attended the first day's exercises to-day at the Ocean Grove campmeeting. Every train coming in is crowded with people bound for Ocean Grove. Every tent within the camp-meeting district has been taken, and the boarding cottages, as well as the hotels in the Grove and Asbury Park, are crowded.

ALEXANDRIA, Aug. 21.--One hundred and forty deaths from cholera have occurred among the British troops in Egypt since the outbreak of the disease to date. Forty-three deaths from cholera occurred here yesterday.

It is the general impression that our mountain counties are the incubating places for drunkenness and illicit whisky. Never was there a graver mistake. There is not a bar-room in Towns County and not more than one in Rabun.
CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 21.--The Chautauqua Cooking College has been permanetly organized with Mrs. Ewing, of Chicago, as chief.

PETERSBURG, Va., Aug. 21.--The Right Worthy Grand Council of the Order of St. Luke of Virginia, commenced its annual session in the Union-street Methodist Church to-day. There was a large attendance of delegates from different sections of the State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21.--J.B.Gardner, wealthy citizen of Boston, recently deceased, provided by will that a large sum of money, bonds, and other securities, aggregating in value $331,600 should be turned over to the United States Treasury to be used in helping to pay the national debt. The bequest has been received at the Treasury Department, and by direction of the Register was today placed to the credit of "patriotic donations."

SARATOGA, Aug. 21.--A brilliant complimentary hop to M.S. Frothingham was given at the United States Hotel this evening. On Friday evening next Clara Louise Kellogg is to give a concert in the ball-room of the same hotel.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 21.--The Chinese question has been main precipitated here by the marriage of one of Willie Loo Chong's friends to one of the fairest flowers of Caucasian womanhood. After the marriage of Willie Loo Chong and the outcome of the Waynesboro disturbances,several legislators, chief of whom was Mr. Jordan, of Hancock, determined to break up the mixture of races by making such marriages unlawful.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 21.--A special to the Tribune from Wichita, Kan., says: "A.B. Steinmetz, of this city, who has been prominent in the Oklahoma movement, has just returned from a tour through the Oklahoma country.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21.--This morning Justice Blatchford began the hearing in the celebrated New-York head money case, the merits of which are briefly these: In August, 1882, Congress passed a law requiring that 50 cents should be paid on every alien passenger coming to the United States.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 21.--The annual gathering of Grangers from Pennsylvania, Maryland, and West Virginia was formally opened today at Williams's Grove. Their exhibit equals, and probably surpasses, that of last year, and the indications point to a larger attendance than ever before.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 21--The consolation race for professionals who failed to take prizes in yesterday's regatta took place at Forest Hill at noon to-day.
Emma Phillips, of No. 71 Watts-street, who shot and seriously wounded Andrew Ryan on Monday night, was yesterday arraigned in the Tombs Police Court.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 21.--A meeting of several representatives of the railroads interested in the Colorado pool was held at the office of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad here today, but little was done because not all the interested persons were present, and another meeting will be held to-morrow. Decisions of several points in reference to the pool have been given to the roads interested by the arbitrator, Joseph Tucker.

On Sunday afternoon last Miss Mary Daly, of No. 290 Baltic-street, Brooklyn, left her home to attend vespers in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church, corner of Congress and Court streets. She has not since been heard from by her relatives.

ALTOONA, Aug. 18.--Gen. Joseph E. Johnston, the Confederate General, is at Bedford Springs. He is modest, unassuming, and courteous and in conversation one can scarcely realize that he is talking with the Confederate General who disputes with Lee for the position of the greatest soldier that the South produced during the late war.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 21.--A report that has been put in circulation that cholera had appeared at Akron, Ohio, is entirely groundless. Nothing has occurred to afford even a pretext for such a rumor.

STRUTHERS, Ohio, Aug. 21.--Through the neglect of some one the switch at the east end of the Pittsburg and Lake Erie yard at Hazleton, two miles east of Youngstown, Ohio, was left open, and passenger train No. 5, due at Youngstown from Pittsburg at 11:30 A.M., ran into the rear end of a freight train standing on the main track.
MADISON, Ind., Aug. 21.--Mrs. Stephen Babbitt, a respected lady residing near Lexington, 55 years old, committed suicide to-day by drowning herself.

Burglars have for more than a year been at work in the Hudson River towns. Several months ago they robbed 13 houses in Tarrytown in one night. It has been believed that they had their head-quarters on a sloop that has been seen moving mysteriously up and down the river, and that they hid the stolen articles on shore until they could get an opportunity to disease of them in safety.

HARRISONBURG, Va., Aug. 21.--At 3:20 o'clock last night Col. George E. Deneal, an aged and respectable citizen of this county, who before the war was a member of the House of Delegates and of the State Senate of Virginia, shot and instantly killed a negro named Ned Rives, who had just forced an entrance into his house, it is supposed for the purpose of robbery and possibly murder.
MONTREAL, Aug. 21.--The high wages offered by the farmers in this neighborhood are causing sailors to desert from their ships.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21.--The committee of the Board of Trade appointed to consider the allegations made against the firm of Fowler Brothers of adulterating lard, will submit its report on Change at 10 o'clock to-morrow.

There was a poultry show at Lion Park last night. The old Ninth Ward Shanghais gathered there for their Summer Night's Festival. The affair was not given over entirely to the old cocks, but the young roosters took a hand in. They all brought their hens--that is the Shanghais of the gentler sex--with them.
LONDON, Aug. 21.--A lively discussion was caused in the House of Commons this afternoon in regard to the case of Mr. Shaw, the British missionary in Madagascar, who is held in custody by the French.

A large number of Chinamen are at work grading the line of the Northern Pacific Railroad along North Front-street. The materials used on that portion between Greenwich dock and Weidler's mills is partly beach sand, brought here as ballast, and partly sawdust.

The National Telegraph Company, the articles of incorporation for which were filed at Albany on Monday, will open up a new means for telegraphic communication between this City and Chicago. The company has a nominal capital of $25,000, with power to increase to $10,000,000.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 21.--The State Turnfest closed to-night after three days or festivities. Prizes to societies were awarded as follows: First class--New-Haven first, Meriden second, Hartford third, Waterbury honorable mention; second class--New-Haven first, Hartford second, Meriden third, Waterbury honorably mention. Individual prizes were also awarded. The festivities closed with a grand ball.
EL PASO, Texas, Aug. 21.--El Paso is determined on having an American-Mexican Exhibition, to be held some time next year. The citizens are taking the matter up warmly and it promises to be a success.

Mr. S.G. Pratt's opera, "Zenobia," was produced last night at Mr. Max Strakosch's Twentythird-Street Theatre in the presence of a large and interested audience, which had gathered to see if, perchance, the founder of the long-expected American school of music had arrived at last.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21, 1883. The Department of State and the Depart ment of Justice were closed to-day in memory of the late Judge Black.

About 7:40 o'clock last evening a meteor fell and burst, with a loud report, near Bedloe's Island. It glowed with a clear white flame, much more clear and white than the electric lights of an Iron Steam-boat Company's boat, near to which it seemed to pass.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 21.--Gov. Crittenden to-day addressed a letter to Marshal Murphy, of Kansas City, calling his attention to the open violation of the statutes by Slade and Mitchell, who are training and preparing for a prize-fight, they and their abettors being guilty of felony under the law and liable to punishment by confinement in the penitentiary for from two to ten years.

Cornelius A. Wortendyke, President of the Wortendyke Manufacturing Company, silks and cotton goods, of Wortendyke, N.J., was arrested in this City on Friday by the Sheriff, on a civil suit brought by John C. Phillips Co., creditors, for $16,000, for obtaining goods, it is alleged, under false pretenses.

UTICA, Aug. 21.--Discouraging reports come from the hop yards. The vine grew luxuriantly and fruited heavily in most cases, and a week ago the promise was good of a yield considerably larger than that of last year. Vermin were then making their appearance, but hope was strong that the necessary elementary aids, heavy rains followed by cool weather, would come to the rescue.

BOSTON, Aug. 21.--An Albuquerque (NewMexico) dispatch yesterday states that J.P. Whitney, of Boston, had been shot dead while serving a writ at the Estancia Ranch. The Whitney referred to was James G. Whitney, the brother of J.P. Whitney.
Steam ship State of Nebraska, (Br.,) Braes, Glasgow and Larne 11 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Austin Baldwin Co.
A short, little, square-built, dark-skinned, twinkling-eyed young fellow was known the regiment over as "Little Potter."

WILMINGTON, N.C., Aug. 21.--Preparations on an extensive scale are being made for the second annual fair of the North Carolina Fruitgrowers' Association, which is to open here tomorrow. A large attendance and an unusually fine display are expected.

The Colored Republican Central Committee held its first Fall meeting last evening at No. 123 West Twenty-fifth-street. The committee is without a Chairman, and, in the absence of either of the Vice-Presidents, Mr. Thomas Jarrett presided over the meeting.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 21.--A dispatch from Findlay to the Leader reports that the construction hands on the Cincinnati. Delphos and Toledo Railway struck to-day because they had not been paid for two months.
At the meeting of the United States Senate Sub-Committee on Labor and Education, in the Post Office Building yesterday, Mr.A.H. Seymour was recalled to the stand to give figures relating ...

LOUIS, Aug. 21.--Ever since the Zoe Watkins and Zerelda Garrison cases of mysterious disappearance anything in the shape of the sudden and unexplained departure from home of a young lady causes intense excitement in this city, and the announcement to-day that Mary Churchill, the 16-year-old daughter of James Churchill,

Although there are so many tranquil, intellectual, and really distinguished persons here, they are but few compared with the multitude. Newport is, even apart from its solidly rich folk, the centre and home of dudedom.

A motion was made before Judge Potter, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, for a mandamus to compel the Executive Committee of the committee appointed to prepare the foundation and pedestal for Bartholdi's Statue of Liberty to cancel the contract for the laying of the foundation recently given to F. Hopkinson Smith, and to award it to Michael Fay.

The Third Ward Republican Association met last evening at Everett Hall, No. 398 Fultonstreet, Brooklyn, Major B.R. Corwin in the chair. The meeting was largely attended, and the enthusiasm exhibited gave promise of the hearty activity with which the Brooklyn Republicans will enter into the coming campaign.
SARATOGA, Aug. 21.--The weather is getting warmer in Saratoga, and, from present indications, the last 10 days of August are likely to be among the hottest of the season.

It was hot enough for all practical purposes yesterday, though students of the thermometer, while they perspired and swore, found the maximum point registered 3 lower than on Monday. They felt cooler at once.

The relative value of different methods of injecting railroad ties, to increase their durability, has been earnestly discussed and opinions still vary widely. It is stated that on one of the German railways the pine trees injected with chloride of zinc required a renewal of 21 per cent. after a lapse of a score of years; beach trees injected with creosote required a renewal of 46 per cent.

The plan to exchange the income bonds of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey for a new issue of debenture bonds drawing interest from May 1, as already announced, was adopted at a meeting of holders at which William Alexander Smith presided yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 21.--The stockholders of the News Journal held a special meeting yesterday afternoon to consider what should be done in view of the theft of the Democratic Convention by John R. McLean on Saturday and the attempt of Judge Hoadly to silence their paper.

Niblo's Garden, which is the home of the spectacular drama in this City, and which was the birthplace, so to speak, of this species of entertainment in New-York, was thrown open to the public last evening with grand spectacle, ...

TROY, Aug. 21.--The sixtieth session of the Grand Lodge of Odd-fellows of this State opened in this city this morning. About 600 representatives were present. The Grand Lodge degree was conferred upon 200 Past Grands.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 21.--The freight famine still threatens this port. Most vessels refuse to take any freight, waiting for still higher rates. Three steam-ships were chartered to-day to load with grain for September and October shipment at 6s. 6d. per quarter for the United Kingdom or Continent.

A meeting of the Trunk Line Committee (passenger department) has been called for tomorrow at the office of Assistant Commissioner S. F. Pierson, at No. 346 Broadway. The principal subjects to be considered are the emigrant business and the attitude of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad in relation to all kinds of passenger business.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21.--The first game in the grand billiard tournament of six days, 6,000 points, for $500, between Sexton and Wallace, opened last evening at the Metropolitan Temple. The attendance was small, not over 200 persons being present. The game was opened by Sexton.

For some time past the members of the cloak-making firm of Wronkow Finn, of No. 58 White-street, have suspected one of their employes, David Lichenstein, of No. 126 Henry-street, of stealing remnants of cloth and cloak trimmings from them. Lichenstein is a cloak-maker, working at home.
PANAMA, Aug. 21, via Galveston.--A fight occurred at Zipaquira between the national troops and those of Cundinamarca, and the commandant of the latter was killed. The Federal troops were triumphant.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Aug. 21.--A few minutes before the departure of the 7 o'clock Raleigh (N. C.) express train this evening, and while a large number of negro excursionists were gathered at the station here, a young man pushed his way through the crowd flourishing a revolver, and in an ...

LIMA, Aug. 21, via Galveston.--El Pueble states that the Chilian army will probably evacuate Lima on Sept. 15 and concentrate in Callao, Tacna, or Pisco. Iglesias has troops ready to proclaim his Government.

PARIS, Aug. 21.--The Gaulois deplores the inability of France to contract any alliance. It says: "America is England's rival. America has already approached Russia. Why should not Rusaia be a hyphen between America and France?"

A member of the American Yacht Club said yesterday that if John Roach would put up $10,000 for a long-distance race, say around Long Island or 100 miles out to sea, in which his Yosemite, Jay Gould's Atalanta, and E.S. Jaffray's Stranger should take part, he had no doubt a test of speed would take place.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 21.--A dispatch has just been received from Sherburne which states that Mr. White returned there this morning and emphatically denies having met with a large loss in Wall-street, or that he is pursued by officers of the law. His friends do not place any credence in the sensational dispatches regarding his losses.

Gen. E.G.W. Butler, who was a ward and intimate friend of Andrew Jackson, has given the St. Louis Republican some very interesting reminiscences of "Old Hickory." "I have his letters," said the General, "from 1821 till his death, in 1845." In a letter to Mr. Butler, dated May 1, 1823, Jackson wrote: "I am much pleased to find that you ...
To be recognized as an individual in American politics is something, considering the uniformity of American politicians in general.

The trial of Bertha Heymann, the confidence woman, who swindled Edward Sanders out of several hundred dollars at various times under false pretenses, was begun yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, before Recorder Smyth. Mr. Sanders told the story of his acquaintance with the woman on June 28.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Aug, 18.--The Hon. M.K. McGrath has received the following significant letter from John Kelly, the Tammany chief, of New-York:

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21.--A special dispatch to the Post-Dispatch from Gallatin, Mo., says: "The Sheriff is busy summoning 100 jurors for the Frank James trial. It is believed that it will take three days to secure the 12 men. The town is crowded.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21.--Another ambitious dramatic company has come to grief, and a number of histrionic stars are to-night twinkling as stars of the eleventh magnitude, avoiding the landlords and wondering how they will get home alive.
LONDON, Aug. 22.--The Hon. William Windom, ex-Secretary of the Treasury of the United States, was entertained at a banquet in London last night.
Capt. John H. McCarthy, who is charged with having falsely sworn that the steam-tug Mary N. Hogan was his sole property, was yesterday released on $3,000 bail by United States Commissioner Shields.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 21.--A special dispatch to the News Journal, from Lawrenceburg, Ind., says:

It is reported, and with some show of reason, that Mr. BLAINE'S book (of which everybody has already heard) is to be the lever by which he is to be hoisted into the Presidency. It will also serve another end.

SARATOGA, Aug. 21.--The sixth annual meeting of the American Bar Association, which will be held at the opera-house here to-morrow, will open with an address by the President, Alexander R. Gov. Crittenden having returned yesterday from California, the Globe-Democrat correspondent at Jefferson City called on him, thinking that he might have something to say regarding the recent attempts to enforce the Sunday law here.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21.--Mgr. Capel attended George Riddle's reading at the Casino today, and this evening he met a distinguished party of guests at a dinner tendered in his honor by Mrs. Marshall O. Roberts, of New-York.
The steam-ships Werra, of the North German Lloyd; France, of the General Transatlantic Line; Servia, of the Cunard Line, and Schiedam, of the Netherlands Mail, will sail for Europe today.

A correspondent, in a communication which we printed yesterday morning, expresses the opinion that our "criticisms". of the distillers who are asking the Government to give them more time in which to pay their taxes are "unjust," ...
The certificate of incorporation of the Importers and Grocers' Exchange of New-York, which has been called the Tea and Sugar Exchange, has been received from Albany.

YORK, Penn., Aug. 21.--The funeral of Judge Black to-day was by far the largest which ever took place in York. All business was suspended and the streets were thronged with people as the funeral cortege passed. Many distinguished persons were present from abroad.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 21.--A conference of the priests of this diocese called by the Archbishop Elder met to-day to consider the subject of devising means by which to pay the debts of the late Archbishop Purcell and his brother.
Mr. Charles T. Mills, aged 62, the father-inlaw of Harry Mann, manager of Haverly's Fourteenth-Street Theatre, died suddenly last night in Atwood's drug store in Broadway, near Thirteenthstreet.

LIVERPOOL, Aug. 21.--James McDermott, who was arrested here recently on his arriva from America in the steamer City of Montreal, on suspicion of complicity in the dynamite conspiracy, has been further remanded.

BOSTON, Aug. 21.--A private meeting of the creditors of Wright, Worster Co., the suspended wool-dealers, was held this afternoon. It was voted to refuse any detailed statement of the affairs of the firm for publication.

Reports made to the Board of Health yesterday show that in the neighborhood of Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth streets and the North River there are 950 loads of manure and stable straw stored; on the bulkhead between Little Twelfth and Bloomfield streets there are 200 loads;

Apropos of the mysterious light which has recently appeared on the railroad track at Amsterdam, N.Y., and has aroused the superstitious fears of the engineers and brakemen who have seen it, an editorial writer is the Rochester Democrat and Chronicle says:

Mr. Peter Gardner had quite a frolic yesterday afternoon at Mayport with a tarpon weighing 150 pounds. Its head measured 20 inches in length and 2 inches across the eyes. Mr. Gardner states that he carried the small row boat through the water at a rapid rate until he was stranded on a sand bar, when a knife was applied to his fishship, and he was safely landed on the beach.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21.--The majority of the striking operators requested yesterday to be reinstated and were received. The same form of oath administered by the Western Union Telegraph Company East was taken here.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug 21.--The Utica Driving Park Association began its trotting meeting to-day with a race between the celebrated stallions Director and Duquesne for a purse of $2,000, of which $800 to the second. Director won in three straight heats. Time--2:25; 2:22 ; 2:20 . Director was the favorite in the pools at five to one.

MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 21.--A sealed bottle, containing information of the probable abandonment of the American bark Huron, from Havre, June 29, in ballast, and commanded by John Heller, was found at Fort Morgan Beach to-day.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 21.--The sidewheel iron passenger steamer Olympian, built by Harlan Hollingsworth for the Oregon Railway and Transportation Company to run on Puget Sound, was launched this afternoon. She is 260 feet long, 38 feet wide, and 14 feet depth of hold.

Mr. George H. Sargent, of the firm of Sargent Co., at No. 37 Chambers-street, left NewHaven, Conn., yesterday, in a steam launch to cruise along the Connecticut and Massachusetts coast, making a thorough search for any trace of the missing sloop-yacht Mystery.
BAR HARBOR, Aug. 21.--In addition to the forest fires which have already been raging for several days, fires have broken out in several new places.
West Market-street was astonished, on Saturday morning, at the display of beautiful undertaking vehicles that were drawn up in front of W. E. Doron's new undertaking establishment.

Mr. Thomas Lisbourne, who is said to be an accomplished Irish comedian, and Miss Clari Majilton are to be members of Mr. Frank Majilton's comedy company, now on their way to this country.
The third annual congress of the Federation of the Trade and Labor Unions of the United States and Canada opened at Turn Hall, is East Fourth-street, yesterday afternoon.
The residence of F.M. Brown, in Webber Block, at the corner of Fourth and Columbia streets, was struck by lightning early yesterday morning.

LONDON, Aug. 21.--The Times's correspondent at Hong Kong reports that Haidoung, in Tonquin, was attacked by the French on Aug. 19. The result of the attack is not yet known. The Standard's Berlin correspondent asserts that the Chinese Government is negotiating with Germany with a view to the purchase of 100,000 rifles.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22.--There were no polo games this afternoon for reasons best known to the polo players, who did not announce "no game" until late this afternoon. The band was not informed, and accordingly was on the ground, and the livery stables were patronized by parties who had made arrangements to take friends to polo.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 22.--The sixth annual session of the American Bar Association was begun this morning with a very large attendance. The convention will last three days. MONTREAL, Aug. 22.--A sister ship of the Ludwig, now so long over due, arrived here today from Antwerp having left that port a month later than the missing vessel. Almost all hope of the Ludwig's safety has been abandoned.

PARIS, Aug. 22.--At Royan, on the Gironde, there was on Friday a scene perhaps unprecedented in the annals of ballooning. M. Gratien, a well known aeronaut, was about to make an ascent in a hot-air balloon called "La Vidouvillaise."

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 22.--Alexander M. Lowery, a member of the Executive Committee of the Democratic State organization, left here to-day for Saratoga. He favors the holding of the State Convention in Buffalo. He was non-committal as to preferences for candidates.

YANKTON, Dakota, Aug. 22.--News has been received here of the legal execution of Ah Yung, a Chinaman, in the jail yard at Missoula, Montana, two days ago for the murder of another Chinaman on Jan. 29. He protested his innocence to the last, but met his fate without flinching. One hundred persons were present by permission of the Sheriff.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22.--A report from Texas states that early in August there was a shower of thousands of fish in Monte Morelos. There was an earthquake at Pachuca causing 20 deaths and the destruction of 30 houses.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Aug. 22.-The Chenango Valley Railroad was sold to-day under a mortgage foreclosure for $100,000 to the West shore Railway Company, which holds all but $10,000 of the $261,000 worth of outstanding bonds. The principal and interest now due thereon amount to $388,000.

The Denver Railroad and Construction Land and Coal Company issued promissory notes, which the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of this City, certified, to the amount of $182,946,55. They were due April 1 and remained unpaid. In the Exchange Sales-rooms yesterday there was sold a quantity of securities put up as collateral as follows: 412 first mortgage bonds of the Denver.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22.--Commissioner Marble, of the Patent Office, will, it is now said, resign his position on Sept. 1. He intended to leave the place some time ago but as an illustrated New-York periodical involved him in a scandal he deferred the step, with Secretary Teller's consent, so that it might not look as if he retired under fire.

BOSTON, Aug. 22.--It was reported here late this afternoon that a warrant had been issued in New-York for the arrest of Mr. Fayette Shaw, of the suspended great leather firm of Shaw Brothers, on the ground that not all of his paper is proper paper. MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 22.--The American Association for the Advancement of Science was not called to order until 10:30 o'clock yesterday, owing to the late arrival of members. The Standing Committee submitted a report recommending that the next annual meeting be held in Philadelphia on Sept. 3, 1884, which was adopted.

There were a good many visitors yesterday to the quarry at North Tarrytown where the alleged finding of a large quantity of burglars' booty was reported to have taken place. The stuff was found in a small dry goods case, and it seems to be the proceeds of the petty thieving of tramps and is not of much value. There were two overcoats.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22.--Col. Dudley, the Commissioner of Pensions, returned to the city last night and to-day resumed work at his desk. He said to the correspondent of THE TIMES that no efforts would be made by the Pension Office, as reported, to keep the pension-list, when printed, from general inspection.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22.--Delegates from the Eastern Glass-blowers' Union, representing the employes in New-Jersey, Baltimore, and Norristown, Penn., met a committee of glass manufacturers in this city to-day, and it was agreed that the schedule of wages for the ensuing year should be the same as those in effect now. BALTIMORE, Aug. 22.--The schooner Waterline, of Boston, Capt. Kelly, from Charleston to Richmond, Va., with a cargo of 385 tons of guano, sprung a leak on the 17th inst. and sank next day, 12 miles east of Body's Island. The crew were all saved by the vessel's boats, and were picked up soon afterward by the schooner Lewis K. Cottingham from Charleston. They arrived at this port this morning.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 22.--The Marquis of Lorne will return to Ottawa on the 5th September, to present the Dominion Rifle Association prizes, and on the 7th, 12th, and 13th the Marquis and the Princess will visit Toronto. They are expected to remain in Ottawa for a month, and Lord Lansdowne will also be here with them for a time before assuming office as Lord Lorne's successor.

LIVINGSTON, Montana, Aug. 22.--Mr. Hatch's excursion party to the Yellowstone Park arrived here at 5:15 this afternoon, and will proceed south into the National Park to-morrow morning. CHICAGO, Aug. 22.--Fritz Schneidmuller, of New-York, has complained to the police that a night or two ago, while intoxicated, he was steered into the gambling-house above Mike McDonald's saloon, and that there he lost $165.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 22.--A meeting of the Bishops of the Province of St. Louis was held today at the residence of Archbishop Kendrick, for the purpose of nominating a successor to the late Bishop John McMullen, of Davenport, Iowa.
LONDON, Aug. 22.--The deaths from cholera in Egypt on Tuesday numbered 131, including one at Cairo.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 22.--Taylor's Opera-house in this city has been engaged by the Democratic State Executive Committee for Sept. 13, for the purpose of holding a State Convention. No formal call has yet been issued for the convention.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 22.--The Hon. W. G. Donnan, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, was to-day nominated for the State Senate in this district, which is composed of Delaware County. Mr. Donnan served two terms in Congress, succeeding the Hon. W. B. Allison.

Samuel Carr, a dissipated painter, made a desperate attempt to commit suicide yesterday morning while at the foot of East Eighty-sixthstreet. Carr had been a good and steady workman until about two years ago, when his wife died. Then he took to drink, neglected his work.

Butter, son of Senator Butler, while riding with a young lady friend at Lancaster Court-house on Monday, was thrown from his horse, which fell upon him, badly crushing him and causing concussion of the brain. SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22.--Last night was the second night of the billiard tournament at the Metropolitan Temple. The game was the balkline game of 600 points, for $500 between Schaefer and Sexton. Schaefer opened the game, but failed to score. After two hours' play Schaefer won, scoring 600 to Sexton's 562. The highest runs made were: Schaefer, 143: Sexton, 105.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22.--The feeling with regard to the disappearance of Col. Churchill's daughter has somewhat abated, the discovery of letters left behind her showing that she was badly stage-struck and leading to the belief that she ran away to join some theatrical company. The police are taking but little interest in the case, but the family and friends of the girl still insist that some dreadful doom has overtaken her.

LONDON, Aug. 22.--Mr. Collings, (Liberal,) member for Ipswich, gave notice that at the next session of Parliament he would offer a resolution declaring that "it is desirable to grant a measure of home rule to Ireland as the best means of securing permanent peace to the Irish." Mr. Collings's announcement was received with cheers.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 22.--Marshal Murphy received Gov. Crittenden's letter to-day calling his attention to the report of an approaching prize-fight. The Marshal thereupon visited Independence, where Herbert Slade is now stopping. He returned to-night, and says that he found no evidence of preparations for a prize-fight and therefore cannot take official action in the matter.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 22.--Fully 2,500 persons witnessed the races yesterday. The favorite in the first race, Force, narrowly escaped a defeat by Glengarine, winning on the line by only a few inches. SHAMOKIN, Penn., Aug. 22--At the Lake Fidler Colliery to-day Richard Lewis, Sr., was killed, and Richard Lewis, Jr., and George Reckert badly injured, by the premature explosion of a blast.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22.--The leading produce markets were again dull to-day and again irregular. The most of them started up strong, and held up pretty well until about noon, when they fell back, losing the early advantage. The inciting cause of the advances was the fear of a cold wave over the corn belt.

LONDON, Aug. 23.--The Irish Tramways bill was passed in the House of Lords this afternoon.

BOSTON, Aug. 23.--It is reported from Portland, Me., that 14 persons were drowned to-day at Wells, in that Stage. No particulars have been received. The telegraph office is closed, and no communication can be had at the point at which the accident is said to have occurred.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 23.--The regatta of the Upper Hudson Navy took place here to-day. The four-oared race was won by the Laureates, of Troy, in 13:06. The Cahoes crew was second, in 13:27. The junior singles was won by Hopkins, of Watervliet, in 15:02, with Degouche second, in 15:16. There were five starters. The double-scultrace was won by the Laureates. Time--13:22 . The Apokeepsing crew was second, in 13:50.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 23.--Prof. Lewis Swift, Director of the Warner Observatory, last evening discovered in the Constellation Andromeda what appeared to be a comet.

A passenger rate war was developed here to-day on round trip tickets from Chicago to Buffalo. The tariff rate has been $22, but it was discovered that several roads had been allowing passengers $1 commission, making the rate $21. The Grand Trunk Road to-day announced an open rate of $21, and other roads have followed this lead.

Charles Lecocq's, opera "Heart and Hand" was revived last night at Daly's Theatre by Mr. J. C. Duff's Standard Opera Company in the presence of an audience that was large considering the earliness of the season and the ambition of the unwearied thermometer.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 23.--The date for the passage of the dummy steamer Maid of the Mist described in yesterday's special to THE TIMES, through the Whirlpool at Niagara, has been fixed for Sept. 6, at 9 P.M. A great effort will be made to draw a crowd upon that occasion.

The mystery which surrounded the disappearance of Mr. L.H. Booth, the Castle Garden pool agent, has not yet been cleared up. The body found in the North River last Wednesday morning is not now thought to be that of Mr. Booth.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23.--Jesse Ferguson has been removed from the chief clerkship of the new Post Office Building now in course of construction here. His accounts are being investigated. Superintendent McArthur says he has lost some money by Ferguson's actions, but the Government will not lose anything.

WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 23.--A game of base-ball was played here to-day between the NewYork and Monitor Clubs, resulting in favor of the former by a score of 11 to 6.

Police Commissioner Joel W. Mason at a meeting of the Seventeenth Assembly District Republican Association last Spring resigned his office as delegate to the Central Committee. At the time he would give no reasons for his actions, but his resignation was accepted.
