Victor Ruhl, a German, was found dead in his room at the boarding-house of Mrs. Paul, No. 125 Canal-street, on Wednesday, having committed suicide several days previously.

A charter long ago granted to the Adirondack Railroad Company to build a road through the heart of the wilderness from the Hudson to the St. Lawrence, and to acquire 1,000,000 acres of land therein, has lately been revived and the prosecution of the work begun.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23.--Sporting circles in this city are in a ferment to-night over the fate and whereabouts of Paddy Ryan, Sullivan's competitor in the prizering. Exactly where he is and in what condition is not at this writing known.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 23.--Malaria has appeared at several of the New-Hampshire beaches, and many persons are ill. Mr. Lewis, a wealthy Philadelphian, died at his cottage yesterday of malignant typhoid fever. His servants and family are ill. Defective drainage is supposed to be the cause of the trouble. Mrs. Ward, a hotel guest at Rye Beach, also died yesterday.

UTICA,--N.Y., Aug. 23.--This was the third day of the trotting meeting here. The weather was fair and the attendance large. The first race was for a purse of $1,000, divided, for the 2:29 class. In the pools Maxy Cobb sold for $25, Zoe B. $12, and the field $4.
RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23.--Benjamin W. Martin, D.D., President of Hamilton College, gave a lecture before the Summer School of Christian Philosophy this morning to a large audience.

Old Chief Red Cloud has gone to the Shoshone agency with a part of his band for a three months' visit with the Arapahoes. Before leaving Pine Ridge he had his hair cut off short, the first step he ever took toward civilization.

LONG BRANCH, N.J. Aug. 23.--The 41 lifesaving stations along the New-Jersey coast, manned by 281 patrolmen and 40 keepers or Captains, will open on Sept. 1 and continue open until May 1, 1884.

MONTREAL, Aug. 23.--Viscount de Pontavia de Hussey and M. Bocafive, who have been inspecting horses in this province to see if they would be suitable for the French Cavalry Service, have left for home. PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Aug. 23.--A man who, from papers found in his possession, is supposed to be W.E. Murty, of Bergen, committed suicide to-day at Sparrowbush, three miles from this place. He saw a train approaching on the Erie Road, and threw himself in front of the engine, at the same time lifting his hands as if in prayer. His head was completely severed from his body.

MOBILE, Aug. 23.--The crop reports from Alabama, Mississippi, and Florida this week are somewhat more encouraging, for the drought is at length at an end and the destruction from this source about finished.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23, 1883. The Treasury Department to-day purchased 350,000 ounces of silver for delivery at the San Francisco, New-Orleans, and Philadelphia Mints.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 23.--Late this afternoon three deeds of assignment were filed by the members of one of the oldest and largest grocery and grain firms in Cincinnati.
TOLEDO, Aug. 23.--The 200 girls employed by Black Hoffman who struck for an advance of wages, for making clothing, were given the advance asked, and they returned to work in a body to-day.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 23.--Herbert Slade, with his trainer, left Independence, to-day, and it is stated that he has gone to Atchison, Kan., to prepare for the coming prize fight. This takes the case out of the hands of the Missouri authorities.

SITKA, Alaska, July 17.--The United States man-of war Adams, which has been in Alaska waters for the past year, is the only visible sign of the Nation's power for which the Indians have any great respect.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23.--The leading produce markets were again very dull to-day, and as irregular as was consistent with dullness. Provisions were weak, while grain was easier. The receipts of cereals were fair in volume, those of oats being large, and the freight engagements embraced about all the vessel room that was ready to load, with some that had yet to arrive.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 23.--The news of the failure of Bishop Co. obtained but limited currency to-night, and business men, as a rule, will be greatly surprised when they read of it in the morning.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 23.--Arrangements were completed to-day between H.I. Kimball and the owners of the Kimball House property and certain citizens by which a larger house will be built at a cost of $500,000. The ruins are being torn away.

The calling of the Democratic State Convention to meet at Buffalo on the 27th of September is of small importance compared with the committee's adoption of the Roosevelt resolution in regard to the election of delegates in this City.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Aug. 23.--The bark Gladiator, arrived from Boston, reports being in a collision on Aug. 15 off Cape Ann with the schooner Effie Young, and carrying away a portion of her mainsail, bulwarks, stanchions, forward chain plates and part of her forward house, and doing her other damage.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 23.--The Republican Committee of Chautauqua County to-day decided to hold the convention at Mayville on Oct. 4.

A number of colored Republicans of the Ninth Ward met last evening at No. 21 Cornelia-street, and organized an Independent Colored Pepublican Club of the Ninth Assembly District.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 23.--E.B. Emory was elected Grand Guard of the Knights of Pythias to-day. The report of the Committee on Laws, over which there has been much discussion, was finally adopted by a vote of 181 to 67.

At the invitation of the manager, Mr. Hugh Paton, a number of gentlemen connected with the city papers paid a visit to the extensive stables of the Shedden Company, on William-street, yesterday, for the purpose of witnessing the effect of nails, which some of the horses have inadvertently trod upon while porforming their work.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 23.--The golden wedding of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Mesler, of Gasport, Niagara County, was celebrated yesterday. One hundred guests were present, some from as far West as Dakota.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 23.--The cushion carom game of billiards at the Metropolitan Temple last evening of 300 points, for $500, between Sexton and Schaefer, was won by the former, Forty-nine innings were played. Schaefer scored 283 points. Sexton's best run was 46, and Schaefer's 33. The time of the game was one hour and thirtyfive minutes.
Ex-Sheriff Albert Daggett was again prostrated by the heat on Wednesday afternoon, and in the seme place where a few months ago he succumbed to the influence of the torrid atmosphere.
MONTREAL, Aug. 23.--The Grasbrook, the first steamer of the new Brazilian line, arrived here to-day from Hamburg after a good passage. She will not proceed to Brazil this trip.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Aug. 23.--Judge Royce this morning appointed Charles W. Rich Receiver of the St. Albans Trust Company. Mr. Rich is a resident of Swanton, but is closely allied to St. Alabans business interests.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23.--A meeting of the Bishops of the Province of St. Louis was held yesterday at the residence of Archbishop Kendrick, for the purpose of nominating a successor to the late Bishop John McMullen, of Davenport, Iowa.
TROY, N.Y., Aug. 23.--The Grand Lodge of Odd-Fellows concluded its sessions this morning. Grand Master Tresider, of Brooklyn, was installed.

The riot at the negro camp-meeting at Trimble Springs bottom Sunday night turns out to have been a much more serious affair than the account yesterday indicated. An American reporter went out to the battle-ground yesterday, but everything presented a perfect picture of peace and rest.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23.--The General Grand Chapter of the Eastern Star elected Rolin C. Gaskill, of Oakland, Cal., Grand Patron, and Mrs. Jennie C. Mathews, of Iowa. Grand Matron.
ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 23.--The number of people killed by the cyclone on Tuesday is now fixed at 34, and the number of the wounded at 82. Of the latter, nine were fatally injured.

Max Wallenstein, a German, 19 years of age, employed to run the elevator at the Metropolitan Hotel, met with a fatal accident at 12:30 o'clock this morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23.--The leave of ab sence on Surgeon's certificate of disability granted First Lieut. William H. McMenn, Eighth Infantry, April 23, 1883, has been attended two months on Surgeon's certificate of disability.

A proceeding, which seems to have been suggested by the recent decision of Judge Nelson, in Boston, that Hong Kong Chinese are British subjects, and, therefore, not amenable to our antiChinese immigration law, was begun in the Supreme Court here yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23.--The Warren Second National Bank has levied an assessment of 75 per cent. on its capital stock, half payable within 10 days and half within 40. When the 75,000 is paid in the bank well reopen for business.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 23.--Although the weather was threatening, the attendance at the races to-day was very large.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 23.--The liabilities of Vincent Shinkle, which at the time of his failure were estimated at $80,000, are now said by the appraisers and Assignees to amount, to about $100,000 more, and the assets at the lowest appraisement will reach $115,000.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Aug. 23.--A grand reunion occurred here to-day of ex-Confederate soldiers. The attendance was quite large, the parading column being a quarter of a mile long-- something unparalled in this historic burg.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 23.--Dr. F.R. Hudson was shot by Charles Osterhoudt this morning in Williams's drug store, Hoosick Falls. A new and peculiarly frightful Fenian plot has just been discovered at Plymouth, England. The police have found a box containing a white powder that takes fire only when brought into contact with water.
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 23.--To-day the Georgia Legislature passed and sent to the Governor for his signature the Registration bill which stands as a singular anomaly in political legislation.

GRANT CITY, Mo., Aug. 23.--A constable and posse attempted to take William Andrews from a house of ill repute at Isadora, and were fired upon by him, one of the posse, Dr. J.C. Rex, being killed. Andrews gave himself up. Dr. Rex was an influential citizen.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Aug. 23.--James Williams, an old gentleman, who arrived here to-day from Madison, Wis., to pay a visit to his sister, Mrs. Henry Clapper, was robbed on the cars, between Amsterdam and Palatine Bridge, of his pocket-book, containing quite a sum of money. Luckily, he had $250 in bills sewed in his shirt. The railroad detectives are on the trail of the thieves.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Aug. 23.--The first bale of new cotton received at this port arrived to-day from Marion, S.C. It was consigned to G. W. Williams Co., was classed as strict low middling, and sold at 12 cents per pound.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 23.--Ferdinand Newman, who is rapresented as a large insurance broker doing business in New-York; gained the confidence of a number of people here and had them cash his checks for several hundred dollars. He was arrested this afternoon by Detective Irving and lodged in jail.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23.--George Stephen, President of the Canadian Pacific Railway, and his party of English railroad magnates arrived in this city this morning, having left Montreal yesterday morning.

The programme offered at Monmouth Park yesterday was not seductive enough to draw a large crowd, and, therefore, the attendance of spectators was very moderate, but nevertheless those who were present enjoyed some good racing, while they were almost driven to desperation by the wretched starting.

Stimulated by similar successful enterprises of THE TIMES, the Boston Traveller has made a careful canvass of the State of Massachusetts, with a view to finding out just what the people think of Gov. B.F. BUTLER as a candidate for re-election.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23.--What with Newport's high tides and heavy seas, the lawn-tennis tournament, c., the "City by the Sea" has been quite gay to-day. The hot weather in the cities is sending many guests to Newport, and the indications ... cations are that all the hotels will be filled again at least 24 hours earlier than they were last week.

BRADFORD, Penn., Aug. 23.--The brokers' express, consisting of an express, a baggage, and a smoking car and two coaches, loaded with passengers, ran through a switch at Red House, a small station on the New-York. Pennsylvania, and Ohio Railroad, a few miles west of Salamanca, this morining.

The body of Alfred C. Mathews, one of the keepers at the County Jail in Jersey City, was found in the Bay last evening, near Brooklyn. Mr. Mathews went to Long Branch on Sunday, and the last seen of him was when he went aboard the steamer Plymouth Rock. It is supposed that he fell from the boat.

It is not often the case that the marriage and death of the same person are noticed in the same paper. Nevertheless the marriage of Miss Sara Brewster with Dr. S. Willard appeared in yesterday's papers at the same time as the notice of the bride's death.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 23.--William Jenkins Co., grocers and commission merchants, have failed. Their liabilities, of all sorts, amount to about $35,000. It is believed that the assets of the firm will be sufficient to pay the secured creditors in full, and will leave the unsecured ones 40 or 50 cents on the dollar.

The recent Chinese case in Boston hinged on the nationality of the Chinese ship carpenter whose landing it was sought to prevent on the ground that he was "a Chinese laborer" within the meaning of the act of 1882.

PETERSBURG, Va., Aug. 24.--The Right Worthy Grand Lodge of the Independent Order of St. Luke, of Virginia, adjourned this afternoon, to meet at Norfolk, Aug. 21, 1884. At the session today the officers elected for the ensuing year were installed and appeal cases were disposed of.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 24.--The shooting-match on the grounds of the Long Branch Gun Club at Deal Beach to-day, was largely attended. The conditions were $50 entrance, 50 birds each, at 30 yards. There we eight entries, making a purse of $400. The birds were very strong flyers. Edgar Murphy, of New-York, killed 44 birds, Mr. Edmonds, of Philadelphia 41, and Walter G. Murphy, of New-York, 40.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 24.--The family of William Ludder, of Winsted, Minn., partook of a luncheon on Wednesday, of which cheese which bad been cooked in a brass kettle formed a part, and all were poisoned. Three of the family have since died, and the others are not expected to recover.

The twenty-fifth excursion of the Floating Hospital for Sick Children took place last Thursday. There were about 1,000 sick children and their mothers on board. Some of the children were left at the Sea-side Nursery, Cedar Grove, Staten ...

CHICAGO, Aug. 24.--The leading produce markets were more active to-day and averaged lower. Provisions were very weak, wheat rather heavy, and corn relatively steady. The fine weather, with news of an increasing grain movement and rumors of cholera in a neighboring city, were assigned as the leading causes of weakness here and elsewhere.

BOSTON, Aug. 24.--Capt. Mathisen and the crew of the steam yacht Ideal arrived here this afternoon en route to New-York. Capt. Mathisen reports the accident to have been caused by an incompetent local pilot, who, when running the yacht in a fog, on the afternoon of Aug. 19, changed her course and ran her on a rock. The yacht was valued at $35,000.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 24.--Senator Butler's son is gradually improving, and his physicians think he will now recover.
Mr. Tong Sing, the steward of the muchlamented Jeannette, upon which DeLong and many other valuable lives were sacrificed in the Arctic Ocean, honored the Chinese-American a visit last week.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Aug. 24.--The Construction Committee of the River Commission arrived here this evening on the steamer Mississippi from Cairo. They have been examining the Government works down to this point, and report them in good condition. At this place they ordered the discontinuance of the dredging in the West Pass of the lake and the resumption of dredging in the harbor proper.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Aug. 24.--This city and the neighboring village of Belpre are shrouded in sorrow over the drowning of John M. Hale and his son, which occurred in the Ohio River here this afternoon.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 24.--The Missouri Free Trade League, of which ex-Gov. Phelps is President, has issued an invitation to all who oppose a protective tariff and favor a genuine reform in the revenue laws to a conference at St. Louis

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--First-Lieut. Loyd S. McCormick, Seventh Cavalry, now on leave of absence at Marietta, Ohio, has been ordered to proceed to Jefferson Barracks, Missouri, and report in person to the Superintendent of Mounted Recruiting Service for temporary duty.

LIMA, Aug. 24, via Galveston.--The Tribune has received information from the Province of Chancay that the troops under Sub-Prefect Rivers, while on their way from Iguari to Sayan, refused to proceed and fell upon the officers, killing Rivera and two Captains. Three soldiers were also killed. The next day, upon the arrival of a detachment of Peruvian Cavalry, under Col. Vargas, 14 of the culprits were hanged.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--The Supervising Inspector-General of Steam Vessels reports that during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1883, the total number of accidents resulting in loss of life was 34,
TUCSON, Arizona, Aug. 24.--During a storm at Camp McDowell this week lightning struck the military quarters, killing Corp. Hempbell, of Company C. Sixth Cavalry, and injuring several others.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24.--The last foxhunt of the season took place this afternoon. The meet was at Southwick's Grove, where many festive gatherings have assembled. The attendance of fashionable spectators was unusually large, and the weather was all that could be wished for.

As required by law, the Board of Estimate and Apportionment fixed the salaries yesterday of William Dowd, James C. Spencer, and George W. Lane, the three citizen members of the Aqueduct Commission, at $8,000 each per year. This is the full limit allowed by the law creating the commission.

Some weeks ago a 3-year-old boy of R.F. Taylor, of No. 418 Main-street, Peterson, N. J., while playing about a lumber-yard fell and was hurt on the breast, where a swelling appeared several days after.
Last week Andrew Heckman was hired as engineer by Anton Hupfel's Sons, brewers, at One Hundred and Sixty-first-street and St. Ann's-avenue.

LONDON, Aug. 24.--The Times this morning again comments at length on the article against France recently published in the Berlin North German Gazette, and which has attracted much attention throughout Europe. The Times says that the Gazette's article is a gross and deliberate insult.

The workmen employed in the shoe shop of S. W. Mela, of No. 74 Warren-street, have gone on a strike for an increase of wages. A notice was published in the newspapers requesting shoe-makers to keep away from this City on account of the strike. Mr. Mela yesterday declined to say anything about the strike.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Aug. 24.--A party of sporting men from New-York have been here for several days negotiating for the purchase of a suitable location for a club-house and training-grounds for prize-fighters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--The following letters, received to-day, disclose two flagrant cases of the notorious N.W. Fitzgerald. It will be seen that in the first case a fee was collected where nothing was done, and in the second case where nothing could be done.

The Bisby Club invited Gov. Cleveland on his way through the wilderness of Herkimer County to indulge in a deer-hunt. Six hounds were sent out to scour the country, and the 16 guns of the club were divided up among the sportsmen.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. The twenty-mile bicycle race at Athletic Park to-day was won by H.W. Higham, of England.

The story telegraphed from Boston and published in yesterday's papers to the effect that criminal proceedings were about to be institued by the Park Bank, of this City, against Fayette Shaw, of the bankrupt firm of Shaw Brothers, of Boston, was positively denied yesterday by E. Kellogg Wright, Cashier of the Park Bank.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24.--There is still great excitement here over the mysterious disappearance of Mary Churchill.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--Supervising Inspector-General Dumont says that the law passed by the last Congress regulating the inspection of foreign steam-ships carrying passengers to and from this country is now in full and successful operation.

The congress of the Federation of Trade and Labor Unions met yesterday morning at 9 o'clook. A resolution was adopted making the consideration of the eight-hour system paramount to all other labor questions and urging the enforcement of the system on all General and State Governmental work.

PETERSBURG, Va., Aug. 24.--During the progress of a storm in Brunswick County last evening, William Stokes was struck by lightning and instantly killed. Two other persons who were near him were stunned.

CHARLESTON, Aug. 24.--The South Carolina Railroad Commission has finally adopted a standard schedule of rates and classifications which will control charges on freight and passenger transportation on all the railroads in this State. BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 24.--There are now no forest fires within four or five miles of here, and there is no cause for alarm. The fires are confined principally to green woods, mostly spruces. Not a house, barn, or rod of fencing has been destroyed and there is no ground for the sensational reports to the contrary.

SARATOGA, Aug. 24.--"Where's Brown?" Is the anxious inquiry of the Tammany Democrats who linger in Saratoga; "What has become of the man?" Brown--Thomas Brown, Jr., of Rochester, as he is recorded in full on the roll of the Democratic State Committee ...

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 24.--The marriage of Carl Bosshard and Elise Clay has a tinge of romance about it. Four years ago a Swiss colony was established near Atlanta. Among its members was Bosshard. Having thrived he sent for his sweetheart in Switzerland.

TUCSON, Arizona, Aug. 24.--At 8 o'clock this morning, on Big Hill, six miles south of Clifton, Arizona, the Pomeroy express wagon, loaded with Chinamen, was attacked by "rustlers." The Chinamen returned the fire, and wounded one of the "rustlers" mortally. Four Chinamen were wounded, two fatally. The "rustlers" succeeded in getting $300.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 24.--The twentyfirst anniversary of the muster-in of the One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Regiment, New-York Volunteers, later known as the Eighth New-York Heavy Artillery, was celebrated on Wednesday by a reunion of the survivors at the International ...
LONDON, Aug. 25.--The steam-ship Avlona, (Br.,) Capt. Sangster, from Montreal Aug. 11, has arr. here.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 24.--Ex-Judge Small, proprietor of an extensive hop farm in Waukesha County, says that his plants have been affected by the hot sirocco, or stifling south-west wind, of the past week, and thinks the crop of the whole State will be seriously reduced in quantity. The brewers, however, will not be affected, as he thinks they regard hops as a luxury, and not a necessity, in the manufacture of beer.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 24.--The attendance at the meetings here is unabated. To-day Presiding Elder Hewitt conducted the opening exercises. Sermons were delivered by the Rev W. P. Corbit, on "Be Perfect;" the Rev. George P. Morris, on "Sirs, What Must I Do to be Saved?" and the Rev. George J. Mingins, on "If Ye Know These Things, Happy are Ye if Ye do Them."
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 24.--The Daily Democrat, a newspaper started in this city 11 months ago, suspended to-day.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 24.--The new Cincinnati Board of Health, consisting of five Democratic saloon-keepers and one physician, also a Democrat whose reputation is not good, is already charged with corruption.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24, 1883. Sitting Bull and four other Indians have been granted permission to attend the Fair at Des Moines, Iowa.

LONDON, Aug. 24.--Among the passengers by the steamer Sardinian, which left Liv erpool yesterday for Quebec and Montreal, are Lord and Lady Carnarvon and the Secretary of the Welsh Quarrymen's Union. The object of the letter's trip is to establish a Welsh colony on a spur of the Rocky Mountains, near Fort Calgarry.
MONTREAL, Aug. 24.--The United States steamer Vandalia arrived here to-day and took a berth at Hochelaga.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 24.--The devotional meeting at 9 o'clock this morning by Dr. H. M. Adams, of Meriden, Conn., was attended by over 2,000 persons, and much interest was shown. The children's prize spelling-match took place this morning, and excited much interest and amusement.

Some remarkable specimens of art produced by a new invention in photography may be seen at No. 40 West Eighteenth-street, the office of the Bonnaudtype Company. The new process, which may be termed photography in color, is the invention of M. Germeuil Bonnaud, a distinguished photographer of Paris.

The bay shore, below the toll-gate, has long been the haunt of a peculiarly impudent alligator, one of those lively saurians which think nothing of coming to the bank and laughing at the ladies and gentlemen of Mobile as they drive past on the Shell road.

When the syndicate headed by George S. Scott, George I. Seney, and Calvin S. Brice obtained control of the Richmond and Danville Rail road the old Board of Directors presented a statement of the operation of the road from Oct. 1, 1882, to June 30 of the present year.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24.--Simon Gaun died to-day in the Philadelphia Hospital from the effects of a dose of oxalic acid administered in mistake. He was an inmate of the epileptic ward in the institution, and on Thursday, Aug. 16, his condition was such that it was found necessary to administer a dose of bromide of potassium, but the narse, Henry Loftus, gave him oxalic acid instead. The Coroner will hold an inquest to-morrow.

P. H. McLogan, of Chicago, who represented the Trades Assembly, of that city, at the Labor Congress here, was the first witness examined by the United States Sub-Committee on Labor and Education yesterday.

CHICO, Cal., Aug. 24.--A fire is raging in the mountains near Feather River. News has been received that 30 miles of valuable timber has been destroyed. There is no knowing where the fire will stop. Sixty men are at work trying to check it.

ROME, Ga., Aug. 24.--A case of wholesale poisoning among negroes living in the suburban town of Forestville has just come to light. Three families living near Walter Price's house had fallen out with Price's wife.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 24.--Ferdinand Neuman, the New-York insurance broker who was arrested yesterday upon a charge of uttering worthless checks, made by David M. Hildreth, was arraigned to-day before Justice Pitcher. Mr. Hildreth did not appear, and the prisoner was discharged. The checks aggregated $800. Neuman, it is said, gave security for the amount.
A lady, who has a longing to become a tricycle-rider, writes to a provincial contemporary, lamenting that she is debarred from the pastime by a circumstance which might easily be remedied.
Leonard Walling, doorman of the Grand Central Station police squad, brought to Police Head-quarters last evening, Ida and Susan Miles, aged 14 and 10 years, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--At 4 o'clock this afternoon a young man named Frank Carr was found lying in a secluded part of the agricultural grounds almost strangled, a handkercheif being tied tightly around his throat.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 24.--The annual camp-meeting at Bethel Church, Cabarrut County, broke up in a row. The Bethel is situated in a corner of Cabarrus, near Union and Mecklenburg lines.

William Nolte, a tailor, 41 years of age, living at No. 68 Canal-street, Newark, was missing since Monday. His body was found yesterday in the meadows, near Elizabeth. The head had been eaten, probably by dogs. Nolte was of rather feeble mind. It is believed that he wandered to the spot where his body was found and committed suicide.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 24.--The case of the people against Collins and Mangin, for selling liquor without a license, the only case commenced since Lockport became a no-license and really a free rum city, last May, was withdrawn by the prosecution before the Police Justice this afternoon. It had been pending for two months.

SARATOGA, Aug. 24.--The attendance to-day at the races was equal to the average on extra days. The racing was fair. Loftin, the favorite in the first event, narrowly escaped defeat by Richard Loud. Apollo won his race handily, although hard pushed in the home stretch. The third race had a very suspicious look about it.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24.--Wasson, the defaulting army Paymaster, now undergoing imprisonment, was a member of the Army Relief Association, and had his dues paid up to Jan. 1, 1884.

Congressman Belmont received a painful wound in his left hand by the accidental discharge of a gun while hunting last Wednesday. Although the wound is not dangerous, it will probably confine him to his home for a month.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 24.--The Grand Lodge of the Knights of Pythias of Pennsylvania closed its annual session to-day.

There probably never was a more busy season of preparation among the theatres of this City than there is at present. The array of entertainments promised for the coming Fall and Winter is remarkably large and important. A reporter of THE TIMES visited a number of theatres yesterday and found nearly all in a bustle of activity.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24.--The inaugura tion of the foundation of the Garfield monument took place at noon to-day, under the auspices of the Grand Masonic Lodge of California, assisted by the Grand Encampment of Knights Templar of the United States, at Golden Gate Park.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24.--Paddy Ryan is safe and sound, except as to the headache which usually results from a night's encounter with the liquid lightning dispensed on the levee in shops like his own.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 24.--The Trustees of Dartmouth College this afternoon elected the Hon. George W. Nesmith, of Franklin; President Bartlett, and the Hon. C.W. Stanley Trustees of the New-Hampshire College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts, on the part of the board.

ATLANTA, Aug. 24.--The travelling public will be interested to know that arrangements have been perfected for the rebuilding of the Kimball House.

The Comte de Chambord died at Frohsdorff, Austria, yesterday morning at 7:15 o'clock. His last hours were tranquil, and his death was very easy. He was conscious to within a moment of his death. There will be no public funeral at Frohsdorf. The obsequies will be celebrated a week hence at Goritz.
OPELIKA, Ala., Aug. 24.--Yesterday Mr. David Hall, of Atlanta, was put off the Columbus and Western Railroad two miles from this city.
LONDON, Aug. 24.--In the Mincing-Lane Markets sugar has been dull. Coffee is steadier, with a better demand; Costa Rica advanced 2s. per hundred-weight. Rice is firm.

RUSHVILLE, Ill., Aug. 24.--The inhabitants of this (Schuyler) county are viewing with much disquietude the steady and rapid growth of a socalled religious movement which started about a year ago. LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 24.--A general assignment for the benefit of creditors by Edwin L. Mather to Theodore H. Van Horn was filed to-day in the Niagara County Clerk's office. The only preferred creditors are the lawyers of the assignor. Mr. Mather has not been in commercial business some time.

BOSTON, Aug. 24.--The professional single scull regatta at the Point of Pines this afternoon was a fine affair, and was witnessed by several thousand spectators. The distance was three miles, and the available course being only onefourth of that distance three turns were necessary. Edward Hanlan officiated as referee, and the race went off without a hitch and no fouls, although 12 men out of the 14 entered started in the race.
MYSTIC, Conn., Aug. 24.--A large number of persons attended the session of the Connecticut branch of the Universal Peace Union, which has just ended here.

The city of Yonkers is to have a new operahouse, and men are now at work on the foundation walls. It is to face on Woodworth-avenue, but will have an entrance on Warburton-avenue.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24.--Two patrol wagons, a dozen policemen, and about 500 boys attempted to run down three wild steers which had escaped from the stock-yards to the open prairie south of the city this afternoon. Two of the animals were recaptured, but the third overturned a buggy containing three persons and made a mad rush for a little child, which, however, escaped. The animal was finally shot by a policeman.

The racing yesterday at Brighton Beach was remarkable for the close finishes and the fast time made. There was much enthusiasm in the crowd, and the dividends in the mutual pools were so large as to make the holders of winning tickets extremely hilarious. It was a bad day for the favorites, as only one of them succeeded in catching the judge's eye first.

The visit of the Lord Chief-Justice of England to this country is an event the significance of which the American Bar in general will no doubt take pains to commemorate, although Lord COLERIDGE is specifically the guest of the Bar Association of this State.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 24.--Thursday morning dawned bright and beautiful. At an early hour strangers began to pour in from all directions, and by noon the streets were crowded with a surging mass of humanity.

CAMP STRONG, Wyoming, Aug. 21, via Bozeman, Montana, Aug. 23.--The reveille call at 5 o'clock awoke us all from a refreshing sleep, although the ice in our buckets this morning showed that three blankets had been none too many during the night for our comfort.

Two negroes and a white man are "wanted" by the police for felonious assaults. One of the negroes is John Taylor, alias "Buck" Taylor, a desperado well known in the Eighth Ward, who on Thursday night made an attempt to kill Patrolman James Duncan, of the Eighth Precinct.

L.C. Merrick, at one time well-known tobacconist of this city, who has of late years devoted himself to stock breeding, has on his farm, opposite Gifford's resort, in Waukesha County, one of the most remarkable herds of Shetland ponies ever brought into the United States.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 24.--An alarm of fire front the Exposition buildings to-night caused grave apprehension all over the city, and within a few minutes every street leading to the buildings was blocked with people. Within the buildings the alarm was as great as on the outside.

LAREDO, Texas, Aug. 26.--A report that Felipe Cortina, in command of 300 revolutionists, had been defeated near Tanjuco, is confirmed. CINCINNATI, Aug. 26.--Two Cincinnati grain firms have an interesting dispute on hand. Maguire Co. purchased of Nelson Perin Co. 2,500 bushels of corn in the Big Four elevator.

W.J. Anderson, formerly city editor of the Milwaukee Republican-News, in referring to the last illness of Judge Black, recalls the experience of a rather verdant reporter who attempted to interview the Judge while he was in Milwaukee on a visit a couple of years ago.
VICTORIA, British Columbia, Aug. 26.--Subject to the sanction of Parliament, all matters in dispute between the Dominion and British Columbia have been satisfactorily adjusted.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 26.--The whaling schooner Charles W. Morse, Capt. Rose, with 500 barrels of sperm-oil, has arrived here after a voyage of 22 months. She spoke on the western groung in June the schooner Pedro Varela, with 660 barrels of sperm-oil all told. In the middle of July she spoke the brig Frances A. Barstow, (no report of oil,) and on the last of July the schooner Admiral Blake. (no report of oil.)

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 26.--A skull has been unearthed in the Bennington battle-field with the track of the bullet that passed through it still discernible. Further investigation disclosed at a distance of 16 inches from the surface of the ground two human skeletons in one grave lying in opposite directions. From their large stature they are believed to be those of American soldiers.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 26.--A State convention of colored citizens of Tennessee will be held at Nashville on Sept. 20 for the election of delegates to the National Convention of colored men, which will assemble at Louisville four days later.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26.--The billiard tournament closed last night with a balk-line game, 200 points up, for $300, between Schaefer and Sexton. Schaefer won in 19 innings. Sexton scored 327 points. Schaefer's highest run was 129, and Sexton's, 88. The game occupied one hour and forty minutes.

By purchases of stock during the past few days the control of the Memphis and Charleston Railroad is taken out of the hands of persons inimical to the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia, by which it is leased. This will end the efforts to break the lease.

VIENNA, Aug. 26.--The body of the Comte de Chambord has been embalmed. The funeral will take place on Sept. 3. It will be the occasion of a grand Legitimist demonstration.

The police were informed yesterday by the friends of W.W. Craig, a gentleman farmer, of Schenectady, N.Y., that he had mysteriously disappeared from his home under circumstances which indicated that his mind was deranged.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 26.--The repairs to Canal Lock No. 48 were completed this morning, and navigation was resumed at 2 o'clock this afternoon. One hundred and fifty boats were waiting to be locked through and the force on the lock was doubled until the rush was over.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26.--Mrs. Helen Schleeht, 33 years old, committed suicide this morning by hanging herself in the cellar of the residence of her father, John Lucas.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 26.--The Cassadaga Lake Free Association closed its third annual camp-meeting to-day, after a month's session. Three thousand persons were present.
BOSTON, Aug. 26.--Five head of imported cattle at the Government quarantine, Waltham, Mass., have died, and a large number are seriously sick from the effects of poison maliciously administered.

EAST SAGINAW, Mich., Aug. 26.--Caleb Lincoln, a farmer, living four miles west of Saginaw City, was shot and instantly killed at a late hour last night by his son Charles, who is unmarried and who resided at home.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 27.--There has recently been brought to the notice of one of the trial Justices in Union County a fearful outrage upon the person of a negro woman in the lower part of the county.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 27.--Henry Jones, colored, was hanged in the jail-yard here this morning for the murder of Alvis H. Blake. During the entire day yesterday a crowd was assembled within the jail inclosure, near the prisoner's cell, many from mere curiosity and not a few to engage in holding religious services for his benefit.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27.--One of the most novel and daring thefts, or series of thefts, came to light to-day. It appears that a quartet of enterprising but dishonest teamsters have been doing a thriving business at the expense of the new Consumers' Gas Company, whose large mains now litter the streets in all directions.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 27.--The closing exercises of the tenth Assembly were impressive. President Lewis Miller, of Akron, Ohio; Superintendent John H. Vincent and Dr. B.M. Adams, of New-York, made the closing addresses. Dr. Vincent announced that the School of Languages and the Teachers' Retreat would open on July 12, 1884, and that the regular eleventh Assembly would open on Aug. 5.

A recent advertisement in a morning newspaper to the effect that $500,000 worth of diamonds and jewelry were offered in exchange for real estate prompted a reporter to inquire who had so large a stock of gems for trading purposes.

Over 3,000 yards of carpets belonging to the Park-Avenue Hotel and the Steamer Dean Richmond were sold at auction yesterday by G.W. Allen, and the sales-rooms at the Bowery and Bleecker-Street resembled an ancient bed-chamber hung with tapestry.

The steam-ship Flamborough, which arrived from Barbados yesterday, encountered very severe weather during the last four days of the voyage. The wind blew with hurricane force, while the sea was very high and frequently swept over the decks.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 27.--The 13 religious exercises at the Ocean Grove campmeeting to-day had as large an attendance as those of yesterday.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 27.--The brig Ruth, owned by J.R. Lithgow and E.P. Archibold, of this city, is reported burned in Little Glace Bay, Cape Breton. The origin of the fire is unknown. The wreck is aground above Harbor Pit. A portion of the sails, stores, and spars have been saved. There is no insurance on the vessel.

EASTPORT, Me., Aug. 27.--Secretary Chandler arrived here on Saturday night on the Tallapoosa. He gave a public reception to-day on board the vessel.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 27.--Conference committees of the New-York, Bradford, Oil City, Pittsburg, and Titusville Oil Exchanges met at Lakewood to-day to examine and prepare general rules governing the relations and business transactions between members of the conference.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 27.--Overcoats and fires were in demand at the mountain resorts in the Catskills this morning. On the Shawangunk range a slight frost is reported.

The National Association of Deaf-mutes begins its second convention to-day at Lyric Hall. Deaf-mutes from all parts of the country arrived in the City yesterday, and about 100 reported at headquarters. The number will be very largely increased by arrivals to-day.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 27.--John Gordon was stabbed last night by Mollie Ritchy, a white woman. She thrust a dagger into his breast three times, puncturing both lungs and inflicting fatal wounds. The woman was captured. No cause is assigned for the deed.

LONDON, Aug. 27.--A dispatch to a local news agency from Madrid says it is officially announced that the King will visit Germany.

BOSTON, Aug. 27.--Lowell dispatches indicate that, so far as the Lowell syndicate is concerned, the proposed consolidation of the NewEngland telephone companies has been abandoned. This practically ends the scheme.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 27.--About 10 o'clock this morning, while taking out the timbers of an old bulkhead to a flume of James Jackson Son's upper mill, in East Lockport, George Dudley was instantly killed by the fall of a heavy piece of timber. His neck was broken. Jackson was 62 years old, and leaves a family. He has resided in Lockport 40 years.

Billy Birch sat in his accustomed spot at the end of an ebony row in the pretty little opera-house of the San Francisco Minstrels last evening. Poor Charlie Backus's round figure and capacious month were missed from the other end.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 27.--The rather sudden disappearance of Capt. John J. Hall, assistant civil engineer on the Pennsylvania Railroad, who had his residence in New-Brunswick and an office in this city, causes much gossip among his acquaintances, and especially among his creditors.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--United States District Attorney Guthridge, of the Eastern District of Texas, has resigned his position and it will be accepted.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 27.--The Directors of the Farmers' Bank, of Richmond, have given notice that the affairs of the bank will be closed up, but that all depositors will be paid in full after Sept. 3.

The Metropolitan Club encountered its seventh defeat at the hands of the St. Louis team on the Polo Grounds yesterday. There was a large crowd in attendance, fully 2,500 persons paying admission to the grounds. The St. Louis men played in splendid form.
The number of immigrants landed at Castle Garden yesterday, 3,002, was the largest for several weeks.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27.--A request for the removal of Josiah W. Begole, Governor of Michigan, from the guardianship of his grandson, Josiah W. Begole, Jr., was filed in the Circuit Court today.

RED SULPHUR SPRINGS, West Va., Aug. 24.--About half a mile up the valley from this place is a gas spring. They have only to tap the ground here in this mountain district of Virginia and out flows whatever they want.

From the Bureau of the Minister of Public Works has been recently issued a statement of the iron and coal production of France up to the end of 1881, which shows both in that and the previous year a fair amount of increase. The total yield of iron ore for 1881 was 3,689,000 tons, an increase of 5 per cent. over that of 1880, which was less by 158,000 tons.

The enterprising priest of Lakeville, Conn., who has lately erected a crucifix twelve feet high in his churchyard has stirred up the Protestant and American sentiment of that village in a manner which, as a Commissioner of Agriculture once reported of the expenses of his department, exceeded his most sanguine anticipations.

Cornelius Cronin, of No. 532 West Fortythird-street, was arraigned before Justice Morgan, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday, on the charge of complicity in the assault and robbery of Charles Langmaack on the highway in Morrisania.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 27.--Advices from Ekaterinoslav, the scene of the recent riots against the Jews, say that 346 houses were wrecked and plundered during the progress of the riots, and that the losses sustained by the Jews are estimated at 611,000 rubles.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 27.--Cora, daughter of Mrs. George Clancy, was fatally burned to-night by the explosion of a kerosene lamp.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 27.--Last night, at Westfield, two masked burglars entered the house of Mrs. Jane Farrington and obliged her to open her safe, from which they took $400 in currency, a bank check, and two one-thousand-dollar registered Government bonds. The burglars bound Mrs. Farrington hand and foot and succeeded in making their escape.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 27.--Judge Hoadly has been confined to his home on East Walnut Hills for a week by a malarial attack. The anxieties of the canvass have been trying to him, but there is no good ground for the report that he has been broken down physically.
ALBANY, Aug. 27.--There is considerable quiet talk among Republicans in different parts of the State about the advisability of putting up a new ticket at Richfield Springs next month.

Patrolman Anton Bauman, of the Twentyninth Precinet, brought to the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday afternoon John P. O'Neil, a milk-dealer, of No. 157 West Thirty-seventh-street, whom he had arrested for being intoxicated and disorderly.

GREEN POND, Ala., Aug. 27.--A.J. Bevells, one of the leading merchants in that section, was assassinated by a man named Johnson last night in that town. Bevells had a quarrel with a man named Shackleford, who is Johnson's friend, and was in the act of ejecting him from his store when the shooting occurred.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 27.--The annual festival of the Baltimore Schuetzen Association was begun to-day at their park on the Belair road and will continue four days. The attendance was larger than for several years past. A large number of visitors from New-York and Washington were present.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 27.--A retreat of priests of the Archdiocese of New-York began to-day at St. Joseph's Theological Seminary. One hundred and ten are present. Father Munch, of NewYork, is conducting the retreat. Archbishop Corrigan is presiding, and Mgr. Preston, the VicarGeneral, is attending it. The retreat will end on Saturday.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 27.--The Pittsburg members of the Western Window-glass Manufacturers' Association met this afternoon. The meeting was the largest ever held, every manufacturer in the city being represented.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27.--In pursuance of an order issued by the Mayor on Saturday all the pool-rooms in this city where pools are sold on horse races are closed to-day. DETROIT, Aug. 27.--The evidence is now very strong that A.A. Atherton, County Treasurer of Roscommon County, has gone with funds amounting to about $18,000, of which $6,000 belongs to Roscommon village, $5,000 to Gerrish township, and $1,800 to Harvey Emery, a poor man, with small amounts belonging to various other persons and townships. His present whereabouts is unknown.

Jeremiah Ryan, the man who reported having seen her in Philadelphia, has concluded that he was mistaken.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27.--The gayeties of the season continue. GALLATIN, Mo., Aug. 27.--The defense in the James trial made a strong, but unsuccessful, effort to-day to break down the State's witness, Dick Liddell. Step by step they took up his story, and plied him question after question with all possible ingenuity.

About this time Mr. TENNYSON wishes that he had never been born. He has been directed by the Queen to write a poem in memory of the late JOHN BROWN, and he must obey or resign his position as Poet Laureate.

WELLS, Me., Aug. 27.--The body of Miss Emma Gould, one of the victims of the recent drowning accident, was recovered to-day. Three bodies have now been found--those of Miss Safford and Mr. Thayer having been recovered yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 27.--Dr. J.C. Beck, a member of the Board of Health, has caused warrants to be issued for the arrest of P.B. Ross and F.B. Gessner, of the Penny Post, for criminal libel, that paper having printed statements that Beck had received pay for making appointments. Ross surrendered to the authorities to-day. Gessner is not at home.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 27.--Five prisoners escaped from the Dover jail late on Saturday night, and are still at large. Among the number were Bob Allen and Henry Raisin, notorious negro burglars, who were leaders of a gang which carried on extensive thieving operations in Kent ...
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 27.--Delegates from the various sections of the country are already arriving for the Free Thinkers' Convention, which commences here, on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--Rear-Admiral Hughes, commanding the Pacific squadron, reports to the Navy Department under date of July 31, latitude 9 48' south, longitude 79 09' west, that on July 12 he transferred his flag from the Pensacola to the Lackawanna.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 27.--The convention of the National Woman's and Christian Tamperance Union at Round Lake closed yesterday. The services were largely attended, and addresses were delivered by Miss E.W. Greenwood, of Connecticut; Mrs. Mary S. Hunn, of Hyde Park, Mass., and by the President, Mrs. Mary S. Burt.
The steamer Normandie, of the French Line, from Havre, brought among her passengers yesterday four Commissioners from France to the Boston Exposition.

TORONTO, Aug. 27.--Hanlan returned to Toronto last evening. He says that he is tired out and will rest for a few days. He will go to the Carlton Place regatta on Sept. 6, and after that to Cincinnati.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 27.--The crew of the fishing sloop Ranger, which left this port yesterday about noon, with 12 persons, arrived here to-night from Cape May Point, where they were landed by the schooner A.W. Parker, of Taunton, Mass. The Parker picked them up in great distress after a stormy night at sea without food or water.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 27.--The badly mangled body of Addison Keller, a farm laborer, was found this morning at the central crossing of the Batavia Railroad at Tonawanda. He had been run over by a train.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27.--The complete returns to the General Land Office of public lands disposed of during the fiscal year ended June 30, as compiled to-day, show that 19,035,683 acres were taken up in that time, an increase of more than 5,000,000 acres over the total for the previous year.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 27.--John W. Bigelow, of New-York, was found dead in his bed at his cottage on Washington-street, Newport, on Sunday. He was recently rescued from drowning, at which time a quiet rumor prevailed that he had attempted suicide. The suicide theory has again been started, the alleged cause being financial difficulties, but the Doctor and the family deny that there is any foundation for the belief.

John E. Johnson, a resident of Tottenville, Staten Island, and keeper of the Great Beds Lighthouse, has mysteriously disappeared. Johnson was last seen on Saturday night, Aug. 18, when he was on duty at the light-house.
CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 27.--It is reported that an American syndicate has purchased the Real del Monte Company's mines for $4,000,000. The mines are situated in Pachuca.

LONDON, Aug. 27.--The Mark Lane Express, in its review of the British grain trade during the past week, says: "Fine weather during the past fortnight has had an inestimable effect on the crops, which are being thrashed and marketed very fast.

BOSTON, Aug. 27.--A meeting of the creditors of Joseph F. Paul Co., lumber merchants, who failed recently, was held this afternoon. The direct liabilities were shown to be $77,000, and contingent $28,000. The creditors agreed to accept the firm's offer of 40 cents on the dollar.
BOSTON, Aug. 27.--The report that the Maverick National Bank of this city had suspended is untrue.

LONDON, Aug. 27.--The steam-ship Amsterdam, (Dutch,) Capt. Lucas, from New-York Aug. 15 for Amsterdam, has passed the Lizard.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 27.--Luther Bateman has notified the Newport City Council committee on the new asylum that the lot he offered to sell is withdrawn. There is considerable surprise caused by the announcement, and it is thought the action may lead to a lawsuit.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 27.--The name of the woman who died at the Prospect House last week from the effects of laudanum has been ascertained to be Jane Stockbridge, who left her home in Appleby, Westmoreland, England, last March. No motive for suicide is known. She was alone and a stranger here, and nothing has been learned of her history. The body lies in the Morgue.

Detective Sergeant McLaughlin, dressed in a fashionable suit of checked cloth, drove up to the Centre-street entrance to the Tombs in a hack yesterday. He was accompanied by a lady about 5 feet in height and of slight build, dressed in a figured black silk dress of fine material.

NEWPORT, R. I. Aug. 28.--S. S. Howland, of New-York, August Belmont's son-in-law, dislocated his wrist while playing polo in the married men team against the single men yesterday afternoon.
Out in Long Creek Township, about two weeks ago, a mad dog bit a hog belonging to Mr. Frank Shoemaker, and last Thursday the hog died, after a week's cavorting around with rabies.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 28.--Jacob Oldenbarger and Jacob Bush had a lawsuit this morning in a Justice's court, which was decided in favor of the latter. Meeting Rush on the street about 1 o'clock Oldenbarger drew a pistol and fired, killing Bush instantly.

PANAMA, Aug. 28, via Galveston, Texas.-- Gen. Refales, late Government Secretary of President Otalora, has arrived here on his way to Canca on an important Government mission. A decree dated Aug 1. printed in the Official Gazette, accepts Marcelino Quinzada's resignation as Secretary of State for Public Works.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 28.--The circuit meeting at Hampden Park opened to-day with a good first-day attendance, fair weather, and a good though dusty track. Good sport was afforded by the horses, and some of the results were surprises to pool-buyers if not to the sellers.

BOSTON, Aug. 28. --The National Lancers have been ordered out to act as an escort to Gov. Rutler at the opening of the World's Fair Sept. 3.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Aug. 28.--The Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company this morning took possession of the Buck Ridge colliery, situated at Shamokin, which has heretofore been operated by May Audenried. President Gowen purchased the colliery yesterday, but interested parties refuse to state the amount paid for the property. Over 500 men are employed at the colliery.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--The examination of the gas-pipe thieves to-day developed the fact that their peculations have been more extensive than was at first thought. They employed four teams, and thought nothing of carying off two-foot mains under the very eyes of the workmen. The contractor estimates his loss at from $7,000 to $10,000. Some of the receivers may be arrested soon.

There was much excitement in the places along the Hudson last evening to which the Riverdale runs, as many of their residents were in the habit of going to and from their homes upon this boat.

SEABROOK, N.H., Monday, Aug. 29--The old town of Hampton, which once stretched all alone this shore from Portsmouth to Salisbury and reached inland to Exeter, has long been parceled out among half a dozen towns, the newest of which, Seabrook, is more than 100 yaars old -having been incorporated in 1768.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 28.--Herr Shadrick, late of the Leipsic Conservatory of Music, has arrived here and will take charge of the violin department of the College of Music of this city.

POINT CHAUTAUQUA, Aug. 28.--The Chautauqua County Veterans' Union held its fifth annual reunion here to-day. Eight Grand Army posts and the Gov. Fenton Guards are present. Interesting exercises were held this afternoon and evening in the tabernacle.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 28--In the Senate to-day the resolution which passed the House last evening requesting all the Senators and members of the Legislature to resign in view of their inability to agree on the apportionment question was received and submitted to the Senate.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug 28.--Howard Seymour, of Brooklyn, N. Y., a Summer guest at Seal Harbor, left Bar Harbor on Sunday evening alone in a sail-boat, for Seal Harbor. He has not since been heard from. The oars of the boat have been picked up and it is supposed that it was capsized during a squall.
OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 28.--A clam-opening match took place here to-day. There were seven contestants. Henry W. Herbert was the winner, opening 500 clams in 35 minutes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--A strange death was reported by the detectives this evening of a woman named Sherman, living at No. 224 South Clarkstreet.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Aug. 28.--Another attempt was made to burn a trestle-work on the Columbus and Rome Railroad on Saturday night. William Perry was returning home about 11 o'clock from the house of a friend when he discovered the trestle just north of the Beallwood station to be burning.
About 300 ladies and gentlemen, each wearing a badge of pale blue ribbon on which were the letters "N. D. M. C.," met yesterday at Lyric Hall, in Sixth-avenue. opposite Reservoir-square.

Mr. John W.Mackey, the California millionaire, has taken the Presidency of the Postal Telegraph Company. At first he declined the position, but reconsidered his determination. Besides being the chief officer, he is, as custodian of a majority of the capital stock, the controlling spirit.

HALIFAX, Aug. 28.--A contract has been made by the Dominion Salvage and Wrecking Company to get the steamer Brantford City off the rocks near Lockeport, Nova Scotia, and bring her to this port for $40,000. The company will also get 40 pet cent. of the value of the cargo they save.
DES MONIES, IOWA, Aug 28. --The new Grand Opera-house was formally dedicated last night by the Emma Abbott Opera Company. There was a large audience.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug 28.--The Frenchman, H. Balsan, who was to swim the Whirlpool Rapids to-day visited the Falls, but did not attempt the feat. He returned to New-York to-night. He says that he will attempt to swim the Rapids in the future, but will name no date.
Max Strauss, aged 28 years, a German, fell through the batchway at No. 43 Lispenard-street yesterday afternoon and was killed.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 28.--The United States practice ships Dale and Constellation arrived at the Naval Academy to-day, the Dale in the morning, the Constellation in the afternoon. The cadets on the Dale were given leave to come ashore and remain until 5 P. M.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--A.P. Luse, a member of the well-known firm of Marder, Luse Co., filed a bill to-day in the United States Circuit Court against his partners, John Marder and Carl Mueller, asking for a dissolution of partnership.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28.--Gen. Sherman has recommended that the Twenty-first Infantry, now on the Pacific, with head-quarters at Fort Vancouver, Washington Territory. change stations with the Tenth Infantry, now on the lakes, with head-quarters at Detroit.

LOCKPORT, Aug. 28.--About one-quarter of the population of the county was attracted to Lockport today by the advertisement of Forepaugh's circus and menagerie and street parade.

JANESVILLE, Wis., Aug. 28.--A hail-storm passed over this county last night which proved more disastrous to crops than any storm ever known in this region. The storm swept through the towns in the Western and Northern parts of the country.

EASTON, Penn., Aug. 28.--An ore train ran into a construction train on the High Bridge Branch of the New-Jersey Central Railroad yesterday afternoon, near Middle valley. Both engines were badly wrecked and a number of care were damaged. Fifty men were on the construction train at the time of the accident, but no one was killed or injured. The wreck was not cleared away till after midnight.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 28.--Charles W. Harned, who was killed by a train accident at Mendota, Ill., this morning, was the son of the Rev. W. F. Harned, a well-known and much-honored Methodist minister residing in this city.

The Riverdale was built about 35 years ago for the Smith brothers, of Nyack. She was run by them in the North River and around New-York Bay. Twelve years ago, while she was the property of Isaac P. Smith, of Nyack, her hull was rebuilt at Jersey City by Michael S. Ellison.

Christian Stock keeps a liquor-saloon of bad reputation in Cross-street, at the corner of Whitealley, Paterson. A short time ago a man went home with his head badly damaged, and said he had received his injuries in Stock's saloon.

VANDALIA, Ill., Aug. 28.--For several weeks Lewis Phillips and Jacob Rosenbeck, who reside in Bowling Green Township, have been on bad terms. The cause of the quarrel was some remark made by Phillips which reflected on the reputation of Miss Rosenbeck.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 28.--John Connor, a local athlete, who works in the mines, publishes a card in the Scranton Republican challenging Edward Bibby, the famous wrestler, to a wrestlingmatch for $1,000 the contest to take place in this city at such time as may be agreed unon, and to be held under the ordinary rules of a catch-as-catchcan tussle. As an evidence of his good faith Connor has deposited $100 with responsible parties here.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Aug. 27.--The schooner Altavelia, Capt. Alley, from Bangor, for Norwich, Conn., at anchor in Vineyard sound, reports that on Sunday night, while off Cape Cod, the mate, Isaiah P. Haynes, fell overboard and was drowned.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 28.--Mrs. Barnwell and two grandchildren named Lewis, in Gordon County, were poisoned last Sunday by eating rice, which, on being analyzed, proved to have contained "rough on rats."
MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 28.--The Pope has authorized the Victoria School of Medicine to be opened and carried on as usual for the present. The mandate arrived by cablegram and is very brief.

BOSTON, Aug. 28.--The failure of the scheme for the consolidation of all the New-England telephone companies appears to be due to the fact that the American Bell Company, it was considered, would have a disproportionately large share of the advantages to be derived from the union.

NASHAVILLE, Aug. 28.--Hart Hicks, a prominent farmer of Rutherford County, became involved in a difficulty with a negro laborer on his farm about the feeding of stock. The negro began to curse Hicks, when his son Halie drew a pistol and shot him, inflicting a very serious if not a fatal wound. Neither Hicks nor his son has been arrested.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 28.--Spencer Coleman (colored) was instantly killed here to-day by the bursting of a large grindstone which was being tried for the first time. George Ohlman, mate of the bark Mascot, was arrested yesterday on complaint of Capt. George P. Buckley, who charged him with having mutinied on the trip from Vera Cruz and having refused to do any work.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 28.--The attendance to-day at the races was the largest of the season. The weather during the last three races was cloudy and cool. Only one of the favorites won. Lloyd Daly, ridden by little Higgs, captured the Equity Stakes in grand style.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 28.--The white screwmen at this port, numbering over 150, who have been on a strike since the organization of the colored screwmen's association several months ago, returned to work to-day. The negroes charge the ship brokers with combining to keep up the rivalry between the white and colored screwmen. The conclusion of the strike will probably cause a sharp decline in fares.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 28.--William H. Hoyt, the postal clerk who was injured in yesterday's disaster on the Pan Handle Railroad, at Mingo Junction died last night.

The strike among the men belonging to the Amalgamated Building Trades Unions employed by John J. Tucker, the builder, continued yesterday. Mr. Tucker said, however, that only about to of his men had struck, and nearly half of them applied to be reinstated yesterday, but he had refused to employ them.

The regatta of the Dundee Rowing Association, of Paterson, was held on Dundee Lake yesterday afternoon. About 3,000 persons thronged the shores of the lake. The first event was a singlescull race, half a mile and return, between Charles Reynolds and James Watson, both members of the association.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28.--The Rapier and De Molay Commanderies left here this afternoon on special trains for home.

The match between those members of the Staten Island Cricket Club who have attended public schools in England and 11 other members of the club was resumed at Camp Washington yesterday. The second inning of the latter eleven was ...

CHICAGO, Aug. 28.--A. conductor on the Chicago and Alton Railroad had a private detective arrested yesterday for following him about, and a Justice fined the "spotter" $10. The managers of the road stated to-day that they had discharged a number of suspected conductors and had employed detectives to keep certain of them under surveillance.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 28.--A part of a cornice on an unfinished building fell yesterday and, striking the scaffolding, precipitated three men standing upon it into the basement, 25 feet below.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 28.--A certified copy of the will of Edward Clark, a New-York millionaire, whose estate is said to be worth $50,000,000, with the proceedings thereupon in the Surrogate Court of Otsego County, was filed in the...

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 28.--The Window glass workers of this district profess to believe that the convention of manufacturers to be held in Chicago to-morrow will result in a modification or the complete withdrawal of the demands for a reduction in wages.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28.--An application will be made to-morrow for an injunction to restrain Mayor King from closing the pool-rooms or in any way interfering with the business of the middlemen of the gamblers.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 28.--To-day is Horticultural Day at the exposition here and there if the largest display of fruits ever seen in the South. No less than 15,000 plates of every variety of fruit adorn the tables. There is a large crowd present.

Notwithstanding the disagreeable weather the number of strangers arriving in Carlsbad is considerable. Until the 5th 22,332 persons were registered, and during the week from the 25th of July to the 1st of August, 1,223 persons came to this city.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 28.--Miss Nellie Arthur, the President's daughter, and Mrs. McElroy and her two daughters left Block Island at 1 P. M. to-day on the United States steamer Despatch for Newport.

DES MONIES, Iowa, Aug. 28.--E. A. Bennett, heretofore a prominent business man in Humboldt, shot himself fatally at his residence about 4 o'clock this morning. Financial troubles, which began last Spring, seem to have caused the suicide.

It is predicted by certain Freethinkers that a new conflict between free thought and Christianity is close at hand, the immediate cause of this conflict being the monument which it is proposed to erect in Green-Wood to the memory of the late D. M. BENNETT.

The formation in Arkansas of a community, or a society for the promotion among the colored people of a "separatist" organization, is only another evidence of discontent among these afflicted people.

YELLOWSTONE PARK, Aug. 26, via Livingston, Montana, Aug. 28.--It was the intention of the Presidential party to remain over Sunday at the Upper Geyser Basin until it was ascertained that the vicinity of the camp did not furnish sufficient forage for the animals.

A meeting of dealers in hops was held yesterday in the room of the Board of Managers of the Produce Exchange, Mr. F. B. Merrill, in the chair. It was finally decided that the following notice should be sent to all dealers in hops in the United States:
The litigation now going on in the Supreme Court between Charles A. Randall, a gentleman who is interested is electricity and its uses, and his wife, Phoebe A. Randall, is interesting.

Railway Post Office service on the Northern Pacific Railroad has been-ordered between Missoula and Helena, Montana, to take effect Sept. 2. This will make a continous railway Post Office service via the Northern Pacific Railroad from St. Paul to Portland, Oregon, a distance of 1,920 miles.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 28.-The trial of James Nutt, the slayer of Lyman Dukes, will begin at Uniontown, Penn., on Thursday of next week. District Attorney Johnson and Mr. John Boyle will conduct the prosecution, and Messrs. W. H. Playford and A. D. Boyd will be counsel for the defense.

NEWBURG, Aug. 28.--The contaminated well in High-street, in this city, which was referred to in THE TIMES of Aug. 3, has so far resulted in four deaths, though the use of its water for drinking purposes was stopped as soon as the cause of the sickness in that street, became apparent.

BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 28.--The Board of Local Steam-boat Inspectors to-day exonerated the steam-ship William Lawrence from blame in the sinking of the schooner Sarah Lavinia in Chesapeake Bay on Aug. 10, by which the wife and two children of Capt. Anderson, of the schooner, were drowned. Capt, Anderson has instituted suit against the owners of the steamer for damages.

William G. Moody, of Brooklyn, was the first witness before the United States Sub-committee on Labor and Education yesterday. Mr. Moody is the author of a work called " Land and Labor." Mr. Moody said that large tracts of ...

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28.--The Directors of the Keely Motor Company held their regular monthly meeting to-night at the offices of the corporation, in Walnut-street, above Ninth. President Randell, Treasurer Green, Secretary Schullermann, and Trustees Baldwin and Smith attended.

CAPE TOWN, Aug. 28.--The Supreme Court has rejected the appeal of O'Donnell to be tried here. O'Donnell sailed for England to-day. The Crown demanded that he be removed to England by a warrant issued by the Governor of Cape Colony, under section 35 of the Imperial Fugitive Offenders act of 1881.

ALBANY, Aug. 28.--The State Civil Service Commissioners--John Jay, Henry A. Richmond, Augustus Schoonmaker, and Chief Examiner Silas W. Burt--met this afternoon to prepare a classification of the employes in the various departments of the State.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28.--Capt. J.J. Hall, Superintendent of Construction, in the employ of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, who fled from his home and many creditors in New-Brunswick on Monday, was well known in Philadelphia.

Some captious persons are complaining of the delay in opening the bridge railroad to the public. The ship Henry L. Sanford, when passing under the Brooklyn bridge on Monday morning, had her royal topmast carried away. Several police officers who were on the bridge at the time of the accident reported that the vessel did not pass under the highest part of the bridge, but toward the Brooklyn side.

NEWTON, N. J., Aug. 28.--Great preparations are making here for the reunion of the Fifteenth New-Jersey Volunteers on Sept. 19. The citizens of Sussex County have entered heartily into the proposition to give the veterans a grand reception. Many posts of the Grand Army of the...

There was not much change in the aspect of the building strikes yesterday. At the building at Broadway and Twenty-second-street Mr. Haight, the architect, concluded to settle with the union and discharged the non-society workmen that were employed there.

Yesterday was the eighteenth day of the August meeting at Brighton Beach and there was another large attendance of spectators present to witness the sport, although the programme was of moderate pretensions.

Justice William Watson, of East New-York, entered the hotel of a man named Jardin in that placoe one night about a week ago. He was accompanied by the wife of Becker, the notorious forger, now confined in the Kings County Penitentiary.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 29.--Nat M. Smith, of this city, to-day received from the Post Office a box of cake, accompanied by a letter signed "Annie L. Sullivan," and dated New-Albany, ...
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 29.--To-day the body of M.E. Duffey was found near Anniston, Ala., in a decaying condition. He went hunting four days ago, and it is supposed that he accidentally shot himself.

BOSTON, Aug. 29.--An attempt was made last night to wreck the Albany express on the Boston and Albany Railroad by placing two sleepers on the track just above Ashland. A very narrow escape was had from a terrible disaster. The engine struck the sleepers, but was running slowly and no damage was done.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--The first appointment in the Post Office Department under the new civil service rules was made to-day, the lucky man being Mr. Ovington E. Weller, of Granite, Baltimore County, Md.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29.--The Chicago Board of Trade to-day, by an overwhelming vote, decided to adopt the new rules proposed some time ago.
LONDON, Aug. 29.--A dispatch from Batavia, Java, to Lloyds says that the towns of Anjer, Tjiringine, and Telokbelong have been destroyed by tidal waves caused by the volcanic eruptions.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 29.--The sessions of the Grand Lodge of Good Templars thus far have been mainly devoted to temperance speeches, music, and recitations.

John King Shepheard, Inspector of Masonry on Governor's Island, was found dead yesterday afternoon in his room at No. 58 Whitehall-street, a hotel kept by Michael L. Flynn. Mr. Shepheard resided with his family at Sandy Hook, where he was formerly employed by the Government as superintendent of construction.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29.--The fourteenth annual convention of the Fire Underwriters of the Northwest began here to-day. It was attended by fully 200 representatives of companies doing business in the North-west and in Ohio, Indiana, Tennessee, Kentucky, Iowa, Wisconsin, and Kansas.

SHELBYVILLE, Ind, Aug. 29.--Four young men last night induced two others to rob a melon patch, expecting to frighten them off with guns loaded with powder only. The joke miscarried. In some way the guns were heavily loaded with shot and three of the boys were wounded, two seriously, William Jollis receiving a charge in the head and side, and Frank Holden being carried off with 200 shot about his person.
The Stewart Memorial Cathedral and St. Paul's School at Garden City, Long Island, have been declared by the contractor to be completed.

Seven thousand pieces of 3-4 and 500 pieces of 6-4 cassimeres were sold at auction yesterday by wilmerding, Hoguet Co., of No. 64 White-street, by order of Knower Thomas, of No. 24 Thomasstreet. The bidding was not very spirited, although buyers representing all parts of the country were present. The prices were generally low.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29.--A consignment of 75 cases of cartridges and 100 cases of rifles and revolvers has been placed on board the steamer City of Peking, for Shanghai City.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 29.--News received here states that an affray occurred yesterday at Rock Creek, Col., between Edward Nottingham and William Maddigam, but they were parted before anything serious happened.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29.--Caldwell Mason, dealers in wool and yarn manufacturers' supplies, have suspended. Liabilities. $10,000 to $15,000; assets small.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 29.--A peculiar association, designed to be national, was organized under a special charter in this city to-day. It bears the name of "the National Longevity Union," and has a capital stock of 1,000 shares at $20 each, all subscribed.

John Curran was arrested in Jersey City yesterday charged with embezzling $1,000 belonging to the Rev. Peter Donohue, of Buffalo. Father Donohue owns the store and dwelling No. 41 Colesstreet, Jersey City, and, being unable to look after ...

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 29.--Reports to the New-England Homestead from over 100 tobacco-growing towns in the Connecticut and Housatonic Valleys indicate that the crop for 1883 will be a full average in yield, while excelling in quality. The total acreage is reduced fully 15 per cent., with one-third increase in Havana tobacco.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--A quarrel occurred this evening at the Metropolitan Hotel here between Miles Commander, Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee of North Carolina, and Col. D. McD. Lindsey, a prominent politician of that State, who is at present employed in the Treasury Department in this city.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29.--The Western Windowglass Manufacturers' Association held a session here to-day to finally determine upon the scale of wages to be paid employes. All the leading manufacturers of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio, and Pennsylvania were represented.

EXETER, Ontario, Aug. 29.--At an adjourned conference of the Bible Christian Church, of Canada, held here to-night, it was decided by a vote of 45 to 3 to go into a union with the other sections of the Methodist Church, notwithstanding the fact that the English Conference has declined to sanction the movement.

A large, worm-eaten walnut log lies in the Butter in front of No. 156 Elizabeth-street, propped up by heavy blocks of wood. It towers above the passing horses and the men on the high seats of the large drays can hardly see over it. It is 9 feet in diameter, 27 feet in circumference, 12 feet long, and weighs 22,000 pounds.

Hearing something of a method of cheating known in grain circles as "plugging;" a Journal reporter made inquiries yesterday at the Board of Trade without much satisfaction until he called upon the jolly grain inspector Mr. J. McLean and inquired if the "plug" were damaging the wheat much this year.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 29.--The withdrawal of the Hon. J.C.S. Blackburn from the contest for the Speakership, which was announced tonight, is the cause of considerable excitement in local political circles. It has an important bearing, not only upon Mr. Carlisle's chances ...

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 29.--Inspector Williams, of the Postal Money Order system, yesterday caused the arrest of Charles F. Heusman, the Postmaster at Marksville, La., for the alleged embezzlement of $1,500, money order funds. Heusman was held in $5,000 bail.
INDEPENDENCE, Iowa, Aug. 29.--The campaign in Iowa was opened to-day by the first of the series of joint debates between Gov. Sherman and L.G. Kinne, his Democratic rival.
