RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 29.--The Monmouth Wheelman, a newly organized bicycle club, held its first regular meeting to-night. Dr. G.F. Marsden was elected President, and S. Lockwood Captain. The club will be a member of the American League, and will adopt the regulation riding dress. The club numbers about 30 at present. Members will be invited from all parts of the country.

The facts, so far as they are known, in the history of the boilers of the Riverdale go to show that they were subjected to all the tests which the law requires to ascertain their sufficient strength. The boilers were not old, in the sense in which that word can be applied to them.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 29.--Senators Logan, Dawes, and Cameron, of the Special Indian Committee, reached here to-day from their tour of inspection of the Missouri River Indian agencies. They go from here to the Pine Ridge and Rosebud Agencies. The Senators are not prepared to say what the committee will recommend, but they express the opinion that the Sioux are ready for lands in severalty. Others members of the committee are prosecuting investigations in Montana.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 29.--Col. W.A. Taylor, correspondent of the Cincinnati News Journal, and W.J. Elliott, editor of the Sunday Capital, had an encounter on the streets to-day, in which both received slight injuries. Both men were arrested. Threats of a more serious nature have passed between the two men. The trouble grew out of an article in the News Journal reflecting on the personal and political record of Elliott.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--A protracted and secret conference by leaders of independent movements at the South, held here to-day, has furnished the city with its first local political sensation for some time.

George Horn, of the Cosmopolitan Hotel at Rockaway Beach, at the opening of the season leased the bathing privileges to Elwood Bolemius. SARATOGA, Aug. 29.--This was the last extra day of the meeting. The attendance was large, the track in excellent condition, the weather all that could be desired, and the betting very active. The contests were spirited. Two of the four favorites were successful.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29.--The eighth session of the School of Christian Philosophy was opened by the Rev. Dr. Kempshall, of Elizabeth, N.J. The lecture of the day was by Dr. Isaac Errett, of Cincinnati, Ohio, editor of the Christian Standard. The school will close on Friday.

The Aqueduct Commissioners listened yesterday to a number of communications from property-owners along the proposed route of the new aqueduct, protesting against the running of the line through or under their property.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 29.--The military authorities here have been informed that a troop ship will leave England on Oct. 15 with the Second West York and Lancaster Regiment for Bermuda, to relieve the Royal lrish Rifles, who will proceed to Halifax to relieve the Royal Munster Fusiliers. The latter will leave here about the first week in November.
VIENNA, Aug. 29.--The anti-Magyar riots at Zagorien have been quelled. The peasants who took part in them have fled to the mountains.

The steam-ships Elbe, of the North German Lloyd; Scythia, of the Cunard Line; Canada, of the National Line; Labrador, of the French Line, and W.A. Scholten, of the Netherlands Mail, sailed for Europe yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--Leave of absence for four months, to take effect upon being relieved from recruiting duty, has been granted Capt. Henry C. Cook, Second Infantry.

BOSTON, Aug. 29.--The steamer John Romer left here this morning on her regular trip to Pemberton and Nantasket, carrying about 700 passangers. The trip was a very rough one, a strong north-easterly wind blowing at the time.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 29.--Two dastardly attempts were made to-day to wreck the south-bound day express on the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad near Knoxville, Tenn.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 29.--The steam barge Saxon, with a cargo of 14,000 bushels of wheat, has grounded on the shore of Lake Ontario, off Wilson. The crew were saved. A heavy sea is running.

BERLIN, Aug. 29.--The Reichstag was opened to-day. The message of the Emperor opening the session relates solely to the treaty of commerce with Spain.

MONTREAL, Aug. 29.--A dispatch received here from Prince Hohenlohe and the party of distinguished tourists now on their way to the Rocky Mountains via the Canada Pacific Railway, says: "Arrived at Calgarry, 32 hours from the Winnipeg line, in very good condition. Coal used on engine was mined in vicinity of line. Country looking well and crops excellent. Visitors speak very highly of the line and country."
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29.--The weather today has been cold and dreary. Rain fell during the morning, and in the afternoon the leaden-colored skies sent forth a disagreeable north-west wind.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 29.--Between 6,000 and 7,000 people witnessed the trotting at Hampden Park to-day. The favorites were again slaughtered, the greatest surprise of the day being the defeat of Edwin Thorne by Wilson in the freefor-all race. Pool-selling was brisk, the stands being ...

Bids for the work of building a new pier at the foot of West Twenty-ninth-street, North River, to be known as Pier No. 59, were opened at the meeting of the Dock Commissioners yesterday.
BOSTON, Aug. 29.--The Republican State Committee has issued an address to the people, thus marking the opening of the campaign in this States. It says:

ORISKANY, N.Y., Aug. 29.--The cry of "hop sack" is heard in the land. In large yards picking began last week, and by the latter part of this week the population of the hop district of Central New-York will be increased by thousands. Picking has begun early because of vermin, immature hops being better than none.

BEDFORD, Ind., Aug. 29.--Much to the astonishment of the business community here the Second National Bank of Bedford, an institution that had not been in operation over 20 days, this noon surrendered its charter and closed. It had not even had time to issue notes. A.C. Voris was President and T.H. Melost Cashier. No one loses anything. A failure to receive expected patronage and a distrustfulness of the future are alleged to be the cause.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 29.--The Fall Circuit Court and Oyer and Terminer will begin in this city Sept. 3. There are 44 cases on the civil jury calendar, some of them of unusual interest. Judge Haight will preside.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--There is a revival of interest in star route matters, both in the Attorney-General's office and in the Post Office Department.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 29.--Hial H. Stoddard, the Central New-York champion, will not spar John Davis. The match made by Fox was unanthorized. Stoddard is training closely to meet Sullivan, and says he will make no matches until he "knocks out" the champion pugilist.

HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 29.--By the falling of a staging at Burden Dock, a few miles below this city, Patrick Caughlin, of Troy, was fatally injured, and John Cain, Frank Walker, Michael McConnerick, Michael Relly, and Michael Shehan, all of Troy, were seriously injured. They were employed by Sutherland Son, boiler-makers, of Troy.
BOSTON, Aug. 29.--The little band of Greenbackers in this State have issued a call for a State Convention, to be held on Sept. 17 ...

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 29.--At the ninth day's services of the camp-meeting at Ocean Grove the early exercises were largely attended. Nearly 2,000 young men and women gathered in the temple at the regular morning young people's meeting.
GALLATIN, Mo., Aug. 29.--In the James trial the defense have all along sought to prove that Jim Cummings was the fifth man in the James gang and that Frank James was not that person.

At a few minutes after 9 o'clock yesterday morning, as pilot-boat No. 2 was coming cut of the slip at the foot of Beekman-street it came in collision with a cattle barge which was being towed up the East River by the tug J. Nickerson.

The National Convention of Deaf-mutes continued yesterday at Lyric Hall. After a letter of greeting had been read from the Mute Circle, of Chicago, Mr. Thomas F. Fox, of this City, delivered an essay upon the social status of deafmutes, in which he said that the position of the deaf-mute in society had been entirely changed within the past few years.

Two members of the Nassan Boat Club, Richard O. Morse and John Walker, contended in a two mile boat-race on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon for a handsome gold medal presented by one of the members of the club.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 29.--To-day it is discovered that Breed, of Kentucky, and Strite, of Maryland, were not among those who engaged in hazing the Fourth Class on the Constellation.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 29.--The boiler in the saw mill of Barnes Jones, at Durango, exploded last night, killing two employes named Ballard and Clark. James Deming, the fireman, was seriously injured.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 29.--The Wabash train which left Council Bluffs last evening at 5 o'clock, when near Council, Mo., at 2 o'clock this morning, ran over a cow. The engine, baggage car, and one coach were derailed and the engine was upset. Engineer Hall, one of the oldest engineers on the road, was killed. The passengers were uninjured.
CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 29.--The City Council gave a grand banquet to-day to Dr. Ramon Fernandez, Governor of the Federal District.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 29.--The tenth annual convention of St. George's Union of North America opened here to-day. Reports from 18 societies affiliated with the union show a membership of 3,177, with receipts of $19,025; the total amount expended in charity during the year to be $11,716, and the value of investments to be $86,782.

Aaron Goldstein died in Paterson, N.J., yesterday at the age of 105 years, according to the best information of his family, some of whom assert, indeed, that he was 107 years of age.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29.--"Sam" Donnelly, the "sport" who procured the arrest of Dink Davis on charges of swindling and conducting a gambling establishment, was himself arrested to-day on warrants sworn out by some of Davis's friends charging him with carrying on a poker-room on North Seventh-street, near Franklin-avenue. Simon Marts. Donnelly's partner was arrested under a similar warrant.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29.--Prof. John A. Salter tested his patent swimming and life-saving apparatus in the Delaware River at the foot of Chestnut-street this afternoon, and the mob of spectators were highly entertained by the exhibition.

AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 29.--The Legislature met this afternoon. The report of the committee on the revision of the statutes was read and accepted. Various bills covering the items of the committee's report were adopted, and the Legislature then adjourned sine die.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 29.--Louis Shaefer, a German, 38 years old, fatally shot himself at his residence and place of business in this city about 2 o'clock this afternoon. His wife went to his room to call him to dinner.
DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 29.--A man named Harry Cutcher was found in an unconscious condition in his wagon on Sunday morning near Perry, Shiawassee County.

CHESTER, Penn., Aug. 29.--One hundred head of Jersey cattle and a number of ponies, sheep, and hogs, valued at $75,000, consigned to A.M. Herkness Co., Philadelphia, were landed here to-day from the steamer Otranto, from Hull. The animals will be placed in quarantine.

A low ridge of timber, about 50 feet long, was the only visible portion of the sunken steamer Riverdale yesterday. The continual sweep of the waters of the North River almost submerged it at times, and the light spray that was dashed upon the object made it glisten in the hot sunlight.

WHITE RIVER JUNCTION, Vt., Aug. 29.-- Lord Chief-Justice Coleridge, accompanied by his son, the Hon. Gilbert Coleridge; Elliott F. Shepard, and Lieut. J. McClellan, of Gen. Hancock's staff, arrived here at 2 P.M. to-day.

HORNELLSVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 29.--A singular sequel has followed the arrest of C.R. Witters, the wealthy farmer of Le Roy, who stole the horse and carriage of I.R. Babcock, of this place, on May 24 last.

MONTREAL, Aug. 29.--The report from Liverpool that Canadian cattle are afflicted with Texas fever is emphatically denied by cattle men here. They say that the disease is wholly unknown in the Dominion and is not a native of the soil, and that no Texas cattle have been imported here for years.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29.--A little love story of the stage was brought to an end to-day by a suit for divorce, entered in Common Pleas Court No. 2 by S. Gilbert Ely, an actor.
HARRISBURG, Aug. 29.--In the House today the Ammerman resolution to submit the formation of apportionment bills to an arbitration committee of 10 prominent citizens ...

CROCKETT, Texas, Aug. 29.--Eight miles north of here to-night on the International Rail road an entire freight train went through a bridge, which had been set on fire, into a creek. Two brakemen are supposed to have been buried in the debris. The engineer was badly burned. The fireman jumped and escaped injury.

A report was circulated yesterday that the Ohio Central Railroad would default on the first mortgage bonds of the river division. Samuel Shethar, the President, said that course was not determined upon. The subject was talked over at a meeting the fore part of the month and the course to be taken would be decided at a meeting to-day. The Directors might advance the money themselves.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 29.--At the County Jail of Wyandotte, Kan., last night, five prisoners overpowered the guard and broke jail. The Sheriff, appearing, endeavored to halt them, who, failing, fired two shots, fatally wounding a confidence man named Dunbar. A second man was recaptured. The other three are still at large.

BOLTON, N.Y., Aug. 29.--The American Dermatological Association met at the Sagamore Hotel this morning, the President. Dr. R.W. Taylor, of New-York, in the chair. Interesting papers were read by Drs. Piffard, of New-York; Graham of Toronto; Stilwagon and Van Harlingen, of Philadelphia, and Atkinson, of Baltimore. The sessions will be continued to-morrow and Friday.
MANDAN, Dakota, Aug. 20.--Although it was Sunday, Fargo had its brass band out in the morning, playing away for dear life, when Mr. Rufus Hatch's Yellowstone excursion rolled into the station.

Patrolman Jacob W. Fees, of the Twentieth Precinet, brought before Justice Duffy, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday morning, two young men named Bernard Finnegan and Charles White, who, he said, were two of the worst ruffians in the Twentieth Ward.
MADISON, Ind., Aug. 29.--Theophilus Wilson, an aged farmer, to-day had a quarrel with his son and went into the house in a towering rage. He threw himself into a chair and expired almost instantly.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 29.--The seventeenth annual convention of the American Institute of Architects began this morning in the rooms of the Providence Art Club.
At about 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon a woman was seen to fall or jump into the water from the wooden pier immediately in front of the Ocean Hotel, on the Concourse, at Coney Island.

OLEAN, N.Y., Aug. 29.--It is thought that a clue to a gang of burglars, which has been operating throughout Potter County, Penn., for a year or more, has been discovered by an arrest which has created great surprise, being that of a prominent resident of the county.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 29.--The California Cotton Mills Company has been incorporated with a capital stock of $600,000. The factory will be situated at Oakland. Spinning and weaving cotton works are now in course of construction in California.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 21.--A miner named Daniel McDonald was instantly killed at the Taylorville Shaft to-day. He was about quitting the chamber where he has been regularly employed when a blast was fired in an adjoining one, and the shock brought down several tons of rock and slate from the roof, under which he was crushed to death.
PLYMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 29.--Simeon Sanborn, a pensioner of the war of 1812, died at Campton on Monday, aged 90 years.
The residence of Mr. Robert Dunlap, the hatter, No. 314 West Twenty-third-street, has been unoccupied during the Summer, the family being in the country.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29.--A very interesting discovery, which promises to add considerably to the city's historical archives, was accidentally made yesterday afternoon by some employes of Rohan Brothers, No. 1,106 Collins-street.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29.--The leading produce markets were steadier to-day, with only a moderate volume of trading, and that mostly local, though New-York figured a little more than usual both in corn and wheat.
Commissioner James Matthews said yesterday at Police Head-quarters that the Democratic factions had better exercise a little common sense and not squabble over officers of election this year.

John Smith, 21 years old, was sleeping off the effects of a carouse last night on the front steps of a tenement-house at No. 121 Mulberrystreet. He was the son of Androw Smith, a shoemaker, of Sixty-third-street and Third-avenue.

Henry Eifert, a young immigrant, who arrived here last year, made a complaint yesterday before the Mayor's Marshal against W. Churchill, the keeper of a boarding-house at No. 41 Oliverstreet. Eifert recently heard that his mother in Germany, was very sick.
CAMP CAMPBELL, FOOT OF YELLOWSTONE LAKE, Wyoming, Aug. 29.--The President and party arrived at this camp at about noon to-day, having marched from the upper end of the lake, a distance of 22 miles.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29.--Keely's workshop, at Twentieth and Harlan streets, was visited to-day by five Directors of the Keely Motor Company, headed by President Randall, who went on a visit of inspection.
NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 29.--Mrs. Alice Atwood, wife of a well-to-do farmer of Watertown, has been arrested charged with brutally maltreating a boy of 14, who was in her husband's employ.

If the commendable habit of dropping dead when telling a lie had survived among the descendants of Mme. SAPPHIRA, that ingenious finder of antiquities, Mr. SHAPIRA, of Jerusalem, would long ago have been carried out to the cemetery by troops of rejoicing young men.

BUFFALO, Aug. 29.--Hilario Balsau, who arrived in this country from France a few days ago with the announced intention of swimming the Niagara Whirlpool Rapids, where Webb was drowned, visited Niagara Falls yesterday and looked over the situation.

DANVILLE, Va., Aug. 29.--The Rev. Dr. G. B. Strickler, of Atlanta, Ga., was unanimously elected a Professor of the Union Theological Seminary of this State by the Board of Trustees, in session here, this evening. Dr. Stickler will fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of the Rev. Dr. Peck, who will take the chair resigned by the Rev. Dr. Dabney.

Twenty-two members of the Board of Aldermen responded to the roll-call yesterday at the first meeting of the board since the Summer vacation. They met in the room of one of the City Court Judges, as the Aldermanic Chamber is now being enlarged.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29.--From Jefferson City comes news that Gov. Crittenden is greatly exercised over Judge Noonan's decision in the Lemp case, which was to the effect that the Downing Temperance law was inoperative on account of the law of 1857.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 29.--The heaviest storm since the gale in last March prevails here to-night. The wind is blowing with great violence from the south-east, and rain is falling in torrents. The storm, it is feared, will prove disastrous to the steamer Brantford City, which is ashore at Little Harbor, near Lockport. The gale is blowing directly on the vessel, and will likely break her to pieces on the rocks.

At the session of the United States Sub-Committee on Labor and Education yesterday Louis Post, counsel for the Central Labor Union, presented witnesses belonging to that organization. P.J. McGuire testified as to the objects of the Central Labor Union, which, he said, was a merely local organization.
The suicide yesterday at No. 598 Eleventhavenue of Alexander Nickle, a barber, is inexplicable. He had been there 13 years, and prospered. Yesterday was his forty-sixth birthday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29.--There was a firm feeling at the opening of the cattle market to-day, holders at least entertaining firm views, and everything good enough to go East was held at fully Tuesday's prices.
PROVIDENCE, Aug. 29.--It is rumored that a steam yacht is ashore at Ochre Point, near the Newport beach.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 29.--A San Francisco club of Knights Templar, made up of representatives of the various commanderies throughout Pennsylvania, arrived here from the West to-day. They will remain until Friday night, when they will resume their journey East.

OMAHA, Neb. Aug. 29.--The Democratic State Convention, to-day, nominated the Hon. J.W. Savage for Justice of the Supreme Court, and Dr. D.R. Daniels, G.W. Johnson, and the Hon. J.M. Woolworth for Regents of the State University.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 29.--The forest fires along the bay shore in Annapolis County have caused much destruction. Eleven houses and barns, two bridges, a saw-mill, and other property were destroyed and a number of sheep were killed. The inhabitants in some cases were surrounded by fire and narrowly escaped with their lives. The fires were started by parties who were clearing land.
The Belgian steam-ship Jan Breydel, from Antwerp, which arrived last evening at Quarantine, brought a number of Norman stallions and mares consigned to Mr. J.H. Dahlman.

Au Yang, the Chinese Consul in this City, has issued an address or proclamation to his countrymen, tendering to them some sound advice as to their relations with each other and with their neighbors. The municipal prohibitions, he says, must not be transgressed. Violators of the law need not expect him to favor or protect them.

NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 30.--Mrs. Maria McGee, a Birmingham woman, left New-York at 9 o'clock this morning on a train of the New-York, NewHaven and Hartford Railroad. She had traveled all night, and, being tired, fell asleep.

POSTVILLE, Iowa, Aug. 30.--In the joint discussion between Gov. B.R. Sherman and the Hon. L.G. Kinne, which occurred at this place to-day, about the same ground was covered as at the debate at Independence yesterday. The order of the debate was different.

At Ivy Bridge, near Plymouth, yesterday, John Heath Sobey, until recently a local preacher and class leader in connection with the Wesleyan Methodists, was summoned by Ellen Baker to show cause why he should not contribute toward the maintenance of her illegitimate child, of which she alleged him to be the father.

Suit has been brought in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn by William Rigney to have his marriage annulled. He says he was compelled by force and duress to marry Lena Hicks.

The Directors of the Ohio Central Railroad met yesterday, and will meet again to-day, to consider the subject of defaulting on the first mortgage bonds of the River Division, the interest on which falls due to-morrow.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 30.--The storm tides seem to have ceased, and to-day hammers and saws have been busily used all along what was Atlantic City's beach promenade. In the darkness of last night's storm it was impossible to see or estimate the amount of damage, which was greatly over-estimates.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 30.--In accordance with a resolution of the Board of Management of the World's Industrial and Cotton Centennial Exposition, to be held in this city in 1884, notice has been given to architects that 30 days after the location of the grounds, which will be fully determined upon by Sept. 18. designs for the buildings will he received by the Director-General.

The annual Corinthian race of the Seawanhaka Yacht Club was sailed yesterday afternoon. A large number of "devoted" yachtsmen assembled in the club-house at Edgewater, Staten Island, to see tho sport.

Henry Ganger was arrested yesterday on board the steam-ship Jan Breydel by Deputy United States Marshal Bernhard. He is charged with having robbed Widow Emilie Horn, of Backnagen, Wurtemberg, Germany, of 36 watches, chains, and ornaments.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 30.--The naval courtmartial to try 17 naval cadets charged with hazing Fourth Class men met to-day and adjourned, the papers not being ready for them to proceed. The court meets to-morrow at 10 o'clock on the ship Santee. when the testimony will begin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30.--There are now more than 16,000 pension claim agents scattered through the country, all intent on pushing claims through the Pension Office, and actively engaged in the various details of the business.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 30.--The Hon. John Sherman attended the Harvest Home Festival in Green Township, in this county, this afternoon, and read an address on the life and work of A.J. Downing, the noted horticulturist and writer on rural architecture. S.F. Cart and E.F, Noyes also made addresses.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 30.--The second day's session of the Fire Underwriters' Association of the North-west began this morning. The Constitution was amended so as to have the annual meetings occur in September on a date to be fixed by the Executive Committee, instead of the third week in August, as heretofore.

BOSTON, Aug. 30.--The Transcript says: "The report telegraphed from New-York that George W. Ballou Co. had less than $750,000 liabilities was erroneous. The two strongest elevens that New-York can produce contested yesterday in Prospect Park. The Staten Island Captain won the toss, and sent his men to the bat.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--There was a little more life in the cattle trade to-day, and prices averaged firmer. Western were in full supply and were barely steady, but all grades or natives sold just a trifle stronger than on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 30.--The Villard party of distinguished foreigners, who are on the way to attend the opening of the Northern Pacific Railway arrived here this evening. They will leave to-morrow night on the North-western Road for Minneapolis. They will be entertained at Lake Minnetonka, where they will be tendered a banquet on Monday, and will leave Monday night on the Northern Pacific Road.

TEXARKANA, Aug. 30.--Cullen Morris was killed at a gravel pit on the Texas Pacific Railway to-day by Conductor William Ganson. The men bad a difficulty, and the conductor dealt Morris a kick which resulted fatally. Ganson has been arrested.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 30.--Senator Anthony last night suffered a brief attack of illness, attended by vertigo, but seems to be fully recovered to-day.

FLORENCE, Wis., Aug. 30.--A strike was begun to-day by 150 miners employed at the Great Western Mine, Crystal Falls, Mich., this morning. The captain was discharged, and the men refused to work unless he was reinstated.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 30.--There is no more dissension, neither any more sorrow, in the Connecticut Fat Men's Association.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 30--Grace Courtland, of Chicago, has brought a suit in the County Court to compel her late husband. Davis, to pay $1,500 alimony, alleged to have been awarded her some time ago, but never paid. Mrs. Courtland came into notoriety lately by cowhiding a young man named Jones on the public street. She has at times dabbled in stocks at New-York, being known in that City as the "Witch of Wall-street."

New-York's two base-ball clubs were defeated on the Polo Grounds yesterday. The New-Yorks succumbed to the heavy batting of the Boston players, and the Metropolitans lost a game by poor fielding to the St. Louis men.

The suicide of Paul Broeser, a young German, on his wife's grave, in the New-York Bay Cemetery, recalls the romantic story of his marriage. His wife was the daughter of John A. Schuler, of Jersey City Heights.
NEWPORT, Aug. 30.--The storm has cleared and peace and good will again prevail to the delight of hotel-keepers and others.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 30.--To-day the corner-stone of the new Methodist church was laid. The services were presided over by the Rev. Dr. Hanlon. The Rev. Dr. Hewitt, Presiding Elder of this district, and many other clergymen were present. The church, which is to replace the structure destroyed in the fire of last November, is to be the handsomest in the county, and will cost $18,500, exclusive of the heating apparatus.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 30.--The sale of 530 acres of land and water front at Virginia Point, the main land opposite this city, by Judge Jones to the California Investment Company, of which Mr. O.P. Huntington is the controling member, causes the somewhat general impression here that wharves will be constructed and the channel deepened for the purpose of making that point the terminous for freight traffic between California and the Gulf of Mexico.

The Brooklyn bridge engine has been running every week-day since the first car was sent across the bridge over a-week ago, one car making several trips each day. The engine, switches, cable, and signals have worked perfectly.
A Broadway stage going up town was boarded at Chambers street, at about 10 o'clock yesterday morning, by Mr. William Brinckerhoff, an old gentleman, who is a clerk in the Register's office.
RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 30.--At the trial of John Horton to-day for the murder of Patrick Mitchell'a verdict of manslaughter was rendered.
A public meeting of machinists was held last evening at No. 192 Third-avenue for the purpose of organizing a protective union. It was said that there were several thousand machinists in the City.

BOLTON, N.Y., Aug. 30.--The American Dermatological Association continued its session to-day. Papers were read by Drs. Fox, Taylor, Alexander, and Hyde, of New-York; Sherwell, of Brooklyn and Hyde, of Chicago; Duhering, of Philadelphia, and Hardaway, of St. Louis. The officers for the ensuing year are as follows: President--Dr. R.W. Taylor, of New-York; Vice-Presidents--Drs. Graham, of Toronto, and Van Hartingen, of Philadelphia; Secretary--Dr. Alexander, of New-York; Treasurer--Dr. Robe, of Baltimore. The association will adjourn to-morrow.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Aug. 30.--There seems to be a mistaken impression at Washington and in the East regarding the attitude taken by the stock men of Wyoming toward the Government in consequence of the decision just rendered by Judge Sener, which will prevent the building of fences on the public lands.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--The leading produce markets to-day were less active and steadier than the recent average, with an upward tendency in prices. There was a fair volume of trading on outside account, but it was not enough to last through the session.

OCEAN GROVE, N.Y., Aug. 31.--No trace of the bodies of the unfortunate sisters, Eleanor and Mary Vail, who were drowned in the surf just south of this place yesterday, has been found.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 31.--The demoralized condition of affairs at the head-quarters of the Democratic Committee which has so long been noticeable has at last awakened the party leaders, and an effort will now be made to bring order out of confusion.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31.--Frederick Dyer, master of the bark Alice, was arrested to-day on a warrant issued by Judge Busler, of the United States District Court, in five suits for personal injuries, instituted by farmer seamen on the vessel.

BUFFALO, Aug. 31.--Two assisted pauper Irish emigrants were sent back to Canada to-day. They stated that 1,100 others came over in the same ship, and that all their expenses were paid by the British Government. The plan is stated to be to ship them to Canada and from there to the States across the border at different points. A large number have been sent back from this country recently.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 31.--Pleasant weather, a large attendance, and a good track were again the order of the day at Hampden Park. The races, however, were log and tedious, and, as there was some delay in starting them, darkness fell before the 2:23 class was finished.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 31.--The American Institute of Architects this morning visited the old stone mill and other points of interest at Newport and had their annual dinner at the Casino at 2 o'clock. AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 31.--The profits of the State prison here for August were $1,349. During the past 10 months the earnings have exceeded the expenses for the first time in many years, the excess being $3,264.
GALLATIN, Mo., Aug. 31.--In the Frank James trial this morning the defense continued their line of impeaching the State witnesses. James S. De Masters, a Justice of the Peace, was the first witness.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31.--John B. Vallequette, age 70, a wealthy French Canadian, one of the earliest settlers of Chicago, having come here in 1843, was declared sane in the Probate Court today. Two of his children asked to have a conservator appointed for their father.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 31.--A race, which drew a large crowd of spectators and caused considerable excitement was rowed over a twomile course this afternoon between a crew from the United States steamer Portsmouth in the commodore's six-eared gig, and six local fishermen in a seine-boat. The fishermen led from the start and finished 15 lengths ahead of their competitors in 15:10.

President Sloan, of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western, said yesterday that the connection afforded by the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia between the Lackawanna and Wabash would be in the shape of a traffic agreement when made. The arrangement was still a matter of the future.

PARIS, Aug. 31.--The treaty of peace between France and Annam was signed on the part of the latter country by Heiphema, who represents the peace party, because Viantar, who succeeded King Tuduc, fled with the army at the approach of the French.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 31.--The Texas cattle fever has broken out in Detroit in the herd of a milkman, in the western part of the city. The whole herd is infected. Several have already died. A herd of 41 steers, bought by a Genessee County farmer for feeding some two weeks ago, havo also been attacked by the disease, and five have already died.

ANDOVER, Mass., Aug. 31.--The funeral services of Miss Emma Gould, Miss Nettie Stafford, and Mr. Greenough Thayer, victims of the Wells drowning accident, occurred at the Seminary Chapel this morning, after which the remains were taken to the Forest Hills and Mount Auburn Cemeteries for burial. Miss Gould's body was inferred at the former cemetery.

GLEN HOUSE, N.H., Aug. 31.--Lord Coleridge and party to-day visited the Glen Ellis Falls and other points of interest in that vicinity. This evening they were tendered an informal reception in the hotel parlors. The party will leave to-morrow for the Crawford House. Lord Coleridge has accepted an invitation from the Bar Association of Portland, Me., and their committee will meet him at the Glen House station in the morning.

OTTAWA, Aug. 31.--Late advices from Newfoundland report the Labrador fishery as likely to turn out fairly food.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Aug. 31.--Suit has been brought against the Bethlehem Iron Company by a large number of former employes to recover the amounts deducted from their wages at the end of each month in payment of bills incurred at the company's store. Judgment has been rendered against the company in two cases for more than $300. The total amount involved is very large, and the question is one which concers other corporations in the State.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2.--There were many saloons open to-day, owing to the recent decision in the Lemp case, which recognized the law of 1957 as still in force. There were also a number of cigar stores and barbers' shops open, but as these are not affected by the Lemp case decision their proprietors are clearly guilty of violating the Downing Sunday law.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Sept. 2.,--The Women's Christian Temperance Union closed its convocation this evening. During the day there was a children's meeting. Bible-readings, and in the evening Mary Lathrop, of Michigan, delivered an address.

BERLIN, Sept. 2.--As a train from Berlin was passing Steglitz, to-day, it ran into a crowd of people who, intending to take a return train to Berlin, were pressing forward to enter the carriages on the wrong side. The number of people killed and wounded is estimated at 40.
OTTAIVA, Sept. 2.--An amusing protest has been made by the Government of British Columbia to the Dominion Government against the unsatisfactory telegraphic facilities the former now enjoys.

GLASGOW, Sept. 2.--Two more men were arrested here to-day changed with having been connected with the attempts to destroy property with dynamite in this city last January. Their names are Casey and Kelly.

BERLIN, Sept. 3.--Seventeen men, 18 women, and 4 children were killed in the railroad catastrophe at Steglitz yesterday. The train dashed into the midst of the large crowd killing, cutting, and hurling the people right and left.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3.--President Arthur will arrive in this city by a special train over the North-western Railroad at 2 o'clock to-morrow afternoon. A meeting of prominent citizens was held to-day, and to-morrow the chief Executive will be tendered a public reception at the Grand Pacific Hotel.

While walking in Peck-slip on Sunday night, an old man named Robert Smith, who lives at No. 886 Water-street, was assaulted by John Sullivan, Jeremiah Kennedy, and Jeremiah Leahy, ...

The Commissioners of the Sinking Fund met in the Mayor's office yesterday and, after an informal discussion, decided that the bonds to be issued for the construction of the new Croton Aqueduct shall be free from City or County taxation.
BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 3.--The Foreign Exhibition opened at noon to-day in the building of the Massachusetts Charitable Mechanics' Association, on Huntington-avenue.

NORWICH, Conn., Sept. 3.--Policeman Frank Hill was fatally stabbed this evening by a Portuguese named Manuel Montairo. Hill arrested Montairo for some minor offense and the latter drew a dirk and stabbed him in the abdomen. Montairo has served one term in State prison for shooting a man named McCabe in Preston in 1878.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 3.--J. Ira Hall, a highly respectable citizen of Rockhill, S.C., died to-day from an overdose of morphine. It is not known whether the medicine was taken with suicidal intent, but the circumstances are suspicious.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3.--Special dispatches report that Lord Headley, who accompanied the Hatch excursion to the Yellowstone, went into the wilderness in search of game, accompanied by two experienced hunters.
ALBANY, Sept. 3.--A company was incorporated to-day to publish in New-York the Ballplayers' Record, covering all the details of base-ball news.

There is food for reflection in the recital of the behavior of Mr. "BILLY," whose hinder name and whereabouts are unknown, to a customer in a Broadway restaurant, in which Mr. BILLY was employed in the double capacity of waiter and "bouncer."
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 3.--J. Proctor Knott, Governor elect of Kentucky, will be inaugurated with imposing ceremonies at Frankfort tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3.--The Charge d'Affaires of France has informed the Department of State that the Government of that republic having been led to interfere in the affairs of Tonquin and to occupy that Province for the purpose of restoring order there, has been compelled to adopt ...
PANAMA, Aug. 25.--The exhausted Treasury has received a loan of $500,000 from the canal company.

William Grant, of No. 240 Elizabeth-street, who the police say has served a term of imprisonment for burglary, with one Foley, was looked up at the Mulberry-street station last night on suspicion of having stolen a case of clothing, valued at $300.

The annual Fall regatta of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club will take place Thursday, Sept. 20. The yachts of the club will be classified as follows: First class--cabin sloops; second class--open jib and mainsail yachts over 28 feet; ...
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3.--The Miantonomoh was put into commission to-day, and will probably leave here for New-York the last of the week.
CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 3.--It is semi-officially stated here that Chief-Justice Doe, of the Supreme Court, will not resign at present.
PARIS, Sept. 3.--The remains of the Count de Chambord were conveyed from Frobsdorf to Wolkersdorf on Sunday morning, and were sent from there to Goritz in the evening.

The pipes for the pneumatic tube service of the Western Union Telegraph Company are being laid between the building of the company, at Broadway and Dey-street, and the new building at Fifth-avenue and Twenty-third-street.

BOSTON, Sept 3.--An appeal is being made by the Italian Vice-Consul, V.D. Revel, of NewYork, for the Ischia sufferers. A subscription list has been started at the Newport Casino. Henry G. Marquand and Cornelius Vanderbilt headed it with $100 each.

Our Geneva correspondent writes: "At the annual meeting of the Swiss Foresters' Society, which has recently been held at Zug, Herr Ryniker, Chief Forester of Canton Aargau and a member of the National Council, read an interesting paper on the effect of forests on hail-storms.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 3.--On Saturday evening, three miles from Dardanelle, Pope County, while going home from town, Robert W. Pendergast, a farmer, was assassinated by some one in ambush.

When Mr. Louis Rippe, a sachel-maker, at No. 189 First-avenue, went to his place of business yesterday morning he found the lock on the front door broken, but on trying to open the door he found that it was barricaded from the inside.

John Schels, of No. 23 West-street, Newark, attempted to jump on a train on the Pennsylvania Railroad this evening while it was in motion, and fell under the wheels. His right arm was severed and he received injuries about the head from which he will probably die.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 3.--The barkentine E. A. Sanchez cleared yesterday for Rio de Janerio with 5,760 barrels of flour, valued at $34,527, shipped by Haxall, Crenshaw Co. The German brig Columbus cleared for Santos with 3,062 barrels, valued at $18,247, shipped by the Gallego Manufacturing Company.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 3.--To-day an answer was filed by the Central Railroad of NewJersey and the New-York and Long Branch Railroad Companies to the amended bill of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

ANNAPOLIS, Sept. 3.--The court-martial for the trial of naval cadets charged with violating the act of Congress to prevent hazing was resumed this morning on the United States ship Santee. Naval Cadet P. Andrews was placed on trial, charged, first, with making Naval Cadet ...
Mme. Mathilde Cotrelly returned from Europe on Saturday and will resume her original part, the title role, in "Prince Methusalem" at the Casino this evening.

The steam-ship Lessing, of the Hamburg American Packet Company, which was reported to have broken her shaft 200 miles east of the Banks of Newfoundland, carried 30,457 letters for Plymouth, England, Cherbourg, France, and Hamburg; also three bags of closed mail from Havana to Paris, one bag from Canada to London, and one bag from Canada to Liverpool.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 3.--George W. Felts, who killed Peter Bloomfield, (colored,) in Warren County, has fled. The Coroner's jury has returned a verdict of willful murder. There is much indignation expressed through the county over the crime. The Governor will probably offer a reward for the capture of Felts.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 3.--A murder that startled the upper part of the city was perpetrated this morning from a front window of the house No. 1,655 North-front-street. The victim was William Meno, a mechanic employed in Disston's saw factory.
NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 3.--Joseph F. Johnson, a workman in the Manning Bowman Silver-plating Factory, at Meriden, was torn to pieces today.

The September meeting at Brighton Beach opened yesterday and there was a large attendance of spectators. The track was in good condition and fast time was made in the several events, which were mostly short dashes. Only two favorites were successful. A summary is appended:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3.--Acting Secretary Joslyn has been called upon to decide the question whether a commission appointed to examine and report upon one section of a land grant railroad can, without the issuance of a further commission, inspect another and an additional section.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3, 1883. Postmaster-General Gresham will leave this city to-night on a brief visit to Boston.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 3.--This morning Judge Webb, of the United States District Court, invited Lord Coleridge and party to attend the session of the court.

Dink Davis, whose winnings at faro have been made the subject of a number of newspaper articles, is now running a faro bank at Coney Island. He doesn't seem to have been so lucky since he established himself on the island as he had previously been, according to current reports.

LONDON, Sept. 3.--China has gone to war against the French occupation of Tonquin. Open hostilities were begun suddenly and after many acts on the part of the Chinese Government which indicated that so far as China was concerned the Tonquin trouble was settled.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 3.--This has been a most eventful day in the history of Minneapolis. The announcement that President Villard and his guests would stop here on their way to witness the driving of the golden spike on the Northern Pacific Railroad caused the citizens to strain every nerve to make the visit a memorable one.
The inquest upon the body of John Smith, who, it is claimed, was killed by Officer McNamara in Mulberry-street on Aug. 29, was held yesterday by Coroner Kennedy.

So far as can be ascertained the collision of Sunday night upon the Long Island Railroad was due chiefly to the negligence of George Johnston, the conductor of the Rockaway train. Just before the train from Far Rockaway, with three cars.

The one hundred and twenty-sixth anniversary of the birth of Lafayette will be celebrated on Thursday in France by the unveiling of a statue to the great patriot in Le Puy, his native place. Cerneau Consistory No. 1, S.P.R.S. No. 33, of this City, will commemorate the event by decorating the statue of Lafayette in Union-Square Thursday morning, and will have a dinner at Earle's Hotel in the evening.

His subject was "Capital Punishishment." He claimed that no thought of passion, vengeance, retribution, or expiation should dictate ...
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 3.--There was a great thinning out of the Summer guests to-day. The weather is very cool.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 3.--Mrs. Rose Clark Ambler, the daughter of Capt. Nathan Clark, a wealthy ship-owner, was found dead to-day in a field close by the Oronoque road, about two miles above the town of Stratford, and within a stone's throw of her father's house.
UNIONTOWN, Penn, Sept. 3.--As the time for the trial of James Nutt approaches, there is considerable speculation as to what the line of defense will be.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 3.--S.C. Slade and J.D. Courint, of El Paso, Texas, are here in the interest of the El Paso sporting fraternity for the purpose of arranging a prize-fight between Slade and Mitchell in that vicinity.

LONDON, Sept. 3.--Further details of the wreck off Penzance, on Sept. 1, of the British bark G.I. Jones, from Bull River, S.C., for Falmouth, state that 11 of the crew were drowned, including Capt. Newton and the pilot.

The People's Theatre, on the Bowery, under the management of Mr. Harry Miner, was opened last evening. The play was "The Lights o' London," played by Shook Collier's company. The theatre takes the place of the old Volks Theatre, and is the handsomest on the east side of the City.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 3.--A heavy sea and a sudden burst of wind resulted in a sail-boat, carrying a pleasure party for a sail on the Sound yesterday, being upset and two men being drowned.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 3.--Charles Read, of the firm of Read Carroll, wood-works, disappeared from this city about two weeks ago, and considerable anxiety is felt about him by his friends. He is supposed to have had only about $500 with him, and he was always considered a man of good habits.

WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 3.--William Hines, aged 30 years, had his head caught in the planer chucks in Blake Johnson's factory this afternoon and his skull was fractured. He will die. He has a young wife, and his first child was born on Saturday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3.--Private dispatches recently received here state that Li Hung Chang, Viceroy of China, has, at the instance of the United States Minister, granted permission for a steamer to run on the Upper Pei-Ho River between Tien-Tsin and Tong-Chow.

Dwight Roberts, manufacturer of lathe chucks and engine governors at No. 291 West Eleventh-street, made an assignment yesterday to George F. Hippard, giving a preference to his wife, Emma M. Roberts, of $1,300 for money loaned. He has been in business 10 years, and half of his capital was invested in tools and machinery. In his last statement the business represented a cost of $15,000.

LOCKPORT, Sept. 3.--The barn of Charles Mabon, in the town of Cambria, Niagara County, was burned early this morning. All its contents, consisting of five horses, farming implements, and the crops just stored, were destroyed. Loss, $3,000; insurance, $800.

PESTH, Sept. 3.--A number of peasants attending the market at Gorican have destroyed the Hungarian escutcheon at the Post Office and the barracks. During the melee one man was killed and several were wounded.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3.--A confession of judgment on a note of the leather firm of Caspari Zeus, No. 42 Fifth-avenue, for $8,000 in favor of Mrs. E.W. Caspari was taken in the Superior Court to-day.

PANAMA, Aug. 25.--President Barrios, of Guatemala, and President Soto of Honduras, have fallen out, and their dispute will tend to promote discord in Central America.
No progress was made yesterday in raising the wrecked steamer Riverdale. A diver went down in the forenoon and ran a rope through the furnace door of one of the boilers.

The new postal notes, which do away with the trouble of procuring money orders and afford an easy method of mailing any sum less than $5, went into use yesterday at the New-York Post Office, and Postmaster Pearson declared that the system had proved itself a success.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 3.--Important discoveries of nickle ore have been made in Churchill County, Nevada. The specimens assayed yielded 30 per cent. pure nickle.

NEW-BRITAIN, Conn., Sept. 3.--An eastbound passenger train on the New-York and New-England Railroad, consisting of one baggage and seven passenger cars, jumped the track near here this morning owing to the spreading of the rails.

HALIFAX, Sept. 4.--At Weymouth Bridge, Digby County, to-day, Arthur Hood, a school teacher, and three boys made a raft and went fishing on Griffith's Lake. WASHINGTON, Sept. 5.--The question is mooted whether Gen. Sherman, on his retirement next February, may not, if he chooses, keep his present staff indefinitely. Gen. Sherman, as General of the Army, is entitled to not more than six aides-de-camp with the rank of Colonel.

The most successful season which Glen Island has known since Mr. John H. Starin made it a day Summer resort will close on Monday next. The season has been a remarkable one in the history of New-York popular resorts.

Post, Robert Blissert, and Justus Schwab.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 5.--The revenue cutter Dallas was placed at the disposal of Lord Coleridge this afternoon by Collector Dow, and he wasreceived on board with the hoisting of the English ensign and a salute of 15 guns. A party of about 50 persons enjoyed a pleasant sail among the islands of the bay.

BOSTON, Sept. 5.--The first meeting of the creditors of S.C. J.G. Phinney, boots and shoes, was held in the Insolvency Court at Dedham this morning. Claims to the amount of $235,000 were represented, but it was stated the liabilities would reach $750,000. Amos W. Downing, of Haverhill, and Charles E. Johnson, of Newton, were appointed Assignees.

MONTREAL, Sept. 5.--Capt. Bourgades, of the schooner Marie Henrietta, found an iron box in mid-ocean on his voyage here. On the lid being pried open gas escaped, causing the examiners to get out of the way, and no one will run the risk of examining the box any further.

Nothing has been heard of William H. Schenck, the young clerk in William H. Beckwith's insurance office, No. 33 Pine-street, who disappeared last Thursday morning.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 5.--The Northwestern Association of Fire Insurance Company Managers held a conference here to-day with the Presidents and officers of various companies in regard to the general interests of the companies. The proceedings were strictly private, and the officers refuse to furnish any information to the press. The convention will continue in session to-morrow.

PARIS, Sept. 5.--The Chinese Legation here is still without any official information in regard to the reported massing of Chinese troops on the Tonquin frontier. It is admitted, however, by the members of the Embassy that if the French Asiatic squadron had been charged with the duty of notifying China of the signing of the Hue treaty, the situation might be greatly complicated thereby.
Ensign John Gibson, United States Navy, was married last evening to Miss Mattie A. Hopper, at Elizabeth, N.J. The ceremony took place at the residence of the bride's grandmother.

BOSTON, Sept. 5.--The opening exercises of the American Exposition of the Manufacturers and Mechanics' Institute took place to-day. The Governor and invited guests were escorted to the fair building on Huntingdon-avenue by a procession embracing the Ninth Massachusetts Infantry; the Jackson Corps, of Albany, N.Y.; the NationaLancers, and several bands of music.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--The Atlantic Club, of Baltimore, comprising Maryland Commandery No. 1, the Columbia Commandery, of Washington, and Demolay Commandery, of Washington, arrived from the West this morning. They will remain here until to-morrow morning.

STONE MOUNTAIN, Ga., Sept. 5.--The Rev. J. T. Pryor is a Baptist preacher living in Morgan County, near Madison. He is a fine preacher, well educated, and a deep thinker and expounder, 35 years of age. He has a wife and children. During his college days he went home with a schoolmate to spend a few days.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 5.--The city is full of strangers attracted by the opening of the Exposition and the reception of Rex. His Majesty and suite arrived last night and were quartered at the Burnet House, but of this the people were kept in ignorance.

There were a good many things for the stock brokers to talk about yesterday. They read with deep interest the remarkable feat of Mr. Jay Gould in cutting the tug-boat in two the day before with his yacht.

The Brooklyn Constitution Club was formally organized at a meeting of nearly 100 Brooklyn gentlemen, held in Dieter's, last night. The club is an offshoot of a club of the same name in this City, of which Gen. Henry E. Tremain is President.

The Metropolitans yesterday defeated the Eclipse Club on the Polo Grounds. Loose fielding on the part of the visitors in the eighth inning lost the game. Umpire McNichol again erred in his decisions.

BOSTON, Sept. 5.--The bark N. Boynton, which arrived here this morning from Manila, reports that on Aug. 24, in latitude 24 , longitude 60 , she took a heavy squall, with rain, the wind increasing to a hurricane. The vessel labored fearfully, the decks being flooded.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5.--The Superintendent of the Mounted Recruiting Service has been ordered to cause 40 recruits to be prepared and forwarded under proper charge to Santa Fe, NewMexico, for assignment to the Fourth Cavalry.
PETERSBURG, Va., Sept. 5.--The first bale of new cotton arrived here to-day. It was raised in Northampton County, N.C., and was classed as middling and sold at 13 cents.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5, 1883. About a dozen promotions were made to day in the clerical force of the Patent Office. Three clerks employed in the census bureau have been transferred to the Patent Office.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5.--Justice Field, of the United States Supreme Court, to-day granted a writ of habeas corpus to Li Ho, a Chinaman, returnable to-morrow. The petitioner sets forth that he is a native of Hong Kong, and is, therefore, a British subject, He arrived by the last steamer from China, and asked permission to come ashore.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 5.--The corporation of Brown University to-day elected Winslow Upton, a graduate of the University, Class of '45, Professor of Astronomy. Mr. Upton is now connected with the Signal Service at Washington.

GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 5.--A special dispatch to the News says: "On the Houston and Texas Central Railroad, four miles west of Ross, a freight train, loaded with 500 head of cattle, was wrecked yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5.--An effort was made to see Judge Hoadly here to-day with regard to the statement published that he would withdraw from the Democratic ticket in Ohio, but he could not be seen.

Tears glistened in Jay Gould's eyes and there was a suspicious huskiness in his voice as he narrated some of the trials of his early life before the Senate Sub-committee on Education and Labor yesterday. A large audience listened in perfect silence to the interesting story which Mr. Gould told.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5.--Col. E.B.C. Cash, of South Carolina, remarked to a correspondent of THE TIMES to-day that he did not think the people and newspapers at the North took the right view of the Independent movement in his State.

Michael A. Foley, whose wife, Kate Foley, died at the Bull's Head Hotel on Tuesday morning, called at the Coroner's office yesterday and made a sworn statement to Deputy Coroner Donlin.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5.--The leading produce markets were active to-day and very irregular. The grain markets were disposed to strength, but wheat gave way, and other cereals were kept down by an unusual weakness in provisions.

Druggist Henry Wackerbarth, who sleeps in the rear of his store in Sixth-avenue, just below the Greenwich Savings Bank, was roused from his slumbers about 3 o'clock Tuesday morning by persons talking in his store.

A conference was held yesterday afternoon between some of the holders of the $1,000,000 city bonds of Evansville, Ind., and a committee of municipal officers of that city in the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company Building, to consider the reduction of the rate of interest.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5.--Reports from Santa Barbara, Wilmington, and Los Angeles, Cal., announce that sharp shocks of earthquake were felt there at 4:30 o'clock this morning. The vibrations were from north-east to south-west.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 5.--Articles of incorporation of the Canada, La Crosse and Southwestern Railroad have been filed with the Secretary of State.

Mr. Charles Wyndham and his comedy company will begin their engagement at the UnionSquare Theatre on Monday evening. The opening play will be "The Great Divorce Case."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 5.--The joint Congressional Committee on the Newburg Centennial will meet at Cornwall at 11 o'clock on Friday morning. Senators Miller and Bayard and Congressman Ketcham have announced their intention of being present.
FORTRESS MONROE, Virginia, Sept. 5.--The new steam launch General Wool, built at Wilmington, Del., for this port, arrived here to-day. The Monroe will be sent to Fort Adams for duty.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 5.--A Jamestown family named Wynkoop has made a costly blunder. For some time the kitchen slops have been emptied into the flues supplying cold air to the furnace under the impression that they were sewer-pipes. The noxious gases from the decaying matter have resulted in sickness to all the family. One young lady to-day has died, and a young man is critically ill.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 5.--All prospects of the South-eastern Railway being sold to the syndicate of New-York capitalists appear to be at an end for the present, and the floating creditors of the road are likely to be frozen out.

The second day of the September meeting at Brighton Beach furnished some extraordinary racing, over which a great crowd became enthusiastic. A high wind prevailed throughout the afternoon, which interfered materially with the speed of the horses, although the track was in excellent condition.

OWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 5.--The Republican Convention for Tioga County was held here to-day. It was the most harmonious held in old Tioga for years.

LOCKPORT, N.Y. Sept. 5.--In the action of Mary McCartney against John Kennedy to recover damages for breach of promise of marriage, tried at the Niagara Circuit Court, before Judge Haight and a jury, a report of which appeared in THE TIMES of to-day, the jury returned a verdict for the plaintiff this afternoon for $400.

COLUMBUS, Sept. 6.--Between 40,000 and 50,000 persons attended the State Fair to-day. It was the largest crowd ever on the grounds. The fair is a great success, both in the character and number of the displays. The officers say that it will be a greater financial success than in any former years.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6.--Mr. Preston, the Haytian Minister, to-day rejected the guns which J. W. Frazier, of New-York, sent here on Monday for the new Haytian cruiser.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--For shipping and export grades the cattle market to-day showed a further slight gain in strength. While the receipts ran up to a very liberal total they did not embrace many wellfatted droves, and under a sharp demand holders found it possible to get 5 to 10 cents advance ...
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6.--The Trustees of Plymouth Congregation Church in this city agreed to pay the Rev. H.W. Beecher $2,400 for his four lectures in this city.

LONDON, Sept. 6.--A private letter from Pekin says that Li Hung Chang is really in favor of a peaceable solution of the difficulty with France, while the intriguers who surround the Court, are urgent in their cry for war.

BOSTON, Sept. 6.--In 1873 Benjamin E. Bates, of Boston, made a conditional contract to give Bates College of Lewiston, Me., $100,000, provided $100,000 more was raised within five years. His heirs claimed that the condition was not fulfilled, and the Trustees of the college brought suit to secure the amount. The full bench of the State Supreme Court has sustained the verdict of the lower court, which decided against the college.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 6.--Gov. Cleveland came out of the North Woods to-day, arriving in Utica at noon and leaving at 2:30 o'clock for Buffalo. He will remain in that city a few days before returning to Albany. He says he has enjoyed every hour of his vacation in the woods, and his appearance confirms his words.

GOUVERNEUR, N.Y., Sept. 6.--The First Assembly District Republican Convention, held here to-day, unanimously nominated Gen. N.M. Curtis for member of the Assembly. It was headed by a long-bearded gentleman wearing a broadbrimmed, white felt hat. Close behind him was another elderly man, with a flowing beard and a hat that was black and slouched after the manner of the men of the plains.

A suit for damages was begun yesterday against Isaac A. Shoemaker, the keeper of a restaurant at No. 1,281 Broadway, by the attorney for Mr. Samuel H. Preston, the gentleman who was assaulted while eating his dinner at the restaurant named by a pugilistic waiter called "Billy" on Aug. 29, Mr. Preston bolds the proprietor accountable to the extent of $5,000. The case is entered in the Supreme Court.
LONDON, Sept. 6.--The correspondent of the Telegraph at Paris says a rumor is current that Gen. Thibaudin Minister of War, will resign his portfolio.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6.--Assistant Secretary of the Interior Joselyn says that it is idle for Illinois people to talk of Arthur and Logan as the Republican ticket of 1884. Logan, he says, will not take the second place on the ticket. Mr. Joselyn's relations with Logan are intimate, and he speaks upon full knowledge of Logan's attitude.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 6.--Charles Adams, a Denver cattle-dealer, was drugged and robbed of $1,500 money and jewelry at the house of Denny Lawler, on Seneca-street, last night. Adams was in company with a woman named Kate Cowell, who was arrested to-day. Lawler and his bartender were also placed in custody.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--Light frosts are reported from Lacon, Freeport, Rockford, and Watseka, Ill.; Fond du Lac, Wis., and Argola, Ind. The damage is generally estimated as very light, and, as a whole, farmers are confident of securing the corn in average shape. The weather continues cool, and little anxiety is reported.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6.--A reception was given the Corean Embassy at the Chamber of Commerce this afternoon, and all the prominent merchants in the city were present. Addresses were made, which were responded to by the Chief Ambassador. The Embassy goes East to-morrow by the Central and Union Pacific Railroads.

MADISON, Ind., Sept. 6.--A young man hailing from Troy, N.Y., giving the name of Charles Davis, broke into the residence of Capt. Charles David to-day for the purpose of robbery. After a hard struggle he was overpowered and taken to jail. A lot of valuable jewelry, evidently stolen, was found on his person. Davis says he came here from North Vernon two days ago with four companions.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 6.--To-day's races at Aquidneck Park were well attended by Summer residents and others, and the weather was very pleasant for racing or for anything else. Several Tally Ho coaches and many of the finest equipages in the city were on the grounds.

The Brooklyn branch of the Irish National League, which is composed of all the local Irish societies, held a sort of grand jubilee yesterday afternoon and evening at Ridgewood Park, on the Jamaica plank road, just outside the Brooklyn City line.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--Martin Kaller, 31 years old, was shot and killed by Constable Johnson in the suburb of Highland Park last night. The constable fled after the shooting, and an attempt was made by the friends of the dead man to burn his house, claiming that the killing was unprovoked.

ALBANY, Sept. 6.--The following companies were incorporated to-day: Strong Sealing and Filtering Company of New-York; capital, $500,000. The Central Vermont Marble Company capital, $500,000; Directors--Green B. Raum, of Illinois; James Gilfillan, of New-York, and Corydon Karr, of Buffalo. The Lubricant Manufacturing Company, of New-York; capital, $500,000.
NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 6.--At 9 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in the light-house at Marianne Pass, Mississippi Sound, and the building was soon totally destroyed.

READING, Penn., Sept. 6.--The body of John Heffner, a German rag-picker of this city, who was killed on a railroad at Lancaster, was brought home to-day. Heffner was a native of Wurtemburg, Germany, was thrice married, and had 42 children. It is said that he had long since forgotten the names of many of his children.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--Five years ago the City Council passed an ordinance imposing an annual tax or license of $50 per car on each street car operated in the city.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--The leading produce markets were active today and generally stronger, with much more steadiness in most departments. There was a general disposition to call a halt on the downward movement both in grain and provisions.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6.--Ex-Speaker Samuel J. Randall, who has been drawn as a Quarter Sessions juror for the term beginning on Monday next, obtained his summons to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6.--A meeting of individual operators in the Schuylkill coal region has been held, at which it was resolved to adhere to the advance in the line and city and harbor prices recently established by the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company.
PARIS, Sept. 6.--The unveiling of the Statue of Lafayette took place to-day at Le Puy in the presence of an immense crowd of people, despite a severe rain-storm.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 6.--Two of the coal operators whose miners are included in the 2,000 men now out on a strike in the Massilon District have decided to pay the 10 cents advance asked, and their men have returned to work. The operators held a stormy meeting here to-day, but reached no decision. The majority of them are in favor of refusing the advance asked and of allowing the strike to proceed.

PARIS, Sept. 6.--King Alfonso and suite arrived here at 5:30 o'clock this morning. He was received at the railway station by Gen. Pittie, on behalf of President Grevy, and by the Duke de Fernan-Nufiez, the Spanish Ambassador here, and a large deputation of Spanish residents.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6.--It is stated by Trustees of the gas-works that deficiencies have been discovered in the accounts of that office, and that the defalcation may exceed $150,000.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 6.--The special train on which President Arthur, accompanied by Surrogate Rollins, of New-York, is returning to Washington, reached this city a little before 9 o'clock this evening, nearly an hour late.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 7.--The United States revenue steamer Manhattan, about which anxiety has been expressed at Washington, and which was bound from Quebec to Philadelphia, with the Chief of the Revenue Department on board, arrived here last night. She encountered the gale of Aug. 30 off Prince Edward's Island without damage, and experienced very heavy weather in crossing the Bay of Fundy on Wednesday. She will leave for Portland to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7.--Commissioner Evans has decided that hereafter brewers of weiss beer must conform to the regulations governing brewers of lager beer in the matter of bottling beer. Under a ruling by Commissioner Raum they were permitted to draw their beer for bottling directly from the vats. This privilege is now rescinded, and they will be required to bottle their beer from stamped packages.

PETERSBURG, Va., Sept. 7.--The first bale of new cotton raised in Virginia was received today from Brunswick County. It is classed middling. It is estimated that not more than a twothird crop will be made in consequence of the drought.

NEWBERN, S.C., Sept. 7.--Mrs. Penelope Whitfield, 36 years of age, fell inso an uncovered cistern at the Central Hotel this forenoon and was drowned. The accident was not discovered until late this afternoon.

JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 7.--Two incendiary attempts were made here this week, one on a boarding-houses and one on a large manufacturing and business block. There is no clue to the incendiaries or their motives.

Messrs. Brooks and Dickson had a varnishing night at the Standard Theatre last evening for Messrs. Sims and Clay's new comic opera. "The Merry Duchess." A full-dress rehearsal, which was a real performance, was given in the presence of an invited audience composed of journalists.
Police Commissioner Sidney P. Nichols called together, in Tammany Hall, last evening the braves who compose the General Committee of the Tammany organization.
BOSTON, Sept. 7.--Lord Chief-Justice Coleridge to-day is the guest of Gov.Butler. After a breakfast at the Revere House, the Governor presiding.

LAREDO, Texas, Sept. 7.--The rains of the last day or two have caused an unprecedented rise in the Rio Grande. At noon to-day the perpendicular rise was 18 feet. It has since fallen 1 foot. Heavy rains have been falling to-day, and it is expected that a greater height will be reached ...

The car stable of the Philadelphia City Passenger Railway Company, at Forty-second and Chestnut streets, erected in 1865 at a cost of $40,000, was totally destroyed by fire last night, involving a loss of about $60,000. The property was fully insured, The fire caused a panicky feeling among the inmates of the alms-house near by, and a female patient was so terribly frightened that she leaped from a window and was instantly killed.
The Amalgamated Trade and Labor Union held its regular semi-monthly meeting last evening at No. 10 Stenton-street. Kenneth Mackenzie occupied the chair.
BRUSSELS, Sept. 7.--A grand fete is announced for Sunday next, the proceeds of which will be devoted to the benefit of the sufferers by the Ischia and Java disasters.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Sept. 7.--The Summer of 1883 has been a peculiar one from a meteorological point of view. Electric storms were prevalent in June and July, and there was frost in the Catskills in August, yet the farmers have had a a much better season than they anticipated. Returns show that the has yield in the Hudson River counties was an average one.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Sept. 7.--The exports to the United States have fallen off since the new United States tariff came into force. There are now no shipments of malt and shellac varnish, and but little iron ore compared with the trade of last 1883.

GODERICH, Ontario, Sept. 7.--The schooner yacht Explorer, bound from Goderich to Cove Island, was lost with all hands on Greenough Shoals during the gale last Tuesday. The names of those lost were Capt. Charles Woods, John McDonald, M. Heale, and Walter Crane, son of Albert Crane, of Chicago, who was on a pleasure trin.

A special meeting of the stockholders of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad will be held at Colorado Springs Oct. 6 to vote on a financial plan whereby it is proposed to establish and maintain the credit of the company.

HAMBURG, Penn., Sept. 7.--Mary Bordy, daughter of Henry Bordy, who resides a half-mile above Hamburg, committed suicide by drowning herself in the Schuylkill Canal on Wednesday evening.

Superintendent Walling received a letter from O. E. Dudley, of No. 62 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, yesterday, informing him that Henry J. Williams, of Greensboro, N. C., had been missing since the 10th of July.
Mr. George D. Chapman, the head of the Chapman syndicate, which has been negotiating for the purchase of the South-eastern Railroad, returned from Montreal yesterday.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 7.--Mrs. Julie P. Smith, the authoress, of Hartford, was killed at her Summer residence in New-Hartford this morning. She was driving about the grounds surrounding her beautiful home preparatory to taking her husband to Hartford, as was her custom every morning.

LONDON, Sept. 7.--The Manchester Cuard ian, in its commercial article, says that the critical condition of the relations between France and China is a source of discouragement in the cotton goods market. Purchases are being made sparingly, but prices remain firm.

MADISON, Ind., Sept. 7.--Charles Davis, captured while robbing Capt. David's residence yesterday, was arraigned in the Circuit Court today, pleaded guilty and was sentenced to five years hard labor in the Penitentiary South.

The will of the late Edward Ridley was offered for probate in the Surrogate's Court of Kings County yesterday. The will is dated July 11, 1876, and the deceased died Aug. 21 of the present year, at his country residence in the town of Gravesend, Long Island.

Greenwood Lake was dotted with excursion parties yesterday. Boats of all descriptions, from canoes to eight-oared barges, conveyed merry parties of ladies and gentlemen along the picturesque shores from morning until sundown. There was a total absence of sail-boats, however, not even a cat-rigged Whiteball boat being visible.

HALIFAX, Sept. 7.--A telegram from the vicinity of Indian Harbor states that a wrecking steamer and a number of boats have been searching there for the sunken wreck reported, but so far it has not been discovered. The opinion now held by some is that the floating spar observed was a place of drift wreckage entangled on the shoal.

Mr. Albert H. Dillingham boards at No. 10 Wavarley-place, and about 1:30 o'clock yestrday morning, after evening the night with some friends he went home intoxicated.

OTTAWA, Sept. 7.--As a result of the conference of cotton manufacturers just concluded in Montreal, in addition to what has been already stated, they have agreed to run their mills only four days per week, in view of the large over-production.

Stephens, was engaged in driving cold chisels through white chalk marks on the bottom of the bursted holler.

LONDON, Sept. 7.--A dispatch to the Times from Paris says that both the Governments of France and China are equally desirous of securing a peaceful solution of the Tonquin question if it can be effected with honor. The general sentiment favors the hope that all the issues involved may be submitted to the arbitration of England.

Coroner Joyce does not suspect him, nor Coroner Joyce's detectives; neither is the suspicion that of State Attorney Fessenden, nor of State Attorney Fessenden's detectives.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7.--The New-York base-ball nine came to grief at Recreation Park today, when for the second time this season they were beaten by the Philadelphia Club, by a score of 11 to 9.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7.--A special to the Times from Huntingdon, Penn., says that the Rev. J. W. White, Pastor of the Presbyterian church at Milroy, was to-day deposed from the ministry by the Presbytery of Huntingdon for heresy. The meeting had been in progress at Lewistown for three days.
MUNICH, Sept. 7.--At the session of the International Law Institute held in this city yesterday ex-Judge John F. Dillon, of NewYork City, was elected an associate member.

Another fine day's sport is promised at Sheepshead Bay to-day. Six races are on the programme, with numerous entries. The principal event is the Autumn cup, three miles, with Eole, Aella, and Monroe as probable starters out of the 36 nominations.
The Episcopal church, Read's blacksmith's shop and house, the Parlet Hall, and the schoolhouse at Oak Bay, Charlotte County, New-Brunswick, were destroyed by fire on Thursday. Loss not ascertained.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 7.--The Acting Governor has issued a proclamation to the effect that an election will be held Nov. 20 in the First Congressional District, North Carolina, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of the Hon. Walter F. Pool.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 7.--In the courtmartial this morning the case of Naval Cadet Moeller was resumed. Cadet W.P. Eyre testified that he was not required to remain in the washroom by the accused, but by other Third Class men. He thought the orders were compulsory.
LONDON, Sept. 7.--The propulsion of tram cars by electricity was tested by the French Electrical Power Company in Paris yesterday with satisfactory results.

UTICA, Sept. 7.--The Oneida Second District Republican Convention to-day elected Henry S. Stark, Charles H. Fister, M. W. Bigelow, and Glenn W. Petrie delegates to the State Convention.
