WASHINGTON, Sept. 7.--The State Department has received a special report from Consul Dockey at Leeds, on the subject of the evasion of the United States tariff laws by British manufacturers of linen threads.
BOSTON, Sept. 7.--The ship Raphael reports that on July 11, while off Cape of Good Hope, Pierre Roberts, a seaman, was lost overboard and drowned.
AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Sept. 7.--Daniel Kelly, of New-York, became intoxicated here, and went to sleep on the Central Railroad track. The fast express huried him in the ditch, fatally injuring him.

Several officers of the "Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers" were before the Senate sub-committee yesterday, and their remarks, though they contained nothing novel, were, on the whole, interesting and useful.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7.--The leading produce markets were less active to-day, but generally stronger. There was a decided advance in most departments, which was led by corn, and the market was strengthened by fears of damage by frost.

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Sept. 7. -- The latest telegraphic news from Trepassey states that everything, including the mails, on board the steamer Canima, which was wrecked yesterday on Guli Island, was lost. BRADFORD, Penn., Sept. 6.--The attention of several prominent Pennsylvania oil operators has been given lately to the possibilities of Wyoming as an oil-producing region and one of them who recently returned from an investigation of the petroleum fields of that district gives some in teresting and important details as to its character and prospects.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 7.--To-day closed the most successful fair ever held in the State of Iowa. It was not only the finest exhibition ever offered in the State to the public, but the attendance was larger than at any previous fair.

CITY OF MEXICO. Sept. 7.--There is much talk of the candidacy of Don Ramon Fernandez, Governor of a federal district, for President. Although Fernandez is very strong, it is authoritatively stated that he will not oppose the candidacy of Gen. Diaz. A number of papers have already come out in favor of Diaz. The election will take place next June.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7.--Wassey Alberson, 10 years old, a son of George Alberson, of No. 1,813 Bond-street, died of hydrophobia this morning. On Oct. 13 last young Alberson, while playing with a half-hreed spitz dog belonging to one of his father's neighbors, was severely bitten in the hand.
Several years ago Mr. Peter B. Ross separated from his wife on the ground of incompatibility of temperament. He made his home in Brooklyn, and she went to live in New-York.

Cool but pleasant weather, a track in fine condition, and excellent racing combined to make the third day of the September meeting at Brighton Beach very interesting. There was a very large attendance of spectators, and the betting during the day was very heavy.

OTTAWA, Sept. 7.--The great falling off in the demand for wooden ships has led to the closing of a number of ship-yards in Nova Scotia and New-Brunswick. Several contracts have been made by Canadian ship-owners with Scotch shipbuilders for iron vessels to be delivered early in the Spring.

An inquirer, whom we may call Smith, writes to THE TIMES to ask which is the best language--English, German, or French. Mr. Smith, being alive to the fact that every man ought to speak some language, evidently desires to select a good one.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7.--Wheat charters have dropped 5s in three days, owing to the large amount of disengaged tonnage in port. To-day wooden charters to Liverpool were taken at 45s. and an iron cahrter to Cork was taken at 52s.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 7.--The steamer Lily, of the Winnipeg and Western Transportation Company, which was rebuilt this season at a cost of $35,000, struck a rock and sunk while on a trial trip in the South Saskatchewan River, about 600 miles west of Winnipeg. It is not known whether or not the passengers escaped, the accident having occurred 50 miles from a telegraph station.
SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 7.--Michael Kelly, the track-layer who was injured by the explosion of fire-damp at Fair Lawn Colliery yesterday, died this afternoon.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 7.--Henry Robinson a convict, who is under a sentence for 10 years for burglary in Troup County, is in a dying condition in the penitentiary hospital from a wound received on Wednesday night while attempting to escape.
HAVANA, Sept. 7.--On Sept. 5 a hurricane passed south of St. Kitts, having done much damage in Martinique.

LEXINGTON, Ky., sept. 7.--The Kentucky Association continued its racing to-day, although the weather was oppressively warm. The track was fast, but dusty, the attendance small, and the betting lively. The colt race was the only interesting struggle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7.--Capt. Charles. W. Williams Assistant Quartermaster, has been relieved from duty in the Department of Texas, and will proceed to the head-quarters Department of Arizona and report to the commanding General for duty as assistant to the Chief Quartermaster of that department.

Major E. A. Truax, book-keeper of the National Branch Bank and a prominent Presbyterian of Madison, Ind., died very suddenly at midnight of heart disease. He was Paymaster in the late war and was well and favorably known at Cincinnati and in the West. He was 56 years old and leaves a wife and three grown children.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7.--In the effort to suppress the smoke nuisance the North western Railroad Company was this morning fined $250 on evidence that five of its switching engines were seen emitting dense clouds of smoke. The crusade of the city officers is particularly directed against the railway companies and the owners of river tugs.

Ex-Water Commissioner Edward J. Lowber, who was at one time prominently identified with local politics in Brooklyn, died, in the sixtyfifth year of his are at his home, in Henry-street, in that city, Thursday night.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 7.--All the harness manufactures in this city excepting two firms have yielded to the demands of the men for a 10 per cent. advance in wages, and the strike will probably be over in two or three days.

ALBION, N.Y., Sept. 9.--Special United States Treasury Agent Henry A. Glidden arrived here from Sitka, Alaska, this afternoon.

Roosevelt, of New-York, has written a long and pointed letter to the editor of the Rochester Post-Express, in which he gives some entertaining views of the factional split in the Democracy of his City, and expresses some decided opinions of "Kelly and his crew," as he characterizes Tammany Hall and its "honored leader."

The Salle d'Asile Francais celebrated its annual fete, or Commencement, yesterday afternoon at Irving Hall. The Salle d'Asile is a benvolent institution which takes care of little French children whose parents go out to work during the day.

A stray buffalo was killed near Yorktown, in Northern Dakota, last week. The appearance of a buffalo in Dakota is now an exceedingly rare occurrence, but 10 years ago they were as numerous in the western portion of our Territory as the heads of the domestic beef cattle are now.

This week will about bring the Peninsula peach season to a close, although a few late smocks and a few white clings will remain for the next week.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 9.--At 9 o'clock to-night a fire broke out in the building on the north-east corner of Genesee-street and the Erie Canal. The offices of the Western Union and American Rapid Telegraph Companies were situated on the first floor.

MATAWAN, N.J., Sept. 9.--The Rev. C.J. Peace, for some time Rector of St. Mary's Episcopal Church, in Keyport, has been arrested as a fleeing debtor. Mr. Peace had resigned his charge in Keyport, and was about to move from the State, leaving a debt of $90 for house rent.

David Hinkley, of La Grange, drove from that place to Dexter, stopped over night and drove from there to Livermore Falls, a distance of about 60 miles, in one day.
LONDON, Sept. 10.--The Anchor Line steam-ship Bulgravia, Capt. Hutchinson, from New-York Aug. 28, has arr, at Queenstown, on her way to Liverpool.
CINCINNATI Sept. 9.--The Mississippi Press Association, of which Mr. F.C. Morehead is President, arrived here to-night from Louisville.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 9.--Dr. William Mahenkin, charged with committing an abortion on Miss Kate Tuskin, has been held for trial on a charge of murder. He denies all knowledge of the affair.

Prof. William R. Brooks says in a note to the Rochester Union, under date of Sept. 6: "The latest observations of the new comet, discovered by me last Saturday evening, were made last night. The sky was very clear, and the comet was an easy object in the large reflecting telescope.

MERIDEN, Conn., Sept. 9.--H.M. Mather's jewelry establishment and H.N. Brooks Co.'s stationery store, in the Palace Block, on Mainstreet, were entered by burglars early this morning. Mather had two safes in his store, an old one in the rear and a new one in the front part of the place.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9.--An international wrestling tournament will take place here to-morrow night under the management of the Caledonian Club. Richard K. Fox, of New-York, has offered a special prize of $600. Dalley, of NewYork; Keating, of Boston; Dunean C. Ross, Gallagher, and others are to be the contestants.

HARRISONBURG, Va., Sept. 9.--A meeting of the citizens was held here last night at which steps were taken to entartain the Union veteran excursionists on Sept. 22. The People are determined not to be outdone by any other town in the valley, and "the boys who wre tha blue" will be well cared for.

The Guion steam-ship Nevada, which arrived from Liverpool yesterday, brought a party of 682 Mormon immigrants. Mr. P.F. Gross had charge of them, and with him were 27 other returned missionaries of the Mormon Church.
TRENTON, Sept. 9.--The primary elections held throughout Hudson County last Thursday night have given shape and direction to the Democratic Gubernatorial canvass throughout the State.
Tennessee papers are appealing to the Legislature to enact a dog tax law and a fence law at its next session.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9.--Colored people may complain, and perhaps with justice, that when it comes to offices the Republican Party is stingy to its dark allies at the polls. Still, there are many negroes in Government employ.

OTTAWA, Sept. 9--A case in which United States soldiers invaded Canadian territory and kidnaped deserters from the American Army has been brought to the notice of the Dominion Government, which will likely inquire more fully into the matter before taking any steps to have the wrong, if any, redressed.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 10.--Frost is reported very generally throughout Ohio, Indiana, and Kentucky the last two mornings. A report from Kentucky says all the tobacco on low ground and creek bottoms is ruined and vegetables everywhere are injured.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 10.--Saturday evening a fine Maltese cat strayed into the store of Mr. Ellis on Houston-street. It made itself quite at home and was fondled by Mrs. Ellis with some degree of pleasure.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 10.--A party of negroes in Wayne County were having a regular breakdown, in which all dance at once. Lewis Stewart and John McGee came in collision.
The branch of the Mercantile Library at No. 431 Fifth-avenue, which is now in operation, is proving a great accommodation to the patrons of the institution.

Thousands of boys and girls could be seen yesterday morning hurrying along the sidewalks with books and slates under their arms. It was school-opening day, and the yougsters, with rested minds and willing hearts, resumed their studies for the ensuing school term.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--Ever since the internal revenue laws were so amended that vinegar-makers were allowed to distill their own spirits the door has been open to the commission of many frauds by the distillation of whisky in vinegar factories.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Sept. 10.--The whaling schooner Ellen Rizpah, Capt. Dunham, arrived here this afternoon with 30 barrels of sperm oil. During the week ended yesterday there were eight arrivals from the Grand Banks, with about 19,000 quintals of codfish.

RUSHVILLE, Ill., Sept. 10.--The Rayborn and Obenshain Pilgrim Temple, at Erwin, 10 miles west of this place, was destroyed by fire Friday night. CONYERS, Ga., Sept. 10.--Miss Susan Townsend and Mrs. Crawley are two ladies who live alone on the edge of the town. For some time they have been annoyed by doubtful attentions, anonymously expressed, and the matter has given them much trouble.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--An innovation was made here to-day in the walking-match line in the attempt of William Kitzig, a laborer, 32 years old, to mount a flight of 45 steps 300 times in 10 hours for a wager.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 10.--This morning Edward D. Cowan, city editor of the Leadville Herald, was brutally assaulted by Alderman Joy, of that city.

A convocation of the colored clergy of the Protestant Episcopal Church will begin in this City to-morrow. The deliberations will continue three days, in the Church of the Holy Communion, Sixth-avenue and Twentieth-street.
PETERSBURG, Va., Sept. 10.--Deer are dying in large numbers in adjacent counties from a disease called "black tongue." The tongue turns perfectly black.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 9.--In a modest two-story frame house in Washington-aveuue, the centre of the aristocracy and culture of this busy manufacturing city, lives Mrs. E.S.W. Jones, widow of Henry Jones, the gentleman who was so frequently mistaken for the late rebel General, Robert E. Lee.

FORSYTHE, Ga., Sept. 11.--A little after 1 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in the Monroe Advertiser building, and Thomas's warehouse and other business houses connected therewith were destroyed.
Lues Garenrer and Karl A. Karsted, young men, supposed to be Swedish sailors, registered Monday evening at Bayer's lodging-house, No. 178 South-street, and went to Room No. 16.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 11.--City Treasurer Walsho, under cover of Judge Lazarus's injunction, resumed possession this morning of his office, from which he had been forcibly ejected yesterday by the police, acting under orders of Mayor Behan. To-night the City Council met and voted to impeach the City Treasurer, which will probably be done before the adjournment of to-night's session.

Few vessels have sailed from this port during the past 48 hours owing to the storm which has been predicted by the weather authorities. The Colon, which left her dock for Aspinwall on Monday, remained at anchor in the Lower Bay all day yesterday.

READING, Penn., Sept. 11.--Capt. A.H. Bogardus and his son Eugene, who have been here for the past two days with the Wild West Show of Buffalo Bill and Dr. Carver, this morning engaged in a friendly pigeon-shooting match will Isaac Eckert and Oliver Hinnershitz, of the Forrester Shooting Club, of Reading.
BOSTON, Sept. 11.--The Journal has reports from Maine, New-Hampshire, and Vermont showing the present condition of the crops: Despite the drought the staples in Maine are in a fair condition.

Anna M. and William Bundenbender were married in June, 1873, and the former has brought suit in the Court of Common Pleas for a separation.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--It is believed that the South Chicago Steel Mills, of the North Chicago Rolling Mill Company, will be again started up in a few days, the men returning to work at the old rates.

There were some sharp contests in several of the wards at the primaries held last evening in Brooklyn to elect delegates to the assembly District Conventions which meet to-morrow evening to elect the 46 delegates who will represent Kings County in the Republican State Convention.

RED BANK, N.J. Sept. 11.--The erection of telephone poles in Broad-street, the main thoroughfare here, has caused a commotion to-day. Neither mild protests nor threats of open warfare have deterred the workmen, and victory so far perches upon the obnoxious poles.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 11.--A close carriage whirled through the streets of Stratford this morning, and went rapidly over the dusty highway leading to Bridgeport. The NewYork newsaper train had arrived, bringing THE TIMES'S story of the grave suspicions ...

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 11.--The new State Board of Claims, created by the last Legislature to take the place of the State Board of Audit and the Canal Appraisers, held its first sitting in the Capitol to-day. Commissioners Lyman H. Northrup, George M. Beebe, and Henry F. Allen being present.

LONDON, Sept. 11.--The continued spread of the cattle disease in nearly every portion of England causes the greatest uneasiness. In some sections of England only American beef is now to be obtained. Reports from Scotland state that the disease has not yet made its appearance there.
The lung troubles of President Darling, of Hamilton College, now confine him to his room. Gov. Knott, of Kontucky, protests with emphasis that he is not a candidate for the United States Senate.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 11.--Last Sunday a body was found floating in the Niagara River near Youngstown. It was almost nude, and appeared to have been in the water some time. The body was recognized as that of young McNamara, who was drowned at Sheenwater, at the head of Grand Island, about a week ago. The body was sent to Buffalo for burial.

CAIRO, Ill., Sept. 11.--Kate Colton, a colored woman, became incensed at Alf Miller, who refused to marry her, and put some poison in the coffee at the house of Miller's father-in-law last night, and the whole family was poisoned. One member has already died and the rest are very low.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11.--A special telegram from Vincennes, Ind., says that J.C. Bedell, who represented the commission house of McCormick Beebe, of Chicago, in that city, has disappeared, leaving an indebtedness of $25,000. The Chicago firm says it is in no way affected by Bedell's flight, as his relations with it were not of a character which could involve the firm in any way.

LONDON, Sept. 11.--A dispatch from Paris to the Exchange Telegraph Company states that Marquis Tseng, the Chinese Ambassador, prior to leaving Paris for London, communicated with M. Challemel-Lacour, the French Minister ...

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11.--The afternoon train from New-England this evening brought to this city L. Scoville Curtis, the mysterious stranger of the Amber murder case at Stratford, Conn. His home is at No. 3,307 Walnut-street, where he lives with his mother.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 11.--A concurrent resolution has been adopted providing for the final adjournment of the Legislature on Sept. 13.

LIMA, Sept. 11, via Galveston.--El Bien Publico says: "Various populaces in Canete have recognized the authority of Gen. Iglesias. The military forces in arms in the District of Pacaran have adopted resolutions to the same effect. A telegram from Mollendo says that Montero has tendered his resignation as Chief of the Council of Ministers, but it has not been accepted."

Two men who were seen loitering near H. Bezzenberger's drug store, on the corner of Grandstreet and Bushwick-avenue, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning, ran hastily away when approached by Special Officer Fowles.
ALBANY, Sept. 11.--The Railroad Commission to-day heard arguments for and against its recent recommendation that quarterly reports of the financial condition of railroad companies be required.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 11.--Two young fishermen named George Hubby and John Collishaw, belonging at St. Margaret's Bay, went out from Digby Saturday to attend their nets. Yesterday their boat drifted ashore near Digby, and it is supposed that the craft was struck by a squall and its occupants thrown out and drowned. The bodies have not yet been recovered.

TROY, Sept. 11.--Howard Stevens and George Brown were drowned in Lake Champlain, near Plattsburg, on Sunday by the capsizing of a sail-boat. A.J. Smith, another of the party, drifted with the boat for 10 hours, finally landing on an Island. He reached Plattsburg last night.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 11.--The court-martial this morning took up the case of Cadet G.B. Bird, charged with hazing Cadets Coleman, Van Antwerp, Carden, Eyre, West, and Ware. ExJudge Magruder appeared as counsel for the accused, ...

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 11.--The NewYork State Agricultural Society's forty-third annual fair was successfully opened yesterday and was attended to-day by thousands. In all the departments the entries are large and include the best in the State. The show of cattle is the best in the history of the society.

WARSAW DEPOT, N.Y., Sept. 11.--Charles Cox, a farmer at Wyoming, while attempting to board a morning train on the Erie Railroad at Linden, was thrown to the ground and his skull fractured. He cannot live.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 11.--It is stated by autority that the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad Company has settled in full with all the persons injured by the collision on the Lake Ontario Shore Branch at Carlyon, Orleans County, in the last week of July.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11.--The ninth annual convocation of the Chapter General of America of the Knights of St. John and Malta was opened here to-day and adjourned after appointing committees. The session will last two days.

ALBANY, Sept. 11.--The Governor has pardoned John Shine, who was sentenced on April 21, 1882, to the Onondaga County Penitentiary, upon conviction of mayhem, for a term of seven years, and has filed the following reasons:

PETERSBURG, Va., Sept. 11.--The protracted drought, which has done great damage to the crops throughout the State, was ended to-day. Very heavy rains have fallen throughout the various sections of Virginia, but too late, it is feared, to do the corn much good.
ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 11.--George R. Eager, of Boston, did not appear before the joint Investigating Committee to-day, but telegraphed that he would leave Boston by the first train.
The district leaders of the County Democracy continued at their head-quarters, No. 1 Union-square, last evening, the series of caucuses which they have been holding for a fortnight.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 11.--Gen. Weaver, making a virtue of necessity, has written the Chairman of the Greenback Committee of the Sixth District declining to be a candidate for the Cotts vacancy.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 11.--The Kentucky Association was favored with beautiful weather to-day. The attendance was very fair, the track was fast, but still very dusty, and the betting and racing were good.

The Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild has closed its work for this season. Thirty-two regular excursions were made, on which 19,564 children and mothers were carried.

Gen. James Jourdan yesterday forwarded to the Governor his resignation as General commanding the Second Division of the National Guard. Following so quickly on the resignation of Tax Collector Tanner from the Presidency of the Republican General Committee of Kings County, Gen. Jourdan's action has set the politicians to making surmises of all kinds.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 11.--A regatta for single sculls for a purse of $1,000, divided into four prizes, took place on a three-mile course on the Ohio River at this place this afternoon. There were 11 entries, divided into two classes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11.--September returns to the Department of Agriculture indicate a lower condition of corn than in August in every section of the country and in nearly every State. The only gains in the West are in Missouri, Kansas, and Nebraska, where slight improvement is indicated.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 11.--The first meeting of the Narragansett Driving Association opened at Narragansett Park to-day with 3,000 persons in attendance. The track had been swept and rolled and was in good condition, but about two seconds slow on account of cold, lowering weather and a north-east wind that swept across the grounds.

The Board of Trustees of the Hebrew congregation Shearith Israel, which means in English the remnant of Israel, is without a President, or "Parnass," and from present indications the deadlock in the board, which has resulted in this condition of affairs, is liable to continue for some time.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 11.--The sea was very heavy to-day, and the landing platform of Ocean Pier was taken up by order of Superintendent Taylor. It is believed that no more trips between the pier and New-York will be made this season by the steamer Plymouth Rock. Most of the hotels are already closed.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11.--The tragedy of last night has already resulted in one death. The true story is that Henry Blessing, an engineer on the steamer St. Genevieve, was jealous of his wife. He lived with her at No. 1,451 Cass-avenue, and the only other occupant of their home was William F. Thielwann, his wife's brother.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 11.--Four posts of the Grand Army of the Republic were organized yesterday by order of Gen. Reynolds, of this city, Commander of the Department of New-York.

The ignorance of practical politics shown by the Italians has already been bewailed in these colmnns. Fortunately, there is a hope that this ignorance will not be permanent, for the Italians of this City have just organized a school for the study of politics, and are about to engage a number of able lecturers on political subjects.

LONDON, Sept. 12.--The Times in a leading article says: "It is difficult to avoid the suspicion that the Canton riot was directly connected with the irritation caused by the French operations in Tenquin.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 12.--The strike of the Manchester Iron and Steel Works has been settled by the company reinstating Superintendent Kloman. The men resumed work to-day.

TORONTO, Sept. 12.--A cable dispatch from London to the Globe says: "The joint exhibit of the Dominion Government and the Canadian Pacific Railroad Company at the North Lancashire Agricultural Show, at Liverpool has been awarded a silver medal."

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12.--The only authority for the rumors of attempts to wreck trains on the Chicago and North western Railroad is the statements of station policemen, who got their information from men on the trains which were supposed to have been in danger.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 12.--On account of the continued rain-storm the managers of the Oriole Association have posted a bulletin announcing that the reception of Lord Baltimore and the electric light parade has been postponed until to-morrow night, and the procession of the Mystic pageant until Friday night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12.--Ex-AttorneyGeneral Bromley, of Tasmania, who is here, says that the feeling in favor of annexation is so strong in the Australian colonies that the English flag will probably to planted in the New-Hebrides within a few weeks.

MILFORD, Penn., Sept. 12.--The Republican Convention to nominate a candidate for President Judge for the Twenty-second Judicial District met here to-day and nominated the Hon. Henry M. Seeley, of Honesdale, the present incumbent, by acclamation.

The Croton Aqueduct Commission met yesterday to hear any persons interested in the proposed plan of building a dam at Quaker Bridge. Among those present beside the Commissioners were Dr. Elisha Harris and Erastus Brooks, of the State Board of Health; Prof. Charles F. Chandler, Orlando B. Potter, Henry T. Pellew, Hugh N. Camp, and Judge William H. Arnoux.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12.--Abraham Goldsmid, lately a diamond broker at No. 97 Madison-street, wants $25,000 more of Leopold Rothgerber, a money lender, and began suit for it in the Superior Court to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12.--The body of Henry M. Brown, an adjuster of accounts for an insurance company, was found on the river bank at Gloucester, N. J., this morning. It believed that he committed suicide by poisoning himself. He had previously made several attempts to take his own life.

MISSOULA, Montana, Sept. 12.--Senator Vest and Delegate Maginnis, of the Indian Commission, returned to-day from St. Mary's Mission. Bitter Root Valley, at the Flathead Agency. The Indians refused to sell any portion of their reserve or to move to another reservation.

The differences that have arisen between Jay Gould and the men who control the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad system have given rice to negotiations which, it is thought, will soon put Mr. Gould in control of the Louisville and Nashville Road and the Central Railroad of Georgia.

QUEENSTOWN, Sept. 13.--The Guion Line steam-ship Wisconsin, Capt. Rigby, from New-York Sept. 4, for this port and Liverpool, was signaled off Fastnet at 2 o'clock this morning.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12.--The city election took place to-day. Robert S. Franklin, Republican, was re-elected Mayor by 322 majority over Lewis Brown, Democrat. This election was looked forward to with much interest in view of the fact that it was the first held since the changing of the time of the annual election.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 12.--The Board of Directors of the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway met to-day, adopted the annual report of the President and Directors, and declared a dividend of 2 per cent., payable on Oct. 1.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 12.--Coroner Holt, of Bridgeport, who has now taken charge of the investigation into the murder of Rose Ambler, said very frankly to-night that up to this time not a single satisfactory discovery had been made promising to bring the criminal to justice.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12.--The Polish citizens of Chicago to-day celebrated the two hundredth anniversary of the expulsion of the Turks from Poland by King John Sobieski by his victory at Vienna.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 12.--On account of extreme low water, a portion of the Amoskeag Mills has been shut down, and will remain idle until the river rises or the engines now being put in are ready to run, which will be in about four weeks. From 8,500 to 4,000 operatives are thus temporarily thrown out of employment. The other mills will run nearly, if not quite, fell time.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 12.--Another Republican Convention is called for the Second District of Oswego County, to be held on Saturday. The reason assigned is that the convention held last week was not in accordance with the new law regulating the holding of primaries and conventions. It is expected that the new convention will ratify the proceedings of the other.

The Chevalier Antoine de Kontsky, whose excellent performances upon the piano have made him a firm favorite in this City, has been engaged by Mr. Maurice Strakoach to appear during the coming season at Miss Emma Thursby's concerts.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 12.--The bodies of five of the girls who perished in the flames at Drelan's rag warehouse fire were taken to St. Francis Xavier's Church this morning, where a requiem mass was celebrated, after which they were buried side by side in the cemetery. A large crowd was present at the funeral.

Many people visited the place yesterday and then wandered across Vernon-avenue and hunted up the wrecked cars and locomotives in the company's repair-yard.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12.--Mrs. G.M. Miller, of New-York, gave a dinner party to-night, and Mrs. J.V.L. Pruyn gave a dinner in honor of Chief-Justice Coleridge. Owing to a storm, Judge Coleridge did not visit the torpedo station as expected.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 12--The House this morning, after a long discussion, agreed to the "no pay" resolution as amended by the Senate, "that no appropriation shall be reported after Sept. 10, except for officers and employes." The Senate did nothing except to recommit the appropriation bill to committee.

The entire amount of $1,400,000 of Rochester and Pittsburg consolidated first mortgage bonds was awarded yesterday to New-York persons at 90 and accrued interest. Bids to the amount of $1,900,000 were received, and they ranged from 85 to 90.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 12.--Efforts are being quietly made to harmonize the Democracy of this county, but thus far with but little success. A part of the State Executive Committee are here for that purpose.

EASTON, Penn., Sept. 12.--A freight train on the Lehigh and Susquehanna Railroad was wrecked this morning at Siegfried's bridge. Eight cars were demolished and the tracks were blocked. All trains were delayed several hours, passengers and baggage being transferred at the scene of the accident.

The Coney Island Jockey Club races at Sheepshead Bay will be run to-day, rain or shine.

The annual convention of the American Bankers' Association will be held in Louisville, Ky., Oct. 10 and 11. This will be the first convention of the association held south of Mason and Dixon's line. Dr. George Marsland, the Recording Secretary, said yesterday that the attendance was expected to be large.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 12.--The anniversary of the battle of Plattsburg was celebrated here yesterday by a firemen's muster, a parade of engine and hose companies, and foot and boat races.

The Amerique, of the General Transatlantic Company, arrived at her pier last evening and brought the passengers of the St. Germain, which ran into the English steamer Woodburn and sank her. One of the passengers who was on the St. Germain said in reference to the collision: "I was on the deck at the time. We left Havre on Aug. 25 and were proceeding with fair weather.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 12.--The Narragansett Park races were postponed to-day on account of rain. The visiting owners and drivers of horses were entertained this evening by the members of the Narragansett Driving Association at the Vue De L'Eau Club-house.

The Cunard steam-ship Pavonia, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool, brought 15 shipwrecked Norwegians, who had been transferred to that vessel from the steamer Llandaff City. These men belonged to the bark Coriolan, which was abandoned on Sept. 2 in latitude 40 15' and longitude 65 19'.

BOSTON, Sept. 12.--The caucuses in this city to choose delegates to next week's Republican State Convention were held to-night. As a rule they were unusually well attended by merchants and business men who seldom come out to the caucuses except during a national canvass, or at times when their interest is directly awakened by an uncommon state of things political.

GRAPEVILLE, Penn., Sept. 12.--Joseph Pune, an Italian, while attempting to steal potatoes from a garden patch last night, was riddled with ballets and then dragged to a railroad crossing and laid on the track, where he was discovered some time later. His wounds are fatal. The farmers have been annoyed for some time past by parties committing depredations, and last night they lay in ambush, with the above results.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12.--The nineteenth biennial session of the American Pomological Society was opened this morning at Horticultural Hall, with about 200 delegates present from all parts of the country.

LONDON, Sept. 12.--At a meeting of the supporters of Mr. Bradlaugh it was resolved that at the next session of Parliament the House of Commons should be given no rest until Mr. Bradlaugh be admitted to his seat or his legal disqualification finally determined.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 12.--Nancy E. Clem, who figured so prominently in the Young murder case in Indiana, 15 years ago, was released from State prison to-day, the anniversary of the day on which the double murder was committed. Mrs. Clem was twice tried for the murder and finally acquitted. Her brother, Silas Hartmann, who was jointly accused with her, killed himself in jail.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 12.--The entire criminal term of the Ulster County Court of Sessions has been occupied with the trial of George Eckert, son of a prominent Democratic politician, who is indicted for seducing the daughter of a farmer of Marbletown under a promise of marriage.

BOSTON, Sept. 12.--The creditors of C.W. Clement, the dealer in boots and shoes who recently failed, have agreed to accept his offer of 30 per cent.--25 per cent. in six months notes and 5 per cent. in one year.

BUFFALO, Sept. 12.--The fourth annual convention of the Railway Traveling Auditors' Association was held here to-day. The following officers were elected for the ensuing year: President--A.A. Post, New-York and New England Railroad, Boston; Vice-President-- Richard Fenby.

A new style of robbery has been introduced by two or three ingenious members of the highwaymen's profession. On Tuesday night last an elderly man from NewJersey, while passing through a quiet street of this City at a late hour, was attacked and robbed of his false teeth.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 12.--The entries closed to-day for all the races except the veteran race in the grand regatta which takes place here on Sept. 25, 26, and 28. The races will be three miles with a turn, and will be rowed on the Allegheny River, 10 miles from this city.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Sept. 12.--A bloody affray took place this morning on the prairie three miles west of Cheyenne. The principals were James Knight, a freighter, and H. Moore and J.H. Wensel, who slept in Knight's wagon.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 12.--The Kentucky Association finished its Autumn meeting to-day. The weather was bright and very warm, and the track was fetlock-deep in dust. The attendance was rather slim and the betting was moderate.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 12.--Running the Rapids of Niagara is no less hazardous than was the course of the oil market to-day. Steadiness and shakiness and strength and weakness succeeded each other in bewildering variety, and the heavy buying was no less remarkable than the reckless selling.
It is said that Capt. John S. Wise stated in a recent speech in Virginia that if President Arthur were re-nominated he would stump the State for him.

Thomas O. Richardson and Edward M. Dennie, of the firm of Richardson Dennie, hide and leather dealers in Boston, Mass., have brought suit in the Supreme Court of this City against Fayette Shaw and Brackley Shaw, of the firm of F. Shaw Brothers, who recently failed.
QUEBEC, Sept. 12.--E.J. Dubeau, a dealer in wholesale groceries, has failed. His liabilities are $80,000.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 12.--It is understood here that the difficulties between the Mexican Government and the British bondholders in relalation to the settlement of the debt have been removed.
GALVESTON, Sept. 12.--At Trinity yesterday Major H.B. Hurlock, a mill owner, and his son, W.H. Hurlock, aged 22 years, were shot by one of their employes named Roseman.
The Board of Aldermen of Jersey City has appointed a committee to investigate the disposition made by the Board of Finance of the $30,000 presented to the city by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 12.--Accounts of damage to the crops from the heavy frosts continue to be received from the back counties. The corn, tobacco, buckwheat, and cucumber crops have been cut very short, and in many sections completely ruined. It is estimated that the damage will fully aggregate $1,500,000.
PARIS, Sept. 12.--The papers here state that Prime Minister Ferry opposes any concession to China regarding the Tonquin frontier question.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12.--The Corean Embassy arrived in this city to-day by the 2:30 P.M. train over the North-western Road, and were at once conveyed to the Palmer House. The two dignitaries of the party are Min Gong Ik and Hong Yang Shik.
A woman appeared at the Fulton-street prayer-meeting last Tuesday and announced that she had a message from heaven which she had been commanded to deliver.
DENVER, Col., Sept. 12.--The details of a bloody affray, which occurred at the McLain ranch, in Elbert County, on Sunday night, in which eight cowboys were engaged, have just reachad here.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 12.--Benjamin Harris, colored 26 years old, was shot and killed in East Nashville at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon while resisting Officers Lloyd and Eaton, who were attempting to arrest him.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 12.--The Welsh Well, in the Balltown pool, is reported to be finished without finding cither oil or sand. Grandin Well No. 13, in the same field, did 65 barrels in the first 15 hours. As the drill is 10 feet in sand, this is a poor showing.

OSAGE CITY, Kan., Sept. 12.--The coal miners' strike, which began in this (Osage) County on Sept. 1, has terminated by all the companies affected paying the increase of 1 cents demanded for digging, except the Osage Carbon Company, which holds out. This mine is practically owned by the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company, and that road is now receiving its coal from Missouri and Colorado.

Judge Gildersleeve, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, joined a young couple in wedlock. The foreman of the Grand Jury gave away the bride, a blushing lass of 15 Summers. Her name was Sophie Grouert.

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Sept. 12.--Reports of additional disasters in the recent storms have been received from Placentia. Capt. Steven's vessel, with five men, was swamped near Point Lance Reefs. Morelli's schooner, of Meirasheen, was wrecked near Cape St. Mary's, and all hands perished.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 12.--Royal M. Bassett, of Birmingham, says that the published statement that he had an interview with the blackmustached man mentioned in the Malley trial was mostly sensational. He did meet a man in Belgium and afterward went with him to the Hotel du Nord, in Antwerp.
The French Republicans are already putting their heads together to discover the best way of celebrating in 1889 the centenary of the French Revolution.

LONDON, Sept. 12.--The race for the St. Leger Stakes, for 3-year olds, was run at Doncaster to-day, and was won by the Duke of Hamilton's b.c. Ossian by three lengths. Mr. C. Perkins's b.c. Chiselhurst secured second place, and Lord Ellesmere's b.c. Highland Chief was a bad third.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 12.--There were three important secret meetings of prominent railway freight men held in this city to-day. The Cotton Committee performed the regular annual task of arranging rates on cotton.

The Secretary of the College of the City of New-York furnished 819 students yesterday with sets of books for the studies of the ensuing year. Of the students, 561 were new pupils who passed their examination successfully in June.

BOSTON, Sept. 13.--The Rev. Mark Hopkins, D.D., for over 30 years President of the American Board of Foreign Missions, will, at the annual meeting of the board at Detroit on Oct. 2, decline the re-election to that position.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13.--Major Young, of Columbus, Miss., a wealthy planter and prominent Democratic politician, in an interview in to-day's Post-Dispatch (Democratic) gives an interesting description of the methods by which colored alliances are secured for the Democratic Party in that State.
BERLIN, Sept. 13.--It is reported that a serious change has occurred in the condition of Prince Bismarck. Doctors have suddenly been summoned to Gastein for a consultation.

The appeal of Patrick Casey, the Long Island policeman who shot Sergt. Comisky in March last and who was sentenced to be handed, was heard yesterday before the general Term of the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn.
The funeral services of the late Hugh J. Hastings will take place tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock, in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Leo, at No. 11 East Twenty-eighth-street.
In December last George Grimshaw was a witness for the defense in the suit of Fannie A. Devine against Thomas Devine for a limited divorce.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 13.--What is pronounced a genuine case of sporadic cholera caused the death here to-day of man named Harris. Intense excitement prevails, and an investigation of the case by the health authorities has been begun, which, it is hoped will result in the assurance that the diagnosis is at fault.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 13.--This morning the workmen in the employ of the New-York and New-Jersey Telephone Company resumed the work of putting up poles in town. They began digging a hole in front of John W. Stout's property on Front-street.

Mr. COURTNEY, who is alleged by imaginative persons to be an oarsman, is about to accomplish the feat of beating HANLAN. He is to do this not by rowing a match with HANLAN but by rowing over a given distance in less time than HANLAN has ever rowed over a like distance.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 13.--Rain to-day caused another postponement of the races at Narragansett Park. The horses are here to fill their engagements, and the association, which has been put to great expense, will have them do so if the weather will permit, but should the storm continue to-morrow the races will be declared off. Should the day be bright the second day's card will be trotted, and the meeting will close on Monday.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 13.--The Eclipse and Metropolitan Base-ball Clubs played the last game of their series here to-day before 500 persons. The batteries were Lynch and Reipschlager for the Metropolitans and Hecker and Sullivan for the Eclipse.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 13.--The wooden bridge of the Fitchburg Railroad over a crossing at West Orange was removed this afternoon to give place to an iron one, but no danger signal was put up.

The second attempt to succor our signal service station at Lady Franklin Bay has failed. The Proteus has sunk and all hands are safe. But pleasure from this portion of the meagre news will be merged into anxiety for the score of adventurous spirits from whom nothing has been heard for now two years.

What is known in New-Jersey as the State-house ring was fairly beaten in the Democratic Convention at Trenton yesterday. It failed to concentrate its strength upon any one candidate for the Governorship, while the opposition was well united in support of Mr. LEON ABBETT.

Mr. Francis Murphy, the temperance lecturer, was among the passengers who arrived yesterday by the Anchor steam-ship City of Rome. A number of his friends were present on the dock and gave him a warm welcome.
TOLEDO, Sept. 13.--Thirty thousand persons attended the Tri-state Fair and races to-day. The fist race, for the 2:37 class, for a purse of $400, had four starters. Harvey was the favorite.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Sept. 13.--Lizzie Ann Harnett and Harvey Janney, the former 20 years of age and the latter about 60, are now on trial charged with the murder of an infant child of Miss Marnett.

NASHVILLE, Sept. 13.--This morning Addie Harris, the widow of Benjamin Harris, the negro who was shot and killed yesterday while attempting to escape from Officers Lloyd and Eaton, went before the Grand Jury and charged the officers with having committed murder.

A case involving a claim for $5,000 damages and the social reputation of two persons, one an unlicensed Methodist exhorter and the other the wife of a young farmer of Peekskill, Westchester County, was tried before a Sheriff's jury at White Plains yesetrday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.--The commission appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury to investigate charges that, under cover of the treaty of 1875 between the United States and the Sand wich Islands, sugars which were not, entitled to exemption from duty thereunder have been imported from those islands into the United States has made its report.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 13.--The court-martial this morning took up the case of Cadet Ballard, of Pennsylvania. Cadet Scales, of North Carolina, testified that Ballard made him stand on his head and crawl around a table leg.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 13.--A reception was given to Lord Chief-Justice Coleridge at the Newport Casino to-day at noon. The dull, moist weather was only a slight drawback on tha festivities, and the attendance of cottagers and distinguished guesis was very large.

A vigorous round of applause from an audience of about 1,000 men greeted Mr. F. B. Thurber as he arose on the platform at the mass-meeting held in Cooper Union last night to read the declarations and resolutions to be considered by the meeting, which was held under the auspices of the NewYork State Anti-Monopoly League.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 13.--Stockholders representing about five-sixths of the capital stock of the American Rapid Telegraph Company met in this city to-day and voted, practically unanimously, to ratify the contract with the Merchants and Bankers' Telegraph Company, of New-York, to take control of their lines and extend their wires through the South-west which will require an expenditure of $3,000,000.

Mr. Henry E. Abbey, who rejoices at present in the titles of impresario of the Metropolitan Opora-house, manager of the Lyceum Theatre, London, and director of Mr. Henry Irving's American tour, arrived in this City yesterday by the steam-ship City of Rome, in company with one of his principal baritones, Signor Kaschmann.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 13.--Peter H. Conly deposited $100 at the Argus office to-day with a challenge to Wallace Ross for a five-mile race for $500 a side, to be pulled on Oct. 24. Ross is given 11 days to deposit forfeit.

The fact that action was to be taken upon the request of Tammany asking for a conference for the purpose of agreeing upon a united delegation to Buffalo had the effect of bringing together last evening very nearly every one of the 360 members of the County Democracy's County Committee.

AGRAM, Sept. 13.--The violence of the rebels against the land-owners between Glina and Petrinia is increasing. The military force which was sent to the scene of the disturbance was compelled to fire into a dense mass of rioters at Jakobovacz, killing 15 and wounding many others.

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Sept. 13.--The United States Greely relief steam-ship Yantic has just anchored here. Har tidings are lamentable. No word has been received from Greely or any of his party.

For some days there have been rumors afloat to the effect that irregularities had been discovered in the office of the Water Register, one of the bureaus of the Public Works Department.

CHESTER, Penn., Sept. 13.--The San Diego, an iron steam-ship, built at Roach's for the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company, was launched this morning. The vessel is 346 feet in length, 40 feet beam, 23 feet depth of hold, and of 2,500 tons burden. She is intended for the Pacific coast trade.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13.--It has been learned that the Treasury instructions to the Custom-house authorities regarding Chinese in transit are being violated.

The problem of making Paris into a sea-port has been the subject of some lively discussions at the recent meeting of the French Association for the Advancement of Science, at Rouen. This project of bringing the sea to Paris is by no means a new one.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.--Commodore English received the following telegram from Pensacola last night: "One of crew of tug Rose, Thomas Sheppard, attached with fever last night at his home in Warrington."

John C. Calhoun, of Arkansas, a grandson of the famous South Carolinian, testified before the Senate Committee on Labor and Education yesterday morning, reading from manuscript answers to a series of questions submitted to him by Senator Blair. His testimony was relative to the condition of labor and the methods pursued in farming in the region along the Mississippi River.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 13.--The exercises of the college year of 1883-4 began to-day. Dr. McCosh delivered the opening address to the students is the old chapel.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Sept, 13.--The low water in the Merrimac River has caused a suspension of operations in some of the mills here, and many employes are temporarily idle. At the Central Paciffic Mills 600 employes are idle. At the Pemberton and Everett Mills several hundred hands are waiting. Very little rain has fallen, and the prospects for an immediate fall are not favorable.

The suit of Cornelius H. Butler against Agnes Butler came up yesterday in the Court of Common Pleas before Judge Van Brunt on a motion by the defendant to set aside a decree of divorce obtained by the plaintiff about two years ago, and for alimony and counsel fee. Counsel for Mr. Butler opposed the motion.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 13.--Fred P. Hall. Jr., proprietor of the Journal, was married to Lucy Houghton Mason, in St. Luke's Church, last evening. Many guests were present from Cleveland, Dayton, and other cities. Wedding gifts of unusual number and worth were received.

VIENNA, La., Sept. 13.--Wilson Clark, colored, was shot and killed in Wheat's corn-field, near this place, to-day. He had a difficulty with Wheat yesterday, and turned his hogs into the latter's field, where his body was found riddled with buckshot.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 13.--It transpires that John R. Martin, the Democratic candidate for the Board of Public Works, is not an elector in Ohio, and therefore is not eligible to the office. He formerly did business in this city, but resided in Newport, Ky.

LONDON, Sept. 13.--Private advices from Canton state that business has been resumed in that city as before the recent outbreak. There are only a few foreign merchants in trade there, the tea traffic having drifted to other localities. The inhabitants of Canton have the reputation of being especially turbulent at all times.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13.--The steamer M. Massey, running between Philadelphia and Chester, ran ashore to-day and sunk in the Horseshoe, near League Island Navy-yard, Delaware River.

TORONTO, Sept. 13.--On Tuesday an Englishman named Gorrie and a New-York jeweler named Jaby Grant had an altercation in the Rossin House, and finished it up with a challenge from Grant to fight a duel. It was arranged that they should meet last night, with their seconds, to arrange the preliminaries, but Grant and his seconds did not keep the appointment.
EUFAULA, Ala., Sept. 13.--Miss Katie Moss a beautiful young lady of this city, was missing from her home yesterday, and no clue was known as to her whereabouts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.--Lieut. F.E. Hobbs, of the Ordnance Department, has been ordered to foundry duty at Philadelphia.
The steam-ship City of Atlanta, of the Charleston Line, left Charleston for this port last Saturday, but had not been sighted off the Highlands at a late hour last night.
LONDON, Sept. 13.--The new Inman Line steam-ship City of Chicago made her trial trip on the River Clyde yesterday, accomplishing a speed of 15 knots an hour.

Capt. Sam S. Thompson, the popular young Captain of the Birmingham Rifles, who visited Mobile during the encampment of the Second Regiment, will be remembered by many citizens. No one of the many who made his acquaintance here imagined that one of his two clear blue eyes was perfectly blind, yet such was indeed the fact.

A meeting of the Joint Executive Committee (passenger department) of the Eastern and Western railroads will be held at the office of Commissioner Fink the latter part of the month. The meeting will be important in many respects. The old pooling contract expired Sept. 1, and is to be renewed.

Generally speaking, the American people are inclined to "Let who will, go marry." But sometimes they draw the line quite irrespective of law, and not the less effectually on that account.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.--The loss of the Proteus fills the minds of those acquainted with the situation of the Greely party with anxiety and concern. The failure of the Neptune to reach the colony last Summer was deemed very unfortunate, and orders were given Lieut. Garlington to exhaust every endeavor to reach ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13.--The Executive Committee of the National Jockey Club of this city has been notified by Mr. Gebhard that he will enter his two famous horses at the coming races here. The note said that he had decided to enter them here instead of sending them to Europe.

BOSTON, Sept. 13.--The clique of Butler men who call themselves independent Republicans, and are sometimes confused with the true Independents in this State, had a conference here to-day to consult as to their course in the campaign.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 13.--Ground was broken yesterday for the foundation of the Monmouth Battle Monument. After an address by exGovernor Joel Parker, the first god was turned by Mrs. Mary A. Schench, the donor of the site.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13.--Secretary Teller reached this city to-day on his return from his trip to the Yellowstone and the ceremonies at the completion of the Northern Pacific Railroad. Speaking of Indian matters, the Secretary said the time had come when the Indian question must be handled without gloves.

Col. Albert W. Preston, a retired officer of the United States Army, died in San Francisco yesterday. Col. Preston was a native of thie State, and joined the Thirteenth Regiment of Volunteers in May, 1861.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 13.--The Times-Democrat's expedition to the Everglades will assemble at Jacksonville, Fla., on Oct. 15, and proceed by rail to Cedar Keys, thence by steamer to Fort Myers and up the Caloosahatchee River, through the canals to Lake Okeechobee.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 13.--The Express tomorrow will print crop reports from 60 qualified correspondents at favorable points of observation in the 10 western counties of New-York. The general result is that the crops all together average about with other years.

STONINGTON, Conn., Sept. 13.--About 10 days ago as swallow while skinning above the Congregational Chapel in this place, flew against the sharp-pointed lightning-rod with such force as to impale itself. The iron passed entirely through the bird, killing it. It is still whirling in the wind about the rod with outstretched wings and ruffled feathers.

Some of the officers of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad went over the road yesterday, with a few invited guests, as far as New-Scotland, a small station just this side of Schenectady. The company went on board a tug at thw foot of Thirty-fourth-street, North River, and took a special train at Weehawken.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13.--Charles A. Lessner, a pilot on a Hudson River steamer, came to Chicago from New-York City a few days ago to escape from a gigantic conspiracy formed against him by Tilden, Conkling, Cameron, and others to keep him fom running a boat on the Erie Canal. He was found to be insane and will be sent back to New-York.
The Directors of the Bureau Veritas has published the following statistics of marine disasters reported during the month of July, 1883, concerning all flags:

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 13.--At a meeting of the Ohio Central Railroad stockholders yesterday, a report was presented showing that the company has failed to pay the River Division mortgages only. All other claims have been met and will be met so long as the property remains under the present management.

Dr. Niles, well known in this city, resides, on account of his health, in a small cottage on the beach about four miles south of the point selected for the terminus of the Jacksonville and Atlantic Railway. About 800 feet above high-water mark his well is located. It is 16 feet deep and yields a full supply of pure fresh water, and yet it rises and falls with the ocean side. This is a fact.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 13.--The third session of the Great Councell of Red Men was held here to-day. The greater part of the session was consumed in the reading of the roports of committees.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 13.--This afternoon a balloon, in which Prof. G.A. Warner has been making ascensions, collapsed when 8,000 feet above the earth. Mr. Warner was enabled to get a firm hold on the ropes and the balloon came down so slowly as to land him on the ground uninjured.

TRENTON, Sept. 13.--Ex-Senator Leon Abbett, of Hudson, was nominated by the State Convention at Taylor's Hall this afternoon for Governor of the State of New-Jersey. The State-house ring, who hate him at badly as they fear him, worked all night in a vain effort to defeat him.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 13.-- A lawsuit which has awakened great interest in Chemung County, owing to the peculiar circumstances which led to it, was concluded at Horseheads a few days ago, before Col, A.E. Boxter, Referce. The parties to the suit are Howlan Evans a farm laborer, and Reuben Tifft, a well-to-do farmer, both of the town of Veteran.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met in the Mayor's office yesterday and appropriated $17,600 from various unexpended balances in the Public Works Department to meet the expense of the recent renovation of the Mayor's ...

The following communication was received yesterday by the Maritime Association concerning the Straits of Sunda from J.R. Planten, Acting Consul-General of the Netherlands:

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 13.--The Republican Convention at Raymond yesterday was composed of delegates from every point in Hinds County, a total of 143 delegates and alternates being present. The Republicans base a club of 150 members at Terry, one of 156 members at Dry Grove, and large clubs at Utica and other points.
Gov. Hamilton, of Maryland, has been asked to address a meeting to be held in his favor in Baltimore to-night.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13.--The cricketmatch between All Philadelphia and All New-York, in spite of the wretched weather, was played out at Nicetown to day. When stumps were drawn on Wednesday the Philadelphia team had completed its first inning for 93, and the New-York players had scored 83 for the loss of five wickets.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 13.--Ex-Alderman John Stape, formerly collector for the Genesee Brewing Company, and Frank G. Adelman, for many years a book-keeper of the some company are under arrest on a charge of embezzlement.

LANCASTER, Penn., Sept. 13.--While going to a wreck on the Columbia and Port Deposit Railroad last night the engine of the wrecking train struck a large rock that had fallen on the track near Connewago.
ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 13.--A million dollars in securities are deposited with the State Treasurer of Georgia by foreign fire insurance companies to secure policy-holders.

Soon after 4 o'clock yesterday morning the Italian steam-ship Independente, from Palermo Aug. 26, and from Gibraltar Aug. 30, went ashore off Jones's Beach, Long Island, a long, narrow strip of land separated from the mainland at Freeport by a seven miles' stretch of ...

Tiffany Co. were requested on the 10th ult, by a lady to have 27 valuable pictures, which were deposited in their vaults, sent to be reframed. The Messrs. Tiffany sent the pictures to the Messrs. T.A. Wilmurt, father and son, at No. 54 East Thirteenth-street, and they were stacked up frameless in their office.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13.--At to-day's session of the Chapter General of America of the Knights of Malta, the following officers were elected to serve for the ensuing year: Grand Commander--James E. Henderson, Syracuse, N.Y.; ...

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 13.--Society in Atlanta has been stirred up by the filing of a suit for divorce by Mrs. Elizabeth Sheehan against her husband, Cornelius Sheehan. Mr. Sheehan is worth $100,000, owning nearly $70,000 in Atlanta real estate. He was married to his wife, Miss Harrison, in Putnam County, Ga., in 1855, and nine children have born to them.

PANAMA, Sept. 5.--A final arrangement has been effected between Great Britain and Nicaragua on the Mosquite question, which was whether, under the decision of the Emperor of Austria as to the sense is which the convention made in 1800 between Great Britian and ...

MANASQUAN, N.J., Sept. 13.--A contract has been awarded for building the new bridge across Barnegat Bay. The bridge will be 16 feet wide and 1,119 long, exclusive of the draw, which will be 40 feet wide. The estimated cost is $6,000, of which Ocean County will furnish $4,000 and the Seaside Improvement Company, of Mansaquan, the remainder.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 13.--After two days of steady rain, which ceased last night, filling the streets with mud and drenching the decorations which were displayed along the line of route of the Oriole procession and other streets, the reception of Lord Baltimore and the attendant parade of military, which was to have taken place on Tuesday night, came off to-night.

NORWICH, Conn., Sept. 13.--On last Saturday Miss K.R. Jones, about 40 years old, left the residence of Asahel Armstrong, at Meeting-house Hill, Franklin, and has not been heard from since. She is a sister of the wife of the Rev. R.P. Stanton, a Congregational clergyman of this city.

There is probably no more uncertain factor in national politics at this moment than the votes of the negroes in the Southern States. There was a period of several years after the reorganization of the States which went into the rebellion during which the negroes voted solidly for the Republican ticket.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 13.--Gov. Hale has vetoed the Colby Railroad bill. TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 13.--The lease of the Toronto, Grey and Bruce Railway to the Ontario and Quobec Railway Company was ratified at a special meeting of the shareholders of the former company to-day.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 13.--The answer is the case of D.M. Osborne Co., of Auburn, N. Y., against George and G.W. Esterly, father and Son, doing business under the firm name of George Fsterly Son, at Whitewater. Wis., manufacturers of the Esterly reaper and mower, was filed in the United States court to-day.
A fashionable wedding took place last evening at the house of Mr. William H. Rogers, No. 148 Macon-street, Brooklyn, Cashier of the Nassau Bank, of this City.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 13.--Prof. G.A. Warner, an aeronaut, who has been making balloon ascensions from the Exposition Grounds in this city, had a thrilling experience and narrow escape from death this afternoon.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13.--The Corean Ambassadors were entertained in this city to-day by the local and military authorities.

Although the weather was cloudy and threatening yesterday a large crowd assembled at Sheepshead Bay. The track was a sen of mud, and the racing was very poor, owing to the wretched work of the handicapper, who virtually gave away three of the races, and especially was this the case in the Great Eastern Handicap.

WITTENBERG, Sept. 13.--The quatrecentenary of Martin Luther's birth was celebrated here to-day. Splendid weather prevailed. The commemoration was a great success. The doorway of the Augustine Monastery was flanked by Venetian masts.

To-night those Republicans who desire to participate in the effort which, it is said, will be made to promote the future welfare of the party can do so by attending the primaries for the selection of delegates to Richfield Springs, which will be held under the direction of the several Assembly district associations of the county.
DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 13.--The side-wheel steamer Queen Victoria was burned at Clemens's wharf, six miles below Chatham, Ontario, this morning. Loss, $13,500; insurance, $10,000.

PANAMA, Sept. 5.--All the Chilian papers declare that the Minister at Washington, Seffor Godoy, has informed the Government of Chili that Gen. Iglesias will be recognized by the United States as President of Peru directly he holds command of Lima.
BETHLEHEM, Sept., Sept. 13.--On Saturday evening several members the Sophomore Class at Leghigh University visited the room of a young man named Collins, Of Altoona, to haze him.

PANAMA, Sept. 5.--Particulars have been received of the revolution at Zipaquira, near Bogota, which was believed to be the commencement of a general rising. Gen. Soler Martinez was sent there to take charge of the garrison of Federal troops, ...

The Rev. Alexander Crummell, D.D., who was elected Chairman of the convocation of the colored clergy of the Protestant Episcopal Church on Wednesday, called the second day's session to order yesterday. Twenty-one colored clergymen and deacons were present. A meeting of the Committee on Resolutions was held, at which resolutions were drafted and subsequently adopted by the convocation.

BELLEVILLEI, Ontario, Sept. 13.--The United Methodist Conference has decided that the name of its new-church shall be the Methodist Church.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 13.--Joseph Ferguson, a son of a leading citizen of Washington County, Tenn., while trailing his gun yesterday accidentally caused its discharge, and the entire load passed through his head, producing instant death.
DENVER, Col., Sept. 13.--The twenty-fifth anniversary of the discovery of gold in Colorado was celebrated here to-day by Colorado pioneers.

ALBANY, Sept. 13.--The classification of the civil service of the State, which was made by the Civil Service Commission and signed by the Governor some days ago, was given to the public this evening. The clasification was sent to the Governor on Aug.

Gen. James S. Negley, President; Thomas G. Baker, Secretary, and William V. Alexander, Treasurer, of the National Union League of America, together with Col. J.E. Bryant, of Georgia, and Mr. C.C. Pinckney, of this City, who are members of the Executive Committee of the League, met at the Astor House yesterday.

Nightingale Brothers, manufacturers of silk, at No. 375 Broadway and at Patereon, N.J., have obtained an extension of three years from their creditors. Their property is to be placed in the hands of a Trustee--Mr. Dean--of the firm of Stoddard, Lovering Co., of Boston, as security until the extension notes are paid in full.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Sept. 13.--Gen. Grant, Mr. Evarts, and others of the Villard party left this morning for Cascade. From there they will go directly East.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13.--Advices from Boise City, Idaho, report that there is a prospect of serious troubles with the Bannock Indians. A party of 10 prospectors had one of their horses ...

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 13.--Quite an excite ment has been created among the negroes here by the case of Barbara Miller, who is to be hanged here to-morrow for being an accomplice in the murder of her husband.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13.--When Paula Hell drowned herself in the lake three weeks ago, because her betrothed lover, Johan Schilling, of No. 820 West Taylor-street, deserted him and married another woman, she laid such a weight of remorse on Schilling's mind that it drove him insane.

On taking their seats in the Coroner's office yesterday afternoon, Coroner Martin told the members of the jury investigating the Riverdale explosion that he had obtained an order from Judge Donohue compelling Inspector Starbuck to produce the pieces of the boiler before the jury.

FARGO, Dakota, Sept. 13.--The North Dakota Convention met here yesterday. Most of the counties were represented in the convention. The permanent officers chosen were W. H. Francis, of Bismarck, Chairman, and Major Hamilton, of Grand Forks, Secretary. The following resolutions were adopted.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 13.--The Montgomery County Democratic Convention at Fonda this afternoon chose John Carmichael, of Amsterdam; Charles Zielly, of Minden, and Frasher Spraker, of Canajoharie, delegates to the State Convention: ...

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 13.--A State Convention of the colored Republicans of Maryland to appoint delegates to the National Convention to be held at Louisville was held in this city to-day, and organized by electing J. E. Briscce President.

DES MOINES, Sept. 13.--The announcement was made to-day by the State Central Committee that the Hon. William H. Morrison, of Illinois; the Hon. W.N. Barnes, of Illinois, and L.H. Palmer, of Mount Pleasant, will take the stump. Morrison will begin Oct. 1.

TROY, Sept. 13.--The funeral of Street Commissioner Miller, of Green Island, took place yesterday afternoon. The coffin was carried by the bearers from the house to the church, and as the procession reached the front of the church one of the handles at the head of the coffin broke.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept, 13.--F.A. Reuss Co., millers, have made an assignment of their assets, embracing their mill property in Belleville, Ill., valued at $27,000. Their liabilities are supposed to be $50,000.

The red flag with a black centre, the "onshore" cautionary signal, which has been flying for the past four days from the Signal Service staff on the roof of the Equitable Building, was hauled down yesterday afternoon.
MACON, Ga., Sept. 14.-A negro dwelling on the plantation of B.M. Bateman, near Byron, was burned this morning, and two children perished in the flames.

The Brighton Beach track was extremely muddy yesterday, and one race only was placed to the credit of the favorite. An unusually large amount of money changed hands. The attendance was large and the weather pleasant.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14.--The Commissioner of Patents has submitted to the Acting Secretary of the Interior his report of the business of the Patent Office for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1883.
MUNCIE, Ind., Sept. 14.--Last Monday night the United States Express Company's safe, in this city, was robbed by burglars of a five-thousanddollar money package.

BOSTON, Sept. 14.--A fire occurred at 4 o'clock this morning on the upper floor of the north-west end of the Hotel Vendome, one of the largest and finest hotels in the city, and the flames spread through the door to the staircase so rapidly that a second alarm was sounded.
LONG BRANCH, H.J., Sept. 14.--Yesterday morning one of the most promising colts in Mr. Withers's stable died from an attack of colic.

Lawrence and Wachner obtained an order on Thursday from Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court, Chambers, in a suit of Kiralfy Brothers against Poole Gilmore, to examine the defendants in order to enable the plaintiffs to prepare their complaint.
One of the laws passed by the last Legislature, the political possibilities of which were criticised at the time as involving a riotous waste of the public funds, is already bearing fruit.

Mitchell, the pugilist, and Madden, his trainer and backer, arrived in New-York, from Kansas City on Thursday, but they did not visit Harry Hill, the referee, until last evening.

Mr. EMERSON, an intelligent colored man who yesterday appeared before Senator BLAIR'S committee, corroborated and supplemented the testimony of Mr. CALHOUN given the day before.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 14.--A general strike of window-glass workers on Sept. 20 seems inevitable. The manufacturers insist upon a reduction, and the employes assert that rather than submit to a cut in wages they will strike.
LONDON, Sept. 14.--In the Mincing-lane markets the business in sugar has increased, and West India muscovado has advanced 6d. per hundred-weight above the rates at the beginning of the month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14.--Gen. H.J. Hunt, commanding the Department of the South was placed upon the retired list of the army to-day, having reached 64 years of age, and was instructed to turn over his command to Gen. Hancock, who will assume command temporarily.
There was a large attendance on the Polo Grounds yesterday to witness the game played there between the New-York and Buffalo Clubs.

The steam-ship Indipendente, which went ashore at Jones's Beach Thursday morning, lay in an easy position all day yesterday. An attempt to haul her off was made by several tugs at high water in the morning, but she remained fast.
Mr. John Jones, who arrived from England by the City of Rome on Thursday, reported at Police Head-quarters yesterday that he had lost about $1,550--in English money.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14.--No additional reports have been received to-day either at the War Department or the Navy Department from the officers of the returned Greely relief expedition at St. John.
An inquest was begun at Hunter's Point last evening by Coroner Robinson into the cause of the deaths by the collision of the Manhattan Beach and Flushing trains on Tuesday.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Sept. 14.--The citizens of Millville, a small farming village five miles from Bloomsburg, Columbia County, were thrown into great excitement this morning by the finding of the dead bodies of William Runyan and his wife in their bedroom.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14.--There was a new development to-day in the lard imbroglio which Fowler Brothers and Peter McGeoch have been ventilating before the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14.--The Surgeon-General of the Marine Hospital Service has received an affidavit sworn to by to pilots in Pensacola bar residing on the naval reservation of Warrington ...

BALTIMORE, Sept. 14.--The steam-ship America, from Vera Cruz, at this port to-day, brought Capt. J.H. Virdin and crew of seven men of the three-masted schoonor Frank Atkins, 363 tons, abandoned at sea on Tuesday last in latitude 31 40' north and longitude 78 24' west.
The recent defeat of Mr. TERRELL, the cold-water champion, by Mr. ABBEY, the champion of bitter beer, will naturally discourage the worshipers of water.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 14.--A heavy rain-storm will spoil many boxes of hops in Otsego County. There is a large quantity of hops yet to be picked. The greater part of the unharvested crop has been rendered almost entirely worthless. Frosts have done great damage, and many yards will hardly stand a storm.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 14.--Under clear skies the races at Narragansett Park were resumed to-day. Fully 4,000 persons were in attendance.

The body of the late Hugh J. Hastings was brought to this City last evening by a special train, arriving at Liberty-street at 6:15 P.M. There were private services at 2 o'clock in the afternoon at Mr. Hastings's late residence, Willowhurst, Monmouth Beach.

RED BANK, N.J., Sept. 14.--At the election of delegates to the Republican Gubernatorial Convention to be held at Trenton next Tuesday, the delegates were instructed to vote for John S. Applegate, the present State Senator from this county.
The failure of Ephraim Berlowitz, manu facturer of clothing, at No. 50 Howard-street, is severely criticised by his creditors.

The New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad will be opened to Syracuse Oct. 1. The laying of track between Syracuse and Buffalo is advancing rapidly. About 20 miles of track between those two points were laid last week.

SODUS POINT, N.Y., Sept. 14.--Ten Eyck, Riley, and Lee have already arrived to take part in the regatta which takes place here on Sept. 20 and 21. Hosmer, Teemer, and Dabinett are the latest entries received. Hanlan, Courtney, Ross, and others are expected to arrive to-morrow and Monday.
OTTAWA, Sept. 14.--Princess Louise has given a picture of her own painting to the Dominion National Gallery as a memento of her residence in Canada.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 14.--At the meeting of milk producers held in Goshen last week a resolution was adopted warning proprietors of creameries that unless they reconsidered their determination to pay only 2 cents for September milk before to-day "decisive action would be taken."
Col. Maple on's prospectus for his coming season of Italian opera at the Academy of Music is expected to reach this City to-day or early next week.

At the day session of the convocation of colored clergy of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the Church of the Holy Communion yesterday the resolutions concerning the state of the colored people in the South and the need of education among them came up for discussion.

George Henry Bangs, aged 52, the General Superintendent of Pinkerton's Detective Agencies at Chicago, Philadelphia, and New-York, died suddenly last Wednesday at Rosello, N.J., where he was spending the Summer. His body will be taken to Chicago on Sunday for interment.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 14.--Detectives are still busily engaged in hunting up the record of William Lewis, Rose Ambler's lover, and they intimate to-night that evidence to his discredit is rapidly accumulating.
LONDON, Sept. 14.-It is announced that the yachting cruise of Mr. Gladstone will be extended from the coast of Scotland to Norway.
The General Committee of the German Democratic organizations of this City met last evening at No. 160 Third-avenue, Michael C. Grosse presiding.
