ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 14.--The tug Kate, Capt. Ellis, while cowing the bark Arlington up the Potomac River last night took fire when off Indian Head and was burned to the water's edge. She was insured for $10,000.

The steam-ship City of Atlanta, of the Charleston Line, which left Charleston, S.C., for this port on Saturday last, was towed into the harbor of Smithville, N.C., late Thursday night. Considerable anxiety was felt about the vessel, both in Charleston, which is the home of the majority of the passengers, and also in this City.

PARIS, Sept. 14.-American and English residents of the French capital take the same languid sort of interest in Mrs. Lily Langtry and her wealthy New-York admirer as the newspaper readers on the opposite side of the ocean.

Messrs. L. Laveosa Co., at the California Market, think that they have a vertible sea-sorpent, but it is not so large as the specimens seen at various watering-places just at the opening of the season.

Emma Margoo, 19 years old, who is said to be the wife of a one-legged beggar sailor, John Margoo, who is 45 years old, fell or was pushed from a third-story window last night at Taylor's Hotel, No. 110 Chatham-street.
Louis Port committed suicide by hanging himself in the yard of a saloon, at No. 293 Bankstreet, Newark, last evening. Despondency on being thrown out of work is the supposed cause.

LONDON, Sept. 14.--This was the last day of the Doncaster September meeting. In the race for the Doncastor Cup Sir F. Johnstone's 5year-old ch. m. Thebais walked over the course for the stakes.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 14.--The fourth session of the Great Council of Red Men was held here to-day.
Capt. Isaac Heins, of the steamer San Marcos, of Mallory's Line, died at the United States Hotel early yesterday morning. He had been ill from a complication of diseases for a long time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14.--A case of leprosy was brought here by the last steamer from Honolulu. The sufferer is a native of the SandwichIslands, of French descent. The quarantine officers refused permission for him to land. A writ of habeas corpus has been issued, and the matter will come up in the Superior Court to-morrow.

Messrs. J.E. Ward Co., the owners of the steam-ship Newport, which was reported as having been towed into Tybee Roads in distress on Thursday, said yesterday that they had received no further particulars in regard to her.

SIOUX FALLS, Dakota, Sept. 14.--At the morning session of the Constitutional Convention the Judiciary Committee reported a preamble to the Constitution to be submitted for the one reported from the Committee on Preamble some days ago.

BUTTE, Montana, Sept. 14.--Three men named Timby, Ninnes, and Littlejohn were coming out of a 500-foot shaft of the Gagnon mine yesterday morning. When the cage was 300 feet from the bottom Ninnes fell backward, owing to nervousness, and was crushed into an almost unrecognizable mass.

LONDON, Sept. 14.--A dispatch to Reuter's Telegram Company from Hong Kong, dated to-day, states that a battle has taken place between the French forces and the Black Flags, lasting eight hours.

FREEFHOLD, N. J., Sept. 14.--The Monmouth County Fair closed here to-night. The inclement weather has caused an unusually light attendance. The track has been too heavy for good racing and poor time was made.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14.--The Standard Cable Company of New-York is to be permitted to lay an experimental line of cables by their underground system connecting the executive departments with the Capitol.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 14.--Barbara Miller colored, was hanged here to-day for complicity in the murder of her husband to February last, Charles Henry Lee, her accomplice, was hanged on the 3d of last month. ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 17.--The comet discovered by Prof. Swift, Director of the Warner Observatory, although announced on Sunday morning, was really discovered by him on Tuesday morning, Sept. 11. Its motion is scarcely perceptible, owing to the fact that it is coming almost directly toward the earth. Hence it was impossible to verify the discovery until the time named. The announcement that there had been a previous discovery was evidently a mistake.

The Monmouth County Fair, at Freehold, N.J., closed on Saturday night, not on Friday, as stated in a dispatch from that place. PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 15.--The rumor that the books of Storer Brothers, the dry goods dealers, who lately failed, showed a deficiency of $1,600,000 is untrue. A clerical error in the statement drawn from them probably gave rise to the report. The mistake will be fully explained at the creditors' meeting to-morrow.

READING, Penn., Sept. 17.--The wife of George Newkirk, a passenger railway official, of this city, took laudanum this afternoon with suicidal intent and is not expected to recover. Domestic trouble is said to have been the cause for the act. She is the mother of six children.

NEWPORT, Sept. 17.--The dance at the Casino to-night was very poorly attended. August Belmont and wife, of New-York, gave a dinner party to-night in honor of their guests, the Earl and Countess of Roseberry.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 17.--At a meeting of the Grangers here to-day reports were brought in showing that a large percentage of corn on high ground escaped destruction by the recent frosts. Buckwheat is a loss, while potatoes will be a larger crop than usual. Late cut wheat shows less rust than that cut early. A more encouraging feeling exists among the farmers than just after the frost.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 17.--The court-martial this morning took up the case of Cadet Charles E. Hawkes, of Wisconsin. Cadets Stearns, Coleman, and Carden each testified that the accused cadet took an active part in hazing them, as charged.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 17.--The three days' bicycle tournament which opens in Hampden Park to-morrow will doubtless be the biggest event of the kind that this country has witnessed. With propitious weather it will also bring to the city the largest crowds that have ever been drawn here, ...
Adolph H. Hamann, a clerk in a bankinghouse in Pine-street, committed suicide at his home, No. 258 West One Hundred and Twentyeighth-street, yesterday morning.

Rufus Kinney's bees have become altogether too neighborly, so much so that there is danger of their driving his family out of house and home. CINCINNATI, Sept. 17.--A meeting of representatives of the two Democratic factions is being held to-night in Congressman Jordan's law office. It is in the interest of harmony, and the indications are that it will not be adjourned before midnight.
BOSTON, Sept. 17.--Major McGrath, of the United States Secret Service, reports that unknown parties recently passed worthless bills upon Boston tradesmen.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 17.--Minnie Kossiey, a beautiful young lady, committed suicide at Somersett, Ky., this morning. The cause of the deed is not known. She was one of the reigning belles.

LIMA, Sept. 17, via Galveston.--A decree will be issued from Gen. Lynch's head-quarters tomorrow, and the following day will be observed as a close holiday in commemoration of Chilian independence. Salutes were fired at sunrise and sunset to-day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17.--The report of the commission appointed by Secretary Folger to investigate the methods and management of the Supervising Architect will be submitted to the press to-mmorow.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Sept. 17.--Matthew Wood, who was once a highly respected and intelligent citizen, but who has fallen to the lowest depths, while stupidly drunk to-day fell into a bed of slaked lime. He was burned perfectly black, and his skin and scalp will come off. He will lose one eye and will probably die.

AUBURN, Sept. 17.--The Republicans of the Second District of Cayuga County send as delegates to the Richfield Convention Sereneo E. Rayne, William A. White. C.C. White, Jr., and Leander Fitts. They are uninstructed.

Edward Gallagher, a boy aged 5 years, and who resided with his parents in the town of Kearney, Hudson County, N.J., died on Sunday in a very singular manner. He had been suffering with the toothache, and, boy like, asked his mother if she could not do something to stop it.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 18.--The Democratic State Convention, which will meet in Masonic Temple at noon to-morrow, is likely to be a harmonious gathering, as there will not be enough opposition to the ring to make even a fair show.

Mme. Minnie Hauk arrived in this City on the steamer France last evening. She will begin her concert tour through the South and West in Richmond on Oct. 1, and close with the end of December in Chicago.

TOMBSTONE, Arizona, Sept. 18.--Since the murder of George Ward, on Sunday last, at Antelope Spring, by the Apaches, nothing further has bean heard of the doings of the Indians. The feeling of this place is one of intense excitement against the Indians, and Gen. Crook's peaceful policy is bitterly denounced as unsuccessful.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18.--Edward Hanlan, the carsman, arrived here from St. Louis this morning for the purpose of meeting E.T. Platt, the representative of Laycock, the Australian sculler, with a view to arranging a match in Australia. Platt, however, has bean called to New-York on business, whither Hanlan goes this evening. The accident by which Laycock broke his leg, will, of course, delay any negotiations for a race.
COLEMAN, Texas, Sept. 18.--In a quarrel last night Thomas Hayes, the Cattle King, was mortally shot by A. Pendleton, a saloon-keeper. Pendleton escaped.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 18.--A dispatch was published in several newspapers to-day stating that a body washed ashore last Sunday at West Falmouth, Mass., is supposed to be that of Joseph W. Bartlett, of New-York, who was lost from the yacht Mystery on Aug. 12.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 18.--A charge of unmercantile conduct was to-day preferred before the Chamber of Commerce against John R. McLean, of the Enquirer.

William Wilson, a well-known resident of the Eastern District of Brooklyn, committed suicide yesterday at his home, No. 259 South Third-street, in that city. Three of Mr. Wilson's brothers had died of consumption and he greatly feared that he would be attacked by the same disease.

A small crowd gathered at the Washington Park Base-ball Grounds, in Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon to witness the return game between the New-York Lacrosse Club and the Independents, of New-York. SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 18.--The ironclad Monadnock was successfully launched at Mare Island Navy-yard this afternoon. In order to most the requirements of Congress, the vessel is supposed to be the old Monadnock repaired, but with the exception of one plank everything is new. The old ship lies in the same spot where she was beached when brought to the navy-yard.

HAVANA, Sept. 18.--The Spanish steamer which arrived here to-day brought an order from the Government raising the direct taxes in the island of Cuba 50 per rent. The date on which the new order is to go into effect has not yet been fixed.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18.--The Phoenix Planing Mill, at Twelfth and Spruce streets, owned by George Breckenridge, was completely gutted by fire this evening, the loss being $80,000.
The Republicans of New-Jersey are evidently determined to do their best to redeem that State from Democratic control.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Sept. 18.--To-day has been spent in watching for the arrival of delegates. The result of the contributions of the half-dozen trains has been to swell the number of visitors to nearly 1,000 persons.

Adam Rapp, a well-known resident of Clinton Township, Essex County, N.J., was found dead is Union-avenue, in that township, yesterday morning. He left home before daylight with a wagon-load of garden-truck, which he expected to dispose of in Newark. It is supposed Mr. Rapp was attacked with heart disease and fell from his seat, his wagon passing over his neck, which was broken. The horses went on to Newark, directly to Mr. Rapp's usual stand.

MONTREAL, Sept. 18.--The excitement relative to the unfortunate turn the affairs of the Exchange Bank have taken is subsiding. The reassuring evidence of the bank managers has assisted largely in this direction.

A meeting of the Board of Trustees of the College of the City of New-York was held yesterday. Trustee Belden presented to the college a one-thousand-dollar bond, the interest on which is to be devoted to procuring medals, which will be awarded as prizes in mathematics.

LONDON, Sept. l9.--The Anchor Line steam-ship Anchoria, Capt. Hedderwick, from New-York Sept. 8, for Glasgow, has arr. at Moville. The steam-ship Cervin, (Br.) Capt. Hughson, from New-York Sept. 1, has arr. at Bremen.
CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 18.--Gabe Green was killed last night near Stevenson, Ala., by John Reed, while he was in the latter's hog-pen.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 18.--A mass-meeting of citizens was held at the Masonic Theatre to-night to select a reform ticket for Mayor and 10 Councilmen to be voted for on the second Thursday in October.

PARIS, Sept. 18.--The Marquis Tseng, the Chinese Ambassador, had a conference with M. Jules Ferry, President of the Cabinet, today.
The proposed race between St. Julien and JayEye-See at Fleetwood Driving Park on Sept. 29 is the principal topic for discussion among the turfmen of New-York.

MONTREAL, Sept. 18.--Disquieting rumors were afloat to-day about a great railway magnate and speculator in mines being embarrassed through the demoralized condition of the Paris money market. It was said that actions were threatened for $200,000 worth of paper due to-day, but the notes were all duly retired.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 18.--Lord Lorne again appears as an author. His last work, which was published to-day, is entitled "Memories of Canada and Scotland." It consists of a number of poems written by his Excellency during his residence in Canada and addresses delivered by him in his official capacity as Governor-General.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 18.--The excursion steamer Saginaw, which left here on Saturday night with 20 passengers for Detroit, was to have returned on Monday morning.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 18.--The annual convention of the Volunteer Firemen of Pennsylvania, representing 600 companies, met here today and will continue in session until Thursday, when the annual parade will take place.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 18.--The parties interested in bridging the Hudson River between Storm King and Breakneck Mountains have appointed an agent in Cornwall to secure the right of way for the western approach. The proposed bridge is to be 150 feet high, with spans of 1,000 feet, and with two piers in the river. The width of the river at Storm King is 2,815 feet.

Over 100 delegates from various parts of the United States and the Dominion were present, and a large number more are expected.

GUAYMAS, Mexico, Sept. 18.--A copious rain fell here last night, clearing the atmosphere and bringing the thermometer down to 84 . The people look upon it as the greatest blessing that could have happened, as it will prevent the spread of the yellow fever.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 18.--Jacob Lawrence, a laborer at the Carpenter Brothers' quarries in Meriden, became entangled in a rapidly moving piece of belting this afternoon, and was whirled 100 times around the quarry shafting. He was crushed into a shapeless jelly. This is the third man who has met death in this manner in Meriden within the past few weeks.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18.--The Metropolitans played the final game of their championship series with St. Louis this afternoon. Nearly 4,000 persons were present. It was a very close fight. At the end of the home half of the ninth inning the score stood 3 to 2 in favor of St. Louis.
ST. PAUL, Sept. 18.--Gen. Grant and William M. Evarts passed through the city on their return from the Northern Pacific opening. Gen. Grant was driven to Fort Spelling.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Sept. 18.--At Echo Park this afternoon D.C. Ashley's bull-dog Toodles and John Clark's bull-dog Toby ran a 200 yards' race for $550 sweepstakes. Toodles won by a yard in 0:16 after a close and exciting race, upon which considerable money had been placed by the spectators, the betting being three to two on Toodles.

The Directors of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad met yesterday and declared a semi-annual dividend of 3 per cent. on both the common and preferred stock. The dividend will be paid on or after Oct. 15.

LIMA, Sept. 18, via Galveston.--It is reported from Huancayo that 3,000 Monteneros who had collected near Izzuchaca for the purpose of sacking that city, were attacked by a small body of men belonging to the Pacific forces. After a quarter of an hour's fighting the Monteneros were defeated with a loss of 200 men. The Department of Ica is in an entirely tranquil state.

BOSTON, Sept. 18.--About 1,000 persons attended the races of the first day of the special September meeting at Mystic Park to-day. The weather was fine, and the track was in excellent condition.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18.--A phenomenal event in the shape of a reporters' strike occurred on Monday evening, the Herald office being the scene of the outbreak. It was something of a strike on general principles, and not exactly that either.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 18.--The Sovereign Grand Lodge of Odd-fellows met here this morning. A memorial from the Grand Lodge of California in the celebrated Robinson case, which has been before the Sovereign Grand Lodge since 1880, was presented, and with Robinson's protest was referred to the Committee on Petitions. At 2 o'clock this afternoon a parade was given complimentary to the Sovereign Grand Lodge of Oddfellows. The city was filled with visitors.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18.--Ten Indian girls were received to-day at the Lincoln Institute, on Eleventh-street. They range from 10 to 17 years in age, and are bright and intelligent. As yet they know little English, but express their desire to begin the study of it at once.

ST. JOHN, Newfoundland, Sept. 18.--People here are astonished that no new expedition will start at once to the relief of Lieut. Greely and his party. It is urged that the party is certainly moving southward and is without resources. WASHINGTON, Sept. 18.--The Powhatan will be ordered to-morrow to leave St. John for NewYork and bring with her the Greely relief party.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 18.--The reduction of the price of THE TIMES from 4 to 2 cents came as an agreeable surprise to the many readers of that paper this morning. At the Post Offices at Long Branch, East Long Branch, and North Long Branch more copies of THE TIMES have always been sold than of any of the other New-York dailies.

CONVINGTON, Ky., Sept. 18.--The programme presented by the association to-day attracted a large concourse of people. The weather was delightful and the track fast, but disagreeably dusty. The betting was very heavy.

Ware, announce the finding of Charlie McCombs, the little son of Judge and Mrs. McCombs, who were butchered by Indians in Arizona some months ago, and report him in good health. The parties who have him claim the $15,000 reward which will be paid. No particulars as to his recovery are given.

Sanitary Superintendent Day yesterday presented a report on the prevalence of typhoid fever during the present year up to the 1st inst. and the means taken to control the disease. Dr. Day say the number of cases up to Aug. 31 was 539, against 304 for the corresponding period of last year.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 19.--The Democratic Convention for the Twelfth Senatorial District, comprising the Counties of Rockland and Westchester, was held in this place to-day, and Senator Henry C. Nelson was renominated by acclamation.

BOSTON, Sept. 19.--Congressman George D. Robinson, of Chicopee, heads the anti-Butler ticket for this Fall's campaign, having been nominated to-day by acclamation, after an informal ballot on which he led far in advance of all the other candidates.

PAYTA, Peru, Sept. 19, via Galveston.-- The steamer Amazons, with 600 infantry and cav alry and two guns, arrived here on Sept. 17. The troops proceeded by rail to Sullana, where 50 men were left, the remainder continuing their journey to Piura the same night. Col. Carvello reports that Piura was occupied yesterday. Prefect Seminario fled.

An audience of over 1,300 people gathered at St. Patrick's Church, in Mott-street, last evening, to hear the lecture by Bishop O'Farrell, of Trenton. His subject was "The Catholic Church, the Foster-mother of the Arts and Sciences."

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 19.--Charles, Ferdinand, and William Weber, three brothers, interrupted a wedding to-night by forcing themselves in and acting disagreeably. They were driven out. When Mr. and Mrs. Thaler, who instigated their ejectment, entered a carriage, the Webers attacked them with knives and clubs, inflicting wounds on both that are presumably mortal. All three are under arrest.

Mr. Charles Coghlan and Miss Florence Gerard, who will play leading parts at the FifthAvenue Theatre during a season of 30 weeks, arrived in Boston from London Saturday and came to this City last night. They will first appear on Oct. 8 in Bulwer's "Money," and other plays will follow, including "Fedora" and "Ace of Clubs." Rehearsals of "Money" will begin on Monday next.

The subscription rate for the daily with the Sunday edition is reduced from $12 to $7 50.

Mackoon, who has gone to a Western university; also Julius Kruger as instructor in rhetoric vice William H. Carpenter, Ph. D., who resigned in June last.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept 19.--Flour dull. Wheat weaker at 91 c., cush; 92 7/8c.@95 c., November; 97c., December. Corn scarce and wanted at 50c. for No. 2. Oats scarce and wanted; Mixed and White, 32c. Rve higher at 54 c. for No. 1. Barley unsettled at 63c. for No. 2; 61 c. for October. A Wall-street broker dropped his tape long enough yesterday to peruse the Tribune's editorial announcement of its reduction in price from 4 to 3 cents. The allusion to "the best people" catching his eye, the cynical broker ejaculated: "Ah! yes: the Tribune can certainly boast that, it its circulation is small, it is select, like the mourners at a small-pox funeral."

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 19.--A serious fire is burning in the woods on Strawberry Hill, threequarters of a mile south of this town, and it is feared that it will cross the Schooner Head road toward the property on the shore. A gang of men from here with engines is fighting the fire, but should the wind shift to the south the town would be greatly endangered.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19.--The Secretaries of War and Navy have decided that it is not practicable to send another expedition to the relief of Lieut. Greely this year. Lieut. Greely's case is retarded as by no means hopeless.

ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 19.--The Narodraja Wolja, the chief Nihilist organ, is being secretly printed in this city. In a recent publication it reviews the work of Count Tolstoi, the Minister of the Interior, and says a continuance of a similar policy cannot be tolerated.

Theodore Hermann, a merchant at No. 93 Pearl-street, has been annoyed of late by having checks fraudulently indorsed returned to him for redemption, having been cashed in food faith by business acquaintances.
PORT SAID, Sept. 19.--The quarantine against vessels arriving from Alexandria has been abolished.

MADISON, Ind., Sept. 19.--The soldiers' reunion opened today successfully both as to numbers and enthusiasm. ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 19.--Calculations based upon observations of the comet recently discovered by Mr. Brooks have just been completed by Prof. Boss, of the Dudley Observatory. They show beyond a doubt that this comet is identical with the Pous comet of 1812, so long expected. The comet will reach its perihelion in January, and will be visible to the naked eye in December, perhaps sooner.

COVINGTON, Ky., Sept. 19.--The attendance at the Latonia Jockey Club's meeting to-day was again large. The weather was bright and very warm. The track was fetlock deep with dust. The betting was active.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19.--Supervising Architect Hill this morning tendered his resignation to Secretary Folger, to take effect as soon as his successor qualifies. He gives no reasons for his resignation in his letter to the Secretary. Secretary Folger said this afternoon that the resignation of Mr. Hill would be accepted ae soon as some one was found to succeed him.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 19.--The fiftyfirst annual convention of the Connecticut Universalist Association met to-day at New-London. During the past year a gain of 27 has been made in the membership of the Universalist Church throughout the State. All the churches in the State were reported to be in a live condition. None suffer from pecuniary embarrassment, while two societies have money out at interest.

LONDON, Sept. 19.--A dispatch to the Times from Calcutta states that the published account of the French outrages at Tamatave falls far short of the truth, and adds that when the English Consul, Mr. Pakenham, was dying the French priests endeavored to force him to become a Catholic and compelled him to kiss the crucifix.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 19.--The Chautauqua Lake season closed to-day, when the Lake View House shut its doors. The season has been prosperous. It was remarkably brilliant, though short. Another large steamboat will be added to the already large fleet of steamers before another season.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 19.--By the breaking of a rope, a swinging scaffold fell from the third story of the Foster Block in Hartford this afternoon, and two workmen, Henry Loveland and John Newcomb, were thrown headlong to the street. Loveland struck upon a pointed iron ralling and was horribly mangled. Newcomb fell upon the pavement, receiving internal injuries which are likely to prove fatal.

One Prof. WINTER has delivered a lecture in Brooklyn entitled, "Let the Children have the Pencil." It was a plea for placing a lead pencil in the hands of every child in the country. He was not mobbed, neither was he arrested and bound over to keep the peace. Truly, the immunity which crime enjoys in the City of Churches is as marvelous as it is painful.

BOSTON, Sept. 19.--C.H. Codman, a prominent dealer in photographic goods, died to-day, having inhaled the fumes of nitric acid yesterday. This led to the widely disseminated rumor that Mr. Codman, Chairman of the Republican State Convention, was dead, which caused some excitement.
LONDON, Sept. 20.--The steam-ship Guildford, (Br.,) Capt. Irwin, from Baltimore Sept. 1, has arr. at Antwerp.

Reduced railroad rates have been given for some time to Chicago and Kansas City. The ViceChairman of the joint Executive Committee said yesterday that this was not due to outting by the line out of New-York.
The exchange of the old defaulted bonds of Elizabeth, N. J., for the new 4 per cent. forty-year bonds of the same city is now going on at the Mercantile Trust Company in this City.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 19.--Soon after 7 o'clock this morning a terrible accident occurred on the West Shore Railway in front of the new station which is in process of erection four miles east of Syracuse.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 19.--The trade tribunal appointed to determine a rate of wages for the railroad coal miners of this district to-day decided to call in the umpire at once in order to obtain a settlement.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 14.--A registered package was put in the mail-bags at King's Creek, Tenn., last Thursday for Rockwood which failed to reach its destination. Harry Bussell, a a mail-carrier between Rockwood and King's Creek, was arrested at Lenoirs and lodged in jail here to-day charged with robbing the United States. He made a full confession to-day implicating several others.
Roswell A. Parmenter, of Troy, is at the St. Denis Hotel. Commodore John L. Davis, United States Navy, is at the New-York Hotel.
BETHLEHEM, Penn., Sept. 19.--The Sophomore Class at Lehigh University has abolished the old practice of having a "cane rush," and Freshmen will hereafter be permitted to carry canes.

The attendance at the New-Jersey State Fair at Waverly yesterday exceeded the attendance at any one day's fair since the NewJersey Agricultural Society was incorporated. It is estimated that there were fully 40,000 persons on the grounds.

OSCEOLA, Iowa, Sept. 20.--To-day has been notable in the political history of this part of Iowa, the occasion being the sixth joint debate between Gov. Sherman and Judge Kinne. The audience numbered, at a moderate estimate, 3,000 persons.

When the 34 yachts which intended to take part in the Fall regatta of the Knickerbocker Club gathered at the Port Morris deck yesterday morning, there was barely wind enough to flutter their flags.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 20.--Last night a party engaged a carryall and drove out to Snyder's Lake. They started on their return home this morning.

HAVANA, Sept. 20.--The steamer Newport, Capt. Sundberg, from New-York Sept. 8, which was towed into Tybee in a disabled condition on Sept. 13, and which sailed thence on Sept. 18, has arrived here. Her cargo is damaged.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 20.--A conference of coal operaters and delegates from various miners' lodges in St. Clair County, Ill., was held at East St. Louis this morning.
BATH, Me., Sept. 20.--The Hon. William Rogers to-day launched the three-masted schooner Douglass Lorey, of 492 tons burden. The vessel is named for a gentleman in Rochester, N.Y.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Sept. 20.--The vilage is well-nigh deserted by the delegates tonight, among the last to leave being Senator Miller and a party of friends, who drove over to Otsego Lake and then across the country to Herkimer.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 20.--On Saturday six convicts escaped from Lockett's convict camp, near this city. They disarmed a green guard, and, holding their guns on him until well away, they disappeared in the woods. On an alarm being given and under the impetus of heavy rewards, many men joined in the search for the fugitives.

TROY, Sept. 20.--Frank Sittmire, of West Troy, and James Harrison, of Jersey City, indicted on charges of burglary and assault in West Troy, were to-day sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment each in Clinton Prison.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20.--The friends of Cadet Hartigan, of Chicago, who was recently dismissed from West Point for hazing, are determined to secure his reinstatement, if possible, and will, at all events, insist that the charges against him ought to be tried by court-martial.

For many years the Diamond Match Company has had a monopoly of the manufacture of matches in this country. It was really made up of many companies blended in one. No rival company could command a tenth part as much capital, and none could successfully compete with it in the American market.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Sept. 20.--At Southesk, in Northumberland County, John Hubbard and a man named Mullen had a dispute over a dog. A fight ensued, in which Mullen struck Hubbard with a stick and killed him.

LONDON, Sept. 20.--A Paris dispatch to the Exchange Telegraph Company states that it is reported there to-day that the memorandum or the French proposals upon the Tonquin question, which the Marquis Tseng telegraphed yesterday to Pekin, has not proved acceptable to the Chinese Government.

SPRINGFIELD, Sept. 20.--The Springfield Bicycle Club has taken in about $24,000 during the past three days' tournament, and their expenses have been about $16,000, so that their profits will be satisfactory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20.--Mr. John R. Lydecker, of New-York, is spoken of as likely to be the successor, some time in October, of Mr. Edgar M. Marble, Commissioner of Patents. Mr. Marble has, it is understood, contemplated for some time resigning his office.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 20.--Upon the expiration of the term of the late National Board of Health in the Mississippi Valley a fleet of vessels which had accumulated at Memphis were turned over to the Marine Hospital officials of this port.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 20.--This was the third day of the special meeting at Mystic Park. The attendance was very large, the announcement that the famous 5-year-old colt Jay-Eye-See would attempt to beat his Providence record of 2:10 bringing nearly 5,000 persons to the park.

SELMA, Ala., Sept. 20.--Tax Collector T.J. Britton, of Hale County, Ala., is reported to be a defaulter in the sum of $17,000. He declines to talk, and will stand trial. His friends say that he is guilty of no intentional wrong. The defalcation is said to extend back for several years.

The New-York Club scored its forty-fourth victory on the Polo Grounds yesterday when it defeated the Cleveland nine by 7 to 5. John Ward again filled the position of centre field, and by his excellent fielding and a three-base hit in the fourth inning, which was instrumental in giving the home team 3 runs, won the game.

COVINGTON, Ky., Sept. 20.--The attendance at the races to-day was large. The weather was warm and cloudy, the track fast and dusty, and the betting lively. The entries for the fifth race were so numerous that they were divided, and two races were run, the same conditions applying to both.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 20.--The oleomargarine bill has been passed by the Senate. It was at first regarded as a joke, and it was thought it would not pass. It did, however, and it now goes to the Governor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20.--It is reported that definite and most emphatic assurances have been received that Senator Miller will not, under any circumstances, accept second place on the Presidential ticket.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Sept. 21.--Lawrence Brainard, A.O. Brainord, and Charles Wyman, officers of the St. Albans Trust Company, were indicted by the Grand Jury to-day for an alleged violation of a penal clause of the company's charter.

DOVER, N.H., Sept. 21.--A belt of woods near Great Falls is on fire. The property-owners and other citizens are fighting it.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 21.--Last night, at Lockwood, 10 miles north of Cincinnati, Philip Kulin, a canal boatman, quarreled with Ezekiel Lee, a colored man, in Pain's saloon over a game of cards.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Sept. 21.--At meetings of the Cotton Exchange and Board of Trade to-day it was agreed to hold a joint meeting on Monday, when arrangements will be completed for the entertainment of the Inter-State Levee Convention, which will meet here Oct. 1. Senator Lamar has been invited to be present.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21.--As announced last night, the Pan Handle to-day made the rate to Louisville $1, and the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago followed suit at once.
Gen. Winslow stated yesterday that more than 100 miles of the track of the New-York, West Shore and Buffalo Railroad had been laid west of Syracuse.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 21.--The huge granite boulder placed in North Buryingground as a memorial of the Indian Sachem, Canonicus, was dedicated this afternoon. ExGov. Dyer presided. The oration was delivered by Gen. Horatio Rogers.

BOSTON, Sept. 21.--Democratic caucuses were held in the various city wards to-night. In the Twenty-second Ward the caucus broke up in a free fight, and in the Third Ward a bolt occurred. All the delegates elected are for Butler.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21.--Before the adjournment of the Board of Trade today the Secretary rapped for order and announced that some one on the floor of the Exchange earlier in the day had mutilated the Signal Service weather report.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 21.--It is understood that Dr. Grant, who has been the personal medical adviser of Princess Louise during her sojourn in Canada, will be knighted before the departure of the Princess for England.
ALBANY, Sept. 21.--One of the most thorough acts of Controller Davenport's administration is his method of collecting the corporation taxes.

A dividend of 33 1/8 per cent, in bonds and 33 1/8 per cent in stock of the Postal Telegraph Company has been declared to the stockholders of the Electro-Graphic Manufacturing Company, of which Charles Jenkins is President, payable Oct. 1.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 21.--Greater confidence is manifesting itself in the financial situation here from day to day. The reports about two small banks being in a tight place for funds are emphatically denied by the managers of the banks. Still, the depositors are anxious and are withdrawing their money.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 21.--The Governor has pardoned John J. Fayley, who was sentenced Sept. 5, 1882, by the Court of General Sessions in New-York, to the State Reformatory at Elmira on his plea of guilty of burglary in the third degree, and has filed the following reasons therefor:

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 21.--Mrs. Hymus Eastman, 45 years of age, of Leon, is now her own mother-in-law. She married a son of Hymus Eastman. When he died she married Stephen Casten, and now that he is dead she has married her first husband's father, her father-in-law, who is 72 years old. Considerable cemment has been caused by the marriage.

Jason H. Hoffman, who is said to be a NewJersey schoolmaster, some time ago bought an interest in private detective agency here, maintained by Samuel J. Lowell, Frederick P. Smith conducted the negotiation.

ITHACA, Sept. 21.--Cornell University opened to-day with 156 applicants for admission, being 14 more than last year. About 140 will be admitted. There are representatives from 15 States and from Russia, Spain, Brazil, Central America, Australia.

QUINCY, Ill., Sept. 21.--O.B. Ward and Charles Johnston were accidentally poisoned at Camp Point yesterday. They procured a quart bottle of what was supposed to be bitters at a drug store, to be taken as a beverage. Drinking of it freely, they both in a short time dropped dead. A third man, who drank with them, was seized with spasms, but will recover.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21, 1883. The nomination of Edward Neumann as Ex aminer of Teas at San Francisco, made by the Collector at that port, has been approved by the Secretary of the Treasury.
Joseph Swift, Vice-President and New-York manager of the Diamond Match Company, denied with some emphasis, yesterday, that that company was a combination to keep up the price of matches.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21.--The Signal Corps Station at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina, reports that the vessel before reported is the three-masted schooner C.W. Lewis, of Thomaston, Me., loaded with lumber. She was picked up by the Mary Bradford, Capt. Miller, from Barranquilla, ...

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21.--At the upper central way bridge to-night a horse attached to a wagon and driven by an unknown man went off the bridge while the draw was turned. Both horse and man were drowned. The driver's body has not been recovered.
The planning mill of Robert Ellis, at Fortyfirst-street and Second-avenue, was destroyed by fire yesterday, together with much valuable lumber stored in and about the premises.
John F. Smyth, of Albany, is at the Victoria Hotel. Joseph Medill, of the Chicago Tribune, is at the Clarendon Hotel.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Sept. 21.--Joseph Baker, a leading jeweller here, was found dead this morning, a mile above Moline. His wagon was above him and his struggling horse was attached. His neck and an arm were broken.

WASHINGTON Sept. 21.--Supervising Architect Hill has addressed a long letter to Secretary Folger in defense of his administration and in answer to some of the findings of the investigating commission just submitted.

Mrs. Elizabeth C. Morton, the Brooklyn lady whose mysterious disappearance last Saturday created so much apprehension, was taken to her home at No. 485 Willoughby-avenue yesterday afternoon by Police Captain Mckaig, of Jersey City.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 21.--Advices from Prop. Nordenskjold's expedition to Greenland have been received via Thurso, Scotland. They state that the expedition started from Autleiksivick on Sept. 4, and reached a distance of 300 kilomtetres inland, attaining a height of 7,000 feet above the level of the sea.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21.--Dispatches from Milwaukee recently stated that the Diamond Match Company, a very large concern, had reduced the wholesale price of matches more than 50 per cent.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 21.--At 10 o'clock to-morrow the old Naval punt that has been rotting at the New-London navy, yard is to be sold at public auction. The gun-boat Florida, which cost the Government $1,750,000 and which is estimated to be worth less than $50,000, is on the auction list, and a small Government steamer, badly rotted, is also to be disposed of.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., 21.--There are few persons in this city and county unacquainted with Miss Annie Sterner, a young lady who resides with her parents on Mahantonga-street, between Eleventh and Twelfth streets.

SUMTER, S.C., Sept. 21.--Yesterday a negro in the upper part of this, county outraged, a white girl named Bottle Dixon, 12 years of age. A sister of the victim, in trying to protect her, was stabbed by the negro, but not fatally. Last night a party of citizens took the negro, tied him to an tree, shot him, then beat him to jelly and left him.

PITTSBURGH, Penn., Sept. 21.--The scene of yesterday's terrible boiler explosion was visited by thousands of persons today. Only a small portion of the debris has been cleared away, as all the men in the building at the time of the explosion have been accounted for.

The question of rebates on property provided with safeguards against fire camp before the board of Fire Underwriters yesterday, and several important changes were made. Hereafter a rebate of 10 per cent.
KNOXBORO, N.Y., Sept. 21.--The funeral services of the late Rev. Dr. W.E. Knox were held in this village, the home of the Knox family, today. There was a large attandence from all parts of the State.
MONTREAL, Sept. 21.--The Collector of Customs has seized a cargo of Philadelphia coal delivered here, for the non-payment or the duty. It was consigned to S.W. Beard.

The dispatch from Milwaukee published in yesterday's TIMES announcing that Mrs. Simon B. Paige, of Davenport, Iowa, was about to publish a sensational history of her life probably attracted more attention in Brooklyn than the book will obtain anywhere. Mrs. Paige was formerly a resident of the city at the other end of the bridge.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 21.--One hundred convicts in the State prison at Wethersfield were poisoned last night in some mysterious way, and for a time the officials feared that the jail was about to be converted into a well-filled morgue.

Some time ago County Clerk Keenan declined to file for the Excise Commissioners the bonds furnished the latter by liquor-dealers unless he received a fee of 50 cents for each bond.

ST. PETERSBURGH, Sept. 21.--The estimated expenses of the Russian Army for 1884 are 7,000,000 rubles in excess of those for 1883.
Albert Strittmatter, who purloined checks while employed as invoice clerk by Theodore Herrmann, a merchant, of No. 93 Pearl-street, was a prisoner yesterday in Jefferson Market Police Court.

FARGO, Dakota, Sept. 21.--The equinoctial storms struck this section yesterday. The farmers are already through with thrashing, but considerable wheat remains in the stack on large farms, and if the weather keeps cold not much damage will be done.

GAINESVILLE, Ga., Sept. 21.--Hall County is enjoying a sensation over the culmination of a little romance in which a young Baltimore physician wooed and wedded, despite parental opposition, one of the beiles of the county.

BOSTON, Sept.--Nemo Camp, No. 1, Oddfollows, of Albany, arrived here this morning from Lyna, and, escorted by the Boston Encampment, marched through the principal streets to the Quincy House, where dinner was served.
The Third Provincial Council of the Roman Catholic Church held in this City will begin in St. Patrick's Cathedral, in Fifth-avenue, to-morrow and continue for a week.

ALBANY, Sept. 21.--The control of the Buffalo Convention and the next Democratic State Committee being fully assured to the followers of Gov. Cleveland and Chairman Manning, the composition of the State ticket is the subject which now attracts the most attention among Democratic politicians.
COVINGTON, Ky., Sept. 21.--There was a large attendance at the races to-day. The weather was cool and the track fast, but dusty.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Sept, 21.--The General Conference of the Evangelical Church, embracing churches in America, Germany, and Switzerland, will convene here on Oct. 4 and remain in session 15 days. Among the important work will be election of Bishops, officers of publication houses, Two hundred ministers and 100 delegatess belong to the Conference.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 21--A romantic elopement occurred last night on the south side, which culminated in marriage this morning. The young man in the case is a glass-cutter named Fisher.

Six started in the race, but four of them came to grief before three jumps were cleared. W. Meaney, who rode Bridecake, was knocked senseless. The weather was pleasant and the track in good condition.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 21.--The National Liberal League met at 10 o'clock this morning. President Wakeman read the opening address and a Committee on Credentials was then appointed.

Mr. Francis B. Thurber was the first speaker to whom the Senate Committee on Labor and Education listened yesterday. WASHINGTON, Sept. 21.--First Lieut. George Andrews, Twenty-fifth Infantry, has been relieved from duty at the Brooks School, Cleveland, Ohio, and will join his company. The extension of leave of absence granted Paymaster Daniel R. Larned has been further extended to Oct. 25.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 21.--An Englishman named Charles Harris, who disappeared from Kingston in May last, is suspected of having been murdered by two deserters from B Battery, named Jack Owles and Pete Patton, for $10 he had in his pockets.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 21.--In the Sovereign Grand Lodge of Odd-fellows several appeals from the action of various lodges were disposed of. The Judiciary Comittee reported, approving all the decisions of the Grand Sire save one.

John Lee, a brakeman employed on the Third-avenue elevated railroad, caused the arrest of Dr. William L. Shine about three months ago on the charge of "striking him in the face and threatening him with a revolver."

EFFINGHAM, Ill., Sept. 21.--George W. Ryan, of Barratt's circus, died last night. He fell in the morning while endeavoring to throw a double somersault at rehearsal. He was 19 years old. His real name was Marsh and he was a remarkable athelete.

DOVER, N.H., Sept. 21.--Ther is a great scarcity of water in this section. That part of the Cochoco Mill operated by Water-power is running only half the time and the saw and grist mills in the surrounding country have shut down. The wells and streams have been drying up and the cattle have to be driven long distances to water.
With the opening of each ensuing theatrical season the annual outcry against ticket speculators begins. That the public has excellent grounds for complaint on this score there can be no doubt.

President Gowen, of the Philadelphia, and Reading Railroad, says, for the information of the Jersey Central stockholders, that during the month of August the last named road earned $90,000 net iu excees of the 6 per cent. guaranteed by the Reading Company.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21.--J.B. McCullagh, editor-in-chief of the St. Louis Globe-Democrat, who returned to-day from the East, was questioned to-night regarding the political intelligence he had gained while absent.
QUEBEC, Sept. 21.--The Governor-General's ball at the Citadel last night was a grand success. 952 invitations being accepted out of a large number issued.
BOSTON, Sept. 21.--This was the fourth and last day of the special meeting at Mystic Park. The attendance was large and the track was in fine condition.

MADISON, Ind., Sept. 21.--Frederick Siebert, 70 years old, while up in a grape-vine yesterday gathering fruit at his place at Stony Point, accidently fell to the ground, a distance of 20 feet, and was killed.
Mayor EDSON has promised the Civil Service Commission of the State to carry out reform in the City service as far as he is able.

LONDON, Sept. 21.--The Manchester Guardian in its financial article says there is no appreciable change in the market for cotton goods. Prices remain steady.
MACON, Ga., Sept. 21.--An epidemic of poisoning seems to have fallen upon the State. A recent attempt to kill a whole family at the Cherokee camp-meeting narrowly failed.

GUAYMAS, MEXICO, Sept. 21.--More rain fell last night. Reports are daily arriving that persons who fled from here are dying in the interior. Ten deaths in this city have been reported during the last 24 hours. It is reported that 600 persons are down with the fever.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21.--The Chicago Driving Park has added another race to its Fall meeting programme, viz, a purse of $1,000, open to all stallions, to be trotted the first or second day of the meeting, entries to close Oct. 1. The meeting is to be held from Oct. 6 to the 13th, and the entries, except to the stallion purse, close Sept. 29. Purses amounting to $17,000 are offered.

FARGO, Dakota, Sept. 21--The Dickey County Bank, at Ellendale, has suspended. The Capital Bank, at St. Paul, had worn out an attachment for $7,000, and this is alleged to have been the final cause of the suspension.

LOUIS, Sept. 21.--A variety theatre known as the Alhambra and kept by a man named Jacob Esher, was the scene at 11:15 last night of a tragedy in which a 20-year-old lad named Richard Whalen shut himselr fatally, after attempting to kill one of the female performers named Carrie Howard, the wife of the head waiter of the place.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 21.--The Inter-State Educational Convention was in season to-day, though many of the delegates had departed. The topic discussed was "The Best System of Schools Under State Control." A resolution was adopted favoring federal aid to education, with only one dissenting voice.

NEWPORT, R.I, Sept. 21.--President Arthur enjoyed a sail and a drive to-day, and this evening attended private theatricals, which were given at the Casino Theatre for the benefit of a local charity. He was taken outside in Frederick W. Vanderbilt's schooner yacht Tidal Wave.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 21.--This afternoon a young man of decidedly dadish appearance was arrested at the Clinton-street station of the Pennsylvania Railroad, by Railroad Detective Ferman, for horse-stealing.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 21.--Mrs. Ann Holleran is lying at her home, in the Eighteenth Ward, suffering from serious wounds in the head, which were inflicted a few nights ago by Sergt. Mershon, of the city police force, while arresting the woman for some trivial offense.
A medical student named Joseph W. Pilington, of Sedalia, Mo., died yesterday at the boarding-house No. 338 Second-avenue from an overdose of morphine,which he had taken while suffering from malaria.

G. W. Ditchott, real estate agent, of No. 2 New-Chambers-street, advertised on the 9th inst. for a loan of $16,000 on New-York property. He received a postal card to the effect that if he would call at No. 34 East Twelfth-street an arrangement might be made with H. E. Davis.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 21.--Thomas Ruffin, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, has resigned on account of ill health, occasioned by overwork while on the bench. Before the constitution was amended the court consisted of five members.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22.--Prof. Charles Herman proprietor of the German-American Select School, at No. 1,526 Mount Vernon-street, left his home last Wednesday morning and mysteriously disappeared. His family offered a reward of $100 for his discovery.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 22.--In the Sovereign Grand Lode of Odd-fellows this morning, the report of the Committee on Petitions confirming the action of the grand officers in granting dispensations for lodges in the kingdom of Denmark and at Brandon, Manitoba, was adopted. Justice Walsh yesterday honorably discharged William Kerrigan, who was accused of having stolen a gold watch and $70 in money from John J. Carey while the latter slept on the stoop in front of his liquor-store in Hudson-avenue, Brooklyn.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 22--Returns from the recent election for chief in tho Creek Nation, in the Indian Territory, are all in except from two precincts. Spiechee is elected over Perriman and Chicate by about 40 majority. The result is a defeat for the liberal and progressive party.

Soon after the passage by the last Legislature of the bill authorizing the Sinking Fund Commissioners to investigate the plan of furnishing to the City an additional water supply from the Ramapo Valley, and to enter into a contract, subject to certain restrictions, for the same if they saw fit, the Ramapo Valley Improvement Company was incorporated.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 22.--The Supreme Court of the State yesterday decided a case which is of interest to the Friends all over the country. Catherine Mulley 25 years ago, in her will, made a charitable beques to the White Lick Quarterly Meeting.

A large number of persons assembled on the Polo Grounds yesterday to witness the game of base-ball between the Chicago and New-York Glubs. The Chicago men secured a lead of 3 runs in the first inning from the pitching of Welch.

SHREWSBURY, N. J., Sept. 22.--Henry W. Wolcott was buried from the Friends' meetinghouse here this afternoon. He was at one time a prominent citizen of New-York, of which city he was the pioneer auctioneer. He was born in NewJersey in 1798, and for many years resided at East Orange, where he died.

King ALFONSO of Spain may or may not have had his home made unpleasant by difficulties with his Queen, but he has certainly left home for the purpose of having what is popularly called "a good time with the boys."

LONDON, Sept. 22.--As a singular illustration of the way in which distinctively American literature is becoming known on the Continent may mention that a recent work of Mr. Bret Harte is now being published as a feuilleton in the St. Petersburg Gazette.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22.--Counsel for John A. Walsh to-day took the usual steps to have dismissed the salt begun by the latter some time ago against Thomas J. Brady, ex-Assistant PostmasterGeneral, to recover money said to have been loaned to the amount of about $28,000.

ATHENS, Ga., Sept. 22.--Yesterday at breakfast an attempt to poison the family of Robert Calloway by putting broken glass in some batter-cakes they were eating was made by a negro named Bob Stark, 14 years old. Mr. Calloway was absent in Jackson County with his brother, Will Calloway, but the wives of both were at home.

OTTAWA, Sept. 21.--The annual report of the Superintendent of Insurance for 1882, contains some interesting information regarding Insurance business in all its branches in Canada. Before any Canadian or foreign company can commence taking life risks a deposit of $50,000 is required by the Government as a security for policy-holders.

The first battle in the contest for Mayor in Long Island City between Mayor George Patry and Alderman Patrick Gileason, was fought yesterday. In the Second Assembly District of Qneens County, at Jamaica. Mayor Petry was not present, but he was represented by his Lieutenant, Corporation Counsel Alvan T. Pavne, who beaded one of the rival delegations from long Island City.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Sept. 13.--The Northern Pacific Railroad from the point at which the last rails were laid, just west of the main divide of the Rocky Mountains, makes a considerable deflection to the north-west, passing through Missoula County, Montana, around Lake Pend d'Orelllie and into Idaho.
NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 22.--With 13 exceptions, all the men who were poisoned at the Wethersfield State prison are sufficiently recovered this morning to resume work.

OTTAWA, Canada, Sept. 22.--A change has been made in the vice-regal programme. The Governor-General and the Princess Louise will return to Ottawa to-morrow morning and remain two weeks prior to their departure from Canada, instead of a stay of one week, as was expected.

PHILADELPHIA. Sept. 22.--Three additional suits were brought to-day against the Evening News Company by Cordella and Elizabeth Haas and Annie Seckinger for the recovery of damages for alleged libelous statements in the News in reference to the disputed sanity of Frederick Haas.

DES MOINES, Sept. 22.--Stephen Nyere died at Cedar Rapids yesterday at the age of 56 years. He was born in Hungary, and was a staff officer of Kossuth. Mr. Nyere had resided in this country 29 years, and in Cedar Repids 27 years, and had been engaged the entire time in the merchant tailoring business. He leaves a widow and 11 children.

F. Price, the Republican nominee, he can do nothing. The convention nominated William Bookstaver. L. W. Wiltsie, and George W. Warner, delegates to the State Convention.

Three largo piles of clams decorated a long wooden table at Clarendon Hall last evening. A select number of spectators, composed chiefly of prominent oyster-stabbers and their friends affiliated with the Oystermen's Benevolent Society, were seated in front.

On Saturday night last, between 11 and 12 o'clock, what appears to be a serious case of crucity to animals occurred at Niagara Falls being an attempt to send a live horse over the cataract. The animal was an old one and had been employed for 27 years in drawing a hus belonging to the Cataract House.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22.--Miss E. Lorden, who was arrested in New-York last night for smuggling, lives at No. 1,409 Michigan-avenue, and is one of the fashionable private dress-makers of the south side. A call at the house brought out the fact that the family knew nothing about the affair.

Jacob Ackerson, a butcher employed in Washington Market, shot himself at his home, on Ogden-avenue, Jersey City Heights, last evening. He was taken to the hospital in a dying condition.

Edwin Francis Hatfield, D. D., died at 12:30 o'clock yesterday morning, of heart disease, at his country residence, in Summit, N. J. He was born in Elizabethtown. N. J., Jan. 9, 1807, and was graduated from Middlebury College, Vermont, in 1829.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept.22.--The case of Benjamin Seal against J.K. Black, a citizen of Pennsylvania, came up for argument to-day on a writ of habeas corpus.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22.--The St. Louis and St. Paul Packet Line lost its handsomest and fastest boat, the Gem City, by fire this morning.

Prop. William Augustus Norton, of Yale College, died at New-Haven, Conn., on Friday. The Professor was born at East Boomfield, N. Y., Out. 25, 1810. In 1827 he was appointed a cadet at the West Point Military Academy, from which he was graduated in 1831.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22.--Secretary Chandler last evening received the following telegram from Commandant Welch at Pensacola: "No new cases of yellow fever to-day. One death in Washington--a colored adult."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 22.--The Tax Commissioners have reduced the levy for city purposes for next year to 16.01 mills. The levy for county and State purposes will increase this to a very small fraction over 2 per cent. which will be the lowest rate of taxation known in Cincinnati for a long time.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22.--The leading produce markets were unsettled and irregular to-day, although within narrow price limits, with little change in provision and a stronger feeling on grain, except at the opening, when corn wilted a little on news of no frost of consequence the previous night.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 22.--The thirty-first anneal Illinois State Fair will open at the Driving Park Grounds Monday morning and remain open daring the weak. It promises to be the largest and most varied in exhibits in the history of the association. There will be trotting and running races every afternoon.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 22.--The liabilities of R. R. Kilby, who suspended some time ago, are $146,000, with assets aggregating $34,000. The largest creditors are T.S. Judah $36,000; La Banque du Pouple, $30,000, and the Bank of Montreal, $20,000. The real estate belonging to Thomas Hodgson, the produce merchant who made such a disastrous failure some time ago, was sold by the Sheriff to-day for $15,500.

OLD POINT COMFORT, Sept. 20.--A rose by any other name, or possibly even Hunter's Point by any other name, might smell as sweet, but no name under the sun could possibly convey such an Idea of ease and quiet and content as Old Point Comfort.

PITTSBURG, Penu., Sept. 22.--This has proved a blue Saturday for those whose faith is pinned to better prices in oil. Yesterday a boom was auspiciously started, but to-day a snag was encountered which sent prices down 3 cents. It came in the shape of the Porcupine Well No. 11.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 22.--The Rev. James McCallen, of St. Mary's Theological Seminary, in this city, has been transferred to the Seminary of Saint Sulpice in Paris and will leave about the 1st of December. The Rev. Edward R. Dyer, D.D., now in Rome, will supply the vacancy in St. Mary's caused by the transfer of Mr. McCallen.

BOSTON, Sept. 22.--Adrian Jacquinot, Assistant Professor of the French language at Harvard University, died at Cambridge this morning, aged 42 years, of pneumonia. He had been connected with the university for several year, and was the author of several text-books now in use in schools.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 22--Three happy detectives and a happy Coroner took a late train tonight from Stratford to Bridgeport. They were the same dotectives and the same Coroner that have been going up and down the highways of Fairfield County for more than a fortnight past, mysterious, austere, and forlorn.

BOSTON, Sept. 22.--The Executive Committee of the Democratic State Committee held a fully attended meeting this afternoon and discussed matters relative to the coming conventin at Springfield. The Hon. Edward Avery, of Braintree, accepted the invitation to preside at the convention. Gov. Butler will be present as a delegate, and will make a speech.

CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 22.--A citizen who cleared $20,000 on a farm and then made $50,000 more by stock speculation, has failed. He says that he has lost evary dollar. Several prominent men here are among his creditors.
There were 103,804 visitors to the free floating baths last week, of whom 26,573 were women and girls.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Sept. 22.--The lacrosse match here to-day between the Shamrock and Montreal Clubs for the championship of the world was won by the former, who secured three games against one for the Montreal Club.

WILKESHARRE, Penn., Sept. 22.--Joseph Lester, an aged farmer residing in Fairmount township, was terribly bitten yesterday by a bulldog belonging to a neighbor. The dog seized him by the throat and tore the flesh from ear to ear. He cannot recover.

READING, Penn., Sept. 22--An event of more than ordinary interest was the reunion at Central Park to-day of Durell's Independent Battery. Trains from surrounding counties brought in a large number of members this morning. At 12:30 o'clock P. fd, the dinner call was sounded by the old bugler of the battery, J. A. Montgomery, and the survivors sat down to a splendid banquet.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 22.--Mrs. Maria Reynolds, a widow, and a resident of Brooklyn, has been visiting her sister at New-Hamburg. This morning she went to visit Mrs. Pitcher, a cousin, at Milton, going thither on the steamer Hurdson Taylor.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 22.--A large attendance fast track, and a general defeat of the favorites were the features of the last day of the Latonit Jockey Club's Fall meeting at Louisville.

ALBANY, Sept. 22.--The change in the Republican State Committeeman from Albany County has attracted such general attention that the new member, A. S. Draper, has been moved to make a public statement of the facts of the contest, and explain his own position.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 22.--Gov. Cameron has pretty well decided not to issue his writ for a new election in the Seventh Congressional District of this State. The district was represented in the last House of Representatives by Mr. John Paul, a well-known Mahonite. Mr. Paul was re-elected last year

CONCORD, N. H., Sept. 22.--The Triennial Council of the Congregational Churches of the United States, begins its session in this city Oct. 1.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 22.--A special dispatch from the Indian Territory says: "On Wednesday night, in the Choctaw Nation, near Big Creek, four hunters named Sadler, Tipton, and two brothers named Gray, of Paris, Texas, were eneamped, when a posse in search of horse-thieves rode up and called on them to surrender.

NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 22.--This morning President Arthur attended to some business of an official nature. At 1 o'clock he lunched with Mr. and Mrs. Cornellus Vanderbilt at their Summer home. The guests were elegantly attired.

OTTAWA, Canada, Sept. 22.--At the Assize Court to-day Stephen Dunn, charged with the murder of Charlie Fletcher, in September, 1881, was put on his trial. Both Dunn and Fletcher were members of Cole's circus, at that time performing in Canada. The principal witness was Silas Curry.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 22.--The steamer Nantasket, of the Boston and Hingham Steam-boat Line, came into collision with an unknown schooner this morning near Point Flats, in this harbor. A dense fog prevailed, and it is claimed that the Captain of the schooner was not sounding either a bell or whistle to denote his presence.

There were reported to the Health Department during the past week 613 deaths, 595 births, and 239 marriages. There were 16 deaths from typhoid fever, and 84 cases of that disease were reported during the week, being 20 more than for the preceding week.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 22.--Col. R. S. Strader, a well-known horseman, last night shot and killed Bradford Foster, a negro employe. Strador was told that Foster had turned a stallion in with a valuable filly, and procuring a shot-gun he went to the stable. Foster ran away, firing at Strader before leaving. He returned shortly afterward, and while advancing on Strader the latter fired twice, killing the negro.
AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 22.--The Democrats of the First Cayuga District have nominated for the Assembly John P. Mosher, and those of the Second, M.E. Kenyon.

LONDON, Sept. 22.--Arrangements are being made by the First National League for a series of mass-meetings in America, which will be addressed by many prominent Nationalists, including Mr. John Redmond, who is now in Australia. Mr. Redmond will return from Australia by way of San Francisco, which he is expected to reach in November.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 22.--The arrest and identification of Sam Pine, the outlaw, has caused much excitement and a vast amount of relief in Daubury.

MOUNDSVILLE, West Va., Sept. 22.--A ghastly discovery, and one forming another link in the chain of evidence proving the truth of the allegations of brutality and inhumanity on the part of the officers of the Marshall County Infirmary, has just been made.

WILKESBARRE, Sept. 22.--One of the most serious mine accidents recorded for a long time occurred this morning at the Woodward shaft, near Kingston, by which four men lost their lives. The shaft is over 500 feet deep, and has in it about 20 feet of water. At a distance of about 80 feet from the bottom six men--George Bugg.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 22.--The Lord Bishop of Rochester is expected to arrive in Baltimore in the next steamer of the Allan Line. The Bishop is the bearer of a letter from the Archbishop of Canter bury congratulating the triennial convention on the centenary of the consecration of Bishop Seabury.

SHREWSBURY, N.J., Sept. 22.--On Thursday morning, at an early hour, thieves stole 23 sheep from George W. Stillwell of Red Bank. The sheep were in a pasture, near Mr. Stillwell's farm-house, at this place. They were tracked to the New-York and Long Branch crossing, near Red Bank, where all trace of them was lost.

NYACK, Sept. 22.--The Zion African Methodist Episcopal Church of this village is in considerable trouble over an unpleasant transaction in which its late Pastor, the Rev. Simeon F. Dickson, is alleged to be one of the principals. Mr. Dickson was until last Sunday afternoon serving in his secand year as Pastor of this church.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 22.--John Smith, colored, was convicted at Oatland, Garrett County, Md., yesterday, of murder in the first degree for the killing of Josiah Harding, near Elkins, on May 15 last.

The seventh company of the Seventh Regiment paraded in full dress and white neckties for review and dress parade in Delmonlee's armory last evening. Lieut. E.G. Haight was in command, and Capt. James C. Abrams, the company commandant, was the reviewing officer.

PETERMARITZBURG, Sept.22.--It is semiofficially announced that the colonial authorities have sent a message to King Cetywayo demanding his surrender.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 22.--Robert Bruce, a hostler, attacked James Ryan, a sailor, in the street at Elyria late last night, presumably to rob him of $80 which he had drawn during the day. Ryan's dead body was found early this morning with an ugly gash in the neck. No money was found on his person. Bruce was arrested and admits the murder, but pleads self-defense.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22.--The week just closed has been an exciting one in railroad circles. The rate to Louisville has been cut down to $1 and remains so. This has demoralized rates to Cincinnati in the scalpers' offices, and it is expected that unless the war is settled at once the Cincinnati rates will be out openly in the offices.

The Hon. E. O. Hall, K. C. B., a member of the Cabinet of Kalakaua King of the Hawalian Islands, and a prominent merchant of Honolulu, died at Falmouth, Me., last Wednesday, in the 71st year of his age. PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23.--Gardeicke Co., representing the owners of the English steam-ship Alvah, of Abordeen, which sunk the fishing schooner Sarah Francis on Sept. 8, 20 miles southeast of Cape Henlopen, have compromised with the owners of the schooner for 4,250.

Prince, the bicyclist, resents the charge that he sold Thursday's bicycle race at Springfield, and has accepted Robert James's challenge to a 10-mile race for $250 a side. OTTAWA, Sept. 24.--Small-pox is prevailing to a large extent among the men at work on the Georgian Bay section of the Canadian pacific Railway. A large number of death are reported, and the medical staff appears to be powerless to prevent its spreading. The Indian tribes quartered in that locality are fleeing for their lives, fearing the consequences of a disease which proves so fatal to those it attacks.

PITTSBURG, Penn,, Sept. 24.--From indications to-night the grand regatta, which will be inaugurated here to-morrow and continue four days, will exceed the greatest expectations of its projectors.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24.--Gen. D. S. Stanley, of Fort Lewis, Colorado, was met by THE TIMES'S correspondent to-day. The General is on a furlough, and has been spending his time traveling. He is waiting for orders from Washington, and expects to be stationed at Santa Fe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24.--The verdict of the Court-martial in the case of Second Lieut. Robertson, who was charged with duplicating his pay accounts, is not as severe as was at first supposed. Instead of dismissal, the sentence is only suspension for a short period, not more than a year.
TORONTO, Ontario, Sept. 25.--Prince George of Wales is in this city seeing the sights.

ASHVILLE, Ohio, Sept. 25.--The small jail at this town was burned yesterday, and one prisoner, name unknown, was burned to death. He was an umbrella-mender, and claimed to have come from the Soldiers' Home at Dayton. He had considerable money, and it is thought that he was murdered and the building set on fire to conceal the crime.

BOSTON, Sept. 25.--The Wesley P. Balch stallion races were inaugurated at Beacon Park today, the attendance being large. Owing to yesterday's rain the track was heavy in places, which made unusually fast time impossible. Two races were trotted--the 2:20 and 2:50 classes.

NEWBURG, N.J., Sept. 25.--By a land-slide at New-Windsor to-day Gilbert Knox, aged 35 years, was instantly killed and Charles S. Vanderlin was probably fatally injured. They both lived at Greenfield, Ulster County.
TROY, N.Y., Sept. 25.--Henry Stewart, a wealthy farmer, 70 years of age, of Kingsbury, Washington County, committed suicide this morning by shooting himself. Poor health was the cause of the act.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 26.--It is reported that John D. Rockefeller has given $10,000 in cash to the persons working for the second amendment, the money to be used in conducting the meetings and business by which the Woman's Christian Temperance Union seek to bring about prohibition.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 26.--The annual meeting of the Board of Overseers of Harvard College was held to-day, the Hon. E. Rockwood Hoar in the chair. The Rev. Andrew P. Peabody, W.C. Endicott, and the Rev. Phillips Brooks were elected Overseers for the ensuing six years, to succeed Stephen Salisbury, J. Elliott Cabot, and William Amory, whose terms have expired. F.M. Weld and Solomon Lincoln were re-elected Overseers for six years.

The attendance at the Queens County Fair yesterday was very large. Politicians were out in full force, and the merits and chances of election of the many candidates for local and other offices were canvassed.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 26.--This was the third day of the Fall meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club. The weather was cool, the track dusty, the attendance good, and the betting improved.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 26.--At a few minutes before 3 o'clock this morning, when the wicked politicians had ceased to trouble and the weary were at rest, a fire broke out in the Sternberg elevator, section A, at the corner of Ohio and Columbia streets, and fronting on the Buffalo River.
The Thirteenth Regiment will attend the Newburg centennial celebration on Oct. 18. Mayor Edson, as Treasurer of the Peter Cooper monument fund, has received $1,750.

BOSTON, Sept. 26.--Two thousand persons were present at the second day's races of the meeting at Beacon Park. The track was in fine condition, and there was but little wind to interfere with the speed of the horses.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 26. --News of fresh disasters continue to reach this city hourly from Northern Lake Michigan and the other great lakes.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Sept. 26.--Two lads, at work on the Michigan Central cantilever bridge at Niagara, were seriously injured yesterday by falling over the scaffolding to the rocks below. One, named Marks, from Pittsburg, had his right leg broken. The other, Robertson, lately from England, had his wrist broken.
AUBURN, N.Y., Sept. 26.--William Howland was renominated for the Assembly by the Second Cayuga District Republicans.

LIMA, Sept. 26, via Galveston.--El Commercio states that Gen. Lynch, the Chilian Commander-in-Chief, has given orders to the various chiefs of corps here to be in readiness to leave Lima to allow the Iglesias troops to enter the city. It is reported that these troops will remain in the vicinity of Lima until Iglesias is established.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26.--The general courtsmartial recently convened at David's Island, NewYork Harbor, Columbus Barracks, Oho, and Jefferson Barracks, Missouri, have been dissolved. Miss Mary Potter, daughter of the Hon. Orlando B. Potter, was married yesterday afternoon to Mr. Walter Geer, of Chicago, in Grace Church, by the Rev. Dr. Henry C. Potter.

Senators Blair, Call, and Pugh listened yesterday to the testimony of Mr. Joseph Medill, pro prietor of the Chicago Tribune. Mr. Medill said he had been connected with newspapers since 1848. He believed the chief cause of the impecunious condition of the wage classes in this country was due to their own improvidence.

WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 26.--Dennis Dwyer, of Thomaston, while hunting yesterday, was accidentally shot by a companion named McCaul. The charge went through the right arm and lodged in his lungs. He is not expected to live. He is young and unmarried.

LOWELL, Mass., Sept. 26.--At a meeting of the telephone companies under the management of the Lowell syndicate this morning the following quarterly dividends were declared: Maine, 1 per cent.; Boston and Northern, 3 per cent.; Bay State, 2 per cent.; Suburban, 2 per cent.; Union, 1 per cent.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 26.--There is a rumor current to-night that the price of the Cincinnati Enquirer will be reduced from 5 to 2 cents on Oct. 1. The story comes from persons near McLean, but he has not made any statement for publication. The story is generally credited.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26.--A curious instance of the relative value of local time at each of two distant points of longitude was developed here recently.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 26.--The Democrats do not intend to lose Ohio without a struggle. At the recent conference of leaders with the State Committee there was some very plain talk from men who, like Mayor John H. Farley, of Cleveland, believe that the Democrats have some interests and expectations beyond mere State offices or the winning of a municipal campaign here and there.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26.--At the meeting of the Executive Board of the National Wool-growers' Association to-day the Secretary read extracts from his voluminous printed report, giving a minute account of the part he and President Garland took in bringing about the reduction of the tariff.
The collegiate examination for women at Columbia College began Tuesday, and will last through the week.

The hurricane which visited Nassau and that vicinity on Friday, 7th inst., destroyed hundreds of vessels and caused great loss of life. LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 26.--A light frost fell here last night. It was the first frost of the season, and as far as can be learned was general throughout the State. The damage to corn is believed to be light, as the crop is pretty well matured.

The attendance at Creedmoor was larger yesterday than on Tuesday. The first match was open to teams of four, from any regiment, company or battery in the Second Division, seven rounds each at 200 and 500 yards.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 26. --The eighth annual reunion of the One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Veteran Volunteer Association commenced here yesterday, and was continued over last night. After transacting regular business the veterans adjourned to meet at Binghamton on Sept.25, 1884. Representatives of 26 different regiment were present.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26.--Lord Chief-Justice Coleridge visited the Criminal Court this morning and spent half an hour listening to the proceedings of the murder trial which happened to be in progress. PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26.--Christian Pepper, a saloon-keeper, was convicted in Judge Finletter's Court of the Quarter Sessions to day of committing an aggravated assault and battery on George D. Ott. The latter had been drinking in the saloon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26.--The Potomac River regatta held to-day was undoubtedly the finest event of the kind that has ever occurred on the Potomac River. The day was bright and clear, but a strong north-westerly breeze made the water somewhat lumpy during the first two hours of the regatta.
PHELPS, N.Y., Sept. 26.--Prof. Brooks, of the Red House Observatory, has been awarded the Warner prize of $200 for his recent discovery of the comet of 1819.

BOSTON, Sept. 27.--at Beacon Park to-day the track was in very good condition. The attendance was excellent. J. S. Campbell's stallion Richball took two more heats and won the pacers' race, which was unfinished yesterday. Time-- 2:17 ; 2:17. Flora Belle secured second money.
