Leiter of Chicago, for a term of years. Mr. L. Z. Leiter, who is of the well-known firm of Chicago merchants, will take pessession this Fall. Ex-Secretary Blaine and family will probably pass the winter in Washington, however, as he is almost compelled to finish his book here."
BOSTON, Sept. 27.--A meeting of the bondholders of the Toledo, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad was held at the Parker House to-day, about 100 gentlemen being present.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27.--The new bond of Postmaster Pearson was approved to-day by the Post Office Department. This bond was made necessary by the death of Mr. Hugh Hastings, one of the original bondsman. Mr. Pearson had no difficulty in quickly complying with the demand for a new bond of $500,000, justification being required in double that amount.

BUFFALO, Sept. 27.--In the contest of the will of Mr. Fillmore, widow of President Fillmore, the relatives not mentioned in the will are trying to prove that she was not of sound mind when the will was made.
PITTSBURG, Sept.27.--John R.McCune, the umpire to whom the railroad coal tribunal referred the question of the wages to be paid miners during the Winter months, announced his decision to-day.

The convention of colored men which has just been held at Louisville is a noteworthy event in the history of their race. Although the proceedings were characterized by much disorder and tumult, the address which was the final outcome is, on the whole, creditable.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 27.--At the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners to-day the time for making annual reports was extended to Jan. 20.

Mr. Jesse Johnson, one of the most widely known and highly esteemed lawyers at the Brooklyn Bar, was yesterday nominated by the Republicans as a candidate for Judge of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial District.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27.--There was no change of rates to the South and South-west to-day, but there are surface indications that the managers are weary of cutting each other's throats and are willing to settle their differences. A meeting has been called by President Ingalls, of the Kankakee line, to convene at Cincinnati to-morrow, and well-informed railroad officers say that rates will be restored Saturday.

Jay-Eye-See, after going over the Beacon park tracj in 2:15 , left Boston Wednesday night and arrived at Fleetwood at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. The trainer of the little horse said that he had stood the journey wonderfully well.
St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Parish, in West Orange, is the largest and wealthiest of the half-dozen Episcopal parishes in the collection of Oranges that cluster together out in New-Jersey.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 27.--At the Republican State Convention yesterday the following nominations were made: For Regents of the University--M.J. Hull, J. M. Heatt, J. T. Mallolleu, and E. P. Holmes; for Judge of the Supreme court--M. D. Reese.

Mr. John Rogers, the maker of numerous statuettes, has completed in plaster the commiseiun fur a horoic equestrian statue of Gen. Reynolds, who was killed is the first day's battle of Gettysburg in 1863.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27.-Edward R. Harris, well known in Chicago as a New-York traveling salesman in the tobacco line, has been committed to the insane asylum at Fort Wayne, Ind. Mr. Harris had his romance, and with it a scandal.

WASHINGTON, Sept 27.--Judge-AdvocateGeneral Swaim has received the record of the court-martial in the case of First Lieut. James F. Simpson, Third Cavalry, who was tried on a charge of conduct unbecoming was officer and a gentleman.

PETERSBURG, Va., Sept. 27.--This afternoon a tooth and a vertebra of a shark, which, from their sizes indicated that the animal must have belonged to a prehistoric period, were found here while workmen were excavating for a sewer. The vertebra is 2 feet long and 8 inches in diameter. The tooth is 5 inches long and 3 inches wide.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 27.--Senator Bayard authorizes the Every Evening to declare the interview in the Chicago Herald on Butler a sheer fabrication. He says he declined to be "interviewed." and the Herald man did all the talking. All Senator Bayard recalls saying is that he did not know Butler to be a Democrat, and that his past did not entitle him to be considered one.

LONDON, Sept. 27.-A report is in circulation that Mr. Parnell has been shot, but it needs confirmation. Inquiry is being made as to its correctness.

A number of homing pigeons were sent on board the steamer Elbe on Aug. 29 by Fritz Uhlenhaut, of No. 197 Pearl-street. Yesterday he was surprised on receiving one of them back, D hen, that had made the voyage on the Cunard steamer Scythia from Liverpool.

Theological Seminary, has been called to the Lafayette park presbyterian Church, of this city, to fill the piece of Dr D. C. Marquis, now Professor in the Theological Seminary at Chicago.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 27.--J. Bates, of Cambridge, he was to have been married yesterday to Miss Houdlett of Catskill N. Y., disappeared on Saturday last. His body was found in the river today. It is believed that he committed suicide in a fit of mental aberration.
The stockholders of the Electric, Manufacturing and Miscellaneous Stock Exchange met in the Mills Building yesterday and adopted a set of by-laws.

HURON, Dakota, Sept. 27.--Billy Madden, of New-York, the trainer and backer of Mitchell, the pugllist passed through this city yesterday enroute for New-York. PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27.--John Wright, a New-York merchant, was arrested in this city to day on a capias issued in a suit for damages for malicious prosecution entered by Amon Redheffer, Wright charged Redheffer with secreting goods to Redheffer alleged that it was made maliciously and without probable cause. Mr. Wright also entered bail to answer a criminal charge of perjury in connection with the same prosecution.

Gen. E. A. Merrit, United States ConsulGeneral at London, gave a dinner to ex-PostmasterGeneral James at the Royal Hotel, Blackfriars, on the evening of Sept. 13.

ST. LOUIS, Sept.27.--The decay of the steamboating interest of St. Louis shown by the remarkable fact that at present not less than 20 fine steamers, 44 barges, and 18 scows are lying unemployed at the levee between Washington-avenue and the arsenal.
The work on the best Shore Road has now advanced so far that the running of regular trains between New-York and Syracuse will be begun next Monday, Oct. 1.

The fair of the Queens County Agricultural Society, which opened at Mineola on Tuesday last, closed last evening. The exhibition, both in point of attendance and the variety and excellance of exhibits in every department, was the most successful ever held by the society.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28.--The Lehigh and Schuylkill Coal Exchanges met to-day and adjusted prices for the line and city and harbor trades for October.

Two Indian squaws, named Slicer and Murray, of the Caughnawages, whose reservation is between La Prairie and Chateaugay, near Montreal, went to the Grand Central Sation on Thursday to take a train to Montreal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--Mr. Jesse Lawson, of New-Jersey, who took part in the convention of colored men at Louisille, and who was here today on his way home, says that some misunder standing has arisen about the action of the convention.

LONDON, Sept. 28.-O'Donnell, the murderer of Carey, was taken from Newgate Prison this morning, and arraigned before Magistrate Flowers at the Bow-Street Court. His examination was resumed: The courtroom was crowded. Among those present were J.C. McCoan, member of Parliament for Wicklow, and Arthur O'Connor, member of Parliament for Queen's County.

BOSTON, Sept. 28.--Some anxiety is now felt regarding the mysterious disappearance of the Rev. John Parkman, a Unitarian minister, of East Peppereil. He was last seen on Monday of this week. The river is to be dredged, as it is thought he may have been drowned.

BATAVIA, Sept. 28.--The New-York County Democracy special train on the New-York Central Road passed through Batavia at 11:20 this morning on its way from the Buffalo convention, being composed of 13 coaches drawn by 2 locomotives.

A suit has been begun in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, by Counselor Charles J. Patterson on the part of Mrs. Catharine McGowan, which, if the allegations contained in the complaint are well founded, reveal the existence of a most infamous system by which young girls are decoyed into houses of infamy.

Ever since CAREY was shot an Irish weekly newspaper published in New-York has been collecting funds for O'DONNELL'S defense. The contributions range from 25 cents to $1, and the names of the donors are printed. The total is now $7,607.12.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 28.--The Right Rev. Anthony Wilson Thorold, Lord Bishop of Rochesten England, reached this port to-day on the steam ship Hibernian from Liverpool. He was met at Locust Point by a committee of gentlemen of the Protestant Episcopal Church, and escorted to the Mount Vernon Hotel.

HAVANA, Sept. 28.--Gen. Castitlo, the newly appointed Captain-General of Cuba, arrived here to-day.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 28.--John P. Howard to-night announced his intention of giving a new building for the Medical Department of the University of Vermont and of refitting the old building for a gymnasium. The aggregate cost will be about $40,000. This will make over $400,000 that Mr. Howard has given to the university and the city within 10 years.
EASTON, Penn., Sept. 28.--At a meeting of the Pennsylvania School Slate Association held here yesterday it was ordered that all the manufacturers shall stop the production for 60 days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--Col. Andrew H. Russell, Ordnance Department, is responsible. Private William Hardesty, Troop M. Third Cavalry, has ...
The Newark (N.J.) Republican City Convention was attended last night by a large and enthusiastic gathering. Mayor Henry Link was renominated by acclamation.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 28.--When the Central Railroad train rolled into the station this morning and the delegates to the Democratic Convention alighted, not a smile was to be seen on their faces. They were a greatly disappointed, chagrinned set of men.
Capt. Charles McEntoe, of the Volunteer Life-saving Service, saved an Italian, who gave his name as Joe Long, from drowning in the East River at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

CHATHAM, Va., Sept. 28.--Sawney Younger, Reuben King, and Isaac Evans, three young negroes, were hanged hero to-day for the murder of William A. Sheppard last month. The execution was private, only about 15 persons witnessing it. The drop fell at 12:20 P.M. Yonnger's neck was broken and the other two died from strangulation.
Dr. S. Vander Heydon, in a fit of despondency, committed suicide by shooting himself at his hotel in the village of Winfield, Long Island, on the 15th inst.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 28.--The execution of George Wallace, in the yard of the jail in this city to-day, was more than ordinarily tragic in its nature. Promptly at 12 o'clock the doomed man marched from his cell to the gallows. He seemed calm and self-possessed. He wore a neat black suit, with white vest, and slippers.

The steam-ships City of Chester of the Inman Line; Circassia, of the Anchor Line; The Queen, of the National Line; Rhynland, of the Red Star Line, and Main, of the North German Lloyd, will sail for Europe to-day. Bishop Ryan, of St. Louis, will sail in the steam-ship City of Chester, of the Inman Line. Col. J.R. Weaver, United States Consul at Vienna, will sail for Antwerp in the Rhynland.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 28.--A special dispatch to the Bulletin from Guaymas, Mexico, regarding the extent of the yellow fever on the Mexican coast, says a panic exists.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 28.--A.C. Richmond, a man of some political note in this city some years ago, committed suicide at his plantation, on the Cooper River, last night, by taking morphine.

Judge HAND, as Referee in the case of the State against the Western Union Telegraph Company for the recovery of the special tax on its franchise for the year ending Nov. 1, 1881, has filed his findings at Albany, in which he directs judgment for the State in the sum of $178,397.26.

BUFFALO, Sept. 28.--It was 2 o'clock in the morning before Mr. Manning's convention completed its job of ratifying the slate and turned off the lights in the Music Hall. More than half the delegates and nearly all the spectators left the hall before the work was finished.
LANCASTER, Penn., Sept. 28.--On Sept. 20 Peter Hershey, a member of the Lancaster Bar, mysteriously disappeared. He went to Philadelphia, however, and made an assignment of his property.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 28.--Several months ago it was announced that a grand lottery would take place under the auspices of the Orange Organization, and a large number of tickets were sold.
The Milk Exchange has issued a card giving notice that "on Oct. 1 and until further notice" the price of milk will be 3 cents a quart.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 28.--Harry Street, the 5-year-old son of Samuel Street, who resides at No. 36 East Canal-street, in this city, has been missing since Wednesday, and it is feared that he has been abducted.
MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Sept. 28.--The twenty-fifth annual convention of the Hudson River Baptist Association, concluded at Kingston yesterday, after having been in session two days.
The bark Shirley is now officially regarded as lost. She left this port March 8 last for Valparaiso, which port she has not reached.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--It appears that nobody except President Ingalls, of the "Bid Four" road, who called for a meeting of the managers of the warring Chicago and Ohio River roads, in the interest of peace, to take place at Cincinnati to-day, went to the place designated.
A woman who calls herself Adelaide Leathers is suing, in the Supreme Court, for a limited divorce from Charles C. Leathers.
It is expected that Mr. Frederick Lovejoy, the new President of the Denver and Rio Grande railroad, will take charge of affairs next week.

VINCENNES, Ind., Sept. 28.--A sensational attempt at lynching was made hero this morning at about 3 o'clock, when from 50 to 75 masked men marched to the County Jail, on Seventh-street.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28.--The first annual meet of the Pennsylvania division of the League of American Wheelmen will take place to-morrow in Fairmount Park.

William R. Lang, Chairman of a committee of the Bakers' Progressive Labor Club, yesterday renewed his application to Justice Gardner for warrants for the arrest of a number of bankers for violating the Penal Code, in kneading dough on Sunday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28.--During the late telegraphers' strike a suit for $10,000 damages was begun in the Superior Court by Emile Hertz, of London, England, against the Western Union Telegraph Company because that corporation refused to accept an important cable message except "subject to delay."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28.--A line of ragged and unkempt wretches filing out of the prison van, up through the trap door, and into Judge Hare's Court of the Quarter Sessions, to-day, was closed by the handsome and elegant form of ex-Gas Trust Auditor Robert B. Morrell.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Sept. 28.--Robert M. Jamison, who until recently has been in the employ of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad as a civil engineer, committed suicide at his residence here to-day by cutting his throat with a razor.

A charge of making a cut of 5 cents on grain east bound from an originating point in Indiana has been preferred against the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. Commissioner Fink will investigatd it.

FINCASTLE, Va., Sept. 28.--An impromptu affair of honor was fought near here last night between George Thomas and Battleheim Doude.

Mr. Richard S. Newcombe yesterday appeared before Judge Van Brunt, to the Court of Common Pleas, and had the provisional bonds fixed in the case of the Assignees of F. Mayer Co.
BOSTON, Sept. 28.--The closing day's races of Balch's stallion meeting at Beacon Park ware as largely attended as those of the opening day and were decidedly the most interesting of the week.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 28.--The Hulton regatta was not largely attended to-day on account of the disagreable weather, but it was a great day for oarsmen. The world's record was shattered by two men who have been heretofore unknown to national fame. The first event of the day was a professional contest, in which Ten Eyck, Priddy, Hosmer, and Elliot started.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 28.--The proceedings of the Convention of Coal Miners in this city to-day did not, as was expected, result in a decision on the part of the railroad miners or any part of them to refuse to eccept the trade tribunal decision concerning wages made yesterday. But the delegates from the river district are inclined to stir up a strike.
The scores made at Creedmoor yesterday to the Fall prize meeting of the National Rifle Association were higher than any others made during the present meeting.
Justice Gardner has no liking for wife-beaters. Francis Schmalz, a photographic artist, was before him yesterday charged with assaulting Mrs. Schmalz, a lady of refinement and education.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 28.--The State election in Louisiana is to take place in April next and already the campaign is warm and exciting. In the first place there is a guarantee that there will be no Republican ticket in the field.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28.--Mrs. Anandibal Joshee, of Serampore, Hindostan, a Hindu lady of the highest caste, arrived in this city to-day, for the purpose of entering the Woman's Medical College as a student.
LONDON, Sept. 28.--The report of the shooting of Mr. Parnell is false. Mr. Parnell is now in England, and left for Leeds at 9 o'clock this morning.

The colossal statue which was unveiled yesterday in the presence of 250,000 persons, near the route over which the German troops passed, in 1870, on their way to attack the armies of France, commemorates not only the defeat and humiliation of France but also the creation and establishment of the German Empire of to-day.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 28.--Senator Bayard was shown this morning the telegraphed extreat from the Chicago Herald's editorial of to-day. While declining to take notice of the Herald's reiteration of the truthfulness of its interview, he furnished the Every Evening the following in writing:
CLEVELAND, Sept. 28.--The Democrats are completing arrangements for one of the largest campaign meetings ever held in Cleveland for next Monday evening.

Social circles in Newark are excited over the elopement and marriage of Wilbur Garrabrant, son of Chief Engineer Garrabraut, of the Pennsylvania Railroad, and Miss Madge Ferguson. The boy is only 17 years of age.
Mr. Chester Childs, formerly of this City, died at his farm, in Ludlowville, Tompkins County, on Sept. 21, in the ninety-eighth year of his age.

BINGEN, Sept. 28.--The great statue of Germania, on the Niederwald, opposite this city, was unveiled to-day in the presence of Emperor William, all the German sovereigns and Princes, and a crowd of about 250,000 people.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Sept. 29.--Jonas Whispell, of Saugerties, Ulster County, recently celebrated his one hundred and second birthday. Considering his years, he is bright mentally and enjoys good health. He is happy in having 52 grandchildren and 34 great-grandchildren living to comfort him in his vigorous old age. Seven of the 15 children which his wife bore him are now living. Mr. Whispell bids fair to live many years yet.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Oct. 2.--James Carey, a brakeman on an east-bound freight train on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, was killed this morning near Crouche's Station. ALBANY, Oct. 3.--Gov. Cleveland left for Watertown to-day. He will be the guest there of John Lansing, who will give a reception in his honor this evening. PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 3.--The fine buildings of the Pittsburg Exposition, on the north bank of the Allegheny River, which caught fire at 2 o'clock this morning, were totally destroyed.
The sun shone brightly yesterday morning as the Old Guard arrived at the St. Nicholas Hotel to escort the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Massachusetts in the direction of the Battery.
Many people who saw Mr. Joseph K. Emmet in "Fritz Among the Gypsies" will remember the splendid, rough-coated St. Bernard dog that played a part with so much intelligence.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3.--The Legislative committee, consisting of three Senators and five Representatives, appointed to investigate the character of the testimony taken in the Standard Oil Company investigation met here to-day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3.--So strong has been the tendency of late years in the Treasury Dapartment to expansion in the service that an instance of contraction becomes worthy of notice, even though it be forced.

LONDON, Oct. 3.--In an interview to-day Mr. A.M. Sullivan gave the following summary of O'Donnell's defense: Till the day after he reached Cape Town, O'Donnell says he never for a moment suspected Power to be Carey.
Seventy-five members of the Eastern Archery Association assembled yesterday at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, to celebrate their fifth annual meeting by a very interesting contest in archery.
PARIS, Oct. 3.--A dispatch from Rome says the Pope is seriously indisposed. It is affirmed that the commander of the French fleet in Madagascar has requested immediate reinforcements.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 3.--Bancroft, the historian, celebrated his eighty-third birthday at Newport to-day, and in the evening gave a dinner party.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3.--Judge Blodgett, in the United States District Court to-day, gave a decision of importance affecting enlistments in the United States Army.
A large force of men is working all night in the Metropolitan Opera-house. The auditorium is about finished, but the stage is somewhat behind.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 3.--Frank Robinson, a mail-carrier on the route between Sunnyside and Powhatan, has been arrested by Special Agent Henderson on a charge of opening letters and stealing checks, drafts, and money.Robinson is now confined in Goodchland Jail, and will be brought to this city for trial.

HARTFOFD, Conn., Oct. 3.--The annual race meeting of the National Association of Trotting Horse Breeders opened at Charter Oak Park this afternoon. A fair attendance of horse raisers was present.

The Board of Aldermen passed a resolution yesterday giving permission to George F. Williams, of the Herald, to place news-stands on the sidewalks within a distance of 50 feet of each of the elevated railway stations.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3.--The Tribune to-morrow will publish an editorial favoring Senator Edmunds, of Vermont, at the Republican candidate for President and Senator Miller, of California, for VicePresident, as the two best men under the circumstances for securing victory at the Presidential election.

SCHOHARIE, N.Y., Oct. 3.--This afternoon Mrs. William Spaulding found her husband dead in his barn. He was nearly 70 years of age and one of the old Dutch residents of the Schabarie Valley. It is thought he committed suicide by taking poison.

OGDENSBURG, Oct. 3.--The Twentieth District Republican Senatorial Convention, held here to-day, nominated the Hon. John J. Gilbert, of Malone, Franklin County, for State Senator. The nomination was made by acclamation on motion of Lewis County.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3.--Col. A. Loudon Snowden, Superintendent of the United States Mint, at noon to-day opened bids for 20,000 pounds of nickel to be used in minor coinage. Joseph Wharton was the only bidder, but his figure, 91 cents per pound, is the lowest at which the Government has ever been able to get the metal.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 3.--The hand-to-hand fight between Sheriff Duzon and a posse with J.S. Lane, the murderer of Neely, the details of which have been published, opens up a chapter unrivaled in the annals of crime. William Neely, the victim of Lane, was an old man of venerable appearance.

BATH, Me., Oct. 3.--Goss Sawyer launched a three-deck ship named the John H. Kolley today. She is the largest vessel ever built in Maine, and measures 353 feet 9 inches in length.Her gross tonnage is 2,364. She is owned in Bath, and will be commanded by Capt. Gibbons, of the place.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3.--Two brothers, Homer A. Herr and Dr. Francis C. Herr, were arrested this afternoon by detectives and a special officer from Harrisburg, Penn., upon the charge of having committed extensive frauds in that city by the sale of worthless mining stock.

Walter S. Graham's little skye-terrier Nellie saved the lives of her master and mistress Tuesday night and lost her own. She lived in Netherwood, a fashionable suburb of Plainfield, N.J., as a petted member of Mr. Graham's family.

Certain fastidious citizens of Memphis, Tenn., whose mouthpiece is the Avalanche, wish the telegraph and telephone poles to be painted some bright and fashionable color.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 3.--Yesterday was the second day of the fair. The attendance, notwithstanding the bad weather, was large. The chief attraction was the procession of the Veiled Prophets last night, which was a gorgeous spectacle, embracing 22 large floats representing fairyland in ...
Col. Henry Mizner, United States Army, is at the Grand Hotel. Senator M.C. Butler, of South Carolina, is at the New-York Hotel.
OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 3.--Fire broke out in the Masonic lodge-rooms, on the upper floor of the Neal Block, at 11:30 o'clock to-night. The block will probably be a total loss.

ALBANY, Oct. 3.--The second day's races of the Fall meeting at Island Park, which were postponed from yesterday on account of rain, were trotted to-day. The weather was cool, the attendance large, and the track in good condition.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 3.--This was the eighth day of the Fall meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club. The weather was cool and the track stiff.

Matters among the cigar-makers were quiet yesterday. The men congregated about the tenements and factories, and conversation with them made it evident that they would willingly resume work if they could.

"Lex" is informed that Maurice Barrymore, the actor, is still living and is in England. The National Rod and Reel Association will hold their annual tournament on Oct. 16 and 17 on the Upper Lake in Central Park.
